HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Suit Is Settled by Salomon

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $15 million to the State of West Virginia to settle a lawsuit that charged the firm with securities fraud.
 Lawyers for West Virginia contended that Salomon had improperly allowed the state's investment fund to pursue a risky trading strategy from 1985 through 1988 in violation of state law. 
The strategy, which resulted in hundreds of millions of dollars in losses in 1987, involved the purchase and rapid turnover of Treasury notes in the investment fund for West Virginia. The strategy essentially involved a bet on interest rates, which rose sharply in 1987.
The investments were made with the agreement of the state's Treasurer, A. James Manchin, who was forced to resign in mid-1989 because of the scandal stemming from the investment. The fund lost $231 million more in 1987 than it was reporting, a fact not uncovered until an audit in 1988.
 A number of other firms, including Merrill Lynch & Company and Shearson Lehman Brothers, have already settled similar charges with the state. The total amount that the state has received in settlements is $20 million.
 In a statement, Salomon said that it was not admitting any liability in the case. "Salomon concluded that it would be prudent to settle the matter to avoid the risk and further expense of litigation," the statement said.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Claims in Jump

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits shot up to an eight-year high of 519,000 in the week ending March 9, the Government said today.
 The Labor Department said initial claims rose by 45,000 from the previous week, hitting the highest level since the 546,000 filed during the first week of January 1983, at the end of the last recession. 
Private economists said the report on jobless claims was not an encouraging sign that the current recession would be short and mild.
 "This suggests that more people are being laid off and it signifies a continuing weakening of the economy," said Samuel Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. Mr. Kahan cautioned that the initial jobless claims report could be volatile from week to week. But he noted that the four-week average for claims has been moving higher since December.
 The new jobless claims report was viewed as especially worrisome because it provided one of the first looks at how the economy was performing in March. Some economists said they expected the broader jobless report for the month, to be issued April 5, to show another turn for the worse.
 The national jobless rate hit a four-year high of 6.5 percent in February. as another half- million Americans joined the ranks of the unemployed.

HEADLINE: Speaker Offers Plan to Raise Income Tax

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 21

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller today proposed raising state income taxes by almost $1 billion, breaking sharply with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and throwing budget deliberations here into turmoil with the legal deadline for a budget only 10 days away.
 Releasing his own alternative to the Governor's proposed budget, Mr. Miller said he wanted to scale back many major spending cuts sought by Mr. Cuomo, a fellow Democrat. For instance, he said, he would restore about $200 million in cuts in aid to New York City. 
Mr. Miller also rejected many of what he described as regressive tax measures in the Governor's budget, including a 10-cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes. He said that an income tax increase that would hit wealthier New Yorkers harder than poorer residents was a fairer way to solve the state's fiscal problems.
 Under Mr. Miller's plan, the maximum personal income tax rate, now 7.875 percent, would be increased to 8.66 percent, after which it would gradually drop back over the next three years to its present level. He said the average taxpayer would face an increase in the first year of about $115, with poor families paying no increase and wealthy ones paying much more.
 
'Totally Unacceptable'
 The Governor has repeatedly pledged to veto any increase in broad-based taxes, and Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader, today dismissed Mr. Miller's plan as "totally unacceptable."
 Officials here had already conceded that budget talks were so hopelessly bogged down that the April 1 deadline was unlikely to be met, but that did not stop either Mr. Miller or Mr. Marino from seizing on today's development as a way to deflect blame for the gridlock.
 Mr. Miller said that by proposing an alternative, the Assembly had demonstrated that it was ready to finish a budget on time. But Mr. Marino seemed to suggest that a late budget would be all Mr. Miller's fault.
 "To pull a surprise budget out of a hat without the bills basically says that April 1st is dead," he said. The most important impact of not having a state budget in place by the deadline would be that most state aid payments to cities would be frozen.
 Whatever budget is adopted, it will clearly include some of the deepest spending cuts New Yorkers have ever seen, as well as some form of increases in taxes and fees. But what remains far from resolved is not only the balance between those two, but questions of where to cut and whom to tax.
 The proposals from Mr. Miller today are part of a complex plan he has devised to spread some of the cuts over a longer period than Mr. Cuomo has envisioned. The Speaker's plan would put a budget into place that would last for 15 months, until July 1, 1992, at which point the state would legally shift the beginning of future fiscal years to July 1.
 Almost all other states, as well as New York City, start their fiscal years on July 1, and Mr. Miller has argued that the extra time would allow lawmakers to construct better budgets because they would have more reliable fiscal data.
 Mr. Miller's plan would eliminate several of the smaller taxes proposed by Mr. Cuomo, including a 2 percent tax on interstate telephone calls, a $5 tax on tires sold in the state and a tax on snack food that some legislators here have dubbed the Twinkie Tax.
 
Taxes That Hit All Payers Equally
 Mr. Miller said that many of Mr. Cuomo's proposed taxes, including the gasoline tax, were regressive because they tended to hit all New Yorkers equally, regardless of their wealth. Of Mr. Cuomo's proposed $5 tax on tire sales, Mr. Miller said, "Whether you have a BMW or whether you have a 15-year-old Ford that you keep on the farm, you're going to pay the same tax."
 Neither he nor Mr. Marino ruled out passing a gasoline tax at some point, with revenues specifically dedicated to repairing the state's roads and bridges, but both firmly rejected the tax in its present form because, they contended, it would basically be used to help balance the state's budget.
 The Governor's spokeswoman, Anne W. Crowley, said that Mr. Cuomo had seen no details of Mr. Miller's proposed budget, and she seemed to minimize its importance by describing it as "part of an ongoing annual ritual dance" of arriving at a budget.
 
Cuomo Repeats Pledge to Veto
 The Governor, speaking on a call-in radio program this evening, repeated his pledge to veto any increase in personal income tax rates, which he said would "crush the back of the economy of New York City."
 Mayor Dinkins is seeking more than $1 billion in new taxes himself, including about $335 million that require approval by the State Legislature.
 Mr. Miller's plan would add tax increases for city residents on top of Mayor Dinkins's, although it would also restore about $200 million of Mr. Cuomo's proposed cuts in aid to the city. The Governor has said that the total value of his cuts to the city is about $400 million, while city officials have pegged it at closer to $600 million.
 Responding to Mr. Miller's plan, the city's budget director, Philip R. Michael, said he did not want "to be in the position of supporting a tax increase." But, he added, "if there's a viable way that we can get an additional $200 million, obviously that would be of major assistance to us and we would be appreciative."

HEADLINE: Minorities A Majority In New York

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
The number of Hispanic residents in New York City grew 26.8 percent in the 1980's as minority groups became a majority of the city's population for the first time, new census figures show.
 The figures confirm a historic shift anticipated by population experts after nearly half a century of whites leaving the city: the succession of European groups who founded New York and dominated it for centuries now transformed into a racial minority. 
Within the city's mix of races and ethnic groups, non-Hispanic whites declined 14.2 percent and are no longer a majority, but they remain the largest, with 43.2 percent of the population, down from 52.4 percent in 1980.
 Non-Hispanic blacks make up 25.2 percent, up from 24.0 percent. But after a decade of continued immigration from the Caribbean and Central America, Hispanic groups now rival blacks with 24.4 percent, up from 19.9 percent. Non-Hispanic Asians are 6.9 percent of the total.
 
'Alter the Economic Mix'
 "Put it in perspective, and you end up with the conclusion that New York City is by far the most ethnically and racially diverse city in the world," said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the Department of City Planning.
 Economists say the new diversity is likely to have large economic consequences for the city.
 "New immigrants do not simply replace old residents in the same jobs," said Rosemary Scanlon, the chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "They alter the economic mix.
 "Look at the way Italians shaped the construction industry or, more recently, how Koreans have changed greengroceries," she said. "They work longer hours and display their products in new ways. It's a different kind of business."
 According to the Census Bureau, there were 3,163,125 non-Hispanic whites living in New York City in 1990, out of a population of 7,322,564.
 In 1980 the census counted 3,668,945 non-Hispanic residents, or 52.4 percent of a population of 7,071,639. In the 1980's New York reversed a population decline and grew by 250,925 people, but it did so on the strength of immigration, as non-Hispanic whites counted by the Census Bureau declined by 505,820, to 3,163,125.
 The number of Hispanic residents counted in 1990 was 1,783,511, compared with 1,404,024 10 years before. Non-Hispanic blacks increased to 1,847,049, from 1,694,127.
 City officials say the census understates the trend of new ethnic and racial groups replacing whites in the city's boroughs, contending that the count missed hundreds of thousands of people, most of them from such minority groups, many of them poor or illegal aliens. New York has joined other cities in challenging the census figures.
 In joining the ranks of American cities where whites are a minority, New York, in its diversity, is more like Los Angeles and San Francisco than cities like Detroit and Newark, where black majorities replaced white ones.
 According to the 1990 census, Los Angeles is 39.9 percent Hispanic, 37.3 white, 13.0 percent black, and 13.0 percent Asian , while San Francisco is 46.6 percent white, 28.4 percent Asian, 13.9 percent Hispanic and 10.5 percent black.
 Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University, suggested that the declining numbers of whites reflects a variety of developments, including the migration to the suburbs that began in earnest in the 1940's and has continued ever since.
 
Whites Having Fewer Children
 In addition, he said, "The white population with European backgrounds is also aging. That means that you have people moving South to retire and children growing up and leaving their parents' homes, which means that the average family size is lower."
 A lower birthrate among non-Hispanic whites compared with other groups is also a factor. "Even the younger whites who live in New York City have very few children."
 Mr. Tobier estimated that more than a fifth of the decline in the city's non-Hispanic white population was due to natural decrease: more deaths than births over the decade. The rest, he said, was the result of more whites leaving the city than coming to it.
 Nevertheless, the rate of decline slowed considerably. The loss during the 1980's of 540,078 white residents was less than half that of the 1970's, when their ranks dropped by 1,327,000. Losses also exceeded the one million mark in the 1950's and 1960's.
 The data showed that Hispanic residents increased at a faster rate than in the previous decade, while blacks also increased, but at a slower pace.
 Outmigration also seems to be occurring among blacks. "The overall black population went up by 153,000, but there should have been a natural increase of 240,000," said Mr. Tobier. "That means undercounting or outmigration or both."
 Other than non-Hispanic whites, the only group to show an absolute decline in population in any of the boroughs was blacks in Manhattan. Their ranks dropped by 29,441, to 261,120, a decline of 10.1 percent during the decade.
 Evelyn Mann, director of the population division of the Department of City Planning, suggested that this drop reflected both undercounting by the Census Bureau and a drop in the amount of desirable housing in Harlem, where most Manhattan blacks are concentrated.
 The new data represent the latest elaboration on Census Bureau figures which showed that the population of New York City rebounded from losses in the 1970's to increase by 250,925 people, or 3.5 percent, during the 1980's.
 For now, the census data sheds little light on substantial changes within the Hispanic population, where immigration from the Caribbean and Central America is diminishing the dominance of Puerto Ricans, and among Asians, where new arrivals now are more likely to be from rural China or Southeast Asia rather than Taiwan or Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Rise Modestly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury securities posted modest price gains in slow trading yesterday, despite reported heavy selling by Japanese institutions.
 As often happens this time of year, Japanese institutions have been closing out positions in the fixed-income and other financial markets in preparation for March 31, the end of their fiscal year. 
Aside from a need to clean up balance sheets, the only news that motivated participants yesterday was a report from the Labor Department showing that initial unemployment claims rose by 45,000 in the week ended March 9, to 519,000.
 The increase, a sign the economy remained very weak after the end of the Persian Gulf war, prompted a bit of buying. But analysts and traders said the market is likely to remain generally listless through the end of the quarter.
 "At this point it will be hard for the market to establish a trend because it is the end of the quarter and we won't have any more meaningful economic data until the March employment report" is released on April 5, said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. "The market is basically biding its time."
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 95 1/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.32 percent, down from 8.33 percent late Wednesday.
 Among Treasury note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 13/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.13 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 3/8, up 3/32, to yield 7.09 percent.
 Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
 By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.86 percent, up one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.85 percent.
 A number of issues were priced in the market for investment-grade corporate bonds, including a $500 million issue of five-year securities for the Province of Ontario.
 The 8.25 percent notes, which mature April 8, 1996, were priced at $99.96, to yield 8.26 percent, 45 basis points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity at the time of pricing.
 Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on the transaction. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 In addition, the Houston Lighting and Power Company offered $160 million of 30-year noncallable bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
 The 9.15 percent securities, which mature March 15, 2021, were priced at $99.79, to yield 9.17 percent, 83 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent bonds of 2021.
 The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
 Participants in the market for high-yield "junk bonds" said an announcement that California's state pension fund intended to sell the $530 million face amount worth of high-yield securities in its portfolio had no impact on prices.
 In part, traders said the market did not react to the news because Calpers, as the pension fund is called, was known to have a large number of healthy names in its high-yield portfolio, issues that are currently in strong demand.
 Traders said that prices of most high-yield issues rose by about 1/2 point yesterday.
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the City of New York offered for the first time $50 million worth of variable-rate notes.
 The notes, backed by letters of credit from Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Industrial Bank of Japan, have maturities ranging from Sept. 1, 1993 through 1995.
 The notes were priced at par with an initial coupon of 1.75 percent. The coupon will be reset on a daily basis by Lehman Brothers, which also acted as lead manager for the transaction. The notes may be "put" back to the issuer for cash. A coupon cap of 9 percent was set on the securities.
 Ratings of AAA from Moody's and AA from Standard & Poor's are expected.
 In the secondary market for tax-exempt securities, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.
 Elsewhere, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended March 11.
 The $6.2 billion increase in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was a bit higher than analysts had been anticipating. But the money figures had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Preserving Assets of the Old and Ill

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
When a middle-class elderly person suffers a debilitating illness like Alzheimer's disease that requires long-term custodial care, it can be devastating to a family, financially as well as emotionally.
The poor are provided for by Medicaid. The rich have ample resources. But all too often those in the middle class see their life savings siphoned off until they, too, are poor and qualify for Medicaid. 
 "This country may be a great place to have your heart transplanted; it's a lousy place to grow old," Robert M. Freedman, a partner in the New York law firm of Freedman & Fish, said last week at a Conference on Elder Law Planning for Professional Advisers sponsored by the UJA-Federation.
Still, Mr. Freedman said, there are steps that families can take to deflect the blow if they plan ahead. One is to buy insurance for long-term care. Another is to transfer assets to others in the family, or possibly to trusts, so the elderly person will qualify for Medicaid earlier.
Private insurance is needed because Medicare does not cover custodial care. It covers only care in a skilled nursing home after hospitalization, but many maladies of age like fragile bones and Alzheimer's disease do not require hospitalization.
Great care must be taken in selecting a policy, Mr. Freedman said, recommending that all policies be reviewed by an independent professional because coverage and state regulations vary.
Among the criteria, he said, are that benefits be high enough to pay nursing home costs plus an inflation rider, that prior hospitalization not be required, that custodial and home care be covered, that the policy be renewable for life, that premiums be level and that the carrier be rated A+ by Best.
The question of how to divest assets to protect a spouse or other heirs and allow an elderly person to qualify for Medicaid is extremely complicated. Regulations vary from state to state and are constantly changing. Relationships within a family must be considered, along with the older person's feelings about losing control of the assets, and possible tax consequences of the transfers.
"Much expert help is needed" on an individual basis, Mr. Freedman said.
One caveat is that a last-minute transfer may not work. In general those that take place more than 30 months before the application for Medicaid are safest.
Decisions about health care itself also have big financial and emotional consequences for entire families. Many people say vaguely that they would not want to be kept alive in a vegetative state, but legally hospitals and physicians may be required to take measures that a person would not want unless there is clear and convincing evidence of what is wanted.
Kathryn C. Meyer, senior vice president for legal affairs of Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, said, "Many people have not planned ahead, and they and their families run into major problems when they are hospitalized" because by then they have lost legal capacity to make the necessary decisions.
"A living will is the simplest way" to provide the necessary evidence for detailing what care is to be provided and what is to be refused, she said. But much of the interpretation of living wills depends on case law, which varies from state to state.
Therefore, it is advisable to supplement a living will with a health-care proxy, she said. In New York, the Health Care Agents and Proxies Law, which took effect on Jan. 18, allows a mentally competent adult to designate another person, often a family member, to make health-care decisions in case of loss of capacity. It does not expire but may be revoked.
She recommended having "lots of signed originals," and giving them to family members, physicians, lawyers and other advisers. Also, it will avoid confusion if the document conforms to statutory wording as closely as possible, rather than embellishing upon it.
Peter J. Strauss, a partner in Fink, Weinberger, a New York law firm, who also spoke at the conference, cautioned that people should designate only one person. A person who attempts to treat all children equally, for example, and names two or more in the proxy could set the scene for a family fight that can be resolved only with a court order.
Emphasizing the urgency for families to plan ahead, Robert J. Wolf, director of medical and geriatric services for the UJA-Federation, pointed out that although there is "more money for aging services than ever before, there is less per capita" from governmental agencies because medical advances have resulted in a large increase in the elderly population.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rolls-Royce Plans to Cut 3,000 Jobs

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, March 22

 BODY:
The British aircraft-engine maker Rolls-Royce said it planned to drop 3,000 from its work force of 35,000 this year. A company spokesman attributed the cuts to the health of the aerospace industry, which has been hurt by the drop in airline travel during the Persian Gulf crisis. Recession in the United States and Britain, among other nations, has also hurt the industry.
"We have not seen any significant cancellation of orders, but it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that this is a possibility," the spokesman said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Strongly; Gold Is Marginally Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced strongly on world currency markets yesterday, failing to fade in the wake of concerted central bank intervention.
Gold prices were marginally higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose 10 cents to settle at $363.10 an ounce, and the active April contract was unchanged at $363.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $362.30, up 50 cents an ounce from Thursday's late bid. 
 Analysts said the dollar had moved higher for no clear reason. The German Bundesbank and other European central banks moved again to stem the dollar's advance as the European trading session drew to a close, the third time this week that they acted to curb the dollar's rise.
About the same time, analysts said, the Federal Reserve intervened in domestic markets, also to drive the dollar lower.
"It was unusual in the sense that we had seen concerted rounds of intervention before, but not one in which the Fed and the Europeans were in at the same time," said Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert's New York office.
Unlike the action on Thursday, the intervention was largely unsuccessful. But some analysts speculate it is just a matter of time before the central banks wear the dollar down.
There is also speculation that the dollar will drift lower naturally once investors turn their attention back to the United States economy, which is not recovering as quickly as many had predicted. Many thought the end of the Persian Gulf war would help the economy snap back, in part as consumer confidence was restored.
The underlying sentiment toward the United States currency remains largely bullish, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.25 yen to a closing 137.05 yen. Later, in London, it rose to 137.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 137.60 yen, up from 136.73 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7890, from $1.7930 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7860 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.7995.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.6485 marks, from 1.6315 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4135 Swiss francs, up from 1.4055; 5.6030 French francs, up from 5.5555; 1,225.38 Italian lire, up from 1,215.50, and 1.1578 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1555.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Goodrich Gives Earnings Outlook

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, March 22

 BODY:
Citing adverse economic conditions, B.F. Goodrich said it expected to break even or report a modest loss this quarter. "The recession is taking an especially heavy toll on a number of our businesses that depend on the strength and vitality of economic conditions generally," the chemical company said.
Sales of its Geon Vinyl Products unit continue to decline, and its Specialty Chemicals segment is reporting results well below those of the period a year ago. The company also said its Aerospace business was slightly below results a year ago. 
 The company earned $16.2 million in last year's first quarter, and analysts' estimates for first-quarter net income have ranged from $2 million to $10 million, Goodrich said. The company's stock fell 62.5 cents today, to $38.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Congress Withholds $55 Million in Aid to Jordan

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Congress today approved but modified the revocation of $55 million in aid to Jordan and a ban on military sales to allies who failed to fulfill their pledges of financial assistance for the Persian Gulf war.
The action reflected Congressional resentment at King Hussein's support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the gulf war, and at what lawmakers considered the laggardly pace of payment by allies who have pledged financial support of the desert operation. 
 The modifications, to overcome President Bush's veto threats, were made in two spending bills intended to pay for the gulf war. Congress then went on a two-week Easter recess.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said that Mr. Bush would sign both bills, a $5.2 billion measure to expand benefits for American veterans of the gulf war, and one for $15 billion to pay for the war in the event that nations that had pleged financial assistance fail to fulfill their pledges.
The Senate passed both bills by voice votes, while the House passed the first bill by a vote of 340 to 48, and the second by 379 to11.
The approval modified a Senate-passed prohibition on $55 million in pending military and economic aid to Jordan, to enable Jordan to receive the full amount if the President certified to Congress that King Hussein was helping advance the peace process. Under the Senate version, Jordan could have received $35 million in economic aid under that certification, but not an additional $20 million in military funds.
President Bush opposed the measure as restricting his flexibility in conducting Middle East diplomacy. He also warned that the move could destabilize the Amman Government and result in a regime more hostile to American interests. The action will not affect humanitarian aid to Jordan, nor $246 million already in the pipeline in the form of pending contracts.
Congress also modified a Senate-passed ban on Government funds for military sales to any nation that failed to make good on its pledge of financial assistance for the gulf war. The compromise exempted those nations that had met their payment schedules, even if they had not paid the entire amount they had pledged.
 
Non-Gulf Measures
 The pledges totaled $54.5 billion, of which $25.6 billion has thus far been paid. Congress estimated the cost of the war at $42.6 billion and rising. If the war costs less than the contributions paid by the allies, they will be rebated on a pro rata basis.
The compromise also included a prohibition on the transfer of weapons used in the war to Middle East countries without Congressional approval. That action will make it harder for Saudi Arabia and Israel to keep Patriot missile batteries in their countries. The restriction, also opposed by the White House, was modified to give military commanders flexibility in the transfer of weapons until a cease-fire was signed, and enabled such transfers thereafter if they were considered essential by the military.
The compromise included some non-gulf war measures. It dropped, for example, a Senate-passed measure that would increase dairy price supports. Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Agriculture committee, said, "It's too bad these dairy farmers don't live in some foreign country. We could probably do something for them."
The bills provide $1 billion for the F-14, built by Grumman on Long Island and Maryland's Eastern Shore. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said: "This is a huge victory for New York, Long Island and Grumman. It will save 4,000 jobs directly and thousands of others in related positions."
The bills also provided $650 million in aid to Israel and $200 million for Turkey; $100 million to buy 156 Patriot missiles; $150 million to let the states cope with increased applications for unemployment insurance, and $1.5 billion for food stamps.
The compromise included a requirement that the Government spend $1.2 billion to refurbish the aircraft carrier Kennedy at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, a reflection of the clout of Representative John P. Murtha, Democrat of Pennsylvania and chairman of the defense subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.
Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, which is threatened with base closings, said: "This will set a precedent. People will say, 'Why didn't you take this precaution in your state?' "

HEADLINE: Changing Warehouses Into a Cultural Center

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Half a mile of water separates the popular, slick and immensely profitable South Street Seaport from an abandoned and forbidding cluster of nine red-brick warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront known as the Empire Stores. By the end of the decade, this huge complex of prime Brooklyn waterfront buildings could become a cultural and retail center as large as the Seaport, if a preliminary development proposal being presented to community groups ever comes to fruition.
Under the plan, which was drafted by the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation and the State Urban Development Corporation, the warehouses would be transformed into art galleries, theaters, artists' studios, a museum, shops and restaurants. 
 The 120-year-old buildings, between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, are now crumbling and littered with debris, their arched windows covered by rusting steel, with a tangle of vines and trees growing on and through their brick facades. They are in a historic district designated by the city, and are also part of Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park, which includes an adjacent three-acre waterfront lawn.
"This could be the focal point for Brooklyn waterfront redevelopment," said Ed Rogowsky, Brooklyn's representative on the City Planning Commission and the chairman of the urban studies department at Brooklyn College. "It provides million-dollar views of Manhattan and could be a great attraction. And it's as close to downtown Brooklyn and new office developments like Metrotech as the Seaport is to Manhattan's financial district."
 
Theaters and Museum
 The proposal is to be completed after public meetings this spring.
Several small experimental theaters would occupy the two smaller buildings near New Dock Street, once used for storing tobacco. The adjacent four- and five-story buildings, formerly used as coffee and spice warehouses, would have an even mix of retail and cultural uses, said Elizabeth Goldstein, the regional director of the State Parks Department. The proposal also includes a museum of Brooklyn waterfront history to be overseen by the Brooklyn Historical Society.
Pedestrian access from Brooklyn Heights, downtown Brooklyn and nearby subway stations -- currently treacherous because of entrance ramps to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway -- would be improved and an parking garage built, Ms. Goldstein said. Ferry service to lower Manhattan, which existed from 1642 until 1924, might be restored, she added.
"We want to activate the site as much as possible," Ms. Goldstein said. "I'd like to see it as a place where there would be children's theater on Saturday afternoons, cabarets in the evening, artists working and people coming for dinner."
The cost of redeveloping the 375,000-square-foot complex is put at $107 million, according to the proposal, which was prepared for $175,000 by Beyer Blinder Belle, the company that did restoration studies for Ellis Island.
 
Public Funds Uncertain
 When planning began two years ago, it was estimated that $20 million would come from the state and city, with the remainder from private developers. But budget problems and the defeat of the Environmental Quality Bond Act in November put the public financing in doubt, said Harold Holzer, an executive vice president for the Urban Development Corporation. Alternative funding will be sought, he said, though private money "will also be very tough to assemble."
The State Parks Department bought the long-dormant Empire Stores from Con Edison in 1978 for $750,000. An entertainment and retail complex was proposed in the mid-1980's by a developer, David Walentas, -- whose company, Two Trees Management, owns several nearby buildings -- but "the project proved unfeasible," Ms. Goldstein said.
Although parks advocates and the waterfront's flourishing artists' community generally welcome the new proposal, some residents worry that it could become too commercially oriented if public financing and control of the project are reduced. Under the current plan, 55 percent of the project would be devoted to nonprofit cultural uses, with the rest as retail development. By comparison, about 85 percent of the 320,000-square-foot South Street Seaport development is given over to retail uses.
"The concern is that it could become another Seaport," Mr. Rogowsky said. "Our basic public-policy problem with this and similar public-private projects is how to get the capital and ongoing revenue stream without ceding them entirely to retail interests."

HEADLINE: Port Authority Raises Tolls for 6 Bridges and Tunnels to $4

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to increase the basic toll on passenger cars by $1, to $4, on its six bridges and tunnels.
The increase, to take effect on April 7, followed weeks of negotiations with the administrations of Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. In return for their consent, the authority will increase to $420 million a fund that the states can divide for transportation and economic development projects of their choosing.
The authority, under pressure from the Governors and constrained by stagnant revenues, also said it would reduce its marketing and advertising programs, cut costs for travel and meals, freeze some salaries and leave certain jobs vacant, postpone replacing staff cars and even sell one of its two helicopters. 
 "Both Governors, from the start, wanted to see evidence that the Port Authority's way of approaching expenses and even symbolic lifestyle issues was going to change," said Richard C. Leone, the authority chairman. "And we have tried to be responsive to that.
 Yesterday's vote came just five days after the New Jersey Turnpike authority raised its tolls by 70 percent for cars and by 100 percent for trucks. A motorist driving the full length of the turnpike and then using a Port Authority bridge or tunnel will soon pay $8.60 for a trip that would have cost $5.70 last week.
Yesterday, in a gloomy, rainy evening rush outside the Lincoln Tunnel, most drivers seemed resigned to higher tolls although a few said they would try to cut down on unnecessary trips.
"I think it stinks," said Brenda Miles, a Plainfield, N.J., resident.
And Bill Freedman, a commuter from Elizabeth, said: "I'm hit both ways. They should fix the roads before raising tolls."
But the Port Authority's tolls, which are charged only in one direction and are collected from 350,000 automobile drivers on a typical workday, are still cheaper than the $2.50 that the Metropolitan Tranportation Authority charges in each direction at its East River crossings.
And the Port Authority, in a reversal from its original plan, has also retained some of its toll discounts, although it has restructured them to take into account mass transit alteratives available to motorists.
"These are smart tolls," Mr. Leone said, "designed to cause the least collateral damage."
Twenty-ticket commuter discount books will continue to be sold for $40 at the Staten Island bridges -- the Bayonne and Goethals Bridges and the Outerbridge Crossing -- where motorists have few mass transit op tions. But starting on May 12, the discount on the George Washington Bridge, by far the busiest crossing, will be reduced from one-third to one-quarter, and drivers will pay $60 for the 20-ticket books. And motorists at the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, who have the most transit options, will get only the 10 percent discount that is available at all Port Authority crossings for motorists using the agency's scrip.
Because of these changes, discount tickets will be good only at the crossings where they are purchased. Refunds for unused tickets will no longer be provided.
Discount ticket books for car pools will remain at $30 for 60 round trips. Tolls for buses and fares on the Path rail line will not change.
 
$2.7 Billion Budget
 "The system of discounts was really an improvement," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association.
The vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, James McGowan, said the Staten Island discounts were "the one glimmer of hope" but added that his organization had not ruled out a legal challenge to the increase.
The toll increase was included in a 1991 budget of $2.7 billion unanimously approved by the six of the 10 Port Authority board members who attended yesterday's meeting at the World Trade Center.
The authority last raised tolls in 1987, when they went to $3 from $2.
In seeking an increase, the agency has been forced to negotiate with the Governors, who have veto power over its actions.
Yesterday's action would increase by $270 million the amount of Port Authority money available to each state. That money comes from a $5.4 billion capital program that the authority plans over the next five years. Mr. Florio has already spoken of several projects that he wants the Port Authority to help pay for, including a transfer station at Secaucus that would let some N.J. Transit rail passengers switch to trains on the Northeast Corridor tracks for New York City.
New York State has not specified any projects yet, but an authority document outlining the toll increase mentions improvements to the Staten Island Expressway and the Cross Bronx Expressway.
Because the toll plan was altered and delayed, it will generate less than the $139 million a year that the authority had anticipated. So the agency said it was cutting operating and capital costs.
But in its financial projections, the authority said it was possible if not likely that another deficit would arise by 1993 or 1994.

HEADLINE: Soviet Oil Industry Outlook Is Called Dismal by Experts

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's oil industry is in a steep, continuing decline, and the most likely remedy -- an infusion of Western capital and technology that both Soviet officials and American oil companies had hoped for -- is beginning to seem out of reach, according to experts at a conference today at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. The reason: political uncertainty within the country.
The Soviet oil industry is still the world's largest, about 18 percent ahead of Saudi Arabia's, and it is both vital to the nation's economic stability and important to the world energy balance. But production is declining rapidly because of cuts in investment in recent years, backward technology and the Soviet Union's general economic breakdown, experts said at the conference, sponsored by Georgetown and Salomon Brothers. 
 Several high-ranking Soviet oil and gas officials told potential investors that with new capital and technology they could raise production. But they, as well as Western analysts, painted a confused picture on such crucial questions as who owns the mineral resources, who has jurisdiction over joint ventures and outside investment, and what taxes will be applied.
For example, Ronald Benson, the American director of White Nights Oil and Gas Joint Venture, which says it is the first American-Soviet joint drilling venture, said that his group had raised $80 million and had agreed to take over three oilfields in western Siberia, now producing 20,000 barrels a day. The group, expecting to expand output to 150,000 barrels and to have new drilling rigs shipped in by May or June, has already spent between $10 million and $15 million.
In January, however, the central Government announced that under a law passed last year, oil exports this year would be taxed at 40 percent.
Mr. Benson, who is also vice president of Phibro Energy Inc., a Salomon subsidiary, said that if the tax stood, drilling would be canceled. He added: "You couldn't go to a bank anywhere in the world today and get money to do work like this in the Soviet Union. You have to be ready to take risks."
An executive of a large American oil company that has been talking with the Soviets for months called the 40 percent tax "a real show-stopper." The executive, who spoke on condition that his company not be identified, said that at that tax level, or even a much smaller tax that was put in place after deals had been signed, there would probably be no joint ventures at all.
Tuboscope, a Houston-based company that makes pipeline-inspection equipment, has experience in the Soviet Union but is finding it harder to work there now. Robert Lahr, its president, said that because of the uncertainties, it is planning to limit its work to subcontracting for a major company that would be paid in oil, to simplify payment.
 
 Investment Failure Seen

Others predicted failure for foreign investors. Dr. Stanislav Shatalin, author of the rejected 500-day plan for transformation of the Soviet economy and a former adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said that under the current conditions, "if I was a banker I would not invest a single cent in our economy." The Soviet Union is backing away from a free-market system, he asserted.
Jeffery Burt, a lawyer with Arnold & Porter in Washington, said that companies would be wise not to invest much until they had approvals in hand from as many layers of government as possible. "The exit strategy may be more important than the entrance strategy," he added.
John Blaney, economics counselor of the American Embassy in Moscow, described doing business in the Soviet Union as "almost like a three-dimensional chess game, where each level has different rules and different pieces, and every once in a while, on any level, all the rules change."
Investors seemed to be souring, too. Rick Woltman, an analyst at ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm that manages $9 billion, said: "The potential is hyped. It's dangerous and problematic."
Despite the gloom, top Soviet officials maintained that with some new capital and technology, they could work wonders in their troubled industry.
Rantik Margulov, the first deputy chairman of the Bureau of Fuel and Power of the U.S.S.R. Council of Ministers, said the Soviet oil industry was "entering a new century with a large portion of unsolved technical, ecological, economic and political questions." To obtain the needed oil, he said, executives would have to "concentrate the economic and technical resources of several countries."
Akif Djabarov, general director of Gazneft Azerbajian, the republic's oil- and gas-producing enterprise, said oil reserves were vast but deeper than the 10,000 feet to which his company could drill. Also, more oil could be recovered from older fields if 4,000 wells could be renovated and air compressor stations built, he said, an impossibility with the resources in Azerbaijian, where the price of oil produced is artificially low.
Although the health of the Soviet industry has been poor for some time, Western experts said they could not tell how bad it was, because some restive republics have stopped reporting data.
 
2.2 Million This Year
 Earlier this week, Pravda reported that President Gorbachev had said that crude oil exports would be only half what was originally planned. Experts at the conference said, however, that much of what the Soviets export is oil products, not crude, and that it was already clear exports were falling.
Robert E. Ebel, vice president of the Enserch Corporation, a Dallas-based energy, engineering and construction company, put exports at some 3.1 million barrels a day last year, down from 4.1 million barrels two years earlier. He foresaw 2.2 million barrels this year. By comparison, the global oil market is a bit over 60 million barrels a day; Kuwait's prewar OPEC quota was 1.5 million barrels a day, and Iraq's was 3.5 million.
Since the late 1970's the United States has feared the transformation of the Soviet Union from a global supplier into a competitor for supplies. The Central Intelligence Agency published a report in 1977 predicting this by 1985. Mr. Ebel said that the same report, with the dates changed, could be convincingly released today.
Thane Gustavson, a Georgetown professor and expert on Soviet oil, said that to halt the decline, the Soviets had more than doubled the annual oilfield investment in the 1980's, until oil consumed 70 percent of new industrial investment. Nevertheless, he added, new wells in 1989 had an average flow of about 80 barrels a day, only one-tenth the level of a decade earlier. Adding wells costs $10,000 a barrel a day of capacity, he said, far above the cost in other countries.
"They did what any oil industry would do," he added. "They went for the fat targets and the easy geology first. They have not exhausted those, but they have run them down." Fields left to be tapped are smaller, more complicated in their geology and more remote, he said.
 
Outlook Called Bleak
 Some experts say that even if Western involvement comes quickly, the production outlook is bleak. Robert Copaken, senior political economist at the Department of Energy's Office of International Affairs, said the Soviets would be fortunate to stabilize production at current levels. "I think they will always go for self-sufficiency," he said. "But they may not continue to be significant net exporters."
Eastern Europe may feel a big part of the decline in exports, because the Soviets are now demanding hard currency from their former bloc, where they once bartered. On the other hand, Shane Streifel, senior analyst at the International Energy Agency, said that exports to the industrialized democracies in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have held up "reasonably well in 1990, and may continue in 1991."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Officers Win Delay on Entering Pleas in Beating

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 22

 BODY:
Four police officers accused of assault in the videotaped beating of a black motorist won a delay today until next week to enter their pleas in court, while new disclosures continued to feed public anger over the incident.
In grand jury testimony quoted this morning by The Los Angeles Daily News, witnesses at a hospital where the beaten man, Rodney G. King, was treated said that police officers taunted him, boasting that they had "played a little hardball" and "hit quite a few home runs" while beating him. 
 A nurse, Carol Diane Edwards, is quoted as telling the grand jury that an officer said to Mr. King, "We played a little hardball tonight, and you lost."
Charged in the beating of Mr. King on March 3 are Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officers Laurence M. Powell, Timothy E. Wind and Theodore J. Briseno. All four are free on bail.
 
Time to Study Transcripts
 In their brief appearance in court today, the officers said nothing. After allowing their lawyers the extra time to study transcripts from grand jury hearings, Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner urged speed, saying, "I want to get this thing assigned out so we can get this thing running at a proper pace."
The prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Terry White, said, "I think they think they need more information than they need to enter a plea."
The police pursuit of Mr. King's white Hyundai began on the Foothill Freeway, on the northern outskirts of Los Angeles, and proceeded on city streets.
The California Highway Patrol today made public a tape recording of radio communications from officers who initially pursued Mr. King's car.
Like an earlier recording released by the Los Angeles Police Department, it made no reference to his speed on the freeway before he turned onto city streets.
A highway patrol spokesman, Sgt. Mike Brey, earlier said that Mr. King had been traveling at up to 115 miles per hour, a speed both Mr. King and a passenger, Bryant Allen, disputed.
The tape released today indicates that Mr. King was pursued for approximately two and three-fourths miles before leaving the freeway.
As the pursuit continued on city streets, the tape includes a report by officers that he was driving as fast as 65 m.p.h. on streets where the speed limit is 45.
The police department tape included a reference to a speed of 55 m.p.h. on streets where the limit was 40.
Mr. King, a 25-year-old unemployed construction worker, remained hospitalized today after an operation on a fractured eye socket. He suffered multiple skull fractures and a broken ankle, among other injuries.
Dr. Alvin Reiter, a plastic surgeon who operated on him, said today, "There's a good possibility that he'll have permanent numbness, permanent paralysis and problems with chewing and opening up his mouth without discomfort."

From left were Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officers Timothy E. Wind, Theodore J. Briseno and Laurence M. Powell. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Some Veterans Facing New Battles on Return

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The return of gulf war veterans to workaday life after the cheering stops will bring surprises for managers, co-workers and spouses, as well as the veterans themselves -- and many companies and workers are poorly prepared.
In several cases, small-business owners, salespeople and professionals are returning to discover that they will have to rebuild their businesses and reclaim old clients and customers who have drifted away while they were in the gulf. Those kinds of competitive pressures on the job will compound the financial worries that plague many returning veterans. 
 "About two more weeks of this and I'd be in financial straits," said Thomas J. Blagg, a gunnery sergeant in the Marine Reserves. Mr. Blagg, who returned to his regiment's base in Dallas last week, said his income plunged to one-fourth the level he earned as a sales manager before being called up in December.
In a few cases, having no job in the midst of a recession will be the worst surprise for returning veterans. At the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in St. Louis, which pared 15,000 jobs in the months after the war began last August, four reservists were caught in the cutbacks. The company guaranteed jobs for all nonunion employees called into the military, but the unlucky four were members of one of two unions whose seniority rules left them without work.
Of the 545,000 American troops sent to Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, 80,000 were called up from the military Reserve and National Guard units. Over all, 227,400 reservists and National Guard members were called to active duty.
It hardly matters, psychologists and experts said, whether a veteran was on the front lines or far from combat. "There was constant, pervasive fear of impending doom, impending death, and never knowing if something might happen," said Dr. Calvin J. Frederick, chief of psychological services at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in Los Angeles, who has counseled several gulf war veterans. "Some of the troops experienced weight loss, fatigue and loss of sleep and are really stressed out. All of these things at one level are normal. It's only if they continue and become intense that they will need to seek help."
How this will manifest itself in the workplace is difficult to predict. But experts say veterans who confronted combat and death are most vulnerable to sleep problems, prickly moods, elevated blood pressure, inability to concentrate on a task and digestion troubles commonly associated with post-traumatic stress disorder, a mental disturbance that some researchers believe affects one of five Vietnam veterans.
Some psychologists say that in stirring old ghosts of battle, the gulf war might even cause more troubles among Vietnam veterans in the workplace than among the new veterans.
 
 Impatience Expected

Dr. Robert Albanese, head of the Center for Human Resources at Texas A & M University, in College Station, Tex., said many workers who saw duty in the gulf might consider their work trivial and show little patience with the mistakes of others.
Dr. Reagan Andrews, a clinical psychologist at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in Dallas, said executives should consider assigning these people to special projects or making them trouble-shooters.
For years, many large employers have relied on employee-assistance programs to provide counseling for troubled workers and their families. Over the years, these programs have provided help for alcohol and drug abuse, family problems and depression. But some experts warn that these programs may not be enough to deal with the special problems that veterans encounter on the job.
Dr. Albanese said managers who direct the assistance programs often know too little about how special counseling services can help or which employees need them.
 
'Prepared to Help'

Many families of reservists on the payroll at McDonnell Douglas have already asked for medical and financial advice. "We are prepared to help, whatever the circumstances," said Daniel C. Smith, the company's director of employee-assistance services.
Many reservists who returned from the gulf last week said emotional outpourings of public support helped to soothe memories of terror and destruction. "We have been deluged with requests for things like color guards and speakers to come to Lions clubs," said Bill J. English, a lieutenant colonel in the Marine Reserves who directed artillery fire in the combat zone and once fought as an enlisted marine in Vietnam. A lawyer in Norman, Okla., Mr. English, who is 44 years old, was toasted by more than 100 friends at a surprise party last Saturday night.
But for many returning veterans, the most immediate problem will be financial. Mr. Blagg, the Marine gunnery sergeant, said that if he was released from duty by the end of next week he would be in his sales office in Krum, Tex., the following Monday. Returnees can take up to 90 days off before they return to work, but Mr. Blagg said, "I can't afford to."
Other sales managers in his division at Central Transport Inc., a transportation company based in Detroit, tried to cover his seven-state territory during his absence, but competitors lured away some big accounts. Mr. Blagg said he must move quickly to regain those customers or his income would suffer. "I'm judged by my production," he said.
Other veterans are thinking about economic warfare, too. David Meek, owner of an office-supply company in Topeka, Kan., and navigator on a KC-135 refueling tanker, said one of his worst moments during the war was when he was told during a call home that Bizmart, a national chain of discount office-supply stores, would open a store in Topeka next month. "That probably shook me the most of anything that happened over there," he said.
Mr. English, the lawyer, had to drop his private practice and its six-figure income when he left on Dec. 4 for the military. The yearly pay rate for his job as a lieutenant colonel in the Marine Reserves is about $50,000. "The pay cut was enough to make my banker go crazy," he said.
Hours before he left, Mr. English got in touch with his clients and gave their files to other lawyers. "Most of the clients were understanding," he said. "But with all due respect, they want you there when they want you there. All that aside, I wanted to go and was happy to go."
Mr. English said he once spoke against legal advertising when he headed the local bar association, but he now sees few options in attracting old and new clients. "It will take a good amount of time to get the practice up to where it was," he said.
 
Threatened With Evictions
 In some cases, spouses and children of reservists with modest incomes have suffered badly. Military chaplains in the Dallas area said Hispanic families were unlawfully threatened with eviction from homes and apartments when paychecks from reservists were slow to arrive in the mail.
"Ribbons are fine, rallies are fine, but I don't think the American people realize that these people need financial help," said Sam Boyd, a former Green Beret commander in Vietnam. A lawyer in Dallas, Mr. Boyd has begun a campaign to raise $1 million to be used for interest-free loans and grants to families of military reservists and National Guard members in northern Texas.
Some psychologists said the military services would be returning thousands of managers and workers who discovered new courage or leadership abilities in the crucible of combat or training that far outweigh any mental or physical ills they bring with them
 
More Appreciation of Life
 And some have learned simply to appreciate life a bit more. Mr. Meek, who flew 32 missions over northern Saudi Arabia and Iraq during the 42 days of war, said: "When you suddenly find yourself in these intense conflicts and question whether or not you're going to survive, you set your priorities differently. I'm going to take a little more time to enjoy life."
James Campbell Quick, a specialist on stress management and a professor of organizational behavior at the University of Texas at Arlington, said: "The low number of casualties has a very important effect on those who have gone to war. Employers can anticipate that there are going to be fewer misadjustment problems as a result. You never have a good war, but from our standpoint this is getting close."

GRAPHIC: Photo Gunnery Sgt. Thomas J. Blagg, right, and Lieut. Col. Bill J. English returned from Saudi Arabia to their Marine reserve regiment's base in Dallas last week. The two men, respectively a sales manager and a lawyer in private practice in civilian life, suffered considerable financial hardship as a result of their call-up and plan to return to work soon after they are released from active military duty (Jarrold Cabluck for The New York Times) (pg. 31)
 
Drawings (pg. 41)
 
Chart: "Helping the Returning Veterans"
 
What managers can do to ease transition from active duty to the office for reservists and National Guard members who served in the war, according to psychologists specializing in veterans' affairs.
 
Talk it out. Encourage veterans to discuss their experience if they want to, but do not pry. Let them set the tone.
 
Be aware of problems. Expect the work of some veterans to be impaired by sleep disorders, their startled responses to unexpected sounds or motions, and vivid, terrifying daydreams.
 
Set goals. Be clear about performance goals but do not coddle veterans. Anticipate that readjustment could take months.
 
Expect new attitudes. Deliver criticism when necessary, but anticipate occasionally angry reactions.
 
Rethink schedules. Consider offering overtime to provide extra income.
 
Be sensitive. Veterans face letdowns as the thrill of victory and homecomings gives way to the mundane realities of life. Many will discover new priorities and want more challenging jobs. The alert manager can direct these restive, new ambitions into special projects. (pg. 41)

HEADLINE: U.S. Law on Hospital Care of Poor Faces Test

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Rosa Rivera had no doctor, no prenatal care and dangerously high blood pressure when she arrived at the emergency room of DeTar Hospital in Victoria, Tex., in labor with her sixth child.
Dr. Michael Burditt, the obstetrician on call, examined Mrs. Rivera and found that her blood pressure was the highest he had ever seen in a pregnant woman. Then he made a decision that has put him at the center of a Federal court case testing the limits of Goverment regulation of emergency care for poor people. 
 Dr. Burditt ordered the woman transferred 170 miles to a public hospital in Galveston, the closest place with advanced equipment for newborns.
When the nurse questioned the wisdom of moving Mrs. Rivera, who waited almost two hours for the ambulance without being re-examined, Dr. Burditt replied, "Until DeTar pays my malpractice insurance, I will pick and choose those patients that I want to treat."
 
Baby Born in Ambulance
 No medical difficulty resulted: Mrs. Rivera gave birth to a healthy baby boy in an ambulance 30 miles from Victoria. But Dr. Burditt's decision on Dec. 5, 1986, has brought the Federal Government's first important test of a 1986 law intended to stop hospitals from refusing to treat poor patients like Mrs. Rivera, a practice sometimes called patient dumping.
An administrative law judge has fined Dr. Burditt $20,000 for violating the 1986 law and acting with reckless disregard of Mrs. Rivera's health. The doctor's appeal is to be argued May 2 in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans.
While the Department of Health and Human Services has brought 15 dumping cases against hospitals, and collected more than $1 million in fines, the case against Dr. Burditt is the first against an individual physician, and may determine just how broadly the 1986 Federal law, the Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act, will apply.
Dr. Burditt said he did not violate the law. He explained that he sent Mrs. Rivera away not because she was poor, but because he thought her baby might need treatment in the Galveston hospital's advanced neonatal unit.
But in supporting Dr. Burditt, the American Medical Association goes further, arguing that the Government is overreaching, seeking to use the dumping law to attack pure medical judgments, and in the process, creating a national standard of medical care that will leave the profession extremely vulnerable to malpractice claims. If the Government wins, the association warns, it will become increasingly difficult to find good emergency-room doctors.
 
Constitutional Issue Raised
 And the Texas Medical Association, also supporting Dr. Burditt, says the whole law is unconstitutional because it requires doctors to treat poor patients without compensation.
Dr. Burditt earns his living in private practice, and is not paid by the hospital. But like all the obstetricians at DeTar, a private hospital, he is required to take a turn caring for the hospital's walk-in obstetric patients -- many of them indigent -- in return for being allowed to admit his private patients to the hospital.
Victoria is a city of 55,000 people in an agricultural area of South Texas. The hospital's nursery has a Level 2 rating, meaning that it is well equipped and able to care properly for all infants except those needing the most advanced technology for their survival.
Michael Astrue, general counsel of the Department of Health and Human Services, which brought the case against the doctor, said the medical associations were in essence challenging the basic idea that emergency rooms have an obligation to treat anyone needing emergency care.
"The Texas Medical Association is holding out for the right to pick and choose among everybody who comes into emergency rooms, and screen out those deemed to be high risk," he said. "That's not how the public understands what an emergency room holds itself out to do. We're very sensitive to the fact that small rural hospitals do not have the same resources as large urban ones. But we do not believe that Mrs. Rivera was sent away because Dr. Burditt thought the case was over his head."
Mr. Astrue says nothing in the law requires the Government to prove either bad faith or that the transfer was economically motivated. To the contrary, the law covers all patients, rich or poor, and all transfers ordered for nonmedical reasons.
According to a coalition of civil rights and women's groups backing the Government, the dumping law would be almost unenforceable if it required proof that a doctor's decision was economically motivated.
 
Provision for $50,000 Fine
 "You're never going to have a doctor who says, 'Take her away because she's poor,' and the law doesn't require that," said Martha Davis of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. "What's amazing about this case is that the doctor said as much as he did, and made this woman have a baby by the side of the road when she should have been in the hospital."
The 1986 law requires all hospitals that receive Medicaid money to provide emergency care to anyone with an unstabilized emergency medical condition and any woman in active labor.
Under the law, such patients may be transferred elsewhere only for medical reasons, and only after the doctor certifies that the risks of the transfer are outweighed by the medical benefits to the patient. For every violation of the law, the doctor or hospital can be fined up to $50,000.
In the Burditt case, an administrative law judge found that Mrs. Rivera's high blood pressure put her at serious risk of stroke, seizures, heart attack and other conditions that could have killed her and her baby, and that her transfer to another hospital "in the uncontrolled environment of an ambulance" increased the risk.
Because the decision to transfer her was not medically reasonable, the judge found, it violated the 1986 law, whether or not it was influenced by Mrs. Rivera's poverty. The judge also criticized Dr. Burditt for not re-examining Mrs. Rivera in the nearly two hours before the ambulance took her away, and for his refusal to treat her when the ambulance returned her and the baby to DeTar Hosptial.
 
Doctor Defends Decision
 Despite his comment to the nurse about the hospital's paying for his malpractice insurance, Dr. Burditt insists he decided to transfer Mrs. Rivera out of concern for her welfare.
"My main concern was that if the baby had problems, as I thought it might based on her blood pressure, it would be in a place where it could get the best care," he said in an interview. "The nurse involved and I were not getting along very well, and some of the things I said were just meant to irritate her, and that remark about malpractice was one of them. And the best obstetrician in the world couldn't have known she was going to give birth so soon."
He said that he never re-examined her because he was busy with another indigent emergency patient, and that he did not treat her on her return because he thought she had dismissed him from her case.
To prove dumping under the law, Dr. Burditt and the American Medical Association argue, the Government must show that the transfer was made in bad faith because the patient was poor.
"That kind of dumping exists, and it's wrong and it must be stopped," said Kirk Johnson, the association's general counsel. "If Dr. Burditt's medical judgment was wrong, and he made a mistake, he can be sued for malpractice. But there's already a crisis in finding good physicians to care for people in emergency rooms, and to have squads of Federal investigators getting into the malpractice business and second-guessing medical judgments is just going to make things worse."
Mr. Johnson said he believed that Dr. Burditt's decision to transfer Mrs. Rivera was based on liability concerns.
"Of course physicians are concerned about being sued, but that's the same thing as saying they're concerned about a bad outcome for the patient, that they don't want to do anything they're not competent to do," he said. "I believe that the defensive practice of medicine does create problems, both in cost and in access, but this law isn't the way to attack those problems, and defensive medicine isn't dumping."
The medical profession is particularly wary about turning the dumping law into another weapon for malpractice claimants, since the law provides that not just the Federal Government, but also private individuals who have been denied treatment, can file charges. But Mrs. Rivera is not involved in the Burditt case.
Dr. William McGanity, of the University of Texas at Galveston's obstetrics department, said the law, as interpreted by the Federal Government, made no sense in the context of rural Texas hospitals, where high-risk patients are routinely sent far away to more sophisticated hospitals. In that context, he said, Dr. Burditt was correct to order the transfer.
"I am not for a moment defending everything Mike Burditt did," he said. "I would wish that it had not taken two hours for Mrs. Rivera to be transported from DeTar. And since it did take so long, I would wish that she had been re-examined before the transport left. But I am not very comfortable with a system in which a Federal bureaucrat comes in afterwards and decides whether there was dumping. As the law is being interpreted, it's going to make it impossible to transfer any woman who is in labor."
Donald Wilcox, general counsel to the Texas Medical Association, said the law, as interpreted by the Federal Government, would actually reduce poor women's access to medical care, swamping small hospitals with high-risk babies who needed expensive intensive care, and creating such financial burdens that many hospitals would close. He said rural hospitals were already fearful that any patient transfer could lead to legal charges.
The Government calls that an unwarranted concern. "We're interested in prosecuting the most egregious cases, not questioning the fine points of medical judgments made in the hurly-burly of the emergency room," Mr. Astrue said. "What the law says is that if you go to emergency room in a crisis, you should not be transferred to another hospital for reasons that are not in your medical interests."
Brenda Willett, a lawyer with East Texas Legal Services, said many East Texas emergency rooms still denied treatment to poor women in labor. Ms. Willett has filed a brief on behalf of five other women who went to their local emergency room while in labor, and were turned away -- one of whom hemorrhaged and died in the ambulance on her way to Galveston.
"It's all inextricably intertwined, whether it's a fear of being sued or a fear of not being paid," Ms. Willett said. "If you're really concerned about a woman's health, you don't put her in an ambulance with no doctor, the riskiest situation. You'd never do that with a rich woman who needed to be transferred. She'd go in a helicopter accompanied by a doctor."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
United Nations Eases Rules On Food and Fuel for Iraqis

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 22

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council lifted its embargo on food supplies to Iraq today and eased restrictions on shipments of certain critical humanitarian goods including fuel for tucks and electrical generators.
These moves came after the United Nations said the allied bombing campaign had inflicted "near-apocalyptic" damage to Iraq's economy and threatened its people with "imminent catastrophe." 
 The Council committee administering the trade embargo decided those wishing to send food to Iraq may do so provided that they notify the committee at the time the shipment is made. This is the same system that has applied all along to medical supplies.
In addition, the committee decided that shipments of humanitarian goods, including fuel for generators, agricultural machinery and water purification and sewage treatment equipment, will be approved automatically if none of the 15 member states objects. Those wishing to send such goods must still notify the committee in advance. The full Council endorsed the committee's action later today, but Council approval was not necessary to lift the restrictions, because the committee is empowered to act alone in emergencies.
 
Cuba and Yemen Seek More
 Cuba and Yemen, two members who have opposed the United States' handling of the Gulf crisis, were defeated in their attempt to have all restrictions on food and humanitarian aid formally abolished, as United Nations Under Secretary General Martti Ahtisaari recommended in a report Thursday.
As a result, the original sanctions remain legally in effect, though with what amounts to a permanent exemption for foodstuffs.
The committee is expected to raise no objection to shipments of humanitarian goods, , diplomats say. But the United States maintains a veto right if it disagrees with a particular delivery.
Today's decision continues the gradual easing of trade restrictions since the end of the ground war.
 
Iraq Will Distribute Shipments
 Food and other goods sent to Iraq as a result of today's decisions will be distributed by the Iraqi authorities because the humanitarian organizations lack the means to do so.
But officials say these organizations will conduct spot checks to ensure supplies are reaching needy people in all parts of the country and are not being hoarded by the Iraqi army.
In Washington the Bush Administration expressed sympathy for the plight of the ordinary Iraqi people today and said it wants to help them.
"We're sympathetic towards the Iraqi and Kuwaiti people and others in the region for the hardships they have suffered at the hands of Saddam Hussein," said State Department spokesman Richard A. Boucher.
"Our main concern at this point is that humanitarian relief shipments actually reach the right people, the vulnerable civilian groups that are truly in need," he added.
 
No Guilt Seen for U.S.
 But Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman, laid responsibility for the destruction in Iraq fully on Saddam Hussein and said, "You will not find America feeling guilty."
Mr. Fitzwater said that officials "have no way of knowing" if the damage was as severe as that described in the United Nations report, but that "that certainly was not our intent."
In any case, he aid, "I just simply reject the argument that somehow there is a guilt associated with the destruction of a war caused by Saddam Hussein."
"We fought the war decisively, we fought it well, and we fought it as discriminatingly as we could," Mr. Fitzwater said. "You will not find America feeling guilty for Saddam Hussein's invasion and destruction of his own people."
Some American diplomats questioned the Ahtisaari report's appeal for emergency fuel supplies to provide electricity for hospitals and water purification plants and to get transport services moving again.
They pointed out that the Iraqi Army has sufficient fuel and trucks to fight a civil war against the rebels trying to oust President Saddam Hussein and suggested the military should hand over supplies for civilian use.
 
U.N. Official Dodges Question
 When asked why he did not recommend the Iraqi army provide fuel and transport for humanitarian purposes instead of recommending an end to sanctions, Mr. Ahtisaari ducked the question at a press conference today.
He said his mission was only to assess Iraq's humanitarian needs "on the basis of what is available in the country" and that these needs could not be met without "addressing the country's underlying energy needs."
But he also said the Iraqi authorities are aware that the international response to his appeal for urgent assistance "will depend on how they handle the internal situation."
"The Iraqi authorities are aware they are under a magnifying glass," Mr. Ahtisaari added.
However the United States did not press its argument about the Iraqi army, diplomats say, in part because it feared that without some easing of the trade embargo today the Security Council might vote to abolish the sanctions altogether.
The United States does not want the trade sanctions against Iraq formally lifted until a new cease-fire resolution is approved and Baghdad has agreed to cooperate with its provisions.
The American draft requires Baghdad to agree to destroy its chemical and biological weapons, abide by its 1963 border agreement with Kuwait, create a mechanism for compensating victims of its aggression and return Kuwaiti detainees and stolen property. It also maintains an indefinite embargo on all military sales to Iraq.
