HEADLINE: ALBANY TO ALLOW LARGER CLASS SIZE FOR HANDICAPPED

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York State took a major step yesterday toward scaling back school programs for the handicapped by increasing maximum class sizes for students with learning disabilities.
The decision by the Board of Regents in Albany, which came over the objections of advocates for the handicapped and the state's teachers unions, is being watched by legislators and school administrators across the nation. Many have expressed frustration that during the fiscal austerity of a national recession they must confine many of their spending cuts to mainstream classes. 
 Special-education classes, as classes for the handicapped are known, are protected by Federal law, state mandates and court orders. Their enrollments have grown as troubled students whom teachers cannot handle have been referred there to receive counseling or individualized help.
 
4.2 Million Involved Nationwide
 There are now 4.2 million special-education students in the nation, about 12 percent of all schoolchildren. Most have been classified as learning-disabled or emotionally disturbed, though critics question how validly the terms are being applied.
William Schipper, executive director of the National Association of State Directors of Special Education, said the Regents' decision was the first that he knew of by any state to increase special-education class sizes. He said the decision would be studied by other states "just to see what people do with tight money."
The 16-member Board of Regents sets overall policy and standards for the state's public and private schools.
In New York City, 119,000 students are classified as handicapped -- one of every eight students in the city and roughly half of all such students in the state. Special education receives almost one of every four dollars spent on the city's schools. Of the total special-education enrollment, 70,000 students are classified as learning-disabled, a term that sometimes reflects neurological impairment but more often signifies a failure to reach intellectual potential.
The Regents' decision, which is not subject to any further review, yesterday raised the maximum class size for learning-disabled students to 15, from 12, and allowed some classes for severely handicapped students to grow to 8, from 6.
In practical terms, the decision to increase class size will mean that fewer teachers will be needed for the same number of children, creating enormous potential savings for financially strapped districts throughout the state. The State Education Department estimated that the changes will save $115.3 million statewide.
New York City will not increase class sizes for severely handicapped children, said Waldemar Rojas, the city's director of special education, because the cost of reclassifying children for larger classes -- which requires tests and interviews with psychologists and social workers -- would exceed any savings. Such reclassifications do not have to be performed with learning-disabled students.
State officials said children classified as severely handicapped include those with autism, multiple handicaps and emotional disturbances.
 
Bitter Opposition
 Joseph A. Fernandez, New York City's Schools Chancellor, who vigorously fought for the new rules, said the Regents' decision would save the city $29.4 million in the next school year, and other steps approved by the Regents would save about $10 million more. The city school system has been told it must cut $505 million from a projected budget of $7.568 billion.
The Regents also voted unanimously on a variety of other proposals to save money, including recommending to the State Legislature that the caseload for teachers who work with small groups of learning-disabled students pulled out of mainstream classes grow to 25 from 20. That is expected to save $8.9 million.
Advocates for the handicapped bitterly denounced the changes. Eli Nieman, education chairman of the Association for Neurologically Impaired-Brain Injured in New York City, said it was the "death knell" for learning-disabled children, and would place them in unwieldy groups where they could not get the help they need.
Describing classes of 15 as a "teaching nightmare," he said that students in special-education classes have been placed there because of a wide variety of dissimilar problems, including dyslexia, organic brain damage, mild retardation and lagging development. Those different problems need different instructional approaches, he said.
Mr. Nieman, principal of a Queens elementary school and a father of a brain-injured child, said many special-education teachers in the city are young and inexperienced.
 
'They Know Better'
 "Classes have become a hodgepodge," he said. "They are destroying these children and they know better."
The United Federation of Teachers also opposed the class-size increases.
Mr. Rojas, the city's director of special education, has defended the increase by noting that educational experts have never demonstrated what is an optimal class size. States like California have a 15-to-1 student-teacher ratio and do well, he said.
At a news conference yesterday, State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol said, "If you had your druthers, in almost any case I can think of you would press for smaller classes rather than larger." But he noted that the state was "in the middle of a budget crisis," and said, "We're having to look at reductions all across the board."
He argued that the "changes we're proposing would not hurt handicapped kids," and "in many cases will improve their education." As an example, he said limiting the time children with mild learning disabilities -- who attend mainstream classes for most of the school day -- spend out of their classes might allow them to use their in-class time more productively.

HEADLINE: Lessons From a Budget Crisis

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins and Gov. Mario Cuomo are reacting to the downward spiral of New York's economy with more realism than they've displayed in the past. The New York City Mayor's call this week for concessions from city unions is a particularly welcome sign, and the Governor has proposed his own solutions to the latest downturn instead of waiting for the Legislature.
At least neither official is ducking. Yet neither is usefully exploiting the crisis to make the innovative, fundamental changes that could help New York get through the next recession. 
 The proposed remedies to the current fiscal crisis are little more than urgent versions of the usual -- a mix of budget cuts and higher taxes. Mr. Dinkins, anticipating a $3.1 billion budget gap in the next fiscal year -- $910 million higher than his earlier estimate -- proposes to cut services even more and demand givebacks from the city unions. The Mayor's new resolve is gratifying; until now, he's been unwisely protective of the unions. The test will be whether he follows through.
Mr. Cuomo also faces a growing deficit. He has proposed a new hodgepodge of one-shot savings, program delays and agency cuts. The Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, complains a lot but offers no alternatives. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller rejects the Governor's call for an increased gasoline tax, argues that an income tax increase would be fairer, and suggests extending the fiscal year.
Some of these ideas have merit, and in the end budgets will emerge in both state and city. But last-minute drama and piecemeal approaches could produce genuinely harmful results and, in any case, are a poor answer to a floundering economy and years of statewide waste and mismanagement.
Government does not have to run this way. Except for Albany's move earlier this year to begin phasing out its spring borrowing, the city and state have failed to make fundamental changes. To do so will require the Mayor and Governor to stop sniping at each other, acknowledge that the city and state are inextricably linked, and work creatively together.
The state's costly Medicaid program, for example, needs restructuring rather than ad hoc cuts. Social services can be delivered more efficiently, helping recipients as well as government. So can education, including higher education. The city and state have to ask whether the state needs so large a state university system, and whether the city can continue to support its city university system and a huge municipal hospital network.
These are extraordinarily painful questions because they involve the relatively high level of services that New Yorkers have grown accustomed to. That was never clearer than last week, when a group of state university students, protesting pending tuition increases, resorted to inexcusably crude, violent tactics in the State Capitol.
But as difficult as it is to restructure government, it can be done. And because it has not been done, the city and state now find themselves dealing with severe fiscal problems in old-fashioned ways, at a punishing cost to the public.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How About Puerto Rico's Self-Determination?;
Hidden Wealth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former New Yorker who lives in Puerto Rico, I believe Tom Wicker's Feb. 9 column on statehood for Puerto Rico lacked basic facts about its political and social situation. I will discuss but one of his premises. 
 Mr. Wicker writes of the relatively low per capita income in Puerto Rico compared with the rest of the United States. There is poverty in Puerto Rico, though perhaps (since our total population is only three million) not so much as in New York City. Even by the official statistics, Puerto Rico has the highest per capita income in Latin America (that is, third behind the United States and Canada for the Western Hemisphere).
Mr. Wicker also describes Puerto Rico as the most important market for United States exports in Latin America, buying more goods than Argentina, Brazil and Chile combined. If three million Puerto Ricans import more United States products than 200 million people in South America (even given the high level of poverty in South America), there may be a problem with the per capita income statistic for Puerto Rico.
Few "mainlanders" know of the tax situation in Puerto Rico, which could contribute to this potential contradiction. Residents of Puerto Rico do not pay Federal taxes, but do pay a local income tax administered by the Commonwealth. It is well known that there is massive tax fraud in Puerto Rico. As an example, the average reported income for physicians or lawyers is $20,000 to $30,000 a year. This statistic was recently rejected by a jury in a Federal Court suit, and a figure closer to $150,000 a year was used to calculate a judgment. Similar disparities almost certainly exist.
In the United States, having a reported income disproportionate to your life style or the average income of your profession is a guaranteed way of producing an Internal Revenue Service investigation. This is not so in Puerto Rico.
Anyone who visits Puerto Rico and sees high-rise apartments and housing developments being built and sold at prices from $150,000 to $500,000 would be hard pressed to think this island has an economy vastly weaker than Mississippi's. This is to say nothing of the many Mercedeses, BMW's and other luxury cars commonly seen on our roads.
Another interesting statistic is that the highest-grossing stores in the Sears and J. C. Penney chains are in Puerto Rico. This is not a statistic you would associate with an economically depressed region.
There are also legal ways to defer a much larger percent of your total income in Puerto Rico than under I.R.S. regulations. For example, when I worked on the mainland, my ability to defer income was limited to a relatively small percent, while at my job in Puerto Rico I can defer up to 100 percent of my income. Thus, comparing per capita income figures calculated under two tax codes is mixing apples and oranges.
A more objective approach to the economic strength of Puerto Rico might be to calculate the per capita consumption of retail goods and services sold on the island, and compare this with other regions of the United States. You might find we are not so far from the rest of the United States as the per capita income figure would suggest.
 
KENNETH A. GRUBER
Condado, P.R., March 1, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Top U.S. Auditor Criticizes Plan To Bolster Bank Insurance Fund

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The Government's senior auditor today sharply criticized the Administration's proposal to bolster the dwindling bank insurance fund by extending its borrowing authority to $70 billion.
 In his first interview about the Treasury plan to reorganize the program that protects bank deposits, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, said that extending the fund's borrowing ability was an unrealistic way of handling the growing crisis that would "ultimately hurt the Administration's credibility." 
Referring to the savings and loan bailout, Mr. Bowsher said, "I've been through taxpayer bailouts before and this is how they often get started." He is highly regarded on Capitol Hill for his nonpartisan and intense scrutiny of bank regulators and other Government agencies. His opinion could become a serious obstacle for Congressional passage of the Administration's plan.
 
Insolvency Seen in Year or Two
 Some officials have predicted that the $8.4 billion insurance fund will be insolvent within the next year or two. The fund is now at its lowest level in relation to deposits in the 57-year history of the insurance program.
 Fears of a taxpayer bailout of the bank fund were heightened on Thursday by the surprise disclosure by L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, that the Administration was actually seeking $70 billion in borrowing authority, not the $25 billion it had said at the beginning of the week.
 Mr. Bowsher heads the General Accounting Office, the agency that audits and investigates Government programs for Congress. He said the G.A.O. would be issuing its recommendations to Congress for reorganizing the bank insurance fund within the next few weeks, but he declined to give any details today. The agency has been sharply critical of regulators for failing to take prompt action that could have avoided the failures of many banks.
 Mr. Bowsher said Congress would be "foolish" to increase the borrowing authority of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, instead of simply providing adequate funds and quantifying the actual losses. "The way to deal with this is up front and not through just increasing borrowing authority," he said.
 The Treasury plan, which has been presented as an effort to avoid the use of taxpayer funds, provides for a $25 billion credit line with the Federal Reserve and another $45 billion from the Federal Financing Bank, which coordinates financing activities of Federal agencies whose obligations are guaranteed by the Government.
 The plan envisions that all borrowings would be repaid through increases in premiums paid by banks to the insurance fund and the proceeds of sales of assets obtained by the Government from collapsed banks.
 
Mechanics of Borrowing
 The $45 billion lending authority would be accomplished by counting a $5 billion existing line of credit with the Treasury as equity. Under current law, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation can borrow up to nine times its existing equity.
 Mr. Seidman's disclosure has prompted some economists and critics from the banking industry to say the plan in effect permits regulators to borrow money that is secured by other borrowed money, not unlike using a Mastercard to repay a loan taken on a Visa card.
 "They blew it politically," said Robert E. Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution who has come out in favor of borrowing $50 billion directly from the Treasury Deaprtment, not the way it has been proposed. "This smacks of gimmickry."
 Mr. Litan, who was a member of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Carter Administration, said the failure of Treasury officials to disclose the accurate size of their request at the beginning of the week reflected that they had either been playing down the magnitude of the problem because of the fear that it would be a replay of the highly unpopular savings and loan bailout or that they had simply been incompetent in the way they had described the plan.
 The F.D.I.C. insures bank accounts of up to $100,000 and would continue to do so even if the bank fund became insolvent. But if the borrowing plan was not adopted or was insufficient, then taxpayer funds might ultimately have to be used to protect those deposits.
Mr. Seidman has estimated that the rising rate of large bank failures would cost the bank insurance fund $30 billion to $35 billion over the next three years to protect depositors.
 Treasury officials denied today that they had deliberately sought to conceal the true size of the request, insisting that it was not a significant change in the borrowing authority of the F.D.I.C.
 Jerome H. Powell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for domestic finance, disputed Mr. Bowsher's assessment.
 "There are various sets of projections," Mr. Powell said. "Under any of them, this plan is adequate to solve the problem with industry contributions and without resorting to taxpayer funds."
 "There is no certainty on the ultimate size of the actual losses," he said. "But the plan is large enough to handle all the projections."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Honolulu

BYLINE: By LENORE MAGIDA; LENORE MAGIDA, a journalist, lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
After nearly 32 years of statehood, millions of visitors and vast transformation, Hawaii and its capital, Honolulu, still retain their aura of far-off tropical exotica. To many mainland residents, it seems, three decades of national togetherness are nothing compared with 3,000 miles of separation. Even the most sophisticated ask Hawaiian friends and relatives, "When are you coming to the States?" Visitors, especially in Honolulu, are surprised at the everyday American-ness, and perhaps even more startled that Honolulu has standard modern headaches -- for example, that it has, per capita, more two-career couples and more cars per mile of road than anywhere else in the country.
Even so, the image of paradise is grounded in reality. Though overbuilt, bumper-to-bumper and burdened, Honolulu has the cachet of being on a mid-Pacific tropical island. But the differences go deeper. In Honolulu, everyone is a part of a minority, but the majority of people are ethnically Asian. And though locals often tend to be ethnically insular, there really is something to the sometimes jaded "aloha spirit." 
 These days are difficult for many who earn their living marketing that spirit. Recession and war have hit hard at tourism, the largest and most important industry in the city and state. Officials expected the recession to cut business by 10 percent, but they've seen a drop of some 20 percent from last year. Moreover, many people from Hawaii's second-largest industry, the military, have gone to the gulf; not infrequently, their families have returned to mainland hometowns.
In Honolulu, the economy depends on tourists and off-duty military personnel. When they're around, good businesses typically do fine, even charging the notoriously high prices. Now, however, they're looking hard for customers; some are offering reduced rates, upgrades and the like.
In such circumstances, you might be tempted simply to bask on relatively empty Waikiki Beach. But Honolulu has other beaches, other attractions and a real life of its own that make it not just a tropical destination but an intriguing American city.
 
Diversions
 The East-West Center International Fair on April 7 features performances, exhibits and food from all over the region. The center, adjacent to the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, is a federally financed institution whose research and other programs are devoted to cultural and technical interchange between East and West; (808) 944-7715.
For an afternoon or evening of all-American recreation with a Hawaiian twist, try a University of Hawaii baseball game. The Rainbows are playing quite well this year. After playing host to the 16th Rainbow Easter Tournament from March 22 to 30, the Bows will have home games April 12 to 21 and May 10 through the month. The game is the same as anywhere else, of course, but sitting in Rainbow Stadium, glimpsing Diamond Head and nibbling with chopsticks at your bento (Japanese box lunch) is not. For ticket information call (808) 956-4481.
The first Hawaiian king, Kamehameha, will be honored on all islands from June 7 to 11 (June 11 is King Kamehameha Day). In Honolulu, there will be music, hula and a lei-draping ceremony on June 7 at the King Kamehameha statue across from Iolani Palace (the palace of the former Hawaiian royalty). On June 8 at 9:30 A.M. will be the 75th Annual King Kamehameha Celebration Floral Parade, ending at Kapiolani Park (next to Waikiki) with a hoolaulea, or cultural arts and crafts fair. Call (808) 586-0333 for information.
All year Honolulu offers many outdoor attractions. For example, the Waikiki Aquarium at 2777 Kalakaua Avenue (on the ocean, just opposite Kapiolani Park) houses a wealth of sea creatures. Its newest exhibit is a mahimahi hatchery, where visitors can see aquaculture at work and also get a look at the swift ocean fish that wind up on so many Hawaiian dinner plates. The aquarium conducts hikes, evening programs and other events. It is open daily 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and requests a $3 donation; admission is free for children under 16.
Many American cities have a Chinatown, but Honolulu's feels different -- perhaps because of the intense ethnic mix, perhaps because the tropical setting makes it feel more like Asia. In any event, there is much to discover in this 15-block area -- markets, bakeries, herbalists, lei vendors, knickknack shops, historical buildings and more. In addition, though the area has hardly been gentrified, it has in recent years become home to quite a few art galleries and a growing number of trendy restaurants. It's an easy neighborhood to explore on your own (though some parts, especially Hotel Street, are best avoided at night) but, if you'd rather, the Chinatown Historical Society, (808) 521-3045, conducts free walking tours on weekdays.
 
Shopping
 Chinatown galleries and a number of shops elsewhere in Honolulu feature local artists and craftspeople whose work conveys -- through style, materials, colors, themes and other means -- the island ambiance and the Asian and Pacific influences. The variety is rich and the price range wide: a $9 set of a half-dozen abstract seascape notecards, $40 beach-glass earrings, calabashes (carved wooden bowls) and fiber baskets for $100 to $300, paintings and sculptures in the four-figure range. Some places to try: Pauahi Nuuanu Gallery, 1 North Pauahi Street (in Chinatown); Gallery EAS, 1426 Makaloa Street (one block behind Ala Moana Center); Nohea Gallery at Ward Warehouse; Following Sea at Kahala Mall.
Honolulu's museum shops are also good: the Shop Pacifica at the Bishop Museum, 1525 Bernice Street; the Academy Shop at the Honolulu Academy of the Arts, 900 South Beretania Street; the Museum Shop at the Contemporary Museum, 2411 Makiki Heights Drive.
 
Night Life
 Honolulu also has its own distinctive night life. For a lively and very dressed-down evening, try Anna Banana's, 2440 South Beretania Street, (808) 946-5190. On Fridays and Saturdays the house band is the excellent Pagan Babies. For a $5 cover you can stay until 2 A.M.
At a very different point on the entertainment spectrum are the Brothers Cazimero (Robert and Roland), who perform Tuesday through Saturday nights at the lovely, venerable Sheraton Royal Hawaiian Hotel, 2259 Kalakaua Avenue, (808) 923-7311. Residents admire the Caz for their integrity in performing -- and explaining -- genuine Hawaiian music in a tourist venue. Shows at 8:30 P.M., $59.95 for dinner and show; $25 for single cocktail and show; additional cocktail shows at 10:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday for $20.
 
Hotels
 There is never a shortage of hotels, and now there is also no shortage of available rooms. From sumptuous to Spartan, you can probably find whatever you want. The rates quoted are current, but be sure to check -- the deals may be improving.
The Sheraton Moana Surfrider, 2365 Kalakaua Avenue, (808) 922-3111, the first hotel in Hawaii, graces its oceanfront location with Old World splendor after its $50 million renovation two years ago. Double rooms, $185 to $285.
The newest addition to the luxury hotel scene is the Hawaii Prince Hotel, where every room faces the ocean. The hotel, at 100 Holomoana Street, (808) 956-1111, is next to the Ala Wai Yacht Harbor, just beyond which are the very popular Ala Moana Beach and the huge Ala Moana shopping center. Rates for doubles are $180 to $320; among the discounts is a 20 percent reduction for senior citizens.
For a lovely beachfront location beyond but still close to Waikiki, try the New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel or the Colony Surf Hotel, both of which are at the foot of Diamond Head on Sans Souci Beach, at the end of Kapiolani Park. Double rooms are $105 or $120 at the Kaimana Beach, 2863 Kalakaua Avenue, (808) 923-1555. At the Colony Surf, 2895 Kalakaua Avenue, (800) 252-7873 or (808) 923-5751, they range from $125 to $285.
Budget choice: For fine budget accommodations, try the Hawaiiana Hotel. The Hawaiiana, 260 Beach Walk, (800) 367-5122 or (808) 923-3811, is a low-rise with lots of tropical flora surrounding a pool, and it prides itself on its knowledgeable staff. Double rooms are $85 or $95.
 
Dining Out
 There is more than one way to eat well in Honolulu. You can certainly find first-rate preparations of standard American and European fare. But it's usually more interesting to choose restaurants that take advantage of the Honolulu's qualities: its predominantly Asian-Pacific ethnic mix, its surrounding seas and its year-round growing climate.
Roy's, one of the most heralded of Honolulu's newer restaurants, draws customers to the suburb of Hawaii Kai with Roy Yamaguchi's distinctive, delicious way of drawing on Asian, Californian and Continental cuisines as well as local ingredients. There are always five or more fresh fish specials, along with such menu standbys as mesquite grilled ginger lime chicken. Dinner for two with a modest bottle of wine, about $90. Dinner daily starting at 5:30 P.M., last seating 9:45 P.M.; Sunday brunch 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. 6600 Kalanianaole Highway, (808) 396-7697.
Another deservedly praised chef-owner is Keo Sananikone, who has five Thai restaurants in Honolulu (three called Keo's, two called Mekong). The flagship restaurant, Keo's, at 625 Kapahulu Avenue, (808) 737-8240, abounds with flowers and celebrities. Dinner for two is about $60 with wine. The signature dish is Evil Jungle Prince, chicken or shrimp prepared with coconut milk, basil and red chilies. Open 5:30 P.M. to 11 P.M. daily.
Smaller, lower key, thoroughly pleasant in its own right is A Little Bit of Saigon, in Chinatown. Its owners, finding Hawaii the source of tropical herbs for their two Seattle restaurants, decided to open in Honolulu as well. Menu standouts include chao tom (broiled minced shrimp on sugar cane) and the two-person Seven Courses of Beef Banquet. Two people can eat well here for about $35. No liquor license, but you may bring your own drink. Open 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily. 1160 Maunakea Street, (808) 528-3663.
With its large Japanese population and usually huge number of Japanese tourists, Honolulu abounds in Japanese restaurants. For a wide variety of the freshest sushi, try Yanagi Sushi, 762 Kapiolani Boulevard, (808) 537-1525. Dinner for two, about $50. Open 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 3 A.M. (Sunday to 10 P.M.); that late closing is a special attraction in early-to-bed, early-to-rise Honolulu. A different sort of Japanese restaurant, but equally worthy, is Iroha Jaya, in the Kaimuki section. You can spend an entire evening on a Kaiseki feast, a traditional, many-course, Kyoto-style dinner that can cost, as they put it, "from $40 a person up to anything." Other choices are less expensive. Open 11 A.M. (except Sunday) and 5:30 P.M. to 9:30 P.M. 1048 Koko Head Avenue, (808) 732-1411.

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
The Telly's Take On Americans? Texans All

BYLINE: By Russell Davies; Russell Davies writes about television and sports for The London Daily Telegraph and other publications.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
British television viewers, especially those of a certain age, got a great kick out of the gulf war briefings of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. There are several reasons, and some are obvious: namely, that the general was our ally, that the news he brought was overwhelmingly positive, and that he was visibly nerved up to make his performances as dramatic as they were informative. But General Schwarzkopf also embodied a more nostalgic appeal, one that is slightly embarrassing for a Britisher to explain.
The fact is that he reminded us of an American we used to know -- in fact, the American we used to know, the American stereotype. From the moment we saw the bullish stride, the meaty face, the hot eyes and the peremptory finger jabbed in the direction of the trembling scribes, we felt at home with this person. We even felt we might have invented him, so perfectly did he correspond to a caricature of American-ness we have guiltily treasured for nearly 50 years. 
 This caricature was born, of course, in wartime, and nurtured by a low-level but persistent resentment of the American G.I., "overpaid, oversexed and over here," his pockets perpetually overflowing with chewing gum, cigarettes and nylon stockings, evidences of an economic ease we did not ourselves enjoy.
Victory removed the problem for a time, but later the G.I. returned to Britain as a plump tourist. He wore a shockingly loud checked jacket, a crew cut, a camera and a cigar, and he demanded, in unsubtle tones, to be shown the way to London Tower and the House of Parliaments and other not-quite-existent destinations. Such men, we believed, were all called Elmer or Floyd. It was ridiculous and unfair, but that's how caricatures are. We preferred our pet distortions of the truth to the truth itself. Americans with downbeat clothes, lank hair and an apologetic manner had to be somehow deficient in their own national hormone.
It would be pleasant to report that the days of distortion are over and gone, but not so: British television fictions, in particular, are still clinging to the stock figures. Even the very best of our output flirts dangerously with stereotypes. Witness "Edge of Darkness," the finest serial thriller Britain produced in the mid-80's, a winner of six awards from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts. The start of the story revealed itself as a brilliantly conceived film noir, set largely in the north of England and proving its single-mindedness by killing off Joanne Whalley (-Kilmer, as she later became) in the opening minutes.
Into this symphony of shadows, Joe Don Baker abruptly strode, wearing a broad-brimmed Dallas hat -- the kind with the crushed cage-bird plastered on the front -- and announcing himself as "Darius Jedburgh" (who?). "Howdy!" continued Mr. Jedburgh, adding, unnecessarily on the whole, that he had just got in from Texas. To be sure, the stereotype was introduced in this way so that we would later have the pleasure of discovering that the Jedburgh character did have some depth after all; but it was still a shock entrance, from which the mood of the piece took some time to recover.
Part of the trouble is that American characters always occur singly in British TV drama. In the days when home-grown actors took the "Yank" parts -- big, rumbustious Irishmen like Harry Towb and David Healy were the favorites -- we could afford to portray them in groups, but now we are ambitious enough to import real American actors, and they cost money. Frederic Forrest has been the latest to appear, in a serial called "Die Kinder" (PBS will show the six-part series beginning Thursday at 8 on "Mystery"). He plays one of those been-through-it-all-and-corrupted-by-most-of-it types who derive ultimately from Philip Marlowe (Raymond Chandler has a lot to answer for).
Michael Wearing, who produced "Edge of Darkness" and is now head of serials at BBC Television, has always favored American involvement. "If we can retain some sort of editorial integrity," he says, "there's nothing wrong in giving an American dimension to the work. If you're going to go in for an international approach at all, an American contribution is a lot easier to work with than any other, and there's a terrific subculture there that our audience is very educated about."
But not educated enough, according to Michael Grade, chief executive of the British Channel 4 (office-wall motto: "Collaboration"). Mr. Grade spent nearly four years in Hollywood and has often found himself squirming in the viewing theater while showing an American buyer his countrymen as perceived by British writers.
"In fiction," Mr. Grade says, "U.K. writers writing for the U.K. market never make an American character central, or properly developed. Americans are just dotted in, and frankly I think we're rotten at it. I don't believe most of the writers have been to America. Manhattan, Hollywood maybe, but there's never any feeling for places like Chicago, or Boston."
In Michael Wearing's opinion, however, the quirkiness of the parts for Americans has its attraction for the actors who fly over to play them. "I think it's a busman's holiday for many of them," he says. "They don't make fortunes, but they get to play parts that aren't relentlessly heroic all the time, in the Americans' own style. Sometimes, in fact, they play characters capable of criticizing the American internal system, political or cultural, and that's refreshing."
Everyone agrees that the age of the fake American, as played by a Briton with tortured vowels, is almost over. Ned Chaillet, a BBC Radio drama producer and a native of Washington, is particularly sensitive to these matters. (And he should be, for radio drama, at all levels from the classics to juvenile farce, is still a big thing in Britain. It's poorly paid, but actors love to do it.) Chaillet is currently casting a production of Noel Coward's "Design for Living," a play that is invaded by a troupe of American ladies in the last act. Listening to an archive tape of the last BBC production of the piece, he was shocked at how lamely the women were played by non-Americans ("just awful"). This time, he is hoping that Gayle Hunnicutt of Fort Worth (who is married to the editor of The Times of London) will lead the invading pack.
 Can we hope for similar care to be taken with newly written material, and on both sides of the Atlantic? Michael Grade of Channel 4 thinks not, and he extends his critique to include America's view of Britain.
"The basic rule, on both sides," says Mr. Grade, "is that foreigners are funny. You look at any Hollywood-made entertainment. If there's a British character in it, he's going to be either a butler, or something royal, a prince. And not even the butlers are right. Years ago, we had a famous series called 'Upstairs, Downstairs,' about life in an aristocratic Edwardian household with lots of domestic staff.
"CBS took this up and made it into a thing called 'Beacon Hill,' " which, he says, he and his colleagues agreed, missed the nuances of the original because "the American networks' idea of the complexities of the master-servant relationship is, basically, room service."
Perhaps both sides could agree on a set of elementary rules and prohibitions. America could cut out the butlers; we could abolish the Stetsons and bow ties (all Americans in "Inspector Morse" are professors with bow ties). In this way we might begin to creep reciprocally toward the complexity that is truth. In the meantime, we, on our side, can give only one guarantee: that, fond though we are of documentary drama, we shall not be employing any Brits to play General Schwarzkopf.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Baron Haussmann, Urban Designer Par Excellence

BYLINE: By Martin Filler; Martin Filler, who frequently writes about architecture, is a contributing editor of Conde Nast Traveler, HG and Vanity Fair.

 BODY:
If any city plan can be seen as the environmental expression of national characteristics, then Paris is among the most obvious. It is a veritable diagram of the French proclivity for centralization, rationalism and prestige. It is also proof of what one dynamic individual can do to reshape a city, a kind of leadership many people long for today, as our urban problems often seem insurmountable, especially through design.
 The man who created Paris as we now know it died there 100 years ago this past January at the age of 81. But the legacy of Baron Georges-Eugene Haussmann, city planner nonpareil, has long outlived him. For historians and critics in recent years, opinion has been sharply divided. Was Haussmann the selfless benefactor of civic progress seen by his admirers, or a cynical promoter of a new consumer culture, as seen by Marxist critics? Did he illuminate the City of Light or vandalize the historic bourg of Louis IX, Saint and King of France? Did his policies stimulate social responsibility or increase class divisions? Since his death, his reputation has fluctuated with the political climate. None, however, can dispute his importance. 
 The current sad state of city planning has stimulated revisionist enthusiasm for Haussmann. The French urban historian Francois Loyer, in his 1988 book, "Paris: 19th Century," summed up that school of thought. "As far as I can see," he wrote, "a neo-Haussmann approach is the only one capable of reunifying Paris. [It is] much less perverse than the post-modernists' anguished derision of cultural tradition. There is nothing wrong with going back to something that worked."
 From 1853 to 1870 as prefect of the Seine -- director of public works for the Paris region -- Haussmann energetically attacked and largely solved many of the ills caused by the rapid and tremendous growth of the commercial center and social lodestone of France. His urban design program was second to none in modern times. Demolishing some 12,000 structures, cutting 85 miles of new direct roadways through the city to replace 333 miles of meandering old ones, erecting imposing landmarks like the Opera and the Halles Centrales, revamping the antiquated and unhealthy water and sewage systems, increasing the number of street lights and sidewalks, and establishing parks equal to contemporary schemes in London and New York, Paris under Haussmann was in an almost constant state of construction upheaval.
 The broad, light-filled, tree-lined thoroughfares that became his hallmark perfectly illustrate the multiplicity of purpose that always underlay the efforts of this protean pragmatist. Haussmann's boulevards, for the most part angled across existing streets and linked together at diagonals, served many different functions. They connected the city's new train terminals more efficiently, allowed the quick deployment of troops in case of revolts like those of recent memory in 1830 and 1848, and "disemboweled" the troublesome neighborhoods where those rebellions traditionally fomented. They also permitted the more expedient transport of goods and services around town as the local economy shifted from small artisans working near their homes to an industrialized system spread over a wide area. Finally, they gave shape to the eight new arrondissements Haussmann added around the periphery of Paris, and set up an extendible matrix for future growth.
 Apolitical but opportunistic, authoritarian but flexible, he was a Janus-like figure. He looked back to Louis XIV's Grande Epoque for the Baroque planning ideal of plazas, radial avenues and junctures, like the Etoile. At the same time, he looked ahead to the 20th century with his concern for sanitary engineering, zoning regulations protecting access to light and air, and even an unfulfilled proposal for a greenbelt surrounding Paris (although by no means was he a crusader for society's dispossessed).
 Esthetics was not neglected. Despite what Haussmann called his "piercings" -- it was said that he tore down half of Paris to build up the other half -- few significant landmarks were razed. Whenever he could, Haussmann made those noble survivors the termination points of his new vistas, and where needed he commissioned churches, monuments and set-pieces to give closure to a boulevard or intersection.
 Among the public who know and love Paris there are mixed responses to Haussmann's urbanism. To some, the city's beauty rests in its dignity and consistency, its symmetry and order. To others, the architectural pleasures of Paris lie far from Haussmann's grand boulevards lined with long stretches of gray, elephantine buildings. Those endless stone-faced apartment houses -- uniform, decorous, and monotonous -- were his quintessential structures, the foundation of his conception of Paris as a paradise for the bourgeoisie. But a great deal else was subjugated to gain such extraordinary unity. No other great city has so little modulation of color, material, texture and scale as Haussmann's Paris.
 To those who prefer the intimacy, diversity and charm of the quarters that escaped Haussmann's monumental will, like the Marais and much of St.-Germain, he is less than a hero. Thus when people say they like the Left Bank better than the Right Bank, they mean more than just architecture and planning before and after Haussmann. They are also acknowledging that one of Haussmann's most enduring effects was to make once-mixed milieus socially homogeneous. In his rebuilt and new neighborhoods, a cross section of rich, middle-class, and poor people no longer lived in the same streets, and the emergent notion of the economically segregated community prevailed. Real estate interests demanded that their investments be protected, and by insuring that at the expense of all taxpayers, Haussmann was less public servant than social engineer.
 Certainly, Haussmann's urban removals now seem like nothing compared to those proposed by Le Corbusier in his never-executed Voisin Plan of 1925, in which several square miles of the Right Bank north of the Ile de la Cite would have been flattened to make way for a phalanx of 18 megastructures. Equally, Haussmann's insistence on formal coherence and visual solidity are a reproach to the late-modernist chaos of La Defense, the cluster of garish office towers that started rising during the 1970's beyond the western terminus of the Champs-Elysees. And President Francois Mitterrand's "grands projets," the most formidable architectural undertaking in Paris since Haussmann, have produced very little that seems likely to withstand the test of time as well as Haussmann's constructions.
 In sheer determination and ability to bring ideas to reality, Haussmann's truest heir was Robert Moses, the longtime New York public works chief. The two master builders were alike in their prodigious administrative capacities, their grasp of popular taste, their understanding of finance and its relation to government, and their willingness to let the private sector profit greatly from public works.
 Nor could either of them fathom why the public did not appreciate the logic behind his most extreme forays, which in both cases exacted high human costs. Haussmann uprooted the Latin Quarter to build the Boulevard St.-Michel in the 1850's, just as in the 1950's Moses wrecked the East Tremont section of the Bronx to make way for the Cross Bronx Expressway, the sunken highway that set up a more unbreachable boundary than even the widest of Haussmann's boulevards. For all the admirable contributions those planners made to the cities they served, respect for democratic procedures was never their strong suit.
 In retrospect, the uncomfortable conclusion appears to be that these incomparable architectural activists cared little about the suffering of a single generation if they thought that future generations stood to benefit. Perhaps that is inevitable among those who begin with great visions and then work down to individuals, rather than seeing the basic unit of a city's greatness in its people, not its monuments.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 38; Column 2; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Globalism and Us

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is disconcerting when a reviewer uses his allotted space as a forum for propounding his own idiosyncratic notions. In his eagerness to argue that the emerging global economy doesn't have much impact on Americans (an idea that contradicts evidence showing that 70 percent of America's manufacturing base and most of its business services are now exposed to foreign competition), the economics journalist Robert J. Samuelson barely deals with the book under review. That book is mine -- "The Work of Nations: Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism" (March 10), which examines the social and political consequences of the global forces now acting upon us.
In the one place where Mr. Samuelson does attempt to test his odd idea that globalism doesn't matter -- using his own job as a columnist at Newsweek as an example -- he blunders badly. "If . . . I'm ever fired, I'll be pounding the doors of other American publications," he writes, as evidence of his apparent insulation from the global economy.
But Mr. Samuelson will be walking the streets for a long time if he limits his job search to American publications. I'd recommend that he consider a job with France's Hachette S.A. (which publishes Woman's Day, along with a number of other popular magazines), or Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based News Corporation (TV Guide, HarperCollins, etc.), or perhaps Germany's Bertelsmann media empire (owners of Bantam Dou bleday Dell). If he has no luck with any of these, Mr. Samuelson might turn to any one of the thousands of foreign-based magazines, newspapers and newsletters that hire legions of Americans to explain to their readers what's happening in the United States. I'd also recommend one of the many foreign-based newsmagazines whose American readership is growing at the expense of newsmagazines like the one that now employs him. (I, for one, don't get my economics news from Newsweek. I rely on The Economist -- published in London.) Or he may want to consider a job with Time magazine, now part of the Time Warner global media conglomerate. Unbeknown to him, Mr. Samuelson has indeed become a participant in the new global economy -- exactly the sort of person I have written about -- whose job depends to an ever greater extent on what happens outside the United States.
But I sincerely hope that Mr. Samuelson is not fired. He is an able journalist, even if mistaken in disputing the global dimensions of the new economy.
 
ROBERT B. REICH
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL ACCOUNT;
Japanese Enlightenment

BYLINE: By SAMA KUSUMOTO; Sam Kusumoto is president of Minolta Corporation, the American subsidiary of Japan's Minolta Camera Corporation. His book, "My Bridge to America," was recently published in Japan.

 BODY:
I vividly recall my flight into New York in 1954, at age 26, as Minolta's first representative in the United States. Night was falling, and I could see a bluish glow spreading over the city from its neon heart, Times Square. It was a stark contrast to my Japanese homeland, which was still so poor that, even in Tokyo, electricity was rationed and lights burned feebly for only a few hours each night. Tokyo's prewar commercial center, the Ginza, was only then beginning to recover from the devastation of World War II.
 I find myself remembering that night whenever I hear Americans decry Japan's economic "invasion" of the United States. My experience suggests that, financial motivations notwithstanding, the Japanese interest in things American is much more complex than many people in the United States might suspect.
 Shortly after the war, I had the humbling experience of walking through the Ginza. Sidewalk peddlers had replaced the famous, now bombed-out, stores. And American military police, filling in for destroyed traffic lights, directed the flow of cars from a raised platform in the center of the main intersection.
 The tall, handsome and healthy GI's, wearing crisp olive uniforms with brilliant white helmets, took turns directing traffic with choreographic flair. Young Japanese women admired the style and authority of those Americans, then cast sidelong glances at underfed Japanese men like me, who waited to cross the street with bowed heads and shabby clothes, jealous of the Americans, knowing we could not compete. The seeds of Japan's postwar recovery may have been sown there in the Ginza in 1946.
 America's generosity ran far deeper than gifts of nylon stockings to the young women. During the six-and-a-half years following Japan's surrender, the economic help and political liberalization the United States provided under Gen. Douglas MacArthur's rule enabled my country to revive its economy, and the confidence that our ill-advised war had shattered.
 Minolta, where I went to work not long out of Keio University, benefited from MacArthur's determination to rebuild domestic industries - and, in the case of camera manufacturers, the general's desire to give his soldiers something to spend money on besides booze, gambling and skirt-chasing. In effect, our sales to the military post exchanges were our first "exports."
 Growing up in the late 1920's and early 30's in what was then the Japanese city of Korea, I developed a great admiration for America. My father, the Ford Motor Company's distributor for the entire colony, was known as "the Henry Ford of Korea."
 When I was sent to the United States in the '50's, my mandate was to expand Minolta's sales to the world's richest customer market. And, as I made my way in New York, I struck up friendships with other young Japanese men here on similar missions from other Tokyo- and Osaka-based employers. We didn't have much money and we whiled away many an evening in the Times Square area. I marveled at the block-long Bond clothing store sign with its flowing waterfall flanked by giant statues of a man and a woman, the replica of a T.W.A. airliner with wings outstretched over Seventh Avenue, and my favorite, the Camel cigarette sign with a man blowing smoke rings.
 Times Square had begun to go dark by the time I was sent back to the United States to be president of the marketing subsidiary in 1969. Broadway's fading lights were symptomatic of the deterioration of New York City in those years; by the 1970's, the night sky over Tokyo was brighter than New York's. The story of what happened next may illuminate, if you will, the controversy surrounding recent Japanese investment in America.
 In my conversations with other Japanese businessmen in New York, I discovered that many of us shared similar career paths and a nostalgic attachment to Manhattan. We struck a gentlemen's agreement to relight Times Square.
 We considered giant neon signs a good advertising medium and believed Times Square to be perhaps the best location in the United States. Our companies were doing well, thanks to the openness of the American market and the buying power of American consumers; what better way to symbolize our achievements in that market than to revive one of its vernacular art forms.
 Sony was first, with its giant sign at the south end of the square in 1972. Fuji, TDK and others followed. There were more than a dozen Japanese companies represented at Times Square by the time Minolta, in 1983, secured the northern facade of 1 Times Square Plaza.
 Since 1907, this building, which once housed the New York Times, has been the site of the annual dropping of the giant ball at midnight on New Year's Eve. Our sign's Broadway premiere was, up to then, the only time other than New Year's Eve that the ball had been lowered from the tower. One magazine headline announced, "Japanese Invade Times Square," and a newspaper attacked us for "commercializing" the New Year's Eve tradition.
 It wasn't as if we were driving the Americans out. The American advertisers had largely deserted Times Square. In fact, following the Japanese "invasion," American firms like Pepsi, Kodak and others - including Camel cigarettes - returned to Times Square with dazzling signs.
 I think about that when I read the headlines about the "invading" Japanese. American investment has benefited the economies of many countries. As the United States now wrestles with a recession, I hope more Americans will welcome investments that foster growth. I've learned from experience that foreign investments can help to keep the lights burning. Not just im Times Square and the Ginza, but all around the world.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kusumoto in Times Square (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2016 words

HEADLINE: Jersey's 'Gold Coast' Losing Its Glitter

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE New Jersey shore of the Hudson River, which emerged in the mid-80's as a powerful new magnet for high-rise office development, is struggling with high vacancy rates, canceled projects and nagging doubts about the capacity of its roads, parking and public transportation.
No area better symbolized the 80's real estate boom in the New York region. An 18-mile corridor of gritty piers, derelict warehouses and abandoned railroad yards, the New Jersey riverfront became a patchwork of huge development sites. 
 It also became the focus of a feisty battle for New York City tenants and the centerpiece of an urban renaissance so sweeping that some began calling the area the "Gold Coast" of New Jersey.
For now, the renaissance has slowed. With 15 million square feet of space -- more than half of it built in the last five years -- developers on the New Jersey shore are beset by the highest vacancy rates in the New York area.
"When the Manhattan market became soft, it really hurt the New Jersey waterfront," said Peter Eppie, managing director of Edward S. Gordon Company of New Jersey, a commercial brokerage, based in Jersey City. In an analysis this month, it found office vacancies in New Jersey's Hudson River cities running at more than 30 percent, nearly double those in Manhattan.
With such large blocks of offices to be filled, an even bigger vision for the waterfront is being put on hold.
"I like to think of it as a glass that is only a third full," said Herman Volk, director of the Governor's Waterfront Development Office, established in 1984 to promote and coordinate the development plans of Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken and other cities swept up in the boom. In all, he said plans have been laid for more than 20 million square feet of new offices in the area.
"The question now is how much of that planning becomes reality," Mr. Volk said. "The first order of business now is to fill up existing space."
While office developers are struggling, others who plan to remake the sparsely populated waterfront area into a major new center of luxury housing have also been mired in financial setbacks and delays. By 1987, more than a half dozen large residential communities were planned from southern Jersey City to the George Washington Bridge, including 16,000 new town houses and apartments.
SO far, only 3,600 have been built, according to an analysis by the Governor's Waterfront Development Office.
One troubled residential project is Port Liberte, a development that may ultimately include 1,690 town houses and apartments on a series of shorefront canals in Jersey City, just west of the Statue of Liberty. With only 300 of the homes completed, the project's developer, Paul W. Bucha, president of Port Liberte Partners of Jersey City, ran into severe financial trouble in 1989 and stopped building. One of his major lenders, CityFed Financial Corporation of Somerset, N.J., attributed a loss of $52.7 million to its bad loans to Port Liberte, and its assets were later seized by Federal regulators.
Now, despite widespread reports that Asian investors stand ready to take over the Port Liberte project, its fate is in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency charged with rescuing the nation's failed thrift institutions.
For home builders and office developers alike, the immediate problem is something far from unique to the Hudson riverfront -- the economics of a deep real estate recession. Since most of the office developers in the area have designed their buildings to appeal to banks, securities firms and other financial-services companies in Manhattan, they are now trying to sell to companies that are eliminating workers and shedding office space.
They are also competing with Manhattan office buildings that can no longer command the lofty prices of the mid-80's. Surveys show that the price of new office space along the New Jersey shore is now running at an average of $22 to $23 a square foot, nearly $10 less than in new Manhattan buildings but no more than is being asked in older buildings in the Wall Street area and on Midtown Manhattan side streets.
Some real estate executives say the slump could be a short one. Because taxes and energy costs are lower in New Jersey than in New York City and because of the riverfront's sweeping views and access to two separate lines of the PATH railroad system into Manhattan, they maintain that the development boom is bound to resume.
"Our feeling is that these buildings on the New Jersey shore stand to gain more when things come back," said Rose Perrizo, senior vice president of Landauer Associates, a real estate consulting firm based in Manhattan.
With large undeveloped sites still available, and intensely competitive efforts to attract corporate tenants by builders and some municipalities along the Hudson River waterfront, she said, high-technology office buildings will be available at bargain rents, at least compared to Manhattan.
Nor has the real estate downturn brought an end to the trans-Hudson migration of Manhattan companies.
In the largest recent New Jersey coup, Merrill Lynch, the securities firm, has leased half of 101 Hudson Street, a 43-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office tower nearing completion next to the Exchange Place complex in Jersey City.
"We found this the most appropriate site, both from a financial and functional point of view," said Fred Yaeger, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch, which plans to move 2,500 data processors to the new building by the end of 1992. He added that the company will save $100 million over the first five years of its Jersey City lease, compared to what it would have cost to renew its current lease at One Liberty Plaza in lower Manhattan.
The Exchange Place area, directly across the Hudson from the World Trade Center, is so far the most heavily developed office section on the New Jersey riverfront. A key advantage, analysts say, is its access to a newly renovated Exchange Place station of the PATH system. That makes offices in the area an easy commute from lower Manhattan and several New Jersey cities.
Harborside, a 1.9 million-square-foot complex completed next to the Exchange Place station in 1989, is 80 percent leased with large tenants, among them Bankers Trust Company and the Bank of Tokyo. Exchange Place Center, a neighboring high rise with 700,000 square feet, is 85 percent leased and anchored by the National Westminster Bank of New Jersey.
The shoreside development surge, still in its infancy, has felt serious growing pains. In Jersey City, despite its access to the PATH system, automobile traffic has become a daily nightmare for thousands of workers trying to wind their way along side streets leading to the waterfront from the New Jersey Turnpike.
"Infrastructure improvements, including transportation, have not kept pace with the rapid development," said a report by the Jersey City Planning Department in 1989.
For those who cannot ride PATH or other public transporation to work, commuting has become "particularly difficult, if not impossible," the report added.
Little has been done since 1989 in Jersey City or other riverfront municipalities to increase public transportation, but plans have been laid.
Congress last year appropriated $20 million for public transporation in the area. The Governor's Waterfront Transportation Office, established in 1987, said the money would be used to improve bus service along a seven-mile stretch of waterfront where most office buildings have been built or are planned, from southern Jersey City to Weehawken.
A more ambitious plan, advocated by municipal officials and developers for years, is for a new, above-ground rail line connecting the waterfront communities and new developments. But that plan, like the those of several office developers, is now on hold.
"Some sort of light rail system is very much favored by citizens here, but financing it will be a major hurdle," said Martin Robins, director of the Waterfront Office. He estimated that the rail line would cost $250 million to $500 million.
Some proposed developments are being stalled by public opposition. In Hoboken, an on-again, off-again plan to develop idle riverfront land and piers that are owned by the city and leased to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was sent back to the drawing boards in October. The plan, involving a huge development of 1.3 million square feet of offices, hundreds of condominiums, a hotel and a marina, was defeated by only four votes in a municipal referendum. Now, Hoboken and Port Authority officials say they are preparing a plan for a smaller development.
In another stalled Hoboken development, the Stevens Institute of Techology, whose 55-acre campus overlooks the Hudson from atop the Palisades, abandoned a plan for 540,000 square feet of new offices a year ago. The offices were to have been built on land the institute owns below the Palisades, with two 12-story buildings starting from its base and rising above it, and was fiercely opposed by environmentalists and others in Hoboken.
IN a new plan, Stevens now says it is looking for investors in a "technology pavilion" that would be built on its campus to attract the research and development operations of large corporations.
"We decided that our business is technology, not real estate development," said Harold J. Raveche, the Stevens president. Nonetheless, he added, the region's real estate slump and waterfront traffic problems are standing in the way of a major resurgence of office construction.
"If we solve our transportation and parking problem, we have a boom town," he said.
Elsewhere along the New Jersey riverfront, office developers are either postponing their plans or struggling to find tenants.
Perhaps hardest hit by the downturn has been the Newport Office Tower, a 36- story, million-square-foot office tower in the 270-acre Newport complex in northern Jersey City, which also includes five residential towers and a major shopping mall. More than half the building was to have been leased by The Limited, a clothing store chain based in Manhattan, but it backed out after construction began last spring.
The building, to be completed in August, now has no tenants.
"We have several major proposals," said Edwin H. Cohen, executive vice president of William A. White/Grubb & Ellis, a brokerage that is marketing the building. He added that two large companies, one a financial services company in Manhattan, may soon sign leases, each for over 100,000 square feet.
Plans for another large Jersey City office tower were dropped last year, when the Vector Real Estate Corporation of Manhattan decided not to build the Liberty Center, a 980,000-square-foot building that was to have been built two blocks west of Exchange Place. Vector let its site plan, which had been approved by Jersey City officials, expire.
SOME analysts say the slowdown in development may ultimately benefit the Hudson River waterfront cities.
"Now is the time for planning," said Richard Bass, the former planning director of Jersey City who resigned in 1989 to become deputy director for land use planning in the office of Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger.
Because of the frenetic pace of proposals and construction over the last five years, he said, it was all but inevitable that the long-term impact on parking, traffic and other parts of the waterfront would fail to receive proper attention.
"When you start to impose New York City scale development on a small-town planning mentality, it is bound to lead to problems," he said.
At the Governor's Waterfront Transportation Office, Mr. Robins said a slower pace of development for as long as four years might benefit the area.
"The waterfront is going to grow over a period of many years, and this may be the time to fill in gaps, to unify the area," he said.
"I hope we use the time well," he added. "If development moves more slowly until the middle of the 90's, we can lay a good foundation for it."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:

Rent-Rise Exemptions
 
Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and would like to know about the rent-increase exemption program for senior citizens. Where can I get information? . . . Claire D. Taylor, Floral Park, Queens 1
 
Answer: Call the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Department's rent-exemption office at 240-7000. Some Nassau and Westchester municipalities also offer exemptions to their residents. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal provides information on those programs at (516) 481-9494 and (914) 948-4434. Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the division, said regulated localities grant full or partial exemptions from rent increases to tenants 62 years of age or older who meet varying local income limits. In New York City, the limit is $15,000, but certain expenses can be excluded. Landlords are compensated for the lost rent through reductions in their tax bills.
 
Co-op Rental Liability
 
Question: The owner of the co-op we rent told us when we moved in that the air-conditioner was not installed, but instead balanced on the windowsill. When an unaware guest raised the window, the air-conditioner crashed to the ground. Luckily, no one was injured. Now the landlord says he will deduct its price from our security deposit. We believe he was negligent. Are we responsible? . . . Lynn O'Kelley, Manhattan
 
Answer: Probably not. Michael R. Finder, a housing lawyer in Manhattan, said both sides were negligent, but standard leases generally hold landlords responsible for maintaining major appliances. You could sue in Small Claims Court to recover any withheld security money. Vahe Tiryakian, spokesman for the New York City Buildings Department, said the Building Code in general requires owners to maintain safe buildings. Specifically, Local Law 10, the facade safety law, requires owners of buildings over six stories to have the exterior walls and appurtenances -- including air-conditioners -- inspected every five years.
 
Co-op Tax Deductions
 
Question: What determines tax deductions on co-ops? Do all apartments in a building, regardless of size, have the same deduction? Can the deduction change? If so, what would cause that? . . . L. Landis, Manhattan
 
Answer: In nearly all co-ps, the co-op corporation may allocate to each owner-resident a proportionate share of what it pays each year for local property taxes and interest on the building's mortgage. Residents may then deduct their shares of the building's payout from their taxable income along with whatever interest they pay on their own apartment mortgages.
The size of the shares is determined by the size and location of the apartments. Larger apartments and those on higher floors usually pay more in maintenance charges each month and consequently they get larger income tax deduction shares. The shares are fixed, but the taxes paid by the building may change annually because of changing assessments and tax rates. The mortgage interest is more stable but also may change if the rate is adjustable or if the loan is refinanced.
Mark B. Shernicoff, a Manhattan accountant and treasurer of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said co-op managements notify stockholders of their allowable deductions early each year so they may meet the April 15 income-tax deadline. He said deductibility is often expressed as a percentage of the maintenance fee. Or it may be given as a dollar amount for each share of the corporation's stock held by an owner.
Homeowners, including co-op owners, may claim deductions for only two residences, Mr. Shernicoff said.

HEADLINE: Legislators Gird for a Marathon of Tax Talk

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
ON Tuesday, the public speaks. Those who think that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan for a 6 percent income tax will help solve the state's financial woes -- and those who don't -- can take a number and line up.
For one day only, members of the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee will conduct a public hearing to allow formal comment by all comers. The testimony will be entered into the record and presumably will be given due consideration in the final tax plan that emerges from the committee next month. Committee members are already bracing themselves for a marathon. 
 "We presume that we will have the mother of all hearings," said State Representative Miles S. Rapoport, a Democrat from West Hartford and a member of the Finance Committee. Mr. Rapoport, a longtime supporter of the concept of a tax on income, proposed an alternative wage tax formula last week, saying he hoped it would draw rave reviews at the hearing and supplant Mr. Weicker's proposal.
The Rapoport plan, co-sponsored by two other members of the committee, would tax wages on a sliding progressive rate that would range from 4 percent for adjusted gross family income over $25,000 to 9 percent for families earning $150,000 or more. Mr. Rapoport said that his plan would spare some middle-income taxpayers from the abrupt increase that they would face under the Weicker proposal. The Governor's proposed tax rate of 6 percent would apply to all family income over $25,000, or $12,500 for an individual.
There are other tax plans and other agendas. But people across the political spectrum agree that the Finance's Committee's work this year could mark a turning point for Connecticut, and that Tuesday's hearing will be a rare opportunity for people outside the political system to be heard.
Governor Weicker, who took office in January, argues that taxes paid by business must be cut to stimulate the economy, and that the long-shunned income tax is the only sound way to allow those tax cuts while making up the huge revenue shortfall in the state's budget caused by the recession.
Opponents of the income tax say it would open the door to unrestrained spending growth by the legislature, that it would make Connecticut less attractive for highly paid executives and artists who have moved to the state over the years, and that it would throw away forever an element of the culture that separates the state from its neighbors. Connecticut is one of only 10 states with no broad-based tax on wages.
Between those two poles lie a vast array of compromise plans and subplots, many of which are expected to receive their first public debate when the doors open at 10 A.M. in Room 2-C of the Legislative Office Building.
Governor Weicker's plan would lower the tax rate on corporate profits from 13.8 percent to 11.5 percent and lower the state sales-tax rate from 8 percent to 4.25 percent. (But it would increase the number of taxable transactions to include gasoline purchases, haircuts and automobile repairs.) Taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains would be eliminated, with all income to be taxed at the flat 6 percent rate for adjusted gross income over $25,000 for a family and $12,500 for an individual.
In addition to the Governor's plan, the most attention is expected to be focused on proposals from the Finance Committee and from Mr. Rapoport and his supporters. The committee's proposal would avoid an income tax and keep the sales tax at 8 percent, but the sales tax would be expanded to include various new purchases. Among the list of potential new targets for the sales tax -- in addition to the items like gasoline that are also in the Weicker plan -- are home utilities like electricity, water, natural gas and heating oil, plus legal, accounting and transportation services. All would be subject to the 8 percent tax.
The committee plan -- which has not been endorsed by any of its members, who said they were offering it primarily for discussion purposes at the hearing -- would leave most of the state's other taxes as they are and would result in up to $300 million in new taxes for businesses. Mr. Weicker has already said that figure is intolerable and would provoke a veto.
The Governor has said that he does not necessarily want an income tax, but that he would send back any alternative that does not achieve the same result: cuts in taxes to business without resorting to short-term solutions or excessive borrowing.
The plan known as the Progressive Alternative has been proposed by Mr. Rapoport along with two other Finance Committee members, Geri W. Langlois, a Democrat from Thompson, and Ernest E. Newton 2d, a Democrat from Bridgeport. Their proposal would lower the sales tax to 4.75 percent over two years, and create a $250 million system of property tax credits that would be paid directly to taxpayers.
 
Restoring Funds to Budget
 Mainly because the sales tax would not be reduced as much under the Rapoport plan as under Mr. Weicker's, the package would raise enough money to maintain the current sales tax exemptions for gasoline, clothing that costs under $75 and car repairs. It would also allow for $285 million to be restored in spending for unspecified "critical" programs that were cut in Mr. Weicker's budget.
What may not be discussed at the hearing is an alternative plan being formulated by the General Assembly's Republicans, who are the minority party in both chambers. On March 14, the vice-chairman of the Finance Committee, State Senator James H. Maloney, a Democrat from Danbury, appealed to the Republicans to have their plan finished in time for Tuesday's hearing.
Mr. Maloney said that presenting the Republican plan with the other options would send a message that the Republicans were serious about having their plan considered as a genuine bipartisan proposal.
Republican leaders have already said that their plan will contain no income tax and will feature some constitutional or statutory cap on state spending. But the ranking minority Senator on the committee, William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich, said last week that his party's plan would be revealed when it was ready and not before. He said the details would not be completed until at least April, long after the period for public comment has ended.
Mr. Nickerson said the Democrats were simply trying, as usual, to tell the Republicans what to do.
