LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Suburban Office Development;
Overbuilding Leaves Huge Legacy of Empty Space

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
VACANCY rates of 25 percent or more are being recorded in many smaller office markets around New York City, where the accelerated pace of development during the 1980's is having much the same debilitating effect as in Manhattan.
For example, the latest report by the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage shows no office buildings under construction in any of the major Fairfield County markets. 
 "That has never happened before," said Michael H. Siegel, executive managing director of the northeast region for Cushman & Wakefield. "That, in itself, is probably one of the most striking items of what is actually going on in the market. I think every developer is faced with very difficult times."
In some measure, as in New York City, the troubles have been self-inflicted.
"Three or four years ago, a bunch of people thought Shelton was going to be the next hot spot in Fairfield County and stuck up a lot of buildings," said Richard Gretsch Jr., senior vice president of the Albert B. Ashforth commercial brokerage, whose office is in Stamford, Conn. "As a consequence, the vacancy rate has been well above 25 percent.
"I guess it was people's feeling that if you put up buildings, it would change the demand. It doesn't work that way."
"Office space was doubled in New Haven in the 1980's, hence the indigestion now," said Larry Hall, of Cavanagh, Fritz & Company, leasing agents for the new 27-story Connecticut Financial Center in New Haven.
From New Jersey came much the same story. "The excess has been built within the last 24 months," said Robert J. Rudin, executive director of the Edward S. Gordon Company of New Jersey, based in Saddle Brook, "and, if you look at the New Jersey market as a whole, more than 50 percent of the space has been built in the last 10 years.
"That says that we really built our oversupply, that the economic malaise has not caused the problem. What caused the problem was that we thought the region was going to expand at the same rate forever. It was that premise that led to overbuilding."
Year-end figures compiled by Cushman & Wakefield show vacancy rates as high as 35.8 percent in New Haven's central business district, 29.9 percent along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront (Jersey City, Hoboken and Weehawken), 25.4 percent in eastern Fairfield County (Bridgeport, Shelton, Stratford and Trumbull) and 25.3 percent in both central Nassau County (Mitchel Field, Garden City, Mineola, Westbury) and in Morris County (including Parsippany).
Using different methods, the Gordon Company found a vacancy rate greater than 30 percent on the New Jersey waterfront.
These stood well above Manhattan at year's end, where the rates were 17.2 percent in midtown, 16.1 percent downtown.
Vacancy numbers can be misleading in smaller markets, which may be dramatically affected by one or two projects.
About vacancies on the waterfront, Donald Eisen, the branch manager of Cushman & Wakefield's New Jersey offices, noted "two very large buildings coming onto the market at once" -- 101 Hudson Street and the Newport Office Tower, both in Jersey City.
As another example, downtown New Haven has 1.9 million square feet of primary office space, contrasted with 169.6 million square feet in mid-Manhattan.
Much of its high vacancy rate can be ascribed to the 500,000-square-foot Connecticut Financial Center on Church Street, developed by Chase Enterprises of Hartford.
Cushman & Wakefield noted that a pending lease with United Illuminating for 200,000 square feet should bring the whole city's rate "down to a more reasonable level."
"Although it is a soft market -- no question about it -- it is not nearly as bleak as the Cushman & Wakefield numbers would indicate," Mr. Hall, the leasing agent, said.
About the United Illuminating deal, he said, "We're within weeks of a final lease signing, so that's virtually a done deal." He said 60 percent of the building was leased or, as in the case of the utility, "committed."
The Rostenberg-Doern Company, a real-estate concern that operates in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, uses different standards for the office buildings it surveys and draws different boundaries for the areas it describes. The rates it compiled are uniformly higher than Cushman & Wakefield's, ranging from 13.7 percent for southern Westchester to 37.5 percent for eastern Fairfield.
"On the good side," said John H. Rostenberg, "our absorption figures have gone to 1.5 million square feet for the Westchester-Fairfield region. The area from Tarrytown along I-287 to Rye, and the area from Greenwich to Norwalk have been very active during 1990 and continue to be the location of choice."
PERHAPS the most dramatic contrast in adjacent markets is between central Nassau County, with 25.3 percent, and eastern Nassau, with 9.2 percent.
"Eastern Nassau -- Woodbury, Plainview -- is a more stable market," said Joseph A. Lagano, managing director of Cushman & Wakefield and branch manager of its Long Island office. "It's a desirable area that's centrally located, with great access to parkways, it has larger-sized tenants and there hasn't been any major new construction to speak of. There was not a lot of land available for new construction."
In contrast, he said, central Nassau has seen the addition of the 240,000-square-foot Garden City Center and the 550,000-square-foot Nassau West Omni at Mitchel Field, which inflated the vacancy rate.
That is also the case in eastern Fairfield County, where there was a "tremendous upsurge in new construction," Mr. Siegel said.
"WHEN Stamford and Greenwich were tight in terms of new space and it was going in the strong mid-$30's," he said, "you might find competing space further east in the mid-$20's."
One of the big projects contributing to the high overall vacancy rates is a new 160,000-square-foot building at the Merritt Eight Corporate Park, at the junction of the Merritt Parkway and Route 8, developed by Hillman Properties of Pittsburgh.
It is now only 55 percent leased but John Markey, the vice president of development for Hillman Properties, said, "We're finding that the market has improved significantly in the last six weeks."
Mr. Gretsch, the broker, took the long view. "I've been doing this for 18 years," he said, "and I've seen five cycles. This one hurt people a little more because there were eight years of up. And they forgot."

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1720 words

HEADLINE: State Feels New Strains as Population Shifts

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS the state's population shifts from the densely packed cities of the northeast to the rolling rural landscapes of central and southern New Jersey, political scientists say the trend toward suburbanization is creating a new set of challenges for residents, employers and many state and local officials.
 With companies continuing their gradual relocation from urban business districts to sprawling suburban office parks, experts say, residents left behind in the inner cities are finding it more and more difficult to get jobs, particularly ones accessible by public transportation. 
 State officials are now at work on a long-range plan for coping with the new population patterns. But some rural communities are already experiencing growing pains, as new residents strain the capacity of municipal services and public school systems. And for those who have fled the crowded cities for the quiet of the countryside, an unwelcome surprise often awaits them: weekend traffic jams on rural roads never meant to accommodate carloads of shoppers heading toward suburban malls and highway shopping strips. "These are several of the new realities that we now have to face," said Dr. James W. Hughes, a professor at the Graduate School of Urban Planning and Policy at Rutgers-New Brunswick.
"The 1980's was the strongest decade of economic growth that the state has ever seen," Dr. Hughes said. "And during the 1980's New Jersey experienced the greatest wave of economic decentralization in its history."
Following the major highways that crisscross the the state, and responding to the lure of affordable land and lower property taxes, businesses that grew during the boom years of the last decade often directed that growth into less expensive rural environs, Dr. Hughes said.
Rather than take over a new floor in an office building in Newark, for instance, a company might instead erect a new building of its own on one of the "growth corridors" along Interstate 78 or Interstate 287. Any new jobs created by the expansion, Dr. Hughes said, could then be easily filled with skilled, educated suburbanites. As a result, he said, both businesses and residents benefited from increasing suburban sprawl.
And whether the jobs followed the people or the people followed the jobs, he said, the end result was inevitable: more traffic, more congestion, more pollution and less open space.
"We no longer have rush hours in New Jersey anymore," Dr. Hughes said. "We have rush mornings and rush evenings, punctuated by lunch-time congestions. We are probably never going back to a congestion-free environment."
Indeed, the results of the 1990 Census of Population and Housing indicate a clear shifting of the population from densely populated counties in northeastern New Jersey, like Bergen, Hudson and Essex, to central and southern counties, like Hunterdon, Somerset, Middlesex, Ocean and Atlantic. In fact, the total population of Bergen, Hudson and Essex Counties declined by nearly 100,000 residents over the last 10 years. At least half that number, a little more than 54,000, is accounted for by a 16.4 percent decline in Newark, the state's most populous city.
Most other large cities, like Jersey City, Paterson, Elizabeth and Camden, managed to post modest population gains of 2 or 3 percent. But far more remarkable, experts say, are the huge growth rates for some of the rural municipalities.
 Galloway Township in Atlantic County, for instance, almost doubled, growing to 23,330 in 1990 from 12,176 in 1980. Voorhees Township in Camden County also nearly doubled, with population figures almost identical to Galloway's. And Plainsboro Township in Middlesex County almost tripled its population, growing to 14,213 residents by 1990, from 5,605 in 1980.
But there is a price to be paid for such growth, Dr. Hughes said. "By decentralizing population, we have also decentralized congestion," he said. "What were once pristine county roads are now packed with cars full of shoppers."
While suburban sprawl is causing traffic problems in formerly rural communities, it is causing problems of a different sort in the cities it leaves behind.
"All kinds of jobs are disappearing from the cities," said Richard W. Roper, executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University. "White-collar jobs, blue-collar jobs, manufacturing jobs and secretarial jobs are all moving from the central cities to the outlying areas."
 
'Locked Out' of Newer Jobs
 As a result, Mr. Roper said, "it means that people who live in the cities will be locked out of many of the newer jobs that have been created over the past 10 years."
The reason, he said, is that such people have no way to get from their homes in the cities to the jobs in the suburbs.
"The public transportation that's available to them just doesn't go to the outlying areas," Mr. Roper said.
Rose Sheridan, a spokeswoman for N. J. Transit, the state's public transportation agency, agreed.
"There are two parts to the problem," Ms. Sheridan said. "One is getting people from the cities to the suburbs, and the other is getting people from the suburbs to the suburbs."
The impediment to solving either or both, she said, is the difficulty of providing public transportation to many different locations spread over a large area. Public transportation, she said, is most effective in taking people to central points: from the suburbs into the cities.
"We expect that New Jersey is going to have to look at nontraditional mass transit to provide service to the suburbs," she said.
 
Forming Car and Van Pools
 Examples of nontraditional mass transit can be found among the state's six "transportation management associations," which are not-for-profit corporations that provide computer-assisted car-pool and van-pool arrangements.
One such company, Morris County Rides Inc. in Parsippany, was founded in 1986 and now operates 163 vans. It has formed almost 600 car pools for people who must commute to areas not served by traditional mass transit.
Treva J. Jones, an administrative assistant and secretary for the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, asked Morris County Rides for help in setting up a van pool when her employer relocated to an office park in Parsippany 18 months ago. Ms. Jones and 14 other so-called reverse commuters leave from Newark's Pennsylvania Station and from stops in Orange and East Orange for their 45-minute ride to work.
Without the pool, Ms. Jones said, some members might find it difficult, if not impossible, to get to their jobs. "That's exactly why we started the service," she said. "There is no other means of public transportation."
 
Feeling Effects of Growth
 The only other alternative, it seems, and one that has been chosen by tens of thousands of New Jersey residents over the last decade, is to move away from the cities and closer to the jobs. But this solution has created some strain on the municipalities into which they are moving.
Evesham Township in Burlington County, for example, has grown to 35,309 residents in 1990 from 21,508 in 1980, an increase of 64.2 percent.
"We're in the Route 73 growth corridor, which is probably the second most active growth corridor in the state," said Burton T. Conway, the Township Manager. "We were putting up about 1,200 new housing units a year. But we've been doing quite a bit in the last five years to stem the tide."
Mr. Conway said township officials were now involved in a "growth control program."
"We passed a $10 million bond ordinance in 1987, and we've been buying open space away from developers," he said.
Mr. Conway said that since 1983, as a result of the increase in population, the township has had to add 10 police officers and increase the number of paid firefighters in its largely volunteer fire department to 14 from 2.
 
A Second School Rejected
 In addition, he said, the township had to build a new elementary school, and last year officials attempted, unsuccessfully, to get voter approval to build a second middle school.
 The municipal budget, he said, which was $5 million in 1983, has risen to $12 million in 1991.
"The tax rate is still relatively low because of all the new ratables," Mr. Conway said, referring to the thousands of new houses and condominiums built in Evesham Township over the last 10 years. Just about each new person who moves in, he said, essentially brings a new ratable to the tax rolls. But that, he said, is not going to last forever.
"This is the first year we haven't had an extremely high ratable growth, and we're beginning to see it in our tax situation already," Mr. Conway said.
"What happens when we're no longer adding ratables, but adding families?" he said. "Once the growth stops, how do we prevent ourselves from being another Camden 20 or 30 years from now?"
 
Drafting a Statewide Plan
 One way, said Martin Bierbaum, assistant director of the Office of State Planning, is to have a statewide development plan in place that encourages growth where there is an existing infrastructure, in cities like Camden and Newark, and to better manage whatever growth inevitably occurs in outlying areas.
To that end, Mr. Bierbaum said, his office is now in the process of drafting a comprehensive 20-year plan for future development in the state, as required by the State Planning Act of 1986. An interim report will be released in the late spring, he said. After hearings and the opportunity for written comment from the counties and municipalities, a final plan is expected to be issued a year from now.
The 1986 act established a 17-member commission to coordinate joint efforts by the state, county and municipal governments in developing a plan that "would see to it that we can provide housing at reasonable cost, protect the environment, retain farm land and rebuild the cities," Mr. Bierbaum said.
"The commission believes that growing in the ways we've grown have been too costly," he said. "In terms of job skills and employment opportunities, you've got the economy growing in one place and stagnating in another.
"And there's a real concern when a society builds a city and then 25 or 30 years later, it's abandoning that one to build one completely new. That just doesn't seem to make much sense."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
WELDED shut long ago, the door to apartment 8C in Building 5 at the Stella Wright housing project in Newark was now glowing red under the heat of an acetylene torch. A few feet away, Gregory P. Sanders waited, wondering what he would find when he and a crew of other housing-project tenants went inside to clean up and reclaim the abandoned apartment.
After a minute and a half, two minutes at the most, the welder, Morris Cirlincione, turned down the torch flame and, with his back to the door, gave it a loud, swift kick. "If there are any pigeons inside, the noise scares them out," Mr. Sanders said. "Otherwise, they come straight out at you." 
 For eight months now, Mr. Sanders, a crew chief, has been part of a team of public housing tenants working on a novel experiment that is being watched from all over the country. Venturing to mix economic advantage with the social-policy buzzword "empowerment," the Newark Tenants Council, which represents residents of public housing all over the city, has been given a yearlong $200,000 contract to clean up hundreds of vacant apartments in the projects so they can be rented again to Newark families.
The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which authorized the apartment-cleaning contract, considers it a model that can be replicated in housing-authority projects around the country. The department is eager for the project to succeed because it has the potential to accomplish so much: rehabilitating the projects and giving the tenants who live in them a stake in their future.
The project, if it works, also has the ability to give back to Mr. Sanders and other residents of the projects the future they thought they had lost.
It is fairly easy to lose the future in the dirt and despair at a housing- project apartment like 8C or any of the hundreds of others in Newark that Mr. Sanders has had to sweep since he began working with the tenants' organization last August.
"They were showing movies in here," he said, stepping over a heap of faded yellow newspapers in the entrance hall. On the floor in the front room of 8C was an old-time movie projector, leaning on three legs. A few feet away was a pornographic magazine. The air was stifling. Someone kicked an oversized plastic eight ball and sent it rolling across the floor.
"This one ain't too bad," said Mr. Sanders, the 24-year-old son of a retired Newark policeman. He wore a Cincinnati Reds baseball cap and, to protect his hands, short-fingered batting gloves. He checked the pigeon droppings on the bathroom sink and bathtub and judged the problem minimal, compared with the foot-deep layers he has found in some apartments.
The kitchen was a mess. Food moldered in the cabinets and a foul smell came from the refrigerator, which no one was willing to open. A burner on the gas stove was still flaming, and the box of baking soda and the dusty tablespoon on the wooden cutting board alongside gave proof that the last thing cooked there was cocaine.
Coke in the kitchen is just the kind of nightmare that makes Mr. Sanders dream so longingly of someday getting out of the projects where he has lived most of his life and moving with his wife, Annette, into their own house -- one with a backyard for their 4-year-old daughter, Nicole, and their baby son, Kahlil.
"That would be one of the greatest things," he said. "I grew up around drugs in the projects. I truly don't want my kids growing up in the same environment."
Mr. Sanders and his family live on the second floor of one of the brooding brick buildings at Hayes Homes, just a few blocks away from Stella Wright and apartment 8C. Until last year he had been doing all right, a high-school graduate working in construction for a small contractor. Then things got slow and the work dried up. He was putting in a few hours a week with the Newark Housing Authority's summer recreation program when he got a call last August saying he could earn $7 an hour with a new project to clean up empty apartments.
He went for an interview on a Monday and started working the next day. "I'm not going to say it's the greatest," he said. "But it's a job, and there are so many guys running around here that don't have jobs."
Although he has come across flocks of dead pigeons, cats wasted to skeletons, car parts, mouse-filled mattresses, a gun and many hypodermic needles, he says there is something about the work that makes it bearable, even worthwhile: knowing that the rooms that had been vacant so long, attracting squatters, addicts and all kinds of abuse, will finally be lived in again.
"You don't know whether the people who move in will be the nasty type person or the clean type," he said, "but I know that at least I've done my part to make things better."
There may be no place in New Jersey that needs improving more than Newark's high-rise housing projects. Three decades old, they had deteriorated so much that the housing authority planned to blow up most of them. Then, two years ago, local groups opposed to the plan won a court settlement to keep some projects, fix others and build new ones to replace every apartment that will be demolished.
So far, the Housing Authority says it has renovated and rented 1,658 apartments, a few more than the settlement called for. It has signed a contract to build 100 new town houses and is working on contracts for 365 more. All eight buildings -- 1,500 apartments -- in the Columbus Homes project in Newark's North Ward are vacant, and the demolition crews are to raze the complex by the end of this year.
Despite the work that has been done, there still are 2,421 abandoned apartments in Newark public high-rises, many of them fused shut long ago by Mr. Cirlincione's welding torch. And there are many people in the projects who, like Mr. Sanders, are waiting and hoping that someday they will be able to live without the smelly elevators and the fearful sounds that always seem to be bouncing off the tiled walls.
Carter Mangan, the supervisor of the tenants' cleanup crew, moved out back in 1975. He now lives in a single-family house in the Weequahic section, the part of Newark with grass and trees that looks a lot like Bergen County.
Mr. Mangan says he sees a younger version of himself in Mr. Sanders and the way he has taken on the responsibilities of crew chief. In this project of rebuilding buildings and restoring hope, such beliefs seem to make the strongest repairs.
"I had been talking about it a long time ago with Carter," Mr. Sanders said. "I wished that things could be better in the projects. They've gone down so bad. It makes you feel good to do this, you know, because it means that at least somebody cares. For a long time, I just thought nobody cared."

HEADLINE: County G.O.P. Sets the Tone Of Its '91 Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
JACK KEMP, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, came to Westchester last week to help county Republican leaders open the 1991 political season. But from the opening moments of Tuesday's fund-raising dinner, it appeared he wasn't needed.
Anthony J. Colavita, the county Republican chairman, set the tone right away, predicting that "this is going to be a great Republican year," with President Bush "showing the world that he is a great leader with great courage and good judgment." 
 Then came the thrust, in the form of another prediction, this one addressed to Nita M. Lowey, the Westchester Democrat who unseated a Republican in 1988 and is now serving her second term in the House of Representatives. "We're going to remember how she voted on the Persian Gulf resolution," Mr. Colavita warned, to the first robust cheer of the evening. "There's going to be an accounting."
 
The Vote to Authorize War
 Mrs. Lowey was one of 179 Democratic Representatives who declined to authorize President Bush to go to war against Iraq in mid-January, preferring to give economic sanctions more time to succeed. A total of 86 Democrats joined 164 Republicans in the House in supporting the President's request to use force. The House vote to enter the war was 250 to 183. The measure passed 52 to 47 in the Senate.
Mr. Kemp, who called for a "new domestic order of freedom and opportunity and help for the helpless," paused near the end of his 20-minute address to make his own comment on those who opposed the Persian Gulf Resolution.
"I know we're not supposed to criticize Democrats for how they voted on the authorization to allow the President to fulfill the mandates given to him by the Security Council of the United Nations," he said, "so instead I will quote Sir Winston Churchill" on the beginnings of World War II.
Sir Winston spoke of "how easily the tragedy of the Second World War could have been prevented," Mr. Kemp said, "how the malice of the wicked was reinforced by the weakness of the virtuous."
 
Mrs. Lowey Responds
 Churchill, Mr. Kemp suggested, "wanted us to see how the councils of prudence and restraint had become the prime agents of mortal danger, how the middle course, adopted from a desire for safety and the quiet life, was bound to lead directly to disaster."
Mrs. Lowey, speaking later from Washington, said she felt that "those who politicize the issue and try to divide the people again are making a great error."
"The country is united and there is a marvelous feeling of confidence," she said.
Mr. Kemp "is very committed to the housing program of this country and is aggressively pursuing an agenda," Mrs. Lowey said. "I'd hope he and Mr. Bush would use that enormous popularity with the same intensity used in focusing on the war.
"The debate on the Persian Gulf resolution was a superb moment, and immediately afterward everyone rallied behind the President."
At the time of the vote, Democrats conceded that a negative vote would be characterized as an expression of appeasement if the war turned out to be short and with relatively few casualties. Republicans feared that a long and costly conflict, like the war in Vietnam, would leave them vulnerable to criticism for an affirmative vote.
Mr. Kemp spoke at the yearly Chairman's Dinner, a fund-raising event and pep rally at the Rye Town Hilton here that drew more than 800 Republicans at $250 each. The Secretary of Housing praised Westchester's leaders and specifically acknowledged the presence of a former Governor, Malcolm W. Wilson, saying, "Oh, that he were Governor today."
He repeatedly jabbed at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, even in a brief chat with reporters who asked whether his department would have a continuing role in the Yonkers housing-desegregation case.
 
'A Viable Alternative'
 "Our party offers the best opportunity that people have had in a long time to have a viable alternative to the politics of envy, the politics of redistributing the wealth, and the politics of higher and higher, ever higher, taxes that has become the keynote of the Democratic Party," Mr. Kemp said.
Speaking of the decision to go to war with Iraq, he said: "When the Governor says he still can't figure out whether or not it was the right decision, you have to question whether or not the national Democratic Party is ready to lead the world into the next century.
"We can only achieve peace and freedom and democracy by keeping our country strong, making sure aggression is not rewarded. And while I never question anyone's conscience, I do question the judgment of those who say they're ready for world leadership but are to the left of the United Nations."
Progress in Yonkers
Addressing the Yonkers desegregation case, Mr. Kemp said that he was "not going to make any accusations" but that he hoped "this can be moved forward." He declined to be more specific. Work is proceeding on the first five of seven sites, where construction of 142 of a planned 200 units of subsidized housing is expected to begin in early April,
The Department of Housing and Urban Development is paying for the first 200 units as part of an agreement that removed H.U.D. from among the defendants in the 10-year-old housing desegregation case. Judge Leonard B. Sand ruled in 1985 in Federal District Court in Manhattan that Yonkers had intentionally segregated schools and housing over a period of four decades.
Yonkers education officials, ordered to find appropriate remedies, quickly introduced busing, created magnet schools to attract students across racially segregated neighborhood boundaries and took other steps that a court-appointed monitor said fulfilled the judge's requirements.
Integrating housing has been another matter. The Yonkers City Council refused to cooperate, so in 1986 Judge Sand proposed his own plan: 200 two-story, single-family town houses on seven sites "scattered" through the city's mostly white eastern and northern neighborhoods; and another 800 units of affordable housing to be built by private contractors, who would be granted incentives to include the apartments in market- rate developments that would have a total of 4,000 units.
 
'About As Far As We Can'
 But after five years, no developer for the 800 second-stage housing units has come forward. Mr. Kemp was asked last Tuesday if he saw a Federal role in breaking this impasse.
In reply, he recalled increasing H.U.D.'s financial contribution for the 200 units and then said, "I think we have gone about as far as we can or should go."
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who accompanied Mr. Kemp, said he thought the soft housing market had made a complex situation even more complex.
Yonkers, meanwhile, is making another bid to delay the start of construction. The city is asking a Federal Appeals Court for extra time while it asks the United States Supreme Court to rule on an issue involving the manner in which DeLuxe Homes, the developer of the first 200 housing units, took control of the building sites last summer.
The city is seeking to challenge Judge Sand's the order transferring the sites to DeLuxe. City officials want a guarantee that Yonkers will regain control of the sites if they are not used for housing.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Duke;
On Special Night, Men Get Lesson On Fear of Rape

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C.

 BODY:
It is difficult to frighten most college-aged men, but a group of students at Duke University hope that bright orange stickers will startle men into realizing a fear that women find hard to forget.
Members of the Date Rape and Sexual Assault Task Force made men the targets Thursday night across the campus. Five couples roamed the Gothic quadrangles in search of their prey -- a man alone at night. 
 When an unsuspecting man walked by, the two people descended on him, one sticking on his chest an orange sticker about two inches across reading "Gotcha," the other handing him an informational pamphlet. "Gotcha," the couple said to the sometimes bewildered, occasionally offended man. The pairs confronted 290 men over four hours.
"This gives men a chance to see what women face every night they have to walk home alone," said Melissa Segal, a sophomore from Mechanicsburg, Pa., majoring in cultural anthropology and a member of the Duke Acquaintance Rape Education Program. The purpose of the operation was not to assault men but to raise men's awareness of the possibility of assault for women, Ms. Segal.
"It's actually a privilege to not have to worry about your safety," said Martha Simmons, director of the Women's Center and one of the operation's organizers. Several of the students involved in organizing the program belong to Men Acting for Change, a group dedicated to raising awareness of sexual violence among men.
"This is not women targeting men," said Philip Poley of Men Acting for Change, a senior political science major from Lexington, Ky. "This is men targeting men."
"Obviously there seems to be a problem with date rape around here," said Bradford Andrews, a junior economics major from Jacksonville, N.C., after he had been "gotten" by a prowling pair.
Recent occurrences on campus include a male student's assaulting a female student as she left the library one night, and a Durham resident's assaulting two women in their dormitory bathroom. Last year, a male student was charged with second-degree rape and eventually pleaded guilty to a lesser charge. The Undergraduate Judicial Board at Duke heard one sexual battery case last year involving two students.
"There are too many instances of it to ignore it," Mr. Andrews said.
 
Surprised by Sticker
 Few men were frightened by the sticker-wielding teams, but many said they were surprised or annoyed. Michael Fritz, a junior biology major from Solon, Ohio, said he had not been worried or frightened when a woman stuck her head through the door of the classroom he was studying in and asked him if he was alone. He was merely surprised when she stuck a sticker on him.
"I know there's no danger of my ever being raped," Mr. Fritz said. "I'm on the wrestling team and stuff, and I really don't have a whole lot of fear." He said this was the first time that he had been confronted with the issue of sexual assault and rape this sharply.
"What do you think a guy would do about it?" he asked. "There's always going be danger. There's always going be an isolated place."
The operation's organizers said they hoped that men would do something about the issue. The pamphlet advises men to generate discussion, show support for women and speak out against sexual violence.
"These men will be in public-policy decision-making positions just like women," Ms. Simmons said. "They'll make decisions that affect women's lives."

(Duane Hall for The New York Times)(pg. 46)

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Ownership, Through the Looking Glass

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
There is a delicious sense of voyeurism here. We are comfortable in the dark, a bunch of car writers and Ford executives, all of us fixated on the one-way mirror that allows us to watch and hear a dozen people talking about the pluses and minuses of their new cars.
This is a clinic, one of a multitude that Ford and the other manufacturers do whenever they introduce a new car. In this case, the car is the '91 Escort, Ford's $2 billion replacement for the compact that has been a leading seller ever since the original rolled out of its first showroom in September 1980. 
 The new Escort is built in America, but it is a hybrid, too, designed by Ford but engineered by the company's Japanese partner, Mazda. The engine in the lineup of hatchbacks and station wagons is Japanese, and the car is based on Mazda's 323.
The clinic is one of six being held across the country this week and next, and the idea is to find out what has been done right and what needs fixing. And some of what is left unsaid turns out to be as interesting as what is said. For instance, only one person mentions fuel economy, and engine performance is not mentioned at all. But we are getting ahead of ourselves here.
The clinic's captain is Martin Goldfarb, who likes to be called Marty. He is a sociologist who gave up teaching to start his Toronto company in 1966, and he now employs 100 researchers. The company has branches in New York, Detroit, Dallas and San Jose, Calif., and Marty has worked with Ford for 20 years.
"I approach this as an anthropologist," Marty has said. "It's interesting to study attitudes, to get people talking. And it's easy to get them to come in. They like to think they have some impact, that they can change the direction of their vehicle."
Respondents are paid $35 to $50, depending on the city, and the Escort owners have been randomly selected from a list of buyers who have had their cars from three to six months. None have been prescreened, and they know only that they will be asked about the cars, that somebody is watching, and that a video camera is running.
Marty is on the other side of the glass, his back and his bald spot to us. The six men and six women are ranged around the gray table. There are sandwiches and fruit, and Marty works to get them relaxed before plunging into the questions.
Then he starts with Robert Velasco, the man on his right. Tell us about your car, he says.
Velasco says he bought his Escort in October, his first new car. What he particularly liked, he says, was that it was American but with Japanese engineering. "I wanted to buy American," he says, "but the car had to more than just domestic. I'm patriotic, but I'm not that patriotic."
His problems, he says, have had to do with two blowouts, one when he ran over a broken bottle, another when the car hit a curb after avoiding an accident. But he is still happy.
Next comes Bill Carpenter, who also is happy, a lot happier, he says, than he was with his old 1986 Escort. He likes the styling and the steering. Charles Martucci complains that the rear windows of his two-door hatchback leak, but he says the car is good in traffic, and he particularly likes the wiper delay and the car's split rear seat.
Like Velasco, Susan Mushalla says she wanted an American-built car, and she agrees with Martucci that one of the nicer features is the back seat, whose cushions can be folded down individually to provide for a passenger and for cargo.
One of the women says she doesn't like the way her Escort handles, and she blames it on the tires. That surprises the rest, who say they have no complaint. Athena Stathes says her car has a leak in the trunk, and another woman complains that opening the hatchback in the rain allows water to run in on the rear radio speakers. There ought to be some sort of redesign, she says.
Marty writes that down, as he does with other suggestions.
The group agrees that the yellow handle of the oil dipstick is all but impossible to get at, and one of the men suggests that the dipstick hole in the engine block also be painted yellow to make it easier to find.
There are complaints about a lack of lighting in some areas, such as the glovebox. Several in the group complain about bad paint, about runs and smears. And Derek Witcraft, who bought an Escort after his Lincoln went the way of thieves, says he wishes mightily for antilock brakes, a safety feature not available on the Escort.
"I only had that Lincoln for nine months before it was stolen," he says. "But I know those ABS brakes saved me from accidents again and again."
The Escort also has no air bag, and that prompts agreement that the car's mechanized seatbelts take some getting used to. "At one point," says one of the women, "I leaned out of the car to look at something, and that belt wrapped itself around my neck and almost strangled me."
In the group discussion, the Escort's cupholders seem to be a winning feature. The remote releases for the hatchback and gas filler flap are well liked, and the car's maneuverability, front-wheel-drive traction and good ride all get high marks. In fact, the 12 owners agree that they love their Escorts, and they talk about the ways in which they have sold friends on the car. One figures he should get a salesman's commission.
The dealer experience seems positive, although one man says he would never go back to "that place." Another says he bought the Escort after shopping for a Honda and being told he had to put down a deposit before the salesman would even discuss price. "Do you believe that?" he says, and heads start to shake.
A simple thing comes up: Patricia's car was delivered with a full tank of gas, and that pleased her a lot. Some in the group say their cars were delivered with less, and Marty makes notes.
Then he asks about advertising, and surprisingly the group is unanimous in its complaint: There are too few commercials for Escort, and the ads don't show enough of the car.
Why, he is asked later, would people who already own the car want to watch the ads?
"Oh, that's easy," Marty says. "They want to validate their purchase. They want to keep proving that they made the right decision. I think it shows that the car is better than its advertising."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Attacking a Scourge of Civilization

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Britain is in a recession, and its voters are furious over taxes. So it is time for tax reform, British style, with higher sales taxes on consumers and lower levies on business profits. That was said to be politically popular, which shows that Britain is far from America in more ways than one.
Judging by the reaction of the British press, one of the more popular elements of the tax package was a provision that Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, said would promote quieter restaurants and safer highways. 
 Mr. Lamont's way of so improving the environment was to propose a tax on what he called in his speech to the Commons "one of the greatest scourges of modern life: the mobile telephone." It turns out that posh London restaurants already have banned what The Times of London called "the infuriating warbling trill" that has "come to mar many a relaxed lunch."
Mr. Lamont's budget, which in the British system is sure to be enacted, calls for a revenue-neutral tax policy, in which the hated "poll tax," a charge levied on every resident of each community, is reduced and the money recovered through higher sales taxes. The value added tax, as sales taxes are known there, rises on April Fools' Day to 17.5 percent, from 15 percent.
The immediate result is likely to be a buying frenzy this week to beat the tax, but longer term that seems like a great way to depress consumer demand. All in all, a curious way to end a recession that appears to be worse than America's current one. Just as on this side of the Atlantic, the intent seems to be to fight recession with monetary policy, but British stocks slumped Friday when the Government cut interest rates by less than traders had expected.
The world economic outlook seemed more important last week, after I.B.M. stunned Wall Street by saying that weak European demand was a major reason this quarter would be a big disappointment. Suddenly, there was fear that the American recovery that the stock market has been forecasting might not be enough. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 89.36 points, or 3 percent, to 2,858.91, for its worst week in five months. Smaller stocks, which generally have less international exposure, barely wavered. The Russell 2,000 slipped just 0.56 points, to 165.80.
Some, such as Pat deBlank Klink, the president of Discount Advisers, a New York bond manager, think that slowing exports will encourage the Fed to ease even more, joining European central banks. France and Britain cut rates last week, Spain the week before, and it is widely expected that Italy will join the trend this week.
Unfortunately, in Germany the preoccupation of the central bank now is to defend the mark while blasting the Government for its ill-advised decision to allow monetary union with the former East Germany on terms that made eastern products totally uncompetitive. In both London and New York, markets probably would be thrilled if the Bundesbank decided to fall in step and lower interest rates. There are no signs, however, that will happen soon.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Geography of Diversification

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
With the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, Wall Street surged and stock markets around the world soared with it, highlighting once again the leadership role the American market can have.
But this is less the rule than one might think. In fact, outside of the big moves -- precipitated by events like the invasion of Kuwait last August and the stock market crash of 1987 -- many foreign stock markets follow their own tune. 
 This often weak correlation between American and foreign markets is one of the main arguments for diversifying a portfolio along geographic lines. If markets outside the United States generally are not led by the nose by Wall Street, then there is less risk of overall loss if stock and bond investments are made in one or more foreign countries.
"If you were of the view that the United States market was going to perform relatively poorly over a period of time, what you would do is ask yourself is there another market that is very poorly correlated with the United States," said Thomas R. Robinson, chief international equity strategist at Merrill Lynch in New York. "That way, you would have a better performance."
A new study by the consulting firm of Ennis, Knupp & Associates of Chicago says one reason for the noncorrelation of stock market moves is that many of the world's exchanges are far less diverse than Wall Street.
Using data from Morgan Stanley Capital International, the Ennis study rates major markets by their correlation with the United States. From 1970 through 1989, the stock market in Canada was the most closely correlated to Wall Street, in dollar terms, with a rating of 0.82. A rating of 1 would be a perfect correlation.
The lowest correlation was for Hong Kong, with 0.10, followed by Austria (0.22), Spain (0.25), Italy (0.32), Norway (0.33), Denmark (0.34), Germany (0.44), France (0.45), Japan (0.46), Belgium (0.48), Singapore/Malaysia (0.49), Sweden (0.52), Switzerland (0.58), Australia (0.58), Britain (0.59) and the Netherlands (0.67).
Not surprisingly, the degree of correlation of a particular market during this period was subject to change, sometimes dramatically so. Spain, for example, fell to a 0.03 correlation from 1980 through 1984 and then rose to 0.40 from 1985 through 1989. France's market also had such a wide swing, falling to 0.12 from 1980 through 1984 and rising to 0.63 from 1985 through 1989. But from 1980 through 1989, France's rating was 0.41, in line with its longer-range performance.
The Ennis report concludes that there is no significant evidence showing that the overall correlation level is rising over the long term.
A look at Japan shows how the general lack of correlation can change in the face of major events. But the Japanese experience also shows that, apart from such events, a foreign market's linkage to Wall Street can be even more tenuous than the overall numbers would seem to indicate.
From 1980 through 1989, the correlation rating for Japan is 0.42. But when the period is changed slightly -- to cover the years from 1981 through 1990 -- the correlation rises to 0.48. Part of this jump is attributed to the similar sharp declines that both the Tokyo and the New York markets took in the third quarter of last year after the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.
"The correlation numbers are colored by the big extreme moves in markets," said Paul Burik, director of international research at Ennis, Knupp, which advises institutional investors, including pension funds and charities.
To make the point, Mr. Burik recalculated the 1981 through 1990 figures without the quarters in which the Japanese stock market had its biggest declines: the fourth quarter of 1987, after the Wall Street crash; the first quarter of 1990, when the Tokyo market fell much further than any other market, and the third quarter of 1990, when Kuwait was invaded. Without these moves, the correlation falls to 0.39, showing that in more normal periods, the correlation is weaker.
What this shows, Mr. Burik said, is "that you do not look to diversification of your portfolio as a protection from a global stock market decline."
Both Mr. Burik and Mr. Robinson of Merrill Lynch said that such coordinated market moves were to be expected in the case of the invasion of Kuwait, given that rising oil prices caused by the takeover were guaranteed to have a major negative impact on economies around the world.
But except for the fallout caused by world-shaking events, the diversification strategy can pay off with benefits that are quite attractive.
And now could be just such a time to benefit, according to Mr. Robinson. With the war in the gulf behind it, Wall Street is losing some of its leadership force, he says.
That means global market activity should move back toward its more normal -- and lower -- correlation levels. This is reflected in the fact that since Wall Street hit its recent peak March 6, the Dow Jones industrial average is down 3.85 percent, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is virtually unchanged, off by just 0.26 percent.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 17-22

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

 
THE ECONOMY

 
Watch Out Taxpayers, Here Come the Banks
 

When lawmakers see a familiar balding man approaching from the direction of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's headquarters, they should declare a national day of mourning. The doleful news Thursday from L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, was that the fund to insure bank deposits needed authority to borrow another $70 billion. Lawmakers, fresh from providing $30 billion more to salvage the savings and loans, fear the worst. As Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, said, "I've been through taxpayer bailouts before and this is how they often get started." Mr. Seidman said that the fund can stay solvent by treating one loan, a $5 billion Treasury Department line of credit, as collateral for another, $45 billion loan, and raising the premiums charged on bank deposits . Maybe so. But the F.D.I.C.'s financing now seems as tottery as all the grandiose construction projects, leveraged buyouts and third-world investments that so many imperiled banks have financed.
 
Inflation on Top of Recession
 
To judge from last week's inflation report, this recession has none of the pleasure, all of the pain. Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in February, but seven-tenths of 1 percent excluding the volatile costs of food and energy. Slower business usually means slower inflation as well. But prices have risen just as much in the six months since August, about when the recession began, as in the six months before. Some economists say that slack commodity and labor costs and unused capacity at factories will keep inflation in check. As Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc., asked, "Because you had a snowstorm in New York a couple weeks ago, does that mean winter is going to be here with us for two or three months?" But after the inflation report blew stock and bond prices down, investors started shivering.
 
The Incredible Trump Divide
 
Memo to Ivana: Why not limit your exposure to your ex-husband's credit woes before the news from the Trump Tower triplex gets any worse? It's time for the world's first securitized divorce deal. Just sell off the rights to last week's settlement -- the $14 million up front, the $650,000 in annual child support -- and take the cash. The new-products boys on Wall Street could come up with a name that yields a jazzy acronym. (How about Special Priority Limited Ivana Transfers?). True, the securities will sell for a good deal less than your settlement's par value. But better to take a haircut than a scalping.
 
Procter & Gamble Fights Back
 
Some competitors implied that the Procter & Gamble Company needed to call in the exorcists, maybe to wave a cross and mumble some incantations over a box of Pampers. Instead, Procter called in the lawyers. Last Tuesday, a Federal judge in Topeka, Kan., awarded the company $75,000 from two distributors of rival Amway household cleansers and detergents. James H. Newton and his wife, Linda, had handed out leaflets urging a boycott of Procter, citing the company's old moon-and-stars trademark as evidence of Satanic sway.
 
Continued Strength in Exports
 
Exports continue as one of the few sources of economic growth, rising 3.6 percent in January to $34.5 billion. Higher imports widened the trade deficit slightly, to $7 billion. Neal M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston, said that even if the dollar remains stronger, exports are unlikely to suffer for a year or more. "People have a tendency to do business with established suppliers," he said, rather than switching at the drop of a pfennig or yen.
 
Women and the Workplace
 
The Supreme Court ruled that employers may not bar women from jobs that might endanger fetuses. Several companies now have to decide whether to reduce the use of hazardous chemicals, increase workplace protections or risk lawsuits.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
I.B.M. Takes the Market Down
 
Last week, I.B.M.'s outlook became a leading economic indicator unto itself. An announcement on Tuesday by the International Business Machine Corporation's chairman, John F. Akers, that first-quarter profits would be half those of the same quarter last year touched off a $12.75-a-share plunge in the stock -- a $7.3 billion one-day loss in the company's market value. Many investors, saying they took I.B.M.'s plight as evidence of a slow economy and weak earnings potential at other companies, sold other stocks, contributing to a 62-point drop in the Dow on Tuesday. After a year when I.B.M. resisted the gathering forces of recession, some analysts are inclined to apply the company's forecast of tough times ahead to the entire computer industry. "Comparing I.B.M. to other players in this tournament, it is reasonably well positioned," said Daniel Mandresh, who follows the company for Merrill Lynch. "The issue is the terrain. It's shaping up as a tough golf course."
 
Yet More Michael Jackson?
 
Sony is betting that the world can take another $1 billion worth of Michael Jackson. A deal announced last week gives Mr. Jackson at least $108 million for issuing six more albums on Epic Records, a Sony Corporation subsidiary. Then there are plans for full-length Michael Jackson feature films, Michael Jackson theatrical shorts, Michael Jackson television programs and a Michael Jackson record label. Sony executives, after some hurried calculations, said the whole package could bring in perhaps $1 billion in revenues. But Mr. Jackson might already have moonwalked out of the spotlight. Michael Jackson shoes, Michael Jackson toys and a Michael Jackson movie have all flopped.
 
First MCI, Now GTE
 
John D. Goeken has succeeded in another guerrilla assault on the telecommunications industry. Last Wednesday, the GTE Corporation announced an agreement to pay him and other investors $15.5 million to settle a suit over GTE's 1986 acquisition and subsequent management of Airfone -- the airborne phone service that Mr. Goeken founded in 1976, based on technology that he invented. GTE also agreed to drop its suit accusing Mr. Goeken of violating an agreement not to compete with Airfone. He founded a rival company, In-Flight Phone, in 1989, despite GTE's insistence that competition was technically unfeasible. GTE should have known how things would end up: Mr. Goeken also founded Microwave Communications Inc., later MCI, whose court actions helped break up the Bell System's monopoly.
 
Continental Outlook: 50-50
 
Can an airline that lost $2.25 billion in the fourth quarter be ready for takeoff? Executives at Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. explain the loss, the industry's record worst for a quarter, as a "balance-sheet cleanup." Like many a new chairman, Hollis L. Harris is willing to take write-offs and confess to the sins of his predecessor, in this case Frank Lorenzo. But the company's operating loss hit $333 million, and net worth is a negative $3.4 billion. Analysts say Continental's chances of emerging from bankruptcy reorganization are little better than 50-50.
 
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation could lose hundreds of millions of dollars if airlines like Continental fail to recover, the agency's executive director said on Friday. Eastern, Pan Am and Continental, all in bankruptcy proceedings, have unfunded pension liabilities of $1.6 billion, with about $1.3 billion covered by the agency.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
The Great Mexican Cleanup
 
First he had to begin cleaning up the oil monopoly's unions, then take care of its foulest oil refinery. Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari ordered the closing on Monday of Mexico City's largest refinery, one of the worst causes of the city's notorious air pollution. The region's exploding population and pell-mell industrialization have left it with air that stings the eyes, burns the throat and leaves many children with permanently impaired breathing. Restricting motorists to alternate driving days has made little apparent difference. Robert A. Pastor, director of the Latin American program at the Carter Center in Atlanta, said that the arrest of the Pemex oil company's powerful union boss in a 1989 shoot-out helped make last week's action possible.
 
Little for Gorbachev in Tokyo
 
The Japan that can say no to the United States is unlikely to say yes to the Soviet Union. Soviets and Japanese both are coming to doubt that a visit by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Japan next month will produce any breakthroughs. The Soviet seizure of several islands from Japan at the end of World War II has stood in the way of so much as a peace treaty to officially end their hostilities. Henry Trofimenko, chief analyst at Moscow's Institute of U.S. and Canada Studies, said that Soviet conservatives bemoaning the loss of Eastern Europe can keep Mr. Gorbachev from returning the islands even if he wants to. Professor Trofimenko, visiting at Columbia University's Harriman Institute, recalls the time years ago when Andrei Gromyko, then Foreign Minister, asked to collect the party cards of any aides who even wanted to discuss the issue. Some Soviets hope that to recover the islands, the Japanese would grant the Soviet Union massive aid, including help in developing Siberian resources. But the Japanese are losing their enthusiasm for investing in a nation where business becomes more difficult each day.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Optical Fiber (Almost) at Home

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Despite years of research and development, telephone equipment suppliers have not yet come up with optical fiber systems that are cheap enough to persuade local phone companies -- or the public utility commissions that regulate them -- to abandon copper wire completely. But they are getting close.
The hair-thin glass fibers have already replaced virtually all the bulky copper cable used in long-distance connections. They also carry more than two-thirds of the traffic from the central offices of local networks to the long-distance lines and between central offices, and that share is growing steadily. Now, fiber technology is pushing its way into the "local loop," as telecommunications engineers call the lines that run from central offices to the curbside of business and residential users. 
 "We are right at the crossover point where fiber to the curb is more economical than copper," said Paul Polishuk, publisher of Fiber to the Home, an industry newsletter.
At stake is a domestic market for replacing copper worth $6 billion annually, according to the Raynet Corporation, a Menlo Park, Calif.-based supplier of telecommunications equipment. Another $9 billion is being spent overseas each year on replacing copper with fiber.
Fiber is making extensive inroads by replacing copper as the conduit to district offices, also known as remote terminals, which function as distribution points in the field serving anywhere from 50 to 1,000 lines. More important, telephone companies are poised to order systems that will take fiber to curbside boxes near the telephone users.
The curbside boxes, also known as pedestals or subscriber interface units are like miniature switching stations. They convert the optical signals into electric pulses that can be sent down the existing copper wire into the home and work in reverse, converting electrical pulses to light signals, when the homeowner is talking on the phone. Phone companies are now willing to install them because the units are economical when serving as few as four customers.
Fiber to the curb still leaves the industry short of its dream of a system composed entirely of fiber. That system could deliver hundreds of video channels and services for home computer users as well as regular telephone service on a single fiber. In addition, the phone companies believe that a fiber network reaching the home would be cheaper to run, more reliable and easier to service.
But going the last few feet to the house itself with fiber promises to be expensive. Each house would need a box of optical and electronic devices to translate the light signals into electric impulses that could register as voices on a phone, data in a computer, or images on a television screen. To pay for that investment, the phone companies say they need permission from regulators to sell consumers more than what is commonly known as POTS, for "plain old telephone service."
As things stand now, the courts, regulators, and Congress have all sided with the cable television companies, publishers and consumer groups that have lobbied furiously to keep the telephone companies from offering video or database services in those areas where they also have the local telephone monopoly. The phone companies' opponents argue that the monopoly phone business would provide revenues that would unfairly subsidize any other services the phone companies might offer.
Few experts doubt that fiber will eventually reach most if not all homes. Copper wire simply does not have the capacity to handle such emerging technologies as high-definition television and integrated transmission of voice, video and data signals on a single line into a home. But which enterprises or consortiums of enterprises will be first remains up in air.
Faced with this uncertainty, telecommunications equipment suppliers have fallen back on a two-pronged strategy: make fiber to the curb competitive with copper and try to design systems that can be easily upgraded in the future. "Our initial approach was to go all the way to box at the home, but it didn't make economic sense so we backed off a bit," said William McCullen, product planner for Fiber in the Loop Systems at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Andover, Mass.
A.T.& T.'s fiber-to-the-curb design is known as an active double star. The first star is the spread of fiber lines from the central office to the remote terminal. The remote terminal sorts out traffic from the central office and directs, over the second star, an array of fiber lines to from 16 to 24 curbside pedestals.
A.T.& T.'s system uses more fiber than some of its competitors and more electronics to route traffic at the remote terminals. But it can use the same inexpensive lasers that are widely used in compact disks and has lower power requirements, according to phone company engineers. A.T.& T. says the system will also be easy to upgrade to handle services like high definition television.
Raynet's system has two approaches that have attracted supporters in the industry. Its bus system is up to 30 percent less expensive than A.T.& T.'s, according to Jane Belcher, an analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago. The bus is a fiber highway running from a central office or one of a group of district offices served by a central office. The bus has a series of curbside pedestals on it, like interchanges on an interstate highway.
Raynet is also marketing a variant on its system that uses a device known as a splitter to allow it to create a branch network. If the signal splitter is inserted at the central distribution point, the effect is to create an array of fiber pathways. It can also be inserted along the bus, creating a system that is part-star, part-bus.
Splitters are passive devices like prisms. Each pathway leaving a splitter carries all of the information that arrived there in a weaker form. Thus, engineers say, systems with splitters need more powerful transmitters than A.T.& T.'s and more sensitive receivers to make sure that no information is lost.
One of Raynet's advantages is Rides, the software package it developed in conjunction with BellSouth, to integrate fiber in the loop into the rest of the phone network and manage its fiber system. One competitor, the DSC Communications Corporation of Petaluma, Calif., has signed up to use the software in its own system and several other competitors are weighing similar moves.
Raynet and A.T.& T's competitors range from giants like Alcatel of France and Fujitsu of Japan to mid-sized companies like ADC Telecommunications Inc. and DSC, and small ones like Broadband Technologies Inc. All of the systems also have to provide power for the electronics they use since, unlike copper wire, the fiber network cannot carry its own power supply.
One unknown is whether deployment of fiber to the curb may in some cases delay fiber to the home. Copper has much more capacity over short distances than when strung for miles as it sometimes is in phones systems. Daniel Boyce, staff manager for fiber to the curb implementation at Southern Bell, figures that a fiber-to-the-curb system that cut the average copper line in a phone system from two miles to 500 feet would have 100-fold jump in capacity. "That creates some good opportunities for high-speed services," he said, while stressing that such a system would still have a fraction of the potential of a pure fiber system.

HEADLINE: France Sees Integration as Answer to View of Immigrants as 'Taking Over'

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Sifting through his papers, Claude Desvaux counted 203 foreigners among the 280 students attending his public school in the crowded Belleville section of Paris. But the real number, he added with a resigned smile, is much higher.
"We have children born in France who remain culturally foreign because they speak Arabic or some other language at home," the school principal said. "We have kids from the French Antilles who are French citizens but they don't feel French." 
 Across France, foreigners represent around 9 percent of all students under the age of 16, but in districts with high concentrations of immigrants, they invariably account for more than 70 percent of pupils.
Throughout Western Europe, there is a perception that immigrants -- Arabs in France, Turks in Germany, Pakistanis in Britain and so on -- are "taking over" schools, housing complexes and neighborhoods. That in turn has led to the movement of European families and the entire process has become known as the ghetto phenomenon. That in turn has become a major factor contributing to rising opposition to new immigration.
 
Viewed With Hostility
 Whether in Birmingham, Frankfurt, Florence or Marseilles, third-world communities have become the target of simmering xenophobia and occasional racist violence, with some ultra-nationalist groups even trying to court popularity by demanding that poor foreigners be forcibly repatriated.
Yet, with immigration already strictly controlled in Western Europe, many experts are now arguing that the problem and the solution lie elsewhere. Today's immigrants are viewed with hostility, they say, because earlier waves of immigrants and their children were not properly integrated.
With many governments under strong pressure to do something about immigration, this view is also gaining favor in European capitals. A recent report by the European Community's executive commission said the focus should now switch to integration, while France's new Council on Integration has just published its first findings.
In many European cities, as in the United States, the ghetto phenomenon occurs almost naturally.
Immigrants are drawn to where their relatives or friends already live. And as they start crowding schools, apartment blocks and hostels, often changing the local scenery with their shops and places of worship, European families move away.
The result is evident in the patio below Mr. Desvaux's office at the College de Fontaine-au-Roi in Paris's 11th arrondissement. At different times of the day, teen-agers of 28 nationalities, five religions and all races take breaks there between classes, but hardly a white French child is to be seen. "The ghetto phenomenon is a permanent danger to us," Mr. Desvaux said.
Experts argue, though, that race is not the principal obstacle to integration. Asked in a recent French poll why cohabitation with immigrants was difficult, respondents overwhelmingly identified different customs and religion and, to a smaller extent, language, while skin color was barely mentioned.
Attitudes have also hardened as immigrants have gone from guest workers to permanent residents. For example, when France, Britain, Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands were welcoming the cheap foreign labor of single men between the late 1950's and the early 1970's, they represented an economic solution.
But by the 1980's, many immigrants had brought their families, customs and religions and had formed highly visible communities in countries with little "melting pot" tradition. Western Europe's economies still need them but, often trapped in poverty, they are now considered a social problem.
"They continually run the risk of unemployment, of having to accept the worst housing and of facing disproportionate difficulties in schools," according to the European Commission's recent report on immigration and integration. "They run the risk of becoming marginalized and remaining marginalized."
The report stressed that the problem not only affected newly arrived immigrants and refugees. "Their children and grandchildren also comprise a social and economic underclass," it said, "and this will not change until integration policies become stronger and more imaginative."
In France, it was only last year after a wave of violent racist incidents and rising support for the extreme-rightist National Front that the socialist Government of President Francois Mitterrand concluded that there was no viable alternative to speeding integration.
As a first step, it appointed a high-level Council on Integration to analyze the crisis and recommend action. And last month, the council issued its first report, drawing a dark picture of an immigrant population that is largely cut off from French society in its schools, housing and employment.
 
'Equality of Rights and Duties'
 Dealing first with principles, it declared that France's concept of integration meant guaranteeing "equality of rights and duties" for everyone rather than reinforcing segregation of immigrants by treating them as special communities or minorities.
But it also recognized that, while earlier generations of immigrants and refugees from Eastern Europe had been naturally assimilated, "patient, vigorous and inventive" measures would be needed to integrate the Arabs, Africans and Asians now crowding schools, housing complexes and hostels.
The problems involved are apparent enough in Paris's 11th arrondissement, where parents can choose among five public schools. And that means, in Mr. Desvaux's words, "they can choose not to integrate." As a result, his school carries the main burden of handling local immigrant children
That in turn has predictable consequences. While 80 percent of pupils at a nearby lycee continue studying after the age of 16, only 40 percent of Mr. Desvaux's students do so. Similarly, nationwide, while 30 percent of immigrants between the ages of 16 and 24 are unemployed, the figure for French youths is 20 percent.
French schools in turn mirror the concentration of immigrant housing. About 120,000 immigrants live in some 400 "temporary" hostels owned and managed by the Government. But most other immigrants live in low-cost housing that quickly brings the ghetto phenomenon to districts and towns.
The French Government has established greater integration of the hostels and the low-cost housing blocks among its objectives, but the problems are myriad. In one well-run hostel in Evry, 30 miles outside Paris, the fact that most of its 271 guests are foreign permanent residents means there is little room for French workers.
A few hundred yards away, a low-cost housing complex crowded with Algerians, Moroccans, Tunisians and growing numbers of sub-Saharan Africans poses even greater obstacles to integration because, in Evry at least, it is already identified with uncollected garbage, violence and frequent police raids.
At the College de Fontaine-au-Rois in Belleville, Mr. Desvaux said he had no difficulty maintaining order inside the school. "But there is a problem of delinquency outside," he said. "The problem is that when the kids go home, there's no one there, so they hit the streets. Often the only social structure is a street gang."
But winding up a two-hour French lesson before a class of 15-year-olds, Claude Beaudoin insisted that the children of immigrants were gradually becoming integrated. "We get young Arab girls asking for our help to prevent them from being sent home to get married," the young teacher said.
In the class, impatient for lunch after studying a poem by Paul Verlaine, there were children from Sri Lanka, India, Cambodia, Mali, Yugoslavia, the French Antilles and all the countries of North Africa. But when asked who wanted to go home, only one boy from Guadeloupe raised his hand. "I miss the weather," he said.

HEADLINE: Real Estate and Tax Abuses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With regard to Ronald G. Weiner's Forum article ("Blame the Recession on Tax Reform," March 10), while I have no quarrel with the general thrust of the article, I think Mr. Weiner is looking through the wrong end of the telescope when he blames the end of a tax abuse for real estate problems.
The very cause of the problem was the fact that investors flocked to real estate ventures of all stripes because of the artificial arrangements. Undoing those has caused and will continue to cause for some time a considerable degree of pain for those lured into such investments.
But Mr. Weiner blames the cure for being the disease. The fact is that the real disease has caused speculative overbuilding at every level and the real estate markets are coming apart from the oversupply (coupled with reduced purchasing power from a recessionary economy).
By Mr. Weiner's logic, the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and now the Resolution Trust Corporation should be held liable for the saving and loan and other banking industry problems!
 
HARVEY L. SHULMAN
New York, March 13

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Wesleyan;
A New Policy Fights the Risks Of Passive Smoke

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.

 BODY:
Because of rising concerns over the health risk that passive smoke poses for nonsmokers, Wesleyan University has begun a new smoking policy for faculty and staff members.
Beginning July 1, employees will not be allowed to smoke in university buildings except in private offices and designated areas. A similar policy for students is being developed by the Student Assembly. 
 David Landsberg, director of human resources, said the new policy was created after several nonsmoking faculty and staff members voiced concern over the dangers of passive smoke. "With more and more documentation of the damage of passive smoke, a number of employees feel they have the right to be protected," Mr. Landsberg said.
Most faculty members appear to support the new ban. "If somebody is in the hall, smoking, it really bothers me in my office," said Priscilla Meyer, a professor of Russian language and literature. "I think it is a good thing."
 
Policy Called Intrusive
 But some faculty members think the policy is unjust. Noting that he was "in the minority," David Titus, a professor of government, called the policy intrusive and an effort "to legislate morality."
"We have an ideology of nonsmoking," Professor Titus said, "but if I die of cancer or emphysema that's my business."
The issue has been more controversial among students. A smoking ban for students, proposed two weeks ago at a Student Assembly session, met with strong opposition. "It is unenforceable and alienates a large segment of the population," said Andrew Beckler, a senior majoring in social studies from Greenville, Del., and an assembly member.
The assembly passed a motion of "vague approval of a more restrictive smoking policy, particularly for student bases such as classrooms and the Campus Center," said the student assembly president, Louis Maggiotto, a junior from Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., majoring in economics and film. The motion also called for the creation of a student committee to study the issue.
Charles Negaro, president of T.P.A. Books, which owns Atticus Books, the Wesleyan bookstore, and the Atticus College Store in the Davenport Campus Center, has joined in the anti-smoking effort.
Mr. Negaro, a former smoker, has suggested to the university administration that the Campus Center be declared a smoke-free building and has volunteered to stop selling cigarettes in the Atticus College Store.
"We would like to assist in the process of sensitizing students to the smoking issue," Mr. Negaro said.
