HEADLINE: Seeking More Minority Council Members

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
A New York City commission is devising new district lines for an expanded City Council intended to accommodate more black and Hispanic members, and possibly Asian-Americans, homosexuals and other minority groups, including Republicans.
Politicians expect the new alignment to insure the election of minority representatives to at least 8 of 16 new seats when the Council expands to 51 members from 35. That would increase minority membership from the current 26 percent to at least 33 percent. 
 Blacks, Hispanic residents and other minorities account for almost 57 percent of the city population, according to the latest census figures.
 
New Power for Council
 The expansion of the Council to its largest membership in 54 years will complete a city government revolution under the new City Charter approved by voters in 1989, in which a more powerful Council has replaced the Board of Estimate as the city's chief legislative body.
By drawing districts that group, for example, large numbers of black or Hispanic residents, the Districting Commission can increase the likelihood that minority members will be elected to the Council from those districts. In the past, the opposite tactic was often used to dilute the voting strength of certain groups.
The drawing of the new lines, to be completed in early June, has touched off a scramble as incumbent Council members, members of minority groups and Democratic and Republican leaders seek to influence the 15-member commission and its 29-member staff.
Several politicians predicted that the districting would draw lawsuits like lightning from minority groups contending that they were not properly recognized. "Everyone is waiting for the mother of all lawsuits," said City Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, Democrat of Queens.
 
'List of Endangered Species'
 There is already a lawsuit challenging the commission itself as a product of racial and ethnic quotas, but that suit is aimed at future commissions, not the present group. The Justice Department must also approve the new district lines under the Federal Voting Rights Act.
A Democratic Party leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the commission had "set itself up for failure by putting everybody but the Aleuts on their list of endangered species."
Despite those concerns, Frank J. Macchiarola, the commission chairman, expressed confidence that the commission would complete its work in time for the 51 members to be chosen for two-year terms in the September primary and the November general election this year. In the regular 1993 municipal election, the Council members would be up for election to their usual four-year terms.
Mr. Macchiarola said that he thought lawsuits challenging the new districts were likely but that he did not expect them to interfere with the election.
In an effort to defuse discrimination arguments, the commission and its staff have held 350 meetings with community boards and civic, religious and ethnic groups and 14 full-scale hearings, with at least that many more hearings scheduled over the next three months, said Alan Gartner, the commission's executive director, who is on leave as research director at the City University Graduate Center. Mr. Gartner pointed with pride to a city map covered with red and green pins denoting meetings and hearings.
He is a long-time associate of Mr. Macchiarola and Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch and was an unpaid issues adviser in the campaign of Mayor David N. Dinkins. The commission itself was appointed jointly by the Mayor and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, often on the recommendation of political leaders.
Mr. Gartner said that so far Asian-Americans, Dominicans and gay groups had been the most vocal advocates of Council representation.
While they do not represent racial or ethnic minorities, the gay groups, as well as Republicans, base their arguments on the charter mandate to "keep intact neighborhoods and communities with established ties of common interest and association, whether historical, racial, economic, ethnic, religious or other."
Using the returns from three elections that included openly gay candidates, gay and lesbian groups have urged establishment of a West Village-Chelsea district that could elect one of their number. Mr. Gartner said such districts had been created in other cities.
Asian-Americans are promoting a district in the Chinatown area, and Dominicans are seeking a Washington Heights district.
New, predominantly Hispanic, districts are likely to be created in the South Bronx, East Harlem and in the Williamsburg and possibly Sunset Park sections of Brooklyn. Queens also has a large Hispanic population, but it is more diffused than those in other boroughs and therefore not likely to warrant a Council seat.
New black districts are likely to be created in Harlem, southeastern Queens, the South Bronx and the East Flatbush and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn.
Republicans, who now have only one Council member, from Staten Island, could elect as many as five in the new districts, though some Democrats dispute that number. New Republican districts could include two in Queens, one on the East Side of Manhattan and a new Staten Island-Brooklyn district. The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, a rare Republican city official, said he and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican candidate for mayor in 1989 and possibly again in 1993, would actively seek viable Republican Council candidates in the target districts.
Each district will have a population of about 143,580, 70,000 less than in the present districts.
Mr. Gartner and Mr. Macchiarola acknowledged that incumbent Council members and other politicians had made many suggestions in private and public meetings and would almost certainly have strong opinions when the first tentative district maps are released in early May. The final versions will be released on June 3 -- about two weeks before the election process starts with the circulation of nominating petitions.
 
Maneuvering by Incumbents
 Many incumbents hope to retain areas of strength and lose unfriendly areas in their districts. Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, said one councilman "is trying to cut a district to exclude" a potential opponent.
Mr. Friedman tried his own selective districting with a bill, enacted last year, that would include Rikers Island and its 18,000 prisoners with the Bronx, as it has been historically. But the City Charter requires a bridge or ferry connection, which would make the island part of Queens. Mr. Friedman conceded that the Justice Department is likely to opt for Queens.
Having the prison in one's domain is considered advantageous because the prisoners add numbers to a borough and thus increase representation but usually do not vote, so they are not an electoral bloc.
Does all the maneuvering constitute new-fashioned gerrymandering? "No question about it," Mr. Friedman said.
Mr. Gartner of the commission called that description "a crude assessment, but not totally absurd."

LENGTH: 652 words

HEADLINE: Democrats Assail Bush and Talk Tough About '92

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The Democratic National Committee fortified itself today for the long march toward the 1992 Presidential election with fiery attacks on President Bush and tough talk about the fight it intends to wage next year.
What was missing was a candidate. 
 Party leaders, gathered here for the Democrats' first national committee meeting since the war in the Persian Gulf, tried to make a virtue out of necessity. They said that Presidential campaigns had grown too long in recent years, that the American people were not clamoring for the Democratic contest to begin and that the dearth of Democratic candidates did not reflect a moribund party.
 
'Plenty of Time' to Campaign
 "I'm glad there's been a delay," said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman. "A Presidential campaign that starts this summer or this fall is plenty of time."
In the meantime, Mr. Brown and others tried to regain the offensive after weeks of watching Republicans glory in the success of the gulf war. "They make no bones about the fact that their vision extends no farther than November 1992," Mr. Brown told Democrats today. "Their domestic policies consist of no more than vetoes and pep rallies."
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, asserted that it was time for Democrats to "take off the gloves" and engage the Republicans on major challenges like health care.
Senator Rockefeller, who told reporters that contrary to speculation he had ruled out a run for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992, asserted, "While health care may be a nonissue and a nonstarter on Pennsylvania Avenue, on Main Street and in cities, suburbs and rural towns across the country health care is the pocketbook issue."
But, while the Democrats tried to push a domestic agenda, concern over political fallout from the gulf war was a persistent undercurrent here.
Senator Rockefeller touched upon it with a dark joke. He said, "Reporters keep asking Ron when our party is going to field some Presidential candidates, when will some Democrats finally go to Iowa." The Senator said it was part of a master plan: "Democrats never got a chance to prove that sanctions could have worked in Iraq, so guess what? We're going to try them against Iowa."
Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, served warning to some of the party's own consultants who talk publicly about the Democrats' grim chances next year. "Those who sup at our table and sleep in our houses should be supporting us," Mr. Foley said. His warning, reminiscent of John L. Lewis's criticism of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1938 ("It ill behooves one who has supped at labor's table . . ."), prompted a standing ovation from the audience.
 
War Opposition Played Down
 Mr. Foley also sought to play down the political impact of the Democrats' votes against a resolution in January authorizing the use of force in the gulf. A majority of Democrats in the House and the Senate voted against the resolution. Republicans have said they intend to make that a major issue in the 1992 elections, asserting that it shows that Democrats are inherently weak and incapable of conducting foreign policy.
The Speaker said the American people would reject such an appeal.
While most of the party leaders were trying to rally spirits, John R. Silber, who ran an insurgent and unsuccessful campaign for governor of Massachusetts last fall, came to the Democrats with some blunt warnings. "If the Democratic Party doesn't open its eyes and read the ticker tape they're not going anywhere," he said, urging that the party get back to basics with solid economic programs and a tough policy on national security.
"We've got to stop this nonsense of trying to create a class war," added Mr. Silber, who has also been the subject of some Presidential speculation. "I have no intention of running, but it's a contingent world."

HEADLINE: Not Euphoric but Perplexed, Nation Deals With the Peace

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
When the war with Iraq ended on Feb. 28, Americans sighed with relief, and many smiled with pride. For a precious few days, the euphoria stilled domestic disputes and indulged a national daydream about solving economic and social woes with something akin to six weeks of surgical bombing. Then America woke up, and the recession was still playing on the clock radio.
In interviews last week, sociologists, economists and poll takers, not to mention plastic surgeons, letter carriers and surfboard salesmen, spoke of a perplexing period of rising and falling moods and expectations. 
 "What Americans are telling me," said Samuel W. Kaplan, a professor of sociology at Swarthmore College, "reminds me of what Rita Hayworth once said about herself: 'Men go to bed with Rita Hayworth and wake up and find it's only me.' America went to bed with a great victory and woke up with a victory that no longer seems so great and a world filled with problems that we basically aren't able to do anything about."
Even the sweet aftertaste of triumph was tainted by omens of civil war, disease and famine in Iraq. "There is still so much turmoil over there in the gulf," said Andrew K. Bassett, a letter carrier who paused in his rounds in downtown Philadelphia. "Who knows how it will end?"
Surveys suggest that while the war caused a lot of anxiety it never fully distracted people from problems at home. On the day the cease-fire was announced, only one number popped up like a champagne cork: Americans gave President Bush an 88 percent approval rating for the way he was handling his job, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll. But even then, the respondents gave the President a 42 percent approval rating (and a 43 percent disapproval rating) on his handling of the economy, which they ranked as far and away the nation's biggest problem.
Nor did the afterglow of victory shine on Vice President Dan Quayle, whose approval rating rose just 3 points, to 19 percent from 16 percent two months earlier. (The nationwide telephone poll of 1,252 adults was conducted March 4-6 and had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.)
If these numbers could talk, though, some of them would certainly sound like Leopold J. Schlogel, a retired aircraft mechanic who lives in White Marsh, Md., a suburb of Baltimore. "I am a Democrat, but I think the war victory will help President Bush. He's going to try to straighten things out here at home, and I think he will do all right.
"Before the war," he continued, "we would say we're going to do this or do that, and we never did. Like in Vietnam, where we just gave up. This time, we did exactly what we said we were going to do, and that means a lot. People will look up to us and believe what we say, and I really do think the victory will help solve our problems over here too."
 
Winning, but So What?
 In a poll conducted in the last two weeks of the war, 677 residents of metropolitan Houston ranked their concern about war in general far behind their concerns about drugs, the environment and the economy. "What this poll says is, 'We're winning this war, but it is largely irrelevant to us,' " said Stephen L. Klineberg, a sociology professor at Rice University who directs the poll, the Annual Houston Area Survey.
America's anxiety level is also measured by how much people spend. Some bankers and economists predicted that the end of the war would reduce uncertainty, entice droves of consumers back to the marketplace and make the recession fade quickly. The Bush Administration encouraged such hopes by linking the start of the recession with the start of the gulf crisis in August, and just about every faltering business and ballet troupe blamed the war for some of its troubles.
But Herbert B. Ershkowitz, a history professor at Temple University, said World War II had imprinted on many Americans an erroneous notion that wars and economic recoveries are linked. The war with Iraq was largely fought with supplies from inventory, and it caused none of the disruptions that accompanied earlier wars in this century, like rationing and price controls. As World War II ended, Professor Ershkowitz said, millions of Americans had been unable to buy new houses or cars for 16 or 17 years; the Iraqi cease-fire came after a decade of prosperity and rising personal debt.
 
A Reservoir of Uncertainty
 Many economists say the war's end does reduce uncertainty and anxiety about the future, but not greatly. John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, said, "There might be some people who, out of largely irrational concerns, postponed consumer durable purchases like houses and automobiles during the war, but their purchases won't have any significant effect on the economy."
And plenty of uncertainty remains. "I was in euphoria when we won the war, and I never use the word euphoria," said Fran Carpentier, an editor at Parade magazine in Manhattan. "I had the sense we were America the Unbeatable again.
"Then there was all this positive stuff about the war carrying over, and the Bush Administration predicting the economy would turn around and that consumers would not behave as dourly as they have. What's happening? I was just getting ready to tighten my belt! Now I am afraid to miss a day's newspaper for fear of missing an entire economic trend."
In a random survey of businesses in several cities, most managers said they had not seen any significant improvement since the end of the war. But there were some exceptions: Home sales in Houston surged after the cease-fire. Sears, Roebuck & Company is seeing more traffic in its stores. Travel to domestic and foreign destinations is picking up, spurred by bargains and giveaways.
Surfboard sales are up at Bruce Jones Surfboards in Los Angeles. Plastic surgery has picked up in Dr. J. Bradford Fisher's office in Fullerton, Calif. And in Manhattan, demand has "gone through the roof" the past two weeks for Elizabeth Arden's Miracle Morning, a $175 package of services that include a facial, makeup application, manicure and cucumber sandwich, said David Fairbrother, Arden's general manager.
Leigh Martin, the manager of Jones Surfboards, said: "People were dealing with the burden of not being sure how long the war was going to drag on, and now there's nothing to watch on CNN anymore, so they're starting to come out and buy things again."
 
People Still Have to Drive
 Automobile sales are way off, but Marion and Leo Brenner, a retired couple from Wilmington, Del., still were shopping for a car in the Winner Lincoln-Mercury dealership in southwest Philadelphia. "We just needed a new car, with or without the gulf war," Mrs. Brenner said.
But Howard Holniker, a Winner salesman, said a flood of customers came with war's end. "The two weeks after the war were our best in four or five months," he said. "Traffic through here tripled."
Other consumer experts say the consumer has not yet spoken. "There is no surprise that the very large positive reaction to the end of the war could not be sustained, but the real issue is how much of that gain in consumer confidence will be maintained," said Dr. Richard T. Curtin, who takes monthly samples of consumer attitudes at the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.
"I think I'm a typical consumer," said Richard Heslin, a professor of psychology with a specialty in consumer behavior at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind. "My two daughters got married this year, and I'm just starting to pull back from credit card disaster. I am determined to pay cash for my next car, and I may only have enough to buy a 4-year-old one.
"The country is feeling good about the war. I'm feeling good about it, but I still can't afford a new car."

HEADLINE: Cuts, but Also Promise, in Mental Health Spending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Many states trying to close budget gaps this year are cutting expenditures for the most helpless and stigmatized populations -- the mentally ill and the retarded. But while the cuts are causing a great deal of anguish among patients and families, this seems to be one of the rare cases in which less spending holds the promise of more service later.
In many states the financial problems are accomplishing what state officials have not had the political muscle to do for many years: overcome opposition from unions and local officials to close underused state mental hospitals, clinics and schools. 
 State officials say that by closing such institutions they can save huge amounts of money and then serve many more patients through expansions of community-based services.
 
Opportunity to Improve
 "The fiscal problems provide an opportunity to improve programs, and most state agencies look at it that way," said Harry C. Schnibbe, executive director of the National Association of State Mental Health Program Directors in Washington.
For years entrenched opposition has forced states to come up with the money to keep the old state institutions open even as thousands of patients were shifted to the care of smaller community-based centers. In many states the cost of operating the institutions limited the states' abilities to finance the community programs and forced many mentally ill people onto the streets or into jails.
But the financial crises many states are now facing have changed the climate.
An outstanding example is Michigan, whose budget gap has forced a 9 percent cut in nearly all departmental budgets. The Department of Mental Health was forced to cut $88 million out of its $915 million budget.
"The budget crunch provided the stimulus to close four state hospitals," said Thomas G. DeLoach, a department spokesman. Two were hospitals for mentally ill children. Together the two cost $12.5 million a year to operate, have 240 workers and serve fewer than 50 children.
"Without the extra push of economic reality it would have continued to be an enormous struggle to close these hospitals," Mr. DeLoach said. "Everybody had their parochial interest in maintaining the status quo and it seemed like at every step of the process, another group would oppose the closing.

 
Legislatures Take a Role
 In all, Michigan plans to lay off 1,200 mental health workers and transfer 400 patients to community residences and other state and community hospitals. More Draconian cuts were averted recently when the Legislature agreed to reconsider the department's budget, and the Legislature is now expected to restore about half of the initial cuts, or about $45 million.
New York, pressed by a $6 billion budget gap this year, has announced similar steps, including the closing of four of its 22 underused state hospitals. Like most other states, New York spends about 70 percent of its mental health budget on institutions even though 70 percent of the mentally ill are in the community.
"I would be crying like you wouldn't believe if we had to take these cuts without improving our outpatient services to the mentally ill homeless and without the expansion of 4,000 new community residence beds in the next two years," said Richard C. Surles, New York's Commissioner of the State Office of Mental Health. The state spends more per capita on mental health than any other state -- $140 a year compared to $37 by California, for example.
Mental health experts generally applaud efforts to focus mental health care in such centers, rather than in state hospitals, but some worry deeply about the immediate budget reductions and inevitable disruptions in care.
"It goes without saying that the cuts in mental health programs will be devastating," said Dr. Allan I. Leshner, acting director of the National Institute of Mental Health. He said public spending on mental health programs, totaling $20 billion a year, must be increased to make up for sharp limits placed by insurance companies on medical and disability benefits related to mental illness.
Laurie M. Flynn, executive director of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, an advocacy group, in Washington, said she hoped some good would come of the budget reductions, but she added, "Until we see the other shoe drop, I don't see this as a net gain for mental health services."
 
Some Cuts Difficult
 Rhode Island, for example, which has one of the nation's top ranked mental health systems, has only one state mental hospital still in operation, making it difficult for the state to make any large cuts in institutional spending. Donald P. Galamaga, executive director of the state's Mental Health Management Services, said the department has laid off 200 employees and put others on periodic one-day furloughs.
The state's budget gap also threatens next year's plan to open 30 group homes for the mentally retarded. That possibility upsets William and Ella Romer, who live in Warwick, R.I., with their severely retarded daughter, Caroline, 49 years old. The Romers say they have been trying to place her in a group home for many years. "We want to make sure that when we go, Caroline is taken care of," said Mrs. Romer. She is 76 years old and Mr. Romer is 81.
Massachusetts, with its now well-known budget woes, is going a step further than many other states. The state plans to transfer 400 to 500 patients from state hospitals to new beds in residential programs and to consolidate state hospitals and transfer some patients to private hospitals in the community. Keeping such patients in general hospitals is cheaper than keeping them in state hospitals because the Federal Government, under Medicaid, picks up half the bill.
Sweeping proposals by the states have generated a lot of debate in the mental health community, which is both fearful of change and desperate for it. "I'm optimistic, but it is too early to judge what will take place," said Dan E. Weisburd, president of the California chapter of the Alliance for the Mentally Ill, based in Los Angeles.
In Michigan the cutbacks in services at state institutions are being balanced somewhat by proposed increases in spending for community mental health programs. Gov. John Engler has proposed an increase of $41 million, or 12.7 percent, in the $366 million budget for such programs in the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
"Because we are strapped financially, we can no longer fund both an institutional approach and a community-based approach to mental health care," said Governor Engler, a Republican who took office in January with a pledge to reduce programs and taxes. "Funding two separate systems, to please the advocates of each, has not worked," he added.
Mental health professionals generally support the Governor's proposals, but for many families with immediate problems the promise of future changes has little meaning.
Denise Kusc said she is "horrified" by the planned closing next month of York Woods Center, one of two children's hospitals being closed, in Ypsilanti. Ms. Kusc, whose 14-year-old daughter, Rachel, is a patient at York Woods, joined other families, advocates and unions in a lawsuit to force the state to keep open all four of the hospitals in the closing plan.
In an affidavit that she filed with the Ingham County Circuit Court, a state trial court in Lansing, Ms. Kusc said that Rachel had been severely ill for several years. "There was one afternoon when she harmed herself terribly by mutilating one of her breasts," Ms. Kusc said. "Sending my daughter home in April would be devastating for both of us. Transferring her to another hospital would interrupt her treatment that is going so well."
On Feb. 25, Circuit Court Judge Peter D. Houk rejected the plaintiffs' arguments in favor of the state's plan to close the hospitals. "The testimony presented at the hearing," he wrote in his opinion, "convinces the Court that the hospitals where patients will be transferred are, for the most part, well run and that the services provided are of a superior nature."

HEADLINE: The World;
Latin Armies Are Looking for Work

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO , Uruguay

 BODY:
WITH civilian governments now the rule rather than the exception, Latin America's armies have to find new things to do. Counterinsurgency operations against foreign-supported guerrillas, a unifying mission since the 1950's, have faded with the decay of Cuba and the Soviet Union. Border disputes, long a pretext for maintaining standing armies, are increasingly papered over in the name of regional economic integration. And the idea of ruling the country seems to have lost its appeal.
So the armies, many with shrinking budgets, are now grappling to define their mission in the 1990's. Some of them have accepted Washington's offer of aid and training in return for joining the war on cocaine. Others are practicing the capitalism they long preached by running profitable businesses like transport companies, uniform manufacturers and gold mines. 
 But the military's centuries-old role of political arbiter of last resort -- or coup maker -- is never far from discourse.
"Is today's civilian rule the deepening of a trend, or is this just a phase in a long alternating cycle of civil and military rule?" asked Louis W. Goodman, dean of the School of International Service of American University, a sponsor of a recent conference here on civil-military relations.
The United States, which has often supported Latin American military regimes, is now firmly on the side of democracy and civilian rule. Last December, President Bush toured Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay -- all recently emerged from military rule -- and spoke glowingly of the world's first "hemisphere of democracy."
In the new civilian systems, the military has become just one more lobbying group, competing with political parties, unions and businesses to influence government budgets and policies. In this environment, military men are scrambling to find useful work to defend their budgets.
"Army engineers are building roads, schools and bridges in remote places," Anibal Rejis Romero, a Paraguayan general, said. "We are preparing the infrastructure for agrarian reform settlements."
To strengthen the foundations of civilian rule, several speakers cited the need to break down the barriers between the military and civilian worlds. "We cannot ignore that the distance between the civilian world and the military world in Chile dates back more than half a century," said Arturo Frei, a centrist Chilean senator.
Civilian politicians see military issues as a political dead end, said Julio Maria Sanguinetti, who was President of Uruguay in the late 1980's. "If you get a group of Latin American politicians together in a room and ask, 'Who wants to be foreign minister?' everyone will wave his or her hand in the air," said Mr. Sanguinetti, whose presidency ended a long period of military rule in Uruguay. "But if you ask, 'Who wants to be defense minister?' everyone stares at the floor."
In several South American nations, civilian rule has meant economic shrinkage and reduction of defense budgets. In Argentina, which returned to civilian rule in 1983 but has faced a number of military revolts, the latest in December, the number of army conscripts has fallen from a traditional level of 50,000 a year to about 10,000 today.
"The whole budget is shrinking, so we also have to shrink," said an Argentine Army colonel.
In Argentina, where military-owned companies produce petrochemicals, iron ore and light arms, among other things, the congress is preparing to privatize 21 of these businesses -- about half. Each service would be allowed to keep sales earnings for its own budget.
In neighboring Brazil, which returned to civilian rule in 1985 after 20 years of military governments, military salaries have fallen far behind the 400 percent annual inflation. Last week the Army Minister, Gen. Carlos Tinoco, complained, "A general with 40 years of service is earning the same salary as a driver for congress."
 
A Different Kind of Shot
 Making a pitch for more money in a full-page article in Brazil's largest selling newsweekly, Veja, Air Minister Socrates da Costa Monteiro listed the military's civic action work: road building, river patrols in the Amazon, vaccination campaigns and air traffic control. He did not make any requests for the traditional and costly defense apparatus -- tank units, air wings, submarines and an aircraft carrier -- to protect Brazil from invaders.
 But in the Andean nations of Colombia and Peru, the military does not have to search far for enemies. Despite the decline of Cuba and the Soviet Union, Marxist guerrilla groups fight on, two in Colombia and two in Peru. Even without outside inspiration or aid, the region's economic underclass and ethnic minorities are expected to continue to seek political gain through the force of arms. "Even if you take away the Communist threat, the tremendous social inequality remains," said Johanna Mendelson Forman, director of Democracy Projects for American University.
With the United States no longer giving counterinsurgency military aid to any country in South America, anti-drug aid is often seen as the only way to go for cash-strapped armies. Last week, for example, under heavy United States pressure and in exchange for aid, Bolivia announced that two light infantry battalions are to start patrols against cocaine refining laboratories next month.
The move is opposed by many politicians, unionists and church leaders, in Bolivia and elsewhere. "There is the problem of corruption," said Hugo Medina, a retired commander in chief of Uruguay's armed forces. "And then, you can't take a unit of soldiers and tell them to act like policemen."
Another factor is rapid moves toward regional economic integration. On Tuesday the presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay are to sign an agreement for a Southern Cone Common Market. And newspapers in Buenos Aires reported that diplomats are working on a regional security treaty.
"In Europe, there was first NATO, then the Common Market," said Carlos Maria Lezcano, a Paraguayan defense analyst. "Here it is the reverse. We will have economic integration, then military integration."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
For Communities, Knowledge of Polluters is Power

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LAST month the New Orleans Times Picayune, Louisiana's most influential newspaper, called the American Cyanamid plant 20 miles upriver "the single largest polluting plant in the state." In October, the Louisiana Environmental Action Network, a Baton Rouge-based coalition of citizens groups, designated American Cyanamid its "polluter of the month," criticizing the company for being responsible for a quarter of the 740 million pounds of toxic chemicals discharged into Louisiana's environment in 1988.
How did the newspaper and the environmental group know so much about American Cyanamid's toxic-waste record? They had access to its discharge data as a result of a five-year-old Federal law, the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act, which requires manufacturers to report the total amount of each of some 330 toxic chemicals that have been released into the air, water and land. 
 The data, reported to the Environmental Protection Agency and to states, are listed in the annual Toxics Release Inventory, a compendium of the country's leading toxic-waste dischargers -- and a powerful tool for pressuring factories to reduce pollution.
"It's been very empowering for local people to know who's polluting and to hold these polluters accountable," said Mary Lee Orr, director of the Louisiana Environmental Action Network.
"I don't want to leave the impression that we didn't have these priorities in the past," said James F. Dutcher, a spokesman at the Louisiana American Cyanamid plant. "But there is much more public pressure for us to reduce discharges, and we are reducing them."
But environmentalists say the law has weaknesses. Some dangerous chemicals, among them radioactive substances and the insecticide malathion, are missing from the list. In some cases, a loophole enables manufacturers to circumvent the need to report toxic emissions. Small businesses are exempt from filing a report altogether.
 
Prompted by Bhopal
 The Community Right to Know Act, prompted by the deaths of thousands in a 1984 chemical disaster in Bhopal, India, was approved despite a desperate lobbying campaign by manufacturers, opposition by the White House and public denouncements by the most powerful lawmakers in Congress, who thought the bill would prove to be too much of an onus on industry.
"It was a philosophical leap of faith," said Representative Gerry Sikorski, the Democrat from Minnesota who sponsored the proposal in Congress, "kind of a heartfelt belief that people in communities have an absolute, fundamental right to know what goes into the air their kids breathe, the water they drink and the ground they play on."
Industrial executives and environmental groups agree that the law's most important contribution has been to cause companies to recognize the extent of their discharges and the effect they may have on public health.
The first inventory, published by the E.P.A. in 1989, showed that releases of toxic chemicals totaled billions of pounds in 1987. Some of the nation's largest companies later responded with voluntary programs to reduce such pollution. A.T.&T., for example, said it would stop all emissions of the listed chemicals into the air by the turn of the century.
After the second inventory was made public in 1990, the E.P.A. asked more than 600 companies to cut in half voluntarily emissions of the 17 most dangerous toxic chemicals, including benzene, cyanide, mercury and chromium, by 1995. "If we succeed," said William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the E.P.A., "this program could set the pace for a new cooperative way of addressing the nation's environmental goals."
The law has galvanized small citizens groups. According to a report in Working Notes, a newsletter in Washington that tracks the use of the law, an environmental group in northern California raised concerns last year about the storage and use of chlorine in treating cooling water at a Chevron refinery in Richmond. Chevron stopped using the chemical at that plant last December.
The Raytheon Company pledged in December that it would use safer water-based solutions to clean computer circuit boards after a group in Massachusetts criticized the company's use of chemicals that deplete the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere.
Despite its growing ability to influence environmental struggles throughout the country, the right-to-know law has flaws, said Paul Orum, editor of Working Notes. Any business with nine or fewer employees is exempted from reporting discharges. And an estimate by a congressional research group, the Office of Technology Assessment, said emissions from these sources could total billions of pounds.
In a report released earlier this month, Mr. Orum and three co-authors said that companies have disposed of at least 200 million pounds of toxic chemicals under the recycling exemption while sidestepping reporting requirements. "This loophole is undermining the law because it allows companies to claim waste reductions when, in fact, they aren't reducing pollution at all," Mr. Orum said.
Few states have reacted to the right-to-know law as aggressively as Louisiana, which has some of the worst environmental problems in the country. Four plants by themselves, including American Cyanamid, Shell, and two owned by Freeport McMoRan, discharged 460 million pounds of toxic chemicals in 1988, more than all the plants in Ohio and nearly three times as much as those in New Jersey. The state Department of Environmental Quality called in the three companies and other top toxic-waste dischargers in the state and demanded that they establish plans to reduce emissions.
Since its plant opened 20 miles from New Orleans in the early 1950's, American Cyanamid has disposed of most of its toxic wastes by pumping them into a well 3,000 feet underground. Some 75 billion pounds of chemicals have been injected underground. The disposal method was certified as safe in November by the E.P.A., but Louisiana has sought for several years to close the well because of concern that chemicals will contaminate ground water.
Mr. Dutcher, the plant spokesman, said last week that 750 jobs and a nearly $25 million annual payroll could be at stake if the plant was forced to change its disposal practices.
Louisiana, which has a $900 million deficit and an array of economic ills, took note. When American Cyanamid submitted its plan last year to reduce the discharging of toxic waste into the well by 17 percent, state officials deemed the proposal "satisfactory."

HEADLINE: The World;
As the Dust Settles, Attention Turns to New Arms Sales

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT war's end, and with a potentially chaotic peace ahead in the Middle East, the Bush Administration made clear last week that it was preparing to arm its friends in the region against a sea of trouble.
After forceful pledges this month by both President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to work toward reducing the flow of conventional arms and defense technology to the region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney last week seemed to adjust the Administration's course. He gave the most detailed explanation to date of the emerging policy on arms and security, which can be boiled down to this: arms for America's friends and arms control for its potential foes. 
 In laying out the rationale, Mr. Cheney said the first order of business in the Persian Gulf must be the security of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other gulf Arab states to make the region safe for an American withdrawal. Then, the United States must cooperate with other industrialized nations to stem the flow of critical technologies that advance the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, along with the long-range missiles to deliver them.
That is the security imperative Mr. Cheney described.
The political imperative, articulated by other senior officials, was that America's allies, those who stood up against Saddam Hussein, must be seen as the clear winners in a region that respects power and performance. Therefore, the winners must receive tangible rewards. But there was also an economic imperative, which left the Administration with a scarcity of funds or other economic benefits to offer.
What Mr. Bush could offer, however, was something devoutly wished by many developing nations: access to America's arms and technology bazaar. And for those who couldn't afford to shop, the Administration was asking Congress to guarantee credits for cash-strapped allies at the Export-Import Bank. In that way, American defense contractors would not lose business to European nations that subsidize weapons sales abroad.
Many members of Congress, who had hoped that Mr. Bush's new world order was going to make a new and stronger effort to restrain the Middle East arms race alongside the new peace process that Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker say they want, were disappointed.
To some members, it seemed a cynical exercise that on the plains of victory, the Administration would sow the seeds of future militarism, arming to the teeth the lightly populated desert kingdoms and emirates along with some of their newfound protectors, whose blossoming arsenals would only spur Israel to outdistance them further and perhaps incite Iran to rearm more quickly and send Syria on a new arms spree in Moscow.
For their part, the Soviets seemed to recognize -- then shrink from -- the old instincts of the superpower rivalry that has fueled the arms race in the Middle East for four decades. Moscow's Foreign Minister and its delegate to the United Nations both called on Washington to agree to a period of restraint in the Middle East, but Mr. Cheney argued this would effectively serve as a disloyal arms "embargo" against America's friends.
With the State Department forging ahead with a sale of 46 General Dynamics F-16 jets to Cairo, part of a package long in the pipeline, the resumption of arms transfers was a reminder of the resource drain they would have on some of Washington's economically strained allies, notably Egypt and Israel, at a time when major challenges of population, immigration, water resources and economic restructuring lie ahead.
Mr. Bush has already forgiven Egypt's $7.1 billion military debt, and the new signals of a return to business as usual come as Egypt's unreformed economy continues to collapse. If Egypt, at peace with Israel, cannot rechannel its resources away from arms, who can?
 
Outfitting a Policeman
 The United States has been trying to find and outfit a policeman in the Persian Gulf since the Nixon Administration, when the Shah of Iran was given the keys to the American arsenal. The newest policeman is a collective: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait leading the Gulf Cooperation Council states (Bahrain, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates), plus Egypt and Syria.
The Bush Administration is seeking a postwar security arrangement built on a presence for the United States Central Command, according to Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. With Arab ground forces armed mostly by the United States, the Central Command will be able to take part in, if not supervise, an alliance built around the Arab allies who fought Iraq. They will be backed by an expanded United States naval presence with greater access to Arab ports, and by regular deployments of American fighter wings and ground troops for visits and exercises.
In a matter of weeks, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the Central Command, will submit a blueprint for the new alliance, including a forecast of the level of armaments it will need.
Part of the pressure on the Administration to back away from controlling arms sales in the region may be simply that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are clinging to the presence of 440,000 American troops, whose departure would require the Arab leaders to come to grips with their future relations with Saddam Hussein, still armed and increasingly desperate in Baghdad. Senator Joseph Biden, Democrat of Delaware, said a "top national security council official" told him Americans should "not be overambitious" in seeking Middle East arms control, and that "defense cooperation will provide far more security than arms control."
But the window for arms control in the Middle East may remain open for some time. The Saudis, while not eager for the American army to leave, are also not in any hurry to plow billions into new arms purchases. Neither are the Kuwaitis, who face a daunting rebuilding task. The gulf Arabs certainly are hoping that a peace process, both on the Arab-Israeli front and in the Persian Gulf, will relieve them of some of the defense burdens ahead.
 
One Less Worry
 In an interview Friday, General Powell almost begged the question of whether there is a future military threat in the area that requires large forces. "There will not be a fourth largest army headed by Mr. Saddam Hussein in 1995," he said. "Perhaps one of the fortunate aspects of this entire unfortunate war is that it came at this time when we did have the capability to deal rather handily with the fourth largest army in the world."
Some pressure for new arms sales can be expected from defense contractors, who face a big contraction in United States spending for the rest of the decade. Without foreign orders for the M1-A1 tank, General Dynamics might have to shut down its production lines in Michigan and Ohio before the Army finds the money in the late 1990's to design a new main battle tank. And if McDonnell-Douglas, Lockheed, Northrop, Grumman and General Dynamics don't win their share of warplane sales to the Pentagon in this decade, foreign sales may be the only thing that can keep their production lines open.
These are big commercial interests that mean tens of thousands of jobs in the United States, and any arms control movement in Congress will run into countervailing pressures to sell. Advocates of arms control also will be hard pressed to oppose what appear to be legitimate security needs for defensive systems, such as air defense, anti-missile protection and interceptor aircraft.
In the final analysis, however, the arms race in the Middle East has never been more than a symptom of the intractible political and diplomatic problems that plague the region. There can be no farewell to arms while strong currents of Shiite fundamentalism seek to violently carve their channels across the Muslim world and while Palestinian nationalists fight to win a homeland against Israel's struggle for recognition and security.
The greatest stimulus to arms control, therefore, will be an active peace process between Israel and the Arabs and, in the Persian Gulf, among Iraq, Iran and the Arabian potentates.

HEADLINE: The World;
Yugoslavia Finds That Breaking Up Is Hard to Do

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
YUGOSLAVIA'S six republics are like people mired in a disintegrating marriage. They hurl insults and scream divorce so often, even casual acquaintances conclude the union will not last. But when they visit the lawyers and calculate the costs of splitting up, they return, reluctantly, to the marriage counselors.
So it was last week, which began with the de facto secession by Serbia, the largest republic, and ended with a resumption of talks among the republics over the future of this multi-ethnic country. 
 For the past few months the Yugoslavs have seemed bent on convincing the world, and each other, that theirs is a country on the verge of dissolution. The republics have refused to pay taxes to the federal government, moved closer to legal secession and formed their own militias. Croatia and Slovenia even designed new currencies.
Among the many people who found these steps persuasive were American intelligence analysts: they recently said they believed that Yugoslavia would fall apart within 18 months.
Many officials in Yugoslavia's republics now privately say their bellicose actions are a bit deceiving. The renewed stirring of national pride within the ethnically diverse republics is real enough, they say. But officials acknowledge that most of the daily maneuvering is political theater, aimed at influencing negotiations that could well end with Yugoslavia remaining together, though with much looser ties.
"It's like a cold war between two bullocks butting heads," said Darko Bekic, an adviser to the President of Croatia, Franjo Tudjman. "There's a consciousness on both sides that this is not Lithuania, it's the Balkans. The hatred and degree of armament is formidable. If war really starts, you'd have 5,000 deaths in the first 24 hours."
The events of the last week are evidence of the republics' willingness both to lock horns and to pull back from confrontation.
Last weekend Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's leader, mobilized local militia and announced that his republic no longer recognized the authority of the nation's federal executive body. Bolislav Jovic, the Serb who heads the eight-member federal body, followed with his own resignation, as did two other members. Croatia, the second largest republic, put its paramilitary forces on alert.
Western nations weighed in with stern warnings. Meanwhile, the Croats refused to be drawn into combat with a breakaway group of Serbs within Croatia who announced their own secession.
By Thursday, leaders of the republics were gathering in Belgrade for renewed discussions. Mr. Jovic withdrew his resignation. The army promised not to interfere with the talks, although with the ambiguous proviso that it would prevent "armed inter-ethnic conflicts" and defend the existing borders. The latter was interpreted as a pointed warning against secession by any republic.
On the surface, life returned to the edgy semi-anarchy that passes for normal in this fractured nation. In fact, the week has clarified some important issues. It now seems clear that the army is unwilling to settle the disputes among the republics unilaterally. The presidents of the two republics that have shouted the loudest about breaking away, Slovenia and Croatia, were the first to push for talks aimed at preserving unity.
The most significant development, however, was the continued weakening in the position of Mr. Milosevic, the former Communist who was elected to the Serbian presidency last year with pledges to support Serbian nationalism and oppose swift transition to a free-market economy.
Last year's elections in Croatia and Slovenia were won by nationalist anti-Communists who promise rapid privatization and the creation of a market economy. They believe Serbia's insistence on retaining key elements of the Communist economic system will drag Yugoslavia to ruin.
Slovenia and Croatia say they also oppose the current federal system of government because Serbia, as the largest republic, has the decisive voice on such important questions as the size of the army.
The two republics have been pressing for a loose alliance of sovereign nations that would collaborate on a few issues, such as national defense and, perhaps, a currency. Until now, Serbia has demanded that Yugoslavia keep the existing arrangement.
These seemingly irreconcilable differences created an impasse that persisted as long as Mr. Milosevic retained tight hold on the media, the Parliament, and other traditional Communist instruments of power in Serbia. In addition, his strident nationalism continually reinforced the nationalist sentiments in the other republics, particularly Croatia.
But earlier this month, Mr. Milosevic was damaged, perhaps fatally, by the rise of a popular anti-Communist movement in his republic. The first demonstrations left two dead and scores hurt and were not put down until army tanks rolled through Belgrade. For the first time in his career as Serbian leader, and before that Communist Party chief, Mr. Milosevic found himself furiously backpedaling. He agreed to dismiss the senior management of state-run television and released opposition politicians jailed after the protests.
The reclusive Mr. Milosevic even held a four-hour session with a handpicked group of students and professors at Belgrade University.
With the next big demonstration scheduled in Belgrade for next Wednesday, the Slovenes and Croats reason that Mr. Milosevic is finally ready to talk seriously about rewriting the 1974 constitution. But they also fear that this is the perfect moment for the Serbs to stir up new ethnic unrest that could force the army's generals to intervene.
"In think Milosevic will go, but it will take some time," said Srdja Popovic, a well known human rights lawyer in Belgrade. "There may be more violence, things of that kind. There has to be a lot more pressure before anything happens."

HEADLINE: The Region;
With a Final Jolt, New York's Budget Gap Is Open to Its Widest -- For Now

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
AFTER weeks of warnings by assorted Cassandras that the earth was opening beneath New York City's budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins officially acknowledged that it had last week, conceding that the total gap in the $29 billion budget for the coming fiscal year would top $3 billion.
That new estimate is more than $800 million above the projection Mr. Dinkins made when he released his preliminary budget just eight weeks ago, but it was hardly a surprise. Proposed cuts in state aid and rising costs had made it clear that the budget was out of whack again, continuing a pattern of fiscal troubles that the Mayor said had "become the defining reality of our government." 
 So when will the bad news end?
"That's very heady stuff, and you're never right," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "You know the story about the 6-foot economist who drowned in a river that was on average 5 feet deep."
But if the Dinkins administration hews to the broad plan it set out last week -- much of it drawn directly from the administration's varied critics -- it might have a chance of dealing with the bad news in new ways. The Mayor held a daylong meeting with business, labor and civic leaders and his own commissioners to knock heads and announce that it was time to work together, something those groups had been begging him to do.
Mr. Dinkins also said -- for what some of his second-guessers thought was the first time -- that the city's problems were bigger than the latest pieces of bad news and required more than the usual mix of higher taxes and spending cuts. He had already proposed more than $1 billion in taxes and $1.2 billion in service cuts and productivity savings to close the gap before last week's announcement. The reality, he suggested, is that for some years the city has been spending more than it could afford and big changes were necessary.
Just how big those changes will be remains to be seen. As a start, Mr. Dinkins said the city would seek major concessions from its union workforce, trying in some cases to take back gains the unions just won in wage settlements granted by Mr. Dinkins. If that happens, the administration said, it might be able to avoid much of the more than $800 million in threatened cuts, which could be devastating. If those were made, the Sanitation Department would have trimmed 33 percent of its budget since last fall, for example, and the Parks Department 37 percent.
At the unions' request, Mr. Dinkins agreed that both sides should keep silent about the substance of their talks, to avoid the embarrassing leaks, lurches, mixed signals and mutual recriminations that have dominated so much of the last year at City Hall.
"I think this was a very good week for the Mayor," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who only two weeks ago said the administration was so confused it was "going into the toilet."
"Without talking about what we did at our meeting," Mr. Feinstein added, "it's clear to me and, I think, my colleagues that what the Mayor said a week or 10 days ago about putting his hands on the city and running it, clearly he's doing. Now whether I'm happy or not about what he wants is not the issue. All of us have the view that it's important to deal with our city's problems."
The Mayor will have an uphill fight, and union leaders make it clear they are not ready to give back anything yet. But that Mr. Feinstein struck such a conciliatory note was a sign that Mr. Dinkins had finally presented his problem with a comprehensive carrot-and-stick approach that gave the unions a way to prepare their members for the probability that something would have to give.
For much of his first 15 months in office, Mr. Dinkins has been whipsawed by the competing demands of the liberal-labor coalition that elected him and a business-financial establishment skeptical of his ability and resolve, and he has striven to mediate between them. Asked last week if he could get through the problem without angering someone, he said: "No, no, for sure. There are some people who are angry now, before we get to this last billion." Asked if there were things he would have done differently, knowing what he knows now, the Mayor said, "There probably are, but I'm not going to examine and enumerate them, because frankly we're still in this process."
There were signs that the Mayor was willing to take his lumps. In a meeting with social-service advocates last week, one senior mayoral aide said Mr. Dinkins reminded them with some asperity that "he could stand on the street and talk about dying babies as well as they could," but did not have enough money to do all that needed to be done.
The Mayor said he hoped social-service groups, which played an important role in his campaign, could give him room to maneuver. "It's not enough for the activists, the advocates, the service providers simply to speak about what they need in their own areas," he said. "I agree with them about that. But I have the responsibility to look at the total picture, and when one does that you have to order priorities and make judgments."
One businessman who often advises the Mayor said he thought Mr. Dinkins had recently "internalized" a deeper understanding of how the fiscal problems could overwhelm him if he did not master them, and of how only by mastering them could he succeed politically. But undoubtedly the hardest part is still to come.
"The challenge is to carry through on the right steps they've taken," said Ronald Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry. "I think the Mayor has to be the leader, and we all have to be around the table. He has to lead it, and he's taken the first steps."
The full force of the city's budget problems occurred months after the beginning of the regional economic downturn that helped drive them. Similarly, most economists say, an economic revival will not by itself solve those problems, even if it happens by next year, as the more optimistic forecasters suggest.
"I think they'll have two years of struggle to cut back jobs on the city workforce," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "It's never easy to grapple with a budget that seems to be sliding out from under you. But it doesn't last forever, even at that."
For his part, Mr. Dinkins says he intends to be around when better times return. Last week, he got a gift from his old friend Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, a small plaque that reads, "I consider the day lost if I don't catch hell about something."
"I've taken this off my wall," Mr. Rangel wrote. "Right now, you need it more than I do, and I hope soon we can both pass it on to someone."

HEADLINE: The Damage Was Not Collateral

 BODY:
The first independent assessment of the damage done to Iraq by allied bombing has painted a grim picture of catastrophic devastation. A United Nations team described the effects of the bombing as "near apocalyptic," knocking Iraq back "to a pre-industrial age."
The facts may not quite support the hyperbole, but the assessment has cast the bomb damage in a new light. The bulk of the damage found by the U.N. team was not accidental or "collateral," but the intended consequence of the successful air campaign to destroy Iraq's war machine by attacking its industrial base and urban infrastructure. 
 The findings raise questions about how much of that bombing was needed, or justified. That debate will go on, but meanwhile there is urgent need to respond to the devastation in Iraq. The U.N. Security Council recognized this when it eased sanctions to allow for humanitarian aid.
The Council was right to stop short of scrapping the sanctions. It is decidedly not in U.S. interests to alienate the Iraqi people permanently or to let the poorest Iraqis suffer interminably. But any relaxation must be measured. Economic sanctions remain the only way to pressure Iraq to destroy its remaining chemical and biological capabilities and to give up its nuclear ambitions. The best way to satisfy these competing objectives is to provide the necessities of life and disaster relief, but maintain a partial embargo until Iraq disarms further.
The U.N. team found that "most means of modern life support have been destroyed or rendered tenuous," including food supply, power generation, water purification, garbage disposal, sewage treatment and other essentials.
Was the bombing of Iraq important to the outcome of the war? The air force continues to believe in strategic bombing, striking targets in the enemy homeland that, broadly construed, affect military capacity: power plants, telephone exchanges, broadcast antennas, roads and bridges.
In air force doctrine, strategic bombing can compel surrender, without a ground war, by destroying industry and infrastructure and by sapping the enemy's will to resist. But bombing city targets did not make Saddam Hussein capitulate. Bombing Iraqi forces in the Kuwaiti theater of operations had a more decisive effect, causing the mass defection and surrender of Iraqi troops.
The air force devoted almost a third of its sorties to striking cities -- with predictably deplorable results for civilians. The U.N. report quotes Iraqi estimates that 9,000 homes were destroyed, leaving some 72,000 people homeless. How many civilians died is not known.
Some of the destruction was caused by wayward bombs. Based on Air Force figures, 70 percent of the bombs dropped in the war missed their targets. Even precision-guided bombs missed their targets 10 percent of the time.
Now the allies are, wisely, moving to mitigate the bombing's effects. While Washington is right to keep pressure on Baghdad to disarm, the U.S. has no interest in prolonging the misery of the Iraqi people. That could lead to the disintegration of Iraq and greater instability in the region.
Oil exports and arms imports must remain prohibited, but humanitarian aid can safely be provided. Food and disaster relief from Americans and the allies could help get the Iraqis back on their feet. That would be the humane thing to do. It could also be prudent.

HEADLINE: A Better Reason to Expand I.R.A.'s

 BODY:
Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and more than 70 other senators are proposing to solve the nation's number one economic problem -- a 40 percent drop in the net national savings rate in the 1980's -- by expanding the use of individual retirement accounts.
Mr. Bentsen's plan would reinstate the right, taken away by the 1986 tax reform, of upper-income workers covered by company pension plans to deposit up to $2,000 tax free into an I.R.A. It would also allow withdrawals for the purchase of a first home, college tuition and medical catastrophe. And the plan would create a Super I.R.A., which would provide no up-front deduction but would exempt interest from taxes as long as contributions were kept on deposit for at least five years. 
 Mr. Bentsen's plan won't be enough to turn the savings rate around. But the Super I.R.A. is an imaginative wrinkle that might attract savers. That alone makes his plan worth trying.
Even before I.R.A.'s were cut back, they did not spur much new saving. Too few families deposited money; some who did merely shuffled funds from taxable accounts. That doesn't raise private savings and, by raising the deficit, actually decreases public savings. On balance, national savings might have increased, but probably not by much.
One of the reasons few individuals joined the program was the penalty for early withdrawals, before age 59 1/2. Young workers with modest incomes couldn't be sure that an emergency wouldn't arise. That's why Mr. Bentsen's Super I.R.A., which doesn't lock in funds for more than a few years, might prove more attractive.
Other than lowering the deficit, Washington doesn't have many ways to boost savings. Besides, Mr. Bentsen's plan wouldn't widen the deficit, because the new budget law effectively requires Congress to raise some other tax to make up for the loss to the Treasury. As long as Congress makes sure that the new taxes fall, roughly, on the same upper-income families that are likely to take advantage of the new I.R.A.'s, the Bentsen plan could do little harm. And it might do a little good. For an economy starved for savings, that is enough.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Arms Sales Heaven

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Syria, Egypt, Iraq and Turkey each have more main battle tanks than Britain or France. Syria, Iraq and Egypt each fly nearly as many combat aircraft as Germany or France or Britain.
 Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Saudi Arabia and Syria have purchased from abroad about $125 billion in arms since 1983. This accounts for more than half the worldwide arms trade. 
 Why are they doing this? Can President Bush do anything to bring the situation under control?
 These nations are not buying all those arms to fight for a Palestinian homeland. They treat Palestinians the way Americans treated Indians.
 Nor do they arm themselves so heavily because they think Israel will grab their territory or oil. Not even the most paranoid Arab fears that.
 There are two simple and powerful reasons for Mideast Muslims making their territories look more like arsenals than countries. First, most of them hate and distrust each other. They have killed hundreds of thousands of their brethren in wars over the last 40 years. Second, they hate Israel, and most would like to destroy it. Israel intruded into their established world and humiliated them in battle many times. Even today they know that Israel, itself an armed camp, could defeat any two of them simultaneously.
 These Arab states and Iran have very little incentive to accept limits on their arms purchases. They live in constant fear that one of their Muslim brothers will gain the upper hand and attack. Also, stopping the arms race would guarantee Israel's continued superiority in military technology and its monopoly in nuclear weapons. Thus the arms race spirals upward and the wars become more terrible.
 The arms exporters understand all this full well. But only on the rarest occasions have they denied arms requests from their oil suppliers. The industrialized world simply wants to keep the oil countries happy and buying arms to help offset the oil bills.
 No one understands this mutual dependency better than the Mideast oil producers, who also know that oil money is their best weapon against Israel.
 Israel cannot afford to compete with its neighbors in arms imports over the long run. It is already strapped with an enormous defense budget. That burden and the goal of keeping military superiority explain why Israel now calls for sharp cuts in arms exports to the Middle East.
To manage these eye-crossing interests and maneuvers over arms, the Bush Administration has developed the following approach:
* Ban sales of chemical, biological and nuclear arms and related know-how, and the long-range missiles capable of delivering such weapons.
(Reasonable, but many Mideast nations already have some of these capabilities. Also missile exporters -- North Korea and China, for example -- will not abide by limits.)
* Consider setting limits on sales of aircraft, tanks, artillery and smart missiles, but in the meantime sell what buyers want -- "to see to it that they're secure," as Defense Secretary Cheney put it.
(As long as other suppliers do not restrain their sales, there is no sense putting ourselves at a competitive disadvantage.)
* Argue that Iraq's defeat has diminished the biggest threat to all and that all can now safely buy less.
(A solid tactic, but the Administration already expects a substantial increase in demand from the victors.)
* Negotiate confidence-building measures like Arabs dropping their economic boycott against Israel and Israel providing better treatment for Palestinians.
(Sensible, but it will not reduce arms demands.)
* Seek peace settlements between Arabs and Israel and between Israel and the Palestinians.
(An essential ingredient for eventual arms restraint on the Arab-Israeli front, but it does not deal with the inter-Arab quarrels, which also trigger demands for arms.)
The Administration's plan is practical and realistic. Too much so.
It is weighed down by business-as-usual realism. There seems nothing in it to exploit the death of the Soviet threat and the diminished value of Soviet arms sales. It contains little to suggest building on the victorious anti-Iraq coalition molded by Mr. Bush -- or escaping the tragic history of Mideast arms races.
Mr. Bush is in a strong position to press other arms exporters for joint limits on sales and to link arms sales creatively with peace diplomacy. But to surmount this arms quagmire, he has to think bigger than his aides and put his new prestige on the line.

HEADLINE: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The sideshow that took command of New York City's St. Patrick's Day Parade this year stole from the Irish people the one day of the year when all eyes focus on the political, economic and human rights realities that beset their troubled homeland. 
 Headlines were dominated by comparatively frivolous goings-on among the Mayor's office, gays and lesbians -- whose expectations of fair and equal treatment no one questions -- and the parade organizers who were caught by surprise and thrown off stride, to say the least.
Where was the talk of Joe Doherty, now in his eighth year at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, a living symbol of justice miscarried? Or talk of the tens of thousands of young Irish immigrants now crowding our neighborhoods in Ridgewood, Queens, the Inwood section of Manhattan or the Bainbridge section of the Bronx, struggling to seize the American dream and put their skills and talents to work? Where was the talk of Gaelic Park and its fate under the Metropolitan Transportation Authority?
Where was the talk of human rights abuses against minority Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland? Their chronic unemployment? Their lack of due process? Federal implementation of the MacBride Principles of fair employment in Northern Ireland, that earned the Irish patriot Sean MacBride the Nobel Peace Prize?
It was lost in a verbal stew, all froth and no substance, that's where.
Next year, let's get it right. Let's give our attention and thanks to the thousands of men and women who commit themselves unselfishly to countless hours of hard labor 52 weeks a year on these priority issues in the Irish-American community.
When the chance to bring this agenda to the attention of our country and the world is telescoped into an annual 72-hour period, at best, let's hope that the focus will be squarely on the real issues and not the sideshow. St. Patrick, St. Patrick's Day and those committed to real Irish-American causes deserve much, much better treatment.
 
JOHN C. DEARIE
Assemblyman, 75th Dist.
Albany, March 19, 1991

HEADLINE: Utility Act Hampers Power Independents

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Independent power producers have over the last decade become this country's most efficient generators of electrical power. Independent studies estimate that the independent producers, which sell power to regulated utilities, will generate about half of new electric capacity in the next decade. More than a third of that will be produced by nonfossil energy sources, including biomass, solid waste, hydroelectric turbines, geothermal, wind and solar technologies. The remaining two-thirds is produced with innovative technology that primarily employs coal and natural gas. 
 Some experts say oil import fees or gasoline taxes are needed to wean America from foreign energy. Others have called for Federal subsidies to make alternative fuels such as methanol, wind and solar economically competitive. The independent producers are already competitive; their only need is the freedom to compete fairly in the marketplace.
Proposals pending in Congress and before the Bush Administration would give the independents that freedom by amending the 56-year-old Public Utility Holding Company Act, which makes it harder for these small producers to provide competitive and efficiently priced electrical power by imposing on them the same regulatory burdens applied to the country's big utilities.
Over the next decade, the United States will invest $100 billion to $200 billion in new electric generating capacity. Freeing the independents to produce this power could mean a 20 percent gain in efficiency, saving as much as $40 billion.
Creating a regulatory environment in which electricity can be produced in the most economically efficient fashion is a simple, straightforward and low-risk policy goal that should be part of any comprehensive energy strategy.
 
PAUL ELSTON
Washington, March 4, 1991
 
The writer, president of Long Lake Energy Corporation, New York, is vice chairman of the National Independent Energy Producers.
