HEADLINE: Harvard Finds a Replacement for Its President

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23

 BODY:
Neil L. Rudenstine, a 56-year-old scholar of Renaissance literature who is former provost of Princeton University, has been offered the presidency of Harvard University by the committee seeking a candidate to succeed Derek C. Bok.
 Friends and associates of Mr. Rudenstine, who is now executive vice president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, said he was expected to meet with Harvard's Board of Overseers on Sunday at a hastily called gathering in New York. At the meeting, the overseers are to appraise Mr. Rudenstine and he is to signal whether he will accept the job, his colleagues said. 
The overseers, one of Harvard's two governing bodies, are then to vote on the nomination at their next regular meeting in early April. The members of the other governing body, the Harvard Corporation, make up most of the search committee and have already interviewed Mr. Rudenstine at length.
 Mr. Bok will retire in June after 20 years as president.
 Mr. Rudenstine, who has homes in Manhattan and Princeton, did not return telephone calls seeking comment today. Harvard officials reached by telephone refused to comment.
 
One of Four Finalists
 Mr. Rudenstine had been reported to be one of four finalists for the presidency. The others were Martin S. Feldstein, a professor of economics at Harvard and a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Philip Leder, a prominent geneticist at the Harvard Medical School, and Gerhard Casper, the provost of the University of Chicago. Earlier this month, when the selection committee was reported to be having trouble choosing the next president, Henry Rosovsky, the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at Harvard and a member of the search committee, was said to be a possible compromise candidate.
 The choice of Mr. Rudenstine, first reported by The Harvard Crimson on Friday, would be somewhat unusual. He did not graduate from Harvard, though he received his Ph.D. there, and he has not taught there since 1968.
 He graduated summa cum laude from Princeton in 1956 and then spent three years at Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar before his doctoral studies in English literature at Harvard. He taught Renaissance literature at Harvard from 1964 to 1968 before returning to Princeton as a professor of English. There he rose rapidly through the ranks as an administrator, holding the posts of dean of students, dean of the college and then provost, Princeton's No. 2 job, for 10 years. He still teaches a popular freshman class on Shakespeare at Princeton.
 He was widely regarded as the logical successor to William G. Bowen, Princeton's president, when Mr. Bowen resigned in 1987 to become head of the Mellon Foundation, which concentrates on educational programs and, with assets of more than $1.8 billion at the end of 1989, is one of the nation's 10 wealthiest foundations. But Mr. Rudenstine surprised his colleagues when he elected to accompany Mr. Bowen to the Mellon Foundation.
 
'Knack for Leading'
 Friends say Mr. Rudenstine is a gentle, thoughtful man, and Princeton officials highly praised him today.
 "I've known Neil since he was an undergraduate, and I just think enormously highly of him," said Robert F. Goheen, the president of Princeton from 1957 to 1972.
 Carl Wartenburg, who was an assistant to Mr. Bowen when he was president and now is assistant to Princeton's current president, Harold T. Shapiro, said: "Neil would have been a very popular choice for president here. He is a man of great integrity and wisdom, who has a knack for leading without making you feel he has taken the initiative away from you."
 Eugene Y. Lowe Jr., Princeton's dean of students, said that when Mr. Rudenstine came to Princeton in 1968 there were 3,200 male undergraduates. "When he left the place in 1988, it was coed and much more diverse," Dr. Lowe said. "During those 20 years, you could say Princeton transformed itself, and Neil was in the middle of it all."
 Dr. Lowe and others at Princeton said Mr. Rudenstine has several qualities that Harvard is especially interested in, given its current needs. Harvard, for example, is about to begin a $2 billion fund-raising drive, the largest capital campaign ever by the university, and Mr. Rudenstine had helped oversee a highly successful $400 million fund-raising drive at Princeton. Moreover, Dr. Lowe said, Mr. Rudenstine proved to be a tough budget administrator, another quality Harvard needs as it faces a serious budget shortfall.
 Mr. Rudenstine's wife, Angelica Zander Rudenstine, whom he met while a Rhodes Scholar in Britain, is an art historian and currator. She is currently chairwoman of the supervisory committee for Harvard's department of fine arts. The Rudenstines have three children, one of whom lives in Cambridge and teaches in the Quincy public schools.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Babies, Sisterhood and Economics

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
A COUPLE of years ago, four women -- two actresses, one director and one playwright -- sat around, talking about an idea for a play. "What's on your mind?" and "What keeps you awake?" were among the questions the director asked.
One actress said she wondered what would happen if women from extremely disparate economic backgrounds were thrust into a crisis together. The other was concerned about the plight of a woman who could not conceive a child. Separate ideas, they assumed. "But it's one play," said the playwright. And then she wrote it. 
 In essence, that's how "The Baby Dance," which opened at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven on Thursday, came to life. Jane Anderson's play, directed by Jenny Sullivan and performed by Linda Purl and Stephanie Zimbalist, had its premiere in February 1990 at the Pasadena Playhouse. The playhouse's artistic director at the time, Susan Dietz, had brought the women together in the first place.
Following a three-month California run, "The Baby Dance" played two weeks at the Other Stage, the tryout arm of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts last summer, and was then brought back for an additional two weeks, with all performances sold out in advance.
 
Great Expectations
 In New Haven, the play runs through April 28.
"The Baby Dance" has aroused great expectations, following a heartening period of gestation and an unusually strong and consistent commitment to it by Ms. Sullivan, Ms. Purl and Ms. Zimbalist, who, in effect, commissioned the work and have a financial stake in it.
Ms. Anderson's plot concerns a well-to-do, infertile Los Angeles couple (Richard and Rachel, played by Joel Polis and Ms. Zimbalist) who place an advertisement in a newspaper. The word "Pregnant?" appears at the top in boldface. In part, the copy reads: "Happily married couple, educated and financially stable, want to give a healthy white baby a lifetime of love, laughter and security. We can help with expenses."
The advertisement is answered by Al and his ever-pregnant wife, Wanda (played by Richard Lineback and Ms. Purl), who already have four children and live in a trailer park in Louisiana.
The first act is mostly concerned with the relationship between the worn-out Wanda and the cool Rachel who, may come off as patronizing and disapproving at first but does not want to jeopardize her chance of getting the baby. The second act, which shifts tone -- too drastically, some observers of the first two productions felt -- is set in a hospital room a month later. There, the two husbands and a smarmy lawyer talk about deals. For the Long Wharf engagement, some revisions have been made in this act, including the ending.
Before a recent preview, the four "Baby Dance" collaborators -- three of them make a point of insisting "Jane wrote the play" -- talked about the work's journey over the past two years.
 
'It's a Big Story'
 Ms. Sullivan commented on the director's adjustments from two roughly 100-seat theaters to the thrust stage in Connecticut, with a capacity close to 500. And, along with the others, she fantasized about what some consider an inevitable move to an Off Broadway or Broadway theater.
"Here, we have to open it up, but keep it claustrophobic," Ms. Sullivan said. "It's a big story we're telling, and it's challenging to fill a bigger space.
"We thought that by now we'd turned over every stone, but new stones have appeared. We have to catch the audience laughing one minute and crying the next -- and we're all older. By that I mean more mature, of course.
"As a director, I mother a lot. We're reaping all the benefits of everyone's life lessons."
Among the lessons Ms. Sullivan and Ms. Purl imposed upon themselves was a trip through Louisiana, from Shreveport to Monroe, with visits to tiny towns like Gibsland and Shoedron. During the trip, the director and the actress, armed with tape recorder and video camera, interviewed local residents in beauty parlors, beer halls and trailer parks.
"At home, there was always a TV game show or a soap opera on, and always a Bible on view," Ms. Purl recalled. "We were clearly California girls out of place, and the people were skeptical at first. We said we were doing a documentary film or taking a survey -- we kept changing our stories. But by the time we got to Monroe, we told the truth, and it worked better. Then, they were warm and open."
 
Heritage Includes Abuse
 Ms. Purl (who was born in Greenwich) and Ms. Zimbalist also visited maternity wards and adoption agencies and met with social workers and counselors of abused women. "Abuse is not a big ingredient in the play, but it's part of Al and Wanda's heritage," Ms. Purl said.
Ms. Zimbalist said she was intrigued by the idea of the bonding of women whose paths would never normally cross. "The play is an attempt to bridge that gap, with total conviction and good intentions -- up to a point," she said. "But I know that Wanda won't come poolside to be my best friend."
Ms. Anderson once wrote comedy material for her own one-woman multicharacter show in which she played an alcoholic husband, a sperm donor, a stage mother, her husband, their daughter as well as "the real Mona Lisa," she said. "In America, class is getting more and more defined, and our differences are getting more severe. Each of the two couples in the play has what the other does not have -- and both are desperate."
About the play's effect upon audiences, Ms. Anderson said: "Middle- and upper-class and mostly white armchair liberals may get uncomfortable with their own smugness. We still judge others and pretend not to. There's a lot of comic relief in it, but I hope it shakes people up. And pregnant women should stay away."

HEADLINE: Focus: Beverly Hills;
A Peninsula Hotel, With Separate Villas

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
THE Peninsula Group, a Hong Kong hotel company known for its Old World-style luxury properties in the Far East, will open a new hotel in Beverly Hills this summer, its second in the United States.
The cost of the hotel, the 200-room Peninsula Beverly Hills, including land, will be more than $100 million, said Robert Zarnegin, president of the Probity International Corporation of Los Angeles, the developer. Rates are expected to range from $265 a night to $2,500 for a two-bedroom, separate villa on the grounds. 
 The Peninsula Group, which will manage and have a 20 percent equity share in the new hotel, began its United States diversification in New York in 1988, paying $127 million for the Maxim's des Paris-Gotham Hotel on Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, now the Peninsula Hotel, and began offering rooms at $250 a night.
In opening a luxury class hotel in the Los Angeles area, it joins a growing movement by hotel developers to mine the industry's richest vein, a movement that has fueled a small building boom of prime hotels in recent years. Analysts say the luxury end of the market in Los Angeles has not suffered as much as the rest of the market, despite the recession, which helped make last year unprofitable for most of the nation's hotels.
Among operators of luxury hotels, "it's getting more competitive, but not less profitable," said Paul DeMyer, hospitality director for Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a Los Angeles real estate accounting firm.
Even so, hotel development, like other forms of real-estate development, is finding bank loans harder to get.
"Hotels are at the top of the heap in terms of risk," said John P. Sipple, a hotel broker for Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage company.
Among the primary full-service Los Angeles hotels, overall occupancy fell to 69 percent last year from 73 percent in 1988 and rates rose to $112 a room from $102, a 9.8 percent increase, according to Kenneth Leventhal. There were 40 hotels with 16,673 rooms in 1990, compared with 34 hotels with 15,584 rooms in 1988.
THE same trend could be seen at luxury hotels. Occupancy fell to 68 percent from 72 percent and rates rose on the average to $276 a room from $231, a 9 percent increase, to offset the loss in operating revenue.
Consultants say that luxury hotels are characterized by room rates beginning at $180 a night, development costs of $200,000 a room or acquisition costs of $225,000 a room. They offer extraordinary service and amenities and typically have fewer rooms than nonluxury hotels.
This category was dominated during the early 1980's in Los Angeles by a local developer, Severyn Ashkenazy, who built Bel Age and Le Mondrian in West Hollywood and L'Ermitage, a remodeled condominium, in Beverly Hills. They have a total of 530 rooms.
More recently, Asian investors began seeking this market. In 1987, the Sultan of Brunei paid $187 million for the 263-room Beverly Hills Hotel. Regent Hotels of Hong Kong bought the 456-room Beverly Wilshire for $125 million in 1985. And in the most expensive deal so far, Japan's Sekitei Kaihatsu Company in 1989 paid $115 million, or $1.2 million a room, for the secluded 92-room Hotel Bel-Air.
Aside from the Ashkenazy properties and the Asian-owned hotels, the only other site in Los Angeles most consultants considered in this category was the 256-room Westwood Marquis.
The number of luxury hotels will have nearly doubled in only four years with the opening of eight new properties, all competing for the wealthy traveler.
Already in business are the 285-room Four Seasons near Beverly Hills, which opened in 1987; the 188-room Checkers Hotel downtown, which opened in 1989; the 350-room Loews Hotel, the 311-room Ma Maison Sofitel and the 306-room Ritz-Carlton in Marina Del Rey, which all opened in 1990, and the renovated 383-room Ritz Carlton Huntington Hotel in Pasadena, which opened this month.
Besides the Peninsula, another luxury hotel that is scheduled to open this sumnmer is the 198-room Park Hyatt in Santa Monica.
The Peninsula "will have immediate recognition in the Los Angeles basin with Pacific Rim business," said Joseph G. Kordsmeier, a Carmel, Calif., hotel consultant. "They have the reputation as the best in the Far East."
The group's flagship property, known as The Pen, "is still the power place in all of Hong Kong," Mr. Kordsmeier said.
A 20 PERCENT stake in the hotel is owned by a public company -- it is traded on the Hong Kong exchange -- that is 69 percent controlled by the Kadoorie family, British nationals who live in Hong Kong and whose wealth was estimated at $1.6 billion by Fortune magazine in 1990.
Peninsula Group and its six hotels is a unit of Hong Kong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd., whose chairman is Michael Kadoorie, son of a British lord.
The Peninsula Beverly Hills's development cost makes it, on a per-room basis, the most expensive new hotel to be opened in Los Angeles. It is also the first hotel built in Beverly Hills since the Beverly Pavilion, on Wilshire Boulevard, in 1963. The architect was Three Architecture of Dallas.
Mr. Zarnegin, whose company also owns the hotel, said he expects it to be profitable in its third year, with occupancy at 65 percent or more. He predicted that the larger $2,500-a-night villas will have lower vacancy rates than the standard rooms.
He and his brother, F. Bo Zarnegin, who grew up in Beverly Hills, succeeded in piecing together a 2.2-acre parcel of 16 lots over 15 years, a feat that had eluded other developers. The triangular site is on Santa Monica Boulevard, near Rodeo Drive boutiques and Century City high-rises.
Other developers with smaller parcels found they were not economical because of the city's 45-foot height limit, Mr. Zarnegin said.
In 1982, the partners first proposed a larger, 250-room, hotel with a 250-seat banquet hall. During the ensuing years, and through several different administrations at City Hall, the number of rooms was trimmed and the hall shrank to 60 seats to satisfy the concerns of homeowners.
"It went through the longest scrutinization anyone could go through," Mr. Zarnegin said, adding that his having lived in Beverly Hills made no difference.
"This city doesn't need anything," Mr. Zarnegin said, "and the residents don't need anything."
Because of Probity's larger parcel, the company was able to meet the height requirements and still build a 195,000-square-foot hotel. There will be, in addition, 195,000 more feet underground for parking, providing 310 parking places, of which 66 will be for the community and the rest for guests. this at request of the city; there had been 1 bldg on lot, rest was parking lot.
What will $265 a night buy? A hotel that says it "will never say 'no' " to a legal request and that has 15 types of marble, $1 million in landscaping, 65,000 linear feet of ceiling moldings, Rolls-Royces for shopping sprees, low-noise toilets and personalized stationery.
"We will provide old-fashioned service and product and charge accordingly," Mr. Zarnegin said.
In searching for a hotel operator, he and other executives from his company visited 20 hotels in Europe, Asia and the United States. "We felt Peninsula is the best we've seen," in the world," he said.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
For Beverly Hills, a New Peninsula Hotel With Villas

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The Peninsula Group, a Hong Kong hotel company known for its Old World-style luxury properties in the Far East, will open a new hotel in Beverly Hills this summer, its second in the United States.

What will $265 a night buy? A hotel that says it "will never say 'no' " to a legal request and that has 15 types of marble, $1 million in landscaping, Rolls-Royces for shopping sprees, low-noise toilets and personalized stationery.
"We will provide old-fashioned service and product and charge accordingly," Mr. Zarnegin said.
In searching for a hotel operator, he and other executives from his company visited 20 hotels in Europe, Asia and the United States. "We felt Peninsula is the best we've seen," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Deal Keeps the Buzz Alive in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Starting a new magazine can be an endeavor fraught with financial peril. Eden Collinsworth, who started Los Angeles-based Buzz magazine in October, found that out last month when Buzz was forced to suspend publication for lack of money. Vowing that Buzz would be back, she set out to raise $4 million.
Two weeks ago, a Thai publisher suddenly appeared and expressed interest in rescuing the magazine, which is a mix of journalism, fiction, gossip and commentary about Los Angeles. He agreed to provide much of the necessary money. 
 The magazine's rescuer is Sondhi Limthongkul, the chief executive and majority owner of the Manager Publishing Group, which together with his other companies in Thailand has annual revenues of $400 million.
 
Expanding Internationally
 Last month, Mr. Limthongkul said he was interested in buying United Press International. Recently, he acquired Frye & Smith, a California-based printing company.
"He is actively expanding his operations internationally," said Douglas Tanner, a lawyer at Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy who represents Mr. Limthongkul. "He has been in discussions about acquiring U.P.I. and employing it in developing his business."
In 1982, taking advantage of a booming Thai economy, Mr. Limthongkul founded the Eastern Magazine Company to publish Manager, a monthly business magazine in Thailand. The magazine is now published in both Thai and English. He subsequently started a society magazine and a weekly financial newspaper in Thailand. In 1989, his media properties were consolidated under the Manager Publishing Group.
 
Stocks and Real Estate
 Peter Kennedy, a former senior vice president of The Economist magazine in New York who is now in charge of Mr. Limthongkul's international publishing operations, said Mr. Limthongkul's money came mostly from stocks and real estate.
Mr. Limthongkul, who has a master's degree in history from the University of Utah, wants to develop an international publishing business that includes North America as well as Asia, Mr. Kennedy said.
"By Thai standards, his publications are fairly large and he has invested a lot in technology," Mr. Kennedy said. "He has one of the most sophisticated data bases on the Thai economy and stock market."
Mr. Kennedy brought Buzz to the attention of Mr. Limthongkul. Mr. Kennedy, who lives in Hong Kong, was visiting Hawaii and met a laid-off Buzz staff member. She told Mr. Kennedy about Buzz's financial plight and gave him a copy of the magazine.
 
'So Foreign and So Abstract'
 Ms. Collinsworth, the president and chief executive of Buzz Inc., said that when she received word that a Thai businessman wanted to invest millions of dollars in the magazine, she simply shrugged off the idea.
"I was pursuing every avenue, but this was so foreign and so abstract," she said. "Then we met him two weeks ago and it became obvious to us right away that he really wanted to do this."
A letter of intent has been signed, with a closing scheduled on or before April 15. Although details are still being worked out, Ms. Collinsworth said her company would be restructured with Mr. Limthongkul as the majority stockholder.
She declined to say how much Mr. Linthongkul was investing in Buzz, but indicated that his investment would enable the magazine to follow its original business plan, which calls for it to become profitable in three and a half years.
 
West Coast Vanity Fair
 The magazine plans to resume publication in August as a bimonthly and become a monthly in the fall of 1992.
Buzz, which is a sort of West Coast Vanity Fair, has been well received by many of its readers. It will increase the circulation rate base it guarantees to advertisers to 65,000 from 50,000 when it resumes publication. Issues up to now have averaged 50 pages of advertising, with 80 percent coming from national advertisers, Ms. Collinsworth said.
Buzz will continue to fight for its place in a crowded Los Angeles market, which includes Capital Cities/ ABC's Los Angeles magazine and American Express's L.A. Style. And on April 7, The Los Angeles Times will introduced its redesigned and enlarged Sunday magazine, which is to have extended coverage of Southern California.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eden Collinsworth, the founder of Buzz magazine, was surprised when a Thai businessman offered to help revive the publication. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Transit Authority Consolidating Its Offices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Can't City Hall Stop Inflation of Bureaucracy?" (letter, March 6), Nancy H. Fink criticized the New York City Transit Authority's planned occupancy of the Livingston Plaza office building under construction in downtown Brooklyn. She believes that the occupancy of this building by the T.A., in addition to its headquarters building on Jay Street, reflects recent increases in the Transit Authority's corps of office workers, which in fact has not occurred.
The Transit Authority occupies leased office space in several buildings scattered around downtown Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens. A great deal of this space is in seriously deteriorated buildings, and the Transit Authority has occupied some of this space for 20 years. 
 More than seven years ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that is the governing body of the Transit Authority, began exploring the possibility of consolidating these offices into a single building convenient to the T.A. headquarters building.
Livingston Plaza was selected as that building, and the office space in that building will be fully occupied by existing employees.
The Transit Authority will at the same time give up the leased spaces these employees occupy. Any significant expansion of T.A. office forces would mean acquiring more space.
I believe that Livingston Plaza represents a healthy recognition on the part of the T.A. of the needs of its workers for decent space and that the on-budget, timely (actually, ahead of schedule), completion of the building is a demonstration of the M.T.A.'s ability to work with the private sector. Obviously, initial occupancy costs will exceed those under 20-year-old leases in obsolete buildings. Our costs will, however, be significantly lower than those incurred in most new buildings and will remain fixed, as the Transit Authority will purchase the building.
 
FREDERICK S. HARRIS
Director, Real Estate, Metropolitan
Transportation Authority
New York, March 13, 1991

HEADLINE: Brighter Days for Machine Tools

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
New orders for machine tools, often an important weathervane for the economy because the equipment is used by a wide range of major manufacturers, are showing surprising strength.
Orders from aerospace, automobile and appliance companies rose 5.4 percent last year, after plunging by 22 percent in 1989. And industry executives say they still have more orders on their books this year than they have seen in a decade. The executives also point out that those orders are coming from foreign as well as domestic companies and are spread across the industry spectrum. 
 Costing $500,000 or more, machine tools are sophisticated machines that cut, grind, bend, drill or shape the metal parts that go into products ranging from Boeing 747 planes to Caloric kitchen stoves. Economists regard orders for these machines as a good indicator of manufacturers' willingness to invest in their factories.
 
Executives in Bullish Mood
 There is evidence of increased demand. New orders for the first two months of this year were up 15 percent, 27.7 percent in February alone.
Citing the increase in demand, despite the recession and the related slump in the auto industry, which is an enormous customer for machine tools, industry executives are in a bullish mood. Tool makers in the last few years have been closing unprofitable plants, undertaking large modernization projects and developing more varied product lines. At the same time, they have benefited from the lower dollar, which has sent more foreign customers their way.
"We hear a lot about the recession," said William J. Fife, chairman of Giddings & Lewis Inc., one of the nation's tool companies. But the slowdown seems to be "more on the consumer side than on the capital-goods side," he continued, adding: "Our orders are strong and demand seems healthy. What we're seeing here indicates that things are going well."
The renewed strength is quite a turnaround for an industry that was ravaged by intense foreign competition in the early 1980's, mainly from Japan and Germany, and more recently by reduced spending by big industries at home. Those factors had led many industry analysts to predict continued declines in new orders in 1990.
 
Worst Is Over, Analysts Say
 Many analysts say that, while conditions will not be strikingly better this year, the industry has already weathered the worst. "The machine tool industry took its punishment in 1989 and 1990, and it has already been through its recession," said Eli S. Lustgarten, a securities analyst who follows the industry for Paine Webber.
Even so, some analysts see clouds on the horizon. They note that the industry remains highly fragmented, weakened by past foreign competition, and is struggling to overcome a legacy of poor management and underinvestment in research and development. As the industry moves to cope with those problems, these analysts say, the growing substitution of plastics for metals puts a damper on prospects for growth.
For now though, industry executives and analysts say that sales are robust, with a great deal of the increase coming from foreign customers, as the declining dollar has made American products more attractive.
 
Foreign Orders Up 16.8%
 Indeed, foreign orders rose 16.8 percent last year, said the Association for Manufacturing Technology, an industry trade group. "We find that American machine tools are just as competitive in price as machine tools made here," said a buyer for a German construction company.
On the American side, there seems to be a growing sense among manufacturers that they have to increase their capital spending to be more productive and compete internationally, said Daniel J. Meyer, chairman of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of machine tools. "And I think there will be continuing increases in capital spending in the 1990's, not just throwing money at new equipment but for product design."
Indeed, the auto industry, whose weakness had been a major contributor to the slowdown in machine tools, is beginning to show signs of retooling as it develops new engines to comply with Federal clean-air legislation enacted last year, executives in the tool industry say. The auto companies are also making major changes in body styles, which adds to the demand for machine tools.
 
Buying by Aerospace Industry
 Orders from the aerospace industry have also been strong in recent months. "Boeing is stepping up its production schedule," said William G. Copeland, head of the Copeland Economics Group, a consulting firm. "They are about to start their new 777 aircraft program, which is a $4.5 billion to $5 billion program, with complete new tooling and design." But he added that back orders for planes are at record levels and will come down in the next year.
Critics say the industry has been slow to invest in its future. American makers of machine tools "haven't invested near the amount that Germany and Japan have since the 1982 recession," said George Graen, executive director of the University of Cincinnati's Center for the Enhancement of International Competitiveness.
Mr. Graen said American tool companies spend 1.5 percent of gross sales, on average, on research and development, compared with 2.5 percent to 3 percent for their German and Japanese competitors. He said foreign-made machine tools already had nearly 50 percent of the American market. With relatively low research spending, American tool makers could lose even more ground.
"A growing reliance on foreign machine tools could hurt United States manufacturing if foreign suppliers reserved their most advanced machines for their home markets or if shipments were cut off during political disputes," Mr. Graen said.
 
Stock Prices Depressed
 Such concerns have been reflected in the stock prices of tool makers. Severe price competition has undermined earnings at the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a large tool maker based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., pushing its share price down to $3.375 as of Friday, from $10 last summer. In the same period, Cincinnati Milacron's share price slipped to $13.875, from $22. And shares of Giddings & Lewis, based in Fond du Lac, Wis., a leading maker of large, high-precision machine tools, had dropped below $14, from $21, before regaining ground to its current price of $20.
Giddings & Lewis stands out in the industry because of its low debt and strong capitalization. Mr. Lustgarten at Paine Webber said Giddings had "up-to-date products and is investing heavily in its own manufacturing ability." The company is a leading proponent of versatile new machine tools called manufacturing cells, which can readily accommodate parts of different sizes and make quick changes. More flexible manufacturing methods could reduce the amount of inventory tied up in production and allow manufacturers to modernize in small steps.
By contrast, Cincinnati Milacron, which in the 1980's became a leading supplier of equipment that shapes industrial plastic, has seen demand falter in recent months.
Cross & Trecker has also been badly hurt. The company, which relies heavily on business from the auto industry, was hurt last year by lower orders, intense price competition and high marketing costs.
But the tool makers remain optimistic. "I think there will be continuing increases in capital spending in the 1990's," Mr. Meyer of Cincinnati Milacron said. "And our industry will benefit from it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I think there will be continuing increases in capital spending in the 1990's, not just throwing money at new equipment but for product design," said Daniel J. Meyer, the chairman of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of machine tools. (Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Expected to Forgo New Interest Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Many credit market analysts expect the Federal Reserve to forgo a further reduction in short-term interest rates when its policy-making Open Market Committee meets tomorrow.
"It is clear to me they are going to stop here," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "The best thing the Fed could do here is take a two-month vacation." 
 The issue will almost certainly be discussed by the Open Market Committee. The Fed's last move to ease credit, when the overnight Federal funds rate was reduced to its current 6 percent target on March 8, after the release of weak February employment statistics, appears to have created some dissension within the Fed. It seems that a number of Fed governors, including John LaWare and Robert Parry, are unhappy.
 
'Some Disagreement'
 "Based on public statements, it seems there is some disagreement" among committee members "about how the Fed should have responded to the February employment data," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities.
"With the level of real economic activity still low, there is no chance they will move to tighten monetary policy," he added. "But if the Fed eases again prior to any clear improvement in inflation, bond yields will rise considerably."
Indeed, long-term investors, whose primary concern is inflation, are wary about the Fed's last cut in the Federal funds rate. Analysts say another cut in short-term rates would risk an increase in long-term bond yields, a development that would further postpone economic recovery. In addition, the Fed has other reasons to be cautious, analysts said.
 
Rebound in Confidence
 Surveys show that consumer confidence, a key precondition for increased spending, has rebounded since the end of the war in the Persian Gulf. Further evidence to that effect is expected tomorrow, when the Conference Board is scheduled to release the results of its March survey.
In addition, recent data from the housing industry suggest that activity may have hit bottom in January. And over the last two months M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, has increased by $47 billion. The rise has put M-2 growth in the middle of the Fed's target range for the aggregate. Analysts said they did not think the Fed wanted to see it grow much faster.
"With the unemployment rate at 6.5 percent, they obviously are not going to tighten policy," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "But a whole lot of things point to not moving monetary policy any more."
 
Rise in Jobless Expected
 Based on weekly unemployment claims data, it seems very likely that the unemployment rate will show a further increase when the Labor Department releases March employment data on April 5. But the Fed, which has reacted to the last two employment reports by easing policy, would probably sit on its hands should that occur, the analysts said.
Economists are confident the sharp increases in core inflation posted during the first two months of the year will be reversed as 1991 progresses. But as Mr. Levy suggested, bond market investors will need to see tangible evidence of improvement before the Fed's credibility as an inflation-fighter is fully restored. And more than one good set of price numbers will probably be needed to accomplish that task.
The recent inflation numbers were "very fluky, and unworthy of a policy response," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "I think the official inflation reports are going to fall off a cliff in the next three to six months."
 
Lower Funds Rate Predicted
 A decision to delay any further easing of policy does not necessarily mean that the Fed's current approach, which began in earnest last July, has run its course. Some analysts continue to say that the funds rate will be moved lower in coming months.
"All the risk is on the down side in the economy," said John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "In those circumstances, a drop of another 25 basis points to 50 basis points makes some sense."
In addition to watching for clues about Fed policy, credit market participants will receive a few more nuggets of information this week about the economy's performance in March. The first bits are expected today, when auto makers report sales figures for the second 10 days of the month. Most analysts are forecasting some improvement, but not much, from the dismal annual rate of 5.9 million units reported for the first 10 days.
On Thursday, the March survey of purchasing managers in the Chicago region is expected. Analysts at Salomon Brothers expect the report to show that this barometer of activity in the manufacturing sector moved higher for the second straight month.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Consumer Pessimism Rises, A Report by Grey Indicates

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
A STUDY to be released today by Grey Advertising found that a majority of consumers were shaken by the Persian Gulf war, discouraged by the recession and saw the American dream of a good life slipping out of reach.
The study, conducted in December and February, found that consumers felt vulnerable because of problems over which they had little control, including the war, AIDS, the homeless and environmental pollution. 
 The report concluded that the euphoria produced by the United States' victory in the war was bound to be transitory and that consumers did not see the victory as a sign that the country had found a solution to its long-term problems.
Seventy-five percent of those polled questioned whether their hopes and dreams for the future would ever come true.
"The easy-come, easy-go attitude that was prevalent in the last decade is gone," said Barbara Feigin, executive vice president and director of strategic services at Grey. "Americans no longer believe life will simply get better and better, and they have become very cautious and uncertain about the future."
Ms. Feigin said the study found that consumer optimism had drastically eroded. In a poll conducted by Grey in 1989, 75 percent of those questioned said they were optimistic about the future. In the new study, 52 percent voiced the same sentiments. Most said they would now have to learn to live with less.
Most of those polled said they have been forced to tighten their belts. A quarter said an adult in their household had either lost his or her job or had taken a cut in pay. Two-thirds said they were cutting spending by buying cheaper brands of household goods. Many said they were forgoing or postponing expensive purchases.
Grey interviewed 725 consumers who said they were the heads of households, asking them about their expectations and priorities, as well as their buying habits and other activities.
There were some bright spots, Ms. Feigin said. Some people said they had bought expensive electronic home-entertainment equipment, presumably because they were staying at home more, she said. And many said they had not given up small luxuries like gourmet food, wine and expensive cosmetics.
But consumers were also more skeptical about brand-name products. The percentage who believed that a brand name alone was an assurance of quality has dropped by 6 percentage points since Grey's 1989 study to 61 percent in the new report.
As a result, advertising will have to become more informative, Ms. Feigin said. "Ads are going to have to contain more news and hard information about products," she said. "More consumers want to know what's in it for them."

HEADLINE: February Jump In Tool Orders

 BODY:
Spurred by sharply higher demand from domestic manufacturers, new orders for American-made machine tools climbed 27.7 percent in February from the January level, according to a report scheduled to be released today.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology, the industry trade group based in McLean, Va., said new orders increased to $255.2 million last month. The figure is a 31.2 percent increase from February 1990. For the first two months of this year new orders increased 15 percent over the comparable 1990 period. 
 Analysts attributed the increase to higher capital spending by American manufacturers in virtually all industries, including aerospace, construction and oilfield equipment. Orders from domestic customers increased 26.5 percent in February from the January level.
Orders from foreign customers declined nearly 17 percent in February. Analysts suggested that the decline was a result of recent strength in the dollar.
Albert W. Moore, president of the association, said that more gains were likely in the coming months. "The fact that machine tools are used to make everything from oilfield equipment to motor vehicles means that they will be needed by companies that are modernizing or expanding their manufaturing facilities," he said.
Shipments of machine tools rose 11.2 percent in February from the January level.

HEADLINE: STATES AND CITIES ARE PUSHING HARD FOR HIGHER TAXES

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A wave of new taxes and tax increases -- the third since the 1930's -- appears to be developing in states, counties and cities.
Many taxes that Americans pay today to these governments originated in two similar periods when money for public services ran short: the Great Depression and a 15-year stretch starting in 1961 when the bills came due for the baby boomers' public schooling. 
 The latest trend shows up in the numerous state and local taxes enacted last year or proposed for enactment in 1991. It is reflected in bitter debates over which public services are so essential that taxes must rise to pay for them. And it is seen in the willingness of three old foes of a state income tax -- Connecticut, Tennessee and Texas -- to consider adopting one.
"When a state adopts or even proposes an income tax, that is almost like a country going to war," said John Shannon, a tax expert at the Urban Institute. "It is the most traumatic thing that a governor can lay on the backs of his constituents."
Not since New Jersey adopted an income tax in 1976 has any state publicly considered instituting one. More broadly, the booming 1980's generated so much revenue from existing taxes that budget surpluses were commonplace, and the pressure for new state and local taxes diminished. Only in the last two years, as a slowing economy and then a recession eroded tax collections, have officials been forced to make tough choices about more taxes or fewer services.
In what may be an acknowledgement of the budget pressures, opposition to tax increases has been surprisingly muted, especially in contrast to the tax revolts of the late 1970's -- although Americans today pay a total of $540 billion a year to their state and local governments in property, sales and income taxes. By comparison, the Federal tax on personal income is smaller: $493 billion.
More important, in contrast to the 1960's and 1970's, the states, counties, cities and towns, rather than the Federal Government, are now absorbing most of the rising cost of public health care, education, prisons, waste disposal and other public works.
This transfer has produced what Alan Auerbach, a University of Pennsylvania economist, and others call "a new Federalism," in which the debate over national concerns like education, public health insurance and programs for the poor is shifting from the White House and Congress to state and city governments, which are paying a growing portion of the bills.
"The corollary of this shift is that states and cities are increasingly adopting different standards for programs that concern our society as a whole," said Harold Hovey, president of State Policy Research Inc., which publishes newsletters on tax trends.
Last year, more than 30 states enacted laws intended to raise $10.3 billion in annual revenue. So far this year, 21 Governors have sent their legislatures bills that are likely to raise another $10 billion or more, according to estimates by the Center for the Study of the States and other organizations that survey state finances. It has been years since states have raised such huge amounts.
 
End of Avoiding Tax Rise
 "The states had been putting off tax increases, borrowing and using up their surpluses, and they finally got to the point where they couldn't put off the increases anymore," said Scott Mackey, a policy associate at the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Most of the new tax legislation, which became effective in the fiscal year that began on July 1, raised sales taxes, broadened their coverage and raised excise taxes and fees on cigarettes, liquor, gasoline, auto registrations and the like. New Jersey and a few other states increased personal and corporate income tax rates, but not until this year did some of the 10 states without a personal income tax begin to give ground.
"The states have been finding ways to get around the public opposition to broad-based taxes," said Marcia Howard, research director of the National Association of State Budget Offices. "They are taxing things like long-distance phone calls and tire sales."
 
Range of State Proposals
 Nevertheless, formal proposals to enact personal income taxes are before the legislatures in Connecticut and Tennessee. Nevada is considering a limited payroll tax. And in Texas, where the budget deficit is rising and a recent court ruling ordered the state to create "equal" school districts at a cost of more than $1 billion a year, Lieut. Gov. Bob Bullock this month became the first high state official in memory to propose publicly a personal and corporate income tax.
"I know deep down in my heart that it is the right thing to do for Texas," Mr. Bullock was quoted as saying. Gov. Ann Richards has neither endorsed nor rejected the proposal.
For governments below the state level, the main source of revenue is the property tax, which is rising, bringing in ever more money to cities, towns and counties. A preliminary survey shows that last year's collections reached $154 billion, up more than 12 percent from the $137 billion of 1989, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Rising tax rates and numerous reassessments of property are likely to produce another sharp jump in revenue in the fiscal year that begins on July 1, Mr. Mackey and other experts predict.
 
First, Budget Is 'Scrubbed'
 Across the nation, governors and mayors are taking a similar approach to raising taxes. Mr. Hovey says this approach has become known as "scrubbing the budget."
"You must show that you have gone through the budget with a fine-tooth comb," he said, "eliminating fraud, abuse, surplus workers, wasteful spending, and you have pared down the budget as far as possible before ever considering tax increases."
Thus, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City announced his intention to trim $850 million from spending while also seeking $1.2 billion a year in new tax revenue. In Connecticut, the campaign by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for a personal income tax also carries a commitment to lay off state workers, freeze salaries and reduce other spending.
In Iowa, which has a surplus but is bracing for a deficit, Gov. Terry E. Branstad seeks to raise $25 million through a higher cigarette tax while slashing $20 million from a fund to buy land for state parks and wildlife preserves.
"Next year we will have to cut more spending," said Gretchen Tegler, Iowa's acting budget director. "But we haven't gotten to the point where we have to say we can't cut anymore and we have to raise taxes."
 
Layoffs in Waterbury
 In Waterbury, Conn., however, the city's $7.5 million budget surplus turned into a $2.5 million deficit by last June 30, the end of the 1990 fiscal year. With Governor Weicker cutting more than $4 million in state aid that it had counted on, the city government announced this month that property taxes would rise 12 percent for the year that begins on July 1, instead of the 7 percent originally planned.
"We are meeting with some fairly stiff early resistance to this proposal," said Paul Rizza, the city's director of audit. Nearly half of the city's $195 million annual budget goes to education, principally to pay for salary increases required under contracts for teachers, police and firefighters. But along with the property tax increase, the city has also announced layoffs.
"The early number is 234 people, but it is yet to be determined who goes and who doesn't," Mr. Rizza said.
Several developments are making the early 1990's another period of rising state and local taxes, similar to the period between 1931 and 1937, when the state income and general sales tax first came into widespread use, and to the 1961-to-1976 period, when another batch of states adopted income and sales taxes to help pay for the baby boomers' education.
The cutback in Federal spending, which began more than a decade ago, certainly plays a role in prompting the tax increases. The huge rise in Medicaid costs, which now represent 12 percent of all state spending, is an even more important factor, said Ms. Howard of the National Association of State Budget Offices.
Costly outlays for new prisons also contribute to the pressure for more tax revenue, as does the cost of raising teachers' salaries and hiring more teachers to reduce class sizes. Money for welfare, the rebuilding of highways and waste-disposal and sewer systems is also pushing state and city budgets into deficit. But the main problem, experts say, is the recession that began last year.
This recession, of course, is not the first to dampen corporate profits, personal income and retail sales, shrinking the tax revenue from these sources. The same thing happened in the 1981-82 recession, and the states, in particular, responded with tax legislation in 1983 that produced as much new revenue as last year's laws. But the recession ended in 1983 and the boom that followed generated more than enough tax revenue until 1989 to cover spending. Some states with growing surpluses even cut taxes in the mid-1980's.
 
Sluggish Growth Is Expected
 A similar rebound from the current recession would also undercut the need for more taxes. But most economists say that when the economy does start to expand again, the growth will be too sluggish to generate enough revenue from existing taxes to balance budgets. What is more, surpluses that existed in the last recession are gone today and spending for hard-to-cut programs like education and Medicaid represents a larger portion of total outlays.
"People have less maneuvering room to avoid raising taxes than they had before," said Douglas Peterson, senior policy analyst at the National League of Cities.
Perhaps reflecting these pressures, there is less evidence today of the sort of opposition that gave rise in the late 1970's to Proposition 13 -- the California revolt against rising property taxes -- and similar protests.
In the November election, for example, candidates who favored higher taxes were defeated, or in some cases won re-election by narrow margins, but at the same time, voters rejected a number of ballot proposals to reduce taxes. As Ms. Howard of the budget-office group put it, "Anti-tax sentiment is pushing against what I would think is some reasonable momentum to cover costs and eliminate deficits."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Metering Water: Will It Drown The Landlords?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
To Robert C. Rosenberg of the Bronx, trickle-down isn't an abstract economic theory. It's a formula for business losses that may presage a renewed wave of abandonment by owners of marginally profitable apartment buildings in New York City.
Typically a landlord's lament doesn't elicit much sympathy. Yet the experience of property owners like Mr. Rosenberg appears to illustrate another case of good intentions gone awry. The consequences for all New Yorkers could be profound. 
 Mr. Rosenberg is worried about water meters; his concern goes beyond pending investigations into how they were installed. His building at 3201 Park Avenue in the South Bronx now has one. His tenants in each of the building's 90 apartments do not.
Mr. Rosenberg has a compelling reason to fix leaks and reduce waste: his company is liable for the entire water bill. Civic responsibility alone may not provide enough motivation for tenants to conserve, though. Some short-sighted ones might even subject their landlords to water torture.
In 1987, when Mr. Rosenberg's water charges were based on the number of feet the building occupied along Park Avenue, he said, the bill was $9,784. Last year, since a meter was installed to measure consumption, the bill gushed to $58,396, he said. Mr. Rosenberg still hasn't paid it.
 The rate of property-tax delinquencies in New York City has climbed to a 10-year high -- about 3.5 percent citywide. It has nearly doubled since 1989. Much of the increase reflects the recession and market forces affecting commercial buildings.
 But as more meters are installed in rental apartment houses, a surge in water charges may contribute to the delinquency rate and perhaps to abandonment. As the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins ponders the political implications of an environmental policy it inherited, rallying landlords may echo a historic refrain: "Remember the main!"
Carol O'Cleireacain, the City Finance Commissioner, says the landlords' lament sounds credible. Angelo Aponte, the State Housing Commissioner, also expresses concern about the financial impact on rental buildings.
Until five years ago, only commercial structures and new residential buildings in the city were required to install water meters, which are common in most other large cities. As the city suffered another drought, it ordered the installation of 630,000 meters in private homes and apartment buildings within 10 years. So far about 150,000 meters have been installed, mostly in one- and two-family homes.
Instead of the flat rate, consumers pay according to how much water they use. The city had estimated that as much as 30 percent could be conserved, but officials told the City Council recently that the savings might be less than half that.
The fees pay for the city's water system; rates are projected to rise by nearly 20 percent July 1.
The apparent unintended consequence precipitated by metering recalls a similar reform: the city's efforts to prolong the usefulness of its Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island by raising the fees to private haulers to discourage dumping. When revenue from the fees plummeted, officials briefly considered reversing the policy last year because raising money seemed a greater priority.
Water-metering may prove equally vexing. Installing meters in every apartment would be an enormous undertaking, and there are no plans to do this. The landlords' Rent Stabilization Association suggests instead "some form of rough justice," like apportioning among tenants at least some of the difference between the old flat rate and the new metered charges.
City officials acknowledge that landlords of some larger residential buildings may be suffering but say water bills for most small homeowners have shrunk.
"There is a shift based on the true amount of consumption," said Richard Mendes, executive director of the New York City Water Board. "By and large, in the aggregate, it balances out."
It hasn't at another Bronx building, 1411 Townsend Avenue, where the owner said water charges soared from $13,710.36 in 1990 to $41,759.65 in 1991.
At Mr. Rosenberg's building, environmental inspectors pointed to "possible abuse or negligent water use by the building's tenants, a variable which we have absolutely no control over," he said.
"Water metering has proven that it has a built-in disadvantage for densely populated, low-income apartment buildings with numerous doubled-up families," he said. "Water charges are as much as my fuel bill. I'm in jeopardy of losing the building. And my tenants' last stop, if I don't succeed, is the street."

HEADLINE: It's Cheaper to Give Unpaid Leave Than to Dismiss, U.S. Study Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Giving workers unpaid leave for family illness or the birth of a child may be cheaper for employers than letting the workers quit and hiring permanent replacements, according to a study for the Small Business Administration.
The study, by Eileen Trzcinski, an assistant professor of economics at Cornell University, and William T. Alpert, an associate professor of economics at the University of Connecticut, found that the cost of giving unpaid leave to a worker was relatively small if the savings in not paying that employee's salary was taken into account. 
 The House and the Senate are considering legislation to guarantee up to 12 weeks' unpaid leave to workers whose companies have at least 50 employees. The House Education and Labor Committee approved the bill on Wednesday, and the full House is expected to debate it next month.
 
Bush Threatening Veto
 President Bush threatens to veto the bill as an undue burden on employers, just as he did a similar one that Congress passed last year.
The study was based on questionnaires sent to 10,000 companies, of which about a third replied.
In calculating the expense of letting workers take unpaid leave, the study asked companies to estimate costs like hiring replacements, letting work pile up until the employee returns or dividing the absent employee's tasks among other people.
For companies with one to 15 employees, the average weekly cost of letting a nonmanagerial worker take leave was $333.67. But that average employee had been paid $320.98 a week, and when that saving was deducted, the cost to the employer was $12.69, the study said.
That net cost for nonmanagers goes down to 97 cents a week for companies of 16 to 99 employees but increases to $97.78 for companies with more than 100 workers, the study found.
 
Outlook With Managers
 With managers, the picture changes. The figures seem to indicate that companies can make money letting some of them stay home.
In companies with one to 15 employees, the net cost of letting managers take leave is $42.11 a week.
But with companies of 16 to 99 employees, there is a net savings of $30.66 in letting managers stay out of the workplace, and in companies of 100 or more employees, the cost is just $1.20.
The study said the cost of terminating nonmanagerial workers and hiring replacements who had to be trained averaged $1,078 in companies with 15 or fewer employees, $783 in companies of up to 49 employees, $1,143 in those of 50 to 99 employees and $1,131 in those of 100 or more workers.
For managers, such termination and hiring costs averaged $1,187 in the smallest companies, $2,115 in those of 16 to 49 workers; $1,911 where there were 50 to 99 employees and $3,152 in companies larger than that.
Ms. Trzcinski said the figures meant not that companies could be run without managers but simply that they could get by for a while.
"You can't have it go on indefinitely," she said.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Seeks Sales Curbs on Japan Autos

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 24

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation has asked the Bush Administration to put pressure on Japan to limit car and truck sales in the United States for the next 12 to 18 months, warning that a surge in sales by Japanese auto makers could put it out of business.
The President has not directly responded to the request, which came in a letter from Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler chairman, to President Bush. But the Treasury Department indicated that the Administration was not inclined to support protectionist measures like those suggested by Mr. Iacocca.
Excerpts of Mr. Iacocca's letter, which was dated March 6, appeared in The Detroit News and Free Press on Sunday, along with excerpts of the Treasury Department's background paper, which addressed issues raised in the letter. The background paper was obtained by The News and Free Press. A Chrysler spokesman declined to comment on the published excerpts, saying Mr. Iacocca's letter was "personal."
In the letter, the Chrysler chairman suggested that if Japanese auto makers could be persuaded to cut exports by 500,000 vehicles this year, they could be limited to their current share of the American market, about 31 percent. Otherwise, he said, Japan's auto makers may cut their prices to reduce growing inventories of unsold vehicles, causing their market share to grow to 40 percent.
"Unless the Japanese act now to immediately cut back their export shipments, they will begin to 'distress merchandise' this huge amount of overshipment and their share will rocket up again," Iacocca said in the letter.
"I can tell you, Mr. President, at a Japanese share of 40 percent in a depressed industry, Chrysler is gone and Ford could be mortally wounded from a competitive standpoint," Mr. Iacocca wrote. "Even G.M. is at risk unless and until we decide as a nation that a domestic auto industry is a strategic industry and should not be allowed to fall victim to Japan's industrial strategy of targeting key industries." Mr. Iacocca said his proposed limits on Japanese sales should remain in effect until American auto makers "regain their footing."
The outlook for Chrysler has looked increasingly bleak in recent months as the company's sales and profits have dwindled. The entire industry has been mired in a downturn for nearly two years, and as the smallest domestic auto maker, and one that was on the brink of financial collapse just a decade ago, Chrysler appears less able than the Ford Motor Company or the General Motors Corporation to weather the current climate, while paying the huge development costs required in producing a full line of models.
 
Chrysler Stands Alone
 None of the Big Three auto makers has prospered in direct competition with the Japanese, but only Mr. Iacocca favors United States intervention against the Japanese industry. Japan's voluntary limit on car exports has declined sharply since the early 1980's, to about 1.6 million from more than 2.6 million. But in recent years, as the Japanese have built factories in the United States, they have been selling more and more American-made vehicles and importing fewer vehicles from Japan.
The Treasury Department managed the Government-guaranteed loans that saved Chrysler from bankruptcy in 1980. Since the mid-80's, the Government has declined to request Japanese export restraints, although Japan has agreed to limit vehicle exports nonetheless.
Indeed, the Treasury Department's background paper noted that the Japanese auto industry has invested $6.4 billion in American plants and employs about 25,000 American workers. Moreover, the Big Three have significant investments in the Japanese auto companies, and they sell Japanese-made vehicles under their own nameplates.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Asked To Review Japan Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Unhappy with the continuing huge trade deficit with Japan, the National Association of Manufacturers has asked President Bush for a complete re-examination of the United States' relationship with Japan.
The policies of the Bush and Reagan Administrations have been rooted in the belief that trade imbalances would automatically improve as Tokyo responded to market-opening pressures and a lower, more competitive exchange rate for the dollar. 
 But the business leaders say progress has been far too slow and uneven. Indeed, Chrysler has asked the Administration to put pressure on Japan to limit car and truck sales in the United States. [Page D10.]
Although the deficit fell to $41.1 billion in 1990 from its record of $56.3 billion in 1987, the improvement was largely in low-technology areas. The gap has widened in the high-technology industries that provide the greatest potential for jobs and wealth, business leaders say.
"Progressively what you are finding is that more and more of the high-tech, high-growth, high-end jobs are being controlled by the Japanese, which will gradually affect our quality of life," said Prof. Bruce R. Scott of the Harvard Business School.
In a letter dated March 13, the president of the 12,500-member manufacturing association asked President Bush to set up a panel to review trade with Japan.
"While N.A.M. members across a broad range of industries have a lot of different concerns about Japan, they do agree that fundamental policy assumptions seem shaky and may be wrong and certainly need to be re-examined," said R. K. Morris, director of international trade for the manufacturers group.
Ellen L. Frost, corporate director of international affairs for the United Technologies Corporation and the head of the association's Japan Working Group, said, "Some are more frustrated than others, but all of us felt the need for stepping back with a view to understanding that mixture of competition and partnership that we have with Japan."
 
Congressional Pressure
 The complaint comes at a time when many members of Congress remain unhappy about Japanese trade and economic policies. Congress is expected to put pressure on the Bush Administration to maintain a hard line in various trade disputes with Japan, including those involving computer chips, the awarding of public works contracts, and the opening of Japanese rice markets.
Japanese officials did not welcome the call for a re-evaluation. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Taizo Watanabe, who visited Washington last week with Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, stressed that present policies were "creating profit and mutual benefit."
He said that if a re-evaluation moved the United States into a "more confrontational phase," this would be "damaging to both nations."
But the association's letter suggested that the Presidential panel should ask: "If these present relationships continue, what will happen to the United States with respect to living standards, leading-edge technologies, research and development-intensive exports, per-capita income in the year 2000 and beyond?"
 
'No Objections'
 The deputy United States trade representative, S. Linn Williams, the Administation official most closely involved in trade negotiations with Japan, said he had "no objections in principle" to a policy review, saying such exercises are "often healthy."
He said the Administration was actually pleased with the way its trade policy has developed. "Reasonable people can differ on the speed of market access," he said in an interview last week. "Yet I can think of no instance in which we have disappointed an industry that has a problem."
The Administration's policy has worked well in Europe. A substantial trade deficit with the European Community in 1987 has turned into a growing surplus. An important reason for this change, economists say, is that market forces are permitted to operate with fewer restrictions in Europe than in Japan.
For many high-technolgy products, the deficit with Japan has actually grown, according to figures compiled by the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research group working with the manufacturers.
 For example, between 1987 and 1990, the trade imbalance in office machines, computers and electrical and power-generating machinery rose by $2.3 billion. The gap, however, narrowed by $3.6 billion for logs, breakfast cereals, meat, fish and scrap metal.
"Making and exporting low-tech and agricultural products simply doesn't provide the same opportunities to generate wealth and spin off new industries as do high-tech production and trade," said Kevin L. Kearns, a fellow at the institute.
Some improvement in the trade deficit with Japan reflects the establishment by Japanese industry of manufacturing plants in Southeast Asia. Since 1985, for example, 46 Japanese electronics companies have set up operations in Thailand.
In 1990, the consumer electronics deficit with Japan fell by 8 percent, or $400 million. But United States imports from Thailand totaled $310 million, a 4,326 percent increase over 1988.
Many Democrats and some business officials have been pressing for years for a "results oriented" trade policy, in which the United States and Japan would set targets for trade flows, either for specific industries or over all.
"Recognition that Japan does not behave like the United States, that it has different national interests, and that Government-business cooperation in devising policies deliberately detrimental to American corporations is an accepted part of Japanese policy must be a starting point for thinking about appropriate counter-strategies," said a report delivered two years ago by a group of industry leaders who have been advising the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills.
The Bush Administration's response was what is known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, a series of negotiations with Japan intended to address the underlying obstacles to fair trade. These included encouraging Japan to improve its distribution system for imported goods and strengthen antitrust enforcement, while Washington undertook to improve American education and reduce the Federal deficit.
Jerry J. Jasinowski, the manufacturers' association president, said it was not the group's intention to blame Japan for the long-term competitive problems of the United States. "It is rather that Japan, more than any other major ally, calls into question some long-standing premises governing America's postwar economic policies, both at home and abroad," he said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Teheran, Dropping Any Ambiguity, Intensifies Its Drive to Oust Hussein

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, March 24

 BODY:
Iran is stepping up its campaign to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the entire leadership of his Baath Socialist Party.
The Teheran Government is supplying Shiite Muslim rebels and Kurdish dissidents in Iraq with more weapons, supplies and moral support in what seems to be a final chapter of the decade-long confrontation between the two Persian Gulf nations. 
 While there was never much good will among the Iranian leaders, whether pragmatists or militants, toward the rulers of Iraq, the country's pragmatic leaders led by President Hashemi Rafsanjani had appeared over the last few months to be advocating the opening of a new chapter in Iraqi-Iranian relations. The idea was to put behind them the enmity engendered by the eight-year war that Iraq started in in September 1980. But now, Iranian policy has sharply changed.
The Teheran radio went so far today as to predict an imminent assault on the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, by rebels "from two axes, north and south." This would include Kurdish rebels from the north and pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims from the south. The broadcast said Baghdad was under siege and "defended by Republican Guards stationed around President Saddam Hussein's residence."
 
Supplying 30,000 Iraqis
 Arab officials in Kuwait and here in Bahrain have said Iran has trained and supplied 30,000 Iraqi dissidents chosen from former prisoners of war held by Iran and from families of Iraqi Shiites evicted from the country 10 years ago. Iran has also said it would confiscate about 150 Iraqi planes that sought refuge in Iran in the recent war over Kuwait.
The distinct shift in the Iranian attitude now is that it unites all elements of the country's ruling establishment, including the rarely heard from but highly influential group of religious scholars. The Government's long-held hope for Iraq is the establishment of a Shiite Muslim leadership there. While fundamentalists would presumably be favored, a more moderate Iraqi Shiite government might also be acceptable in Teheran.
With Iran's long and porous borders with Iraq and with tens of thousands of Iraqi dissidents living as refugees in Iran for nearly a decade, Teheran's renewed threats to Iraq take a new and credible dimension.
Mr. Hussein's leadership -- already isolated in the gulf region, the Arab world, and the world at large -- appears now on the ropes with no friends left.
Turkey, a major regional power in the gulf, as well as several important Arab nations including Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria, have said they are opposed to dealing with Mr. Hussein. Even previous supporters, like Jordan, now appear convinced that it is only a matter of time before Mr. Hussein is forcibly removed from power.
The United States and much of Western Europe have made it similarly clear they are looking forward to a new leaderhip in Iraq and will not lift economic sanctions as long as he remains in power.
Still, it is the renewed enmity of Iran that creates the biggest threat to the Iraqi leadership.
What appears to be the latest blunder of the Iraqi leadership has been Mr. Hussein's way of dealing with the most senior Shiite Muslim cleric in Iraq, Ayatollah Abolqassem al-Khoei. That blunder has coalesced Iranians around the goal of bringing him down.
 
'Final Nail in His Coffin'
 On Wednesday Mr. Hussein brought the 91-year-old Ayatollah, who is one of the two most revered figures in the highly politicized world of Shiite Islam, to Baghdad from his native city of Najaf, and had him appear on Iraqi television sitting next to him to express support for the repression of Shiite rebels.
"He may have struck the final nail in his coffin by doing this," said a Shiite Muslim from Bahrain who is an expert on that branch of Islam. "No Shiite in Iran, in the gulf or anywhere else in the world will ever believe that Khoei was not forced to say what he said. Indeed no Muslim will believe it."
"By doing this, Saddam has confirmed the degree to which he is willing to manipulate the highest Islamic values even as his regime is tumbling," the Bahraini said. "He has stepped on what is most precious to the Shiites."
Indeed for Iran, a nation led by a Shiite Muslim revolutionary clergy, the apparent mistreatment of such a senior religious figure has led to a virtual declaration of war against Mr. Hussein's leadership.
 
Iran Had Kept Door Open
 Iran was already supporting the Shiite rebellion in Basra, Karbala and Najaf with supplies of weapons, food and medical help, but in its pragmatic way, was still keeping a door open to Iraq and denying that it stood behind the rebels.
But after the spectacle of Ayatollah Khoei being made to sit next to a man regarded by Iranians as a vicious oppressor, Iran has said it will not rest until Mr. Hussein is gone.
Since 1980, Mr. Hussein had systematically persecuted Shiite leaders in Iraq and condemned many of their leaders to death. Then he tried to paint his invasion of Kuwait as an act that among other things reflected the confrontation of the world of militant Islam against Western imperialism.
On Saturday, Iran's senior cleric, Ayatollah Mohammed Reza Golpaygani, who ranks higher than the Iranian religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, called on the world's Muslims to stage protests in mosques to condemn the treatment of Ayatollah Khoei. In a declaration broadcast by the Teheran radio, Ayatollah Golpaygani said the "the forced abduction" of Ayatollah Khoei was an affront to all Muslims.
 
Ayatollah's Aides Abducted
 Iran said the abduction of several senior aides of Ayatollah Khoei from Najaf was also abhorrent. Najaf, which is in Iraq, and Qom, which is in Iran, are considered to be the two centers of Shiite Islamic scholarship.
While the Iraqi leadership has kept Shiite scholars in Najaf under close scrutiny, it had never dared to interfere with Ayatollah Khoei. For his part, the Ayatollah has been restrained in his public comments on subjects other than religion.
Iran's denunciation of this act was its most dramatic gesture since the call by Ayatollah Ruhallah Khomeini for the kiling of the British author Salman Rushdie for what the ayatollah called his blasphemy of Islam in his book "The Satanic Verses." The fact that Ayatollah Golpaygani made the call personally reflects the degree to which Iran objected to Mr. Hussein's move.
If there was any ambivalence among the ruling circles of Iran about the need to pursue the confrontation with Iraq, that event has wiped it out.
Over the last year, Iranian pragmatists like President Rafsanjani pursued a two-track policy toward Iraq, encouraging the making of peace, but also undermining the Iraqi leadership by discreet support for the Shiite Muslim rebels. Now even President Rafsanjani has said the Iraqi leader has to go.
 
Turk Predicts Hussein's Fall
 He is not alone among the regional gulf powers to say so. Today, the Turkish President, Turgut Ozal, said he did not believe that Mr. Hussein or anyone close to him would be in power much longer.
Mr. Ozal told Cable News Network in an interview broadcast today in the United States that "the next man after Saddam is not the second, third, not even 20th" in the Baath Party structure,
Even the Jordanians appeared resigned that a change in Iraq was coming, and maybe necessary.
"Everything in Iraq has changed," Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan in San Francisco said in another CNN interview. "I think ultimately one hopes that the situation will change to a participatory system."
Elsewhere in the Arab world, both President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia have stated they will not deal with an Iraq headed by Mr. Hussein.
