HEADLINE: Free Trade Fatefully Near For Paraguay's 'Hong Kong'

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CIUDAD DEL ESTE, Paraguay

 BODY:
In this bustling town on the border of Brazil and Argentina, often called the Hong Kong of South America, smugglers fear that their long and lonely advocacy of free trade is about to become respectable.
On Tuesday, the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay are to meet in Asuncion, Paraguay's capital, to sign a treaty forming the Southern Cone Common Market. 
 Known as Mercosur, a contraction of its name in Spanish, the market will allow goods and services to circulate tariff free between the 200 million consumers of the region by January 1996.
Brazil and Argentina, the two largest economic players of the region, are to eliminate all tariffs on trade with each other by January 1995. In addition, both countries plan to lower duties on imports from outside the region to an average of 20 percent. In some cases, those tariffs are as high as 100 percent.
Brazil is already the largest importer of goods from the other three nations. Last year, $2 billion worth of goods was traded between Argentina and Brazil.
Chile, which lowered its tariffs in the 1980's, declined to join the common market. Instead, Chile starts talks in May with the United States in the hope of establishing a free-trade agreement.
"It's a world trend toward economies of scale," Celso Amorim, Brazil's common-market negotiator, said in an interview in Brasilia. "It's happening in Europe, the Far East, North America."
On the other side of South America, Venezuela, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia have decided to abolish virtually all regional tariffs by year-end.
Both South American common markets dovetail with a proposal for a Western Hemisphere free-trade zone that was promoted by President Bush during his five-nation tour of South America in December.
This city's practitioners of free trade may be among the first to lose if free trade breaks out in the region.
In a back office of the seedy Lai Lai shopping center here, a Brazilian computer smuggler whose business card identified him only as Marcio said with a mix of apprehension and bravado: "Mercosur would finish off this town -- if it ever happens. But it won't. Brazil's big thing has always been bureaucracy and import duties."
 
The City Protectionism Built
 Indeed, to walk though this town is to see a mirrored reflection of the protectionist economies of Brazil and Argentina, which start on the other side of the Alto Parana River.
Roller skates with pink wheels, Scotch, fishing rods, American potato chips, electronic organs, Taiwanese pocket calculators, Space Laser Gun toys, ersatz Ming vases, cordless telephones, designer-label sneakers, French perfumes, I.B.M. personal computers -- all are on sale here. On the other side of the river, all are considered "contrabanda."
While many countries outlaw imports of illicit drugs, pornography and firearms, Brazil and Argentina banned imports of these and thousands of other consumer goods to foster domestic industry. Items that were not banned outright were kept out with stiff duties, sometimes more than 100 percent.
Indeed, Brazilian and Argentine protectionism built Ciudad del Este, now Paraguay's second-largest city.
"When I arrived here in 1972, there were only 5,000 people and this was mostly forest," Oscar Escobar, a local television reporter, said, surveying the urban sprawl that is now home to 150,000 people.
 
One Big Duty-Free Shop
 To the outrage of Brazil's economic planners, Paraguay's free-market pioneers built this frontier city as one large duty-free shop to cater largely to Sao Paulo, South America's largest city, 600 miles to the east.
In what is now a classic excursion, hundreds of thousands of middle-class Brazilians board buses each year for an overnight trip to Ciudad del Este.
The currencies that flow into cash registers here are American dollars, Brazilian cruzeiros, Argentine australs and Paraguayan guaranis. By nightfall, commerce has usually been so intense that packing materials are ankle deep in the streets. In the evening, the Brazilians either visit the casinos -- there are none in Brazil -- or return home by bus.
Because little is officially exported, import statistics show Paraguay, a largely rural nation of four million people, to be South America's largest per capita consumer of French perfume, American cigarettes and Scotch.
 
End of 'Hong Kong' Position Seen
 Some politicians in Asuncion are predicting that Ciudad del Este will have to adapt to the times.
"Economic integration is never achieved without spilling a little blood," said Guillermo Caballero Vargas, a businessman who is seen as a possible presidential candidate in the 1993 elections. "We can't give up integration with the Southern Cone because of a deformation in one point of the nation. Ciudad del Este has to abandon its position as the Hong Kong of South America."
Paraguay, which has low labor costs and large expanses of fertile land, can develop agriculture, largely soy and cotton. Farm products can be processed cheaply because of virtually limitless amounts of low-cost hydroelectric energy.
 
Central Role Likely for Uruguay
 Uruguay is expected to emerge as a service and financial center for the common market. It has the region's top literacy rate, a strong university system and a tradition as a banking center for Argentines and Brazilians.
For Brazil and Argentina, the common market is expected to provide more sales and foreign investment.
"This is a very positive move which opens up new areas of opportunity," Robert Stone, president of General Motors of Brazil, said in a telephone interview from his factory outside Sao Paulo. Partly with an eye to increasing exports, General Motors recently announced a $1 billion five-year modernization of its production lines in Brazil.

Practitioners of free trade there may be among the first to lose if the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay sign a treaty forming the Southern Cone Common Market when they meet on Tuesday. HEADLINE: Rumors Roil Coffee Market

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 24

 BODY:
Traders say that one of Brazil's largest coffee exporters profited from inside information about the Government's decision last week to suspend new export sales of coffee, newspapers reported on Saturday.
The exporter, identified by several Brazilian newspapers as Guilherme Ribeiro, denied the accusation in an interview with the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo. He said he had not operated for a long time in the New York coffee market, where the inside trades were said to have occurred. 
 Mr. Ribeiro owns two companies, Montenegro Exportacao e Importacao in Sao Paulo, and Irmaos Ribeiro in Santos, a port city. No one could be reached at either company this weekend.
Rumors swept the New York coffee market on Friday that some traders had been buying heavily in advance of Brazil's announcement the day earlier suspending export sales of coffee. On Thursday evening, the Government said it would suspend new export sales while it studied a return to international export quotas to push up prices.
On Friday, coffee for May delivery soared 5 cents a pound, to $1, on the news, but later closed at 93.05 cents a pound, down 1.95 cents.
Brazil's Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, said today that she would support an investigation into the accusations of speculative trading.
On Friday, the Federation of Brazilian Coffee Exporters had called for an investigation by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in the United States into what it called suspicious speculative movements in the New York market in the two days before the announcement.

HEADLINE: Poor Are Rocked by Closing of Gynecological Clinics

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Thousands of low-income women in New York City must now scramble to find routine gynecological care because the clinics where they used to receive it have been closed or scaled back for lack of money -- victims of city budget cuts and economic problems.
Nonprofit agencies are trying to find alternative clinics for these women, but until then the closings may mean no examinations, no counseling, no prescriptions for birth control pills or diaphragms, no Pap smears and no referrals to obstetricians or for abortions. 
 The closing of subsidized clinics in New York is an extreme example of a national trend, said Thomas C. Kring, a former president of the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association, which represents about 1,000 providers of gynecological care.
"Providers have been tightening their belts and trying to combine services rather than totally close them off, because they must operate with less money than they had in 1980, when Ronald Reagan took office," Mr. Kring said in a telephone interview from his Los Angeles office, where he is director of the California Family Planning Council, a nonprofit agency that administers Federal family-planning funds. In 1980, the Federal budget for family planning was $162 million; in 1990, it was $144 million.
"Nationwide, there are 1,000 fewer clinics providing subsidized services than there were in 1980," down from about 5,000, said Mr. Kring, who added that the number of patients getting subsidized care dropped to four million last year from five million in 1980.
 The clinic closings in New York illustrate how government budget gaps, often discussed in abstract terms, can disrupt the lives of ordinary people.
Three publicly financed family-planning clinics serving about 10,000 women -- in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens -- were closed this month. The one in Manhattan was merged with another nearby.
The closings have come at a stressful time for such subsidized clinics. Some have become the only source of medical care for many low-income women, and all are having to broaden their services beyond birth control and prenatal care. Now they are increasingly testing for AIDS and handling growing numbers of teen-age pregnancies.
At the same time, several thousand more New York City women also lost a source of routine gynecological care this month when Planned Parenthood of New York City discontinued providing such services at its only Manhattan clinic. Again, the reason was financial. Now women seeking pill prescriptions, diaphragms, testing and other services are referred to Planned Parenthood clinics in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Helena Greer, a 27-year-old mother of four, has received gynecological care for 13 years at the Qualicap Clinic in Long Island City, Queens. The other day, she heard that it had closed.
Now Ms. Greer wonders where she, her three sisters and her many friends in the neighborhood will go. "There is nothing else like it around here, especially not for teens." said Ms. Greer, who began using the clinic when she was 14. "It was free for people without Medicaid. Now I think that pregnancy among teens will get really bad."
The Qualicap Clinic and the others that have closed were operated by the Community Family Planning Council, a nonprofit voluntary agency that gets 46 percent of its financing from the city's Human Resources Administration. The rest of its budget comes from state, Federal and private sources.
 
Alternative Sources of Care
 In January, the H.R.A., facing budget cutbacks, announced that it would cut its $3.5 million grant to the family-planning council by $1 million this year and by almost $2.3 million next year.
As a result, the council closed Qualicap, at 42-15 Crescent Street in Long Island City, and two more of its 12 centers; the Action for Progress clinic at 92-94 Ludlow Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and the Coney Island Clinic at 2836 West 23d Street in Brooklyn. The Lower East Side center was merged with another at 191 Canal Street in Chinatown.
But administrators are still trying to find alternative sources of care for the patients in Brooklyn and Queens.
The three clinics to be closed were chosen because they were in areas with relatively lower rates of teen-age pregnancy and infant mortality, said Ana O. Dumois, the council's executive director. In addition, she said, "we didn't want to close clinics in boroughs with only one of our facilities, such as the Bronx and Staten Island."
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, said she was trying to restore some of the money cut from the Community Family Planning Council's grant so the Lower East Side clinic could reopen.
"This program is an investment in preventive services," Ms. Messinger said as she dropped by the Chinatown center the other day to see how the merger was going. "If you don't allow people the choice not to have children, and if you don't provide quality care early in pregnancy, then you end up paying for additional hospital costs for sick mothers, low-birth-weight babies and for the economic dependency and substantial poverty that will haunt some of these families for decades."
Dr. Dumois said that if some of the expected cuts were not restored in next year's allocation, "we may have to close two to three more clinics."
"If we have to go into another series of cuts," Dr. Dumois said, "then we will have to go into neighborhoods where infant mortality, low birth weight, teen-age pregnancy and HIV infection are among the highest."
 
A Question of Money
 At Planned Parenthood of New York City, the Margaret Sanger Center in Manhattan discontinued its routine family-planning and gynecological care this month and will now restrict its services to more technically complex and lucrative procedures. The center, at 380 Second Avenue near 22d Street, is Planned Parenthood's only clinic in Manhattan.
Many clients are working women who can afford its fees but not the fees of private gynecologists, many of whom do not accept Medicaid. Other clients are on public assistance. In either case, the Sanger Center's patients are now being referred to Planned Parenthood centers in Brooklyn and the Bronx for contraceptive counseling, physical examinations, Pap tests and treatment for all sexually transmitted diseases but AIDS. The Sanger Center recorded 7,500 visits for contraceptives in 1989, the last year for which data was available, and 1,800 for sexually transmitted diseases.
Now the clinic is concentrating on colposcopy, the examination of the cervix by microscope, and cryotherapy, the removal of lesions on the cervix by freezing. Abortions, HIV testing and counseling and intrauterine device insertion will continue to be available.
Alexander C. Sanger, the new president of Planned Parenthood of New York City, said changing the mission of the Manhattan center that bears his grandmother's name was "not something I came here to do."
On the horizon for Planned Parenthood and other organizations is the prospect that the United States Supreme Court may uphold rules that bar programs receiving Federal money from mentioning abortion as a choice for patients. An injunction has prevented the rules from being enforced until the court decides, but Planned Parenthood says that if the regulations are upheld, it will cease taking Federal funds rather than comply.
So far, budget cuts have not affected other programs that offer family-planning services to low-income and welfare patients in the city -- 11 acute-care municipal hospitals and five neighborhood primary care centers run by the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Appropriations by both the Federal and state government for family planning have remained more or less constant in the last few years, but clinic directors say the failure to keep pace with inflation has in fact led them to stretch their services thin.
"Everyone is having to retrench, at a time of inflation and at a time when they are having to add new services," said Shirley Gordon, executive director of Family Planning Advocates, an association of 140 clinics in New York State. She said clinics were being asked to deal with sharp rises in sexually transmitted diseases and more cases of cervical cancer and adolescent pregnancy.
The combination of factors is leaving many women without the gynecological care they had been used to. Donna Charles, 31, a bank clerk and former patient at the shuttered clinic on the Lower East Side, made the best of the situation the other day during her first appointment in the Chinatown center.
"I can't go anywhere else," she said. "I can't afford anything else. But I am glad to see some of the same staff here. I would follow these people wherever they are. I am not a stranger here."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
A wave of new taxes and tax increases appears to be developing in states, counties and cities. The trend, the third wave of local taxes since the 1930's, shows up in the many taxes enacted last year or proposed for 1991. It is reflected in bitter debates over essential public services and it is seen in the willingness of three states without an income tax to consider one. [Page A1.] 

 New orders for machine tools show surprising strength. The orders are often an important weathervane for the economy because the equipment is used by a wide range of manufacturers. [D1.] Spurred by higher demand from domestic companies, new orders for U.S. machine tools jumped 27.7 percent last month. [D7.]
The Supreme Court will decide who should hear a discrimination case filed by a brokerage executive who lost his job. Although the case concerns the long-established arbitration procedures of the securities industry, civil rights advocates say what is at stake is far more fundamental: a worker's right to sue for discrimination. [A1.]
 
Companies
NCR ended weeks of resistance, agreeing to meet for the first time with A.T.& T., which has been seeking to acquire it since December. The move came four days before a special shareholders meeting to consider A.T.& T.'s offer. [D1.]
Peter S. Kalikow has not repaid about $60 million in bank loans due in recent months, and three banks have sued him, bankers and lawyers said. Mr. Kalikow, one of New York City's largest owners of apartment buildings and the owner of The New York Post, could be forced to seek bankruptcy protection for himself and some assets if banks refuse to negotiate new terms. [A1.]
Chrysler has asked the Bush Administration to pressure Japan to limit vehicle sales in the U.S., warning that gains by the Japanese could put it out of business. The Treasury indicated that such tactics were unlikely to gain Administration support. [D10.]
 
International
The National Association of Manufacturers has asked for a complete re-examination of the U.S. relationship with Japan. The business leaders say progress toward erasing the huge trade deficit has been far too slow and uneven. [D1.]
Four South American presidents are expected to sign a treaty forming the Southern Cone Common Market. Under the treaty, goods and services are to circulate free of tariffs among Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay by 1996. [D1.]
Apple strudel and eclairs are signs of bold economic initiatives undertaken in Bhutan by King Jigme Singye Wangchuck. [D2.]

In his years at the helm of Paramount, Martin S. Davis has antagonized and driven out executives who went on to become big winners in the industry. The latest to depart was Frank Mancuso. [D1.]

New York is to book publishing what Wall Street is to finance and Broadway is to theater. There appears little likelihood that important publishers will leave. Edwin McDowell: Publishing. [D8.]
A majority of consumers are shaken by the gulf war, discouraged by the recession and see the American dream of a good life slipping out of reach, according to a study by Grey Advertising. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Bias Lawsuit Jolts Suburb Widely Cited As Integrated

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, March 22

 BODY:
Whatever else New Rochelle has done, or failed to do, in the postwar decades of suburban expansion, integration of its minority residents is considered a major success. So when four residents filed a lawsuit last week charging that the city's election system discriminated against blacks, many in this suburban city were startled.
House-hunting for blacks transferred to the metropolitan area often begins here because, as a bank executive said, "The mix is good." 
 But apparently not good enough to produce more than one black City Councilman, Joseph Evans, in the city's history. Mr. Evans was appointed to the five-member Council in 1965 and went on to win election twice.
Blacks, who represent 18 percent of New Rochelle's population, have been disenfranchised, contends the suit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, because election to the Council is at-large, or citywide, which tends to favor the white majority, rather than from districts.
 
'System Should Be Changed'
 During an era when many Northeastern cities have been touched by racial strife, New Rochelle has long been known as one of the New York metropolitan region's best integrated cities. Its neighbor to the west, Mount Vernon, has a much larger black community, representing 55 percent of the city's population. But it is essentially divided from the predominantly white community by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad line, which cuts the city in half.
Farther to the west of New Rochelle, Yonkers, with a 13 percent black population concentrated on the west side of the city, has had its share of racial discord. Yonkers is under Federal court orders to build 200 units of low-cost housing at seven sites on the east side of the city.
Still, Edward O. Howard, a black lawyer who lives in Rochelle Heights, an integrated community in the city, said this week in an interview that more needed to be done. "Black candidates are not known, generally, outside their neighborhood," he said. "We're not a ghettoized community, nor is New Rochelle racially polarized, but the system should be changed."
Kim Christensen, an assistant professor of economics at the State University of New York at Purchase and a New Rochelle resident, agreed, saying that "every group needs to have its views heard." Professor Christensen, who is white, lives "in a neighborhood that has Hispanics, whites and blacks -- possibly 60 or 70 percent white."
 
Concentration of Blacks
 According to the 1990 Census, New Rochelle's population is 67,160, down 5 percent from the 1980 total of 70,794. Blacks also declined in numbers, and in nearly similar proportion, from 12,689 in 1980 to 12,166, or 4 percent. The city's fastest-growing population is Hispanic, doubling in size from 3,800 in 1980 to 7,200 today.
Black residents, while represented in every neighborhood, are concentrated in a central belt that has City Hall, coincidentally, at its center. Two of every three New Rochelle blacks live in that area, fulfilling one of the "threshold" conditions that mark successful prosecution of Voting Rights Act cases.
Some blacks argue that if the Council members were elected from districts, a black candidate might have a good chance of winning in the neighborhood where black voters are concentrated.
Randolph Scott-McLaughlin, an associate law professor at the Pace University Law School who helped the Center for Constitutional Rights prepare its case against New Rochelle, said, "There have been more than 60 such suits, mostly in the South, and we know what the U.S. Supreme Court looks for in these cases."
"They want to know if the minority community is both politically and geographically cohesive," he said. "If it has no political clubs, no N.A.A.C.P., it probably won't support a minority candidate. Similarly the Court wants to know if a district can be formed with a 65 percent minority population. A city that is perfectly integrated could not form such a district."
 
At-Large Elections Defended
 The center sued the city, the Council and the County Board of Elections on behalf of these black residents: Ossie Davis, the actor; Napoleon Holmes, head of the New Rochelle chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; Wilhelmena Strong, a public-school teacher, and Paul D. Dennis, director of the New Rochelle Youth Bureau.
Ruth Kitchen, a Democratic Council member, defends at-large elections, saying that dividing the city into districts "will polarize the city, forcing Council members to think first of their home district and secondly of the city."
"It is untrue that blacks cannot be elected," Ms. Kitchen said. "A black Democrat who ran with me in the last election lost to a Republican only by the margin of his opponent's Conservative Party vote. Also, election to the Board of Education is citywide, and two of its nine members are black."
New Rochelle is far from perfectly integrated, and Edward Coll, a clothing industry executive, finds that situation satisfactory. Standing at the city's refurbished train station, he said: "New Rochelle is a suburb, but it provides a view of urban life. Our children have gained a lot from living here."
Karin Battersby and Fran Oliver, friends at the high school, find a measure of pride in their racial differences. "It makes a difference; it makes you open-minded," said Karin, who is white. Fran, who is black, said, "It's the real world."
Robert D. Kuklis, principal of the high school, said white students represented 58 percent of last year's graduating class, black 28 percent, Hispanic 8 percent and "rising," and Asian 7 percent.
 
A Suburban Prototype
 For generations, New Rochelle was the prototypical suburb. George M. Cohan set his musical "Forty-Five Minutes From Broadway" in New Rochelle, where he lived. Rob and Laura Petrie, the family depicted in television's long-running "Dick Van Dyke Show," lived in New Rochelle.
But the glitter of the "Queen City of the Sound," as it was known, has faded somewhat over the years. Local merchants were unable to compete with the easy shopping in outlying malls and were further depressed to see New Rochelle companies moving to campus-like settings elsewhere.
New Rochelle is now 31 minutes (and $114 a month) from Grand Central Terminal by Metro-North, and the city is a lot more sophisticated than Mr. Cohan saw it in the song that is better known for its title, "Forty-Five Minutes From Broadway," than for its verses:
 
If you want to find a real hick delegation
The place where the real reubens dwell
Just hop on a train at Grand Central Station
And get off when they shout "New Rochelle."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fran Oliver, left, and Karin Battersby are friends at New Rochelle High School, where white students represented 58 percent of last year's graduating class and black students represented 28 percent.; "The system should be changed," said Edward O. Howard, a lawyer who lives in Rochelle Heights, referring to charges that the election system in New Rochelle discriminates against blacks.; Ruth Kitchen, a New Rochelle City Council member, defended at-large elections, saying that dividing the city into districts "will polarize the city." HEADLINE: Outdoors: Free-Spirited Search for Shad

BYLINE: By PETER KAMINSKY

 BODY:
WHEN I took up fly fishing I was captivated by Charles Waterman's written accounts of shad fishing on Florida's St. Johns River.
It seemed such a free spirited and adventuresome kind of angling. All you had to do was throw a couple of flies in your box and head for the river and never mind the gators and moccasins. 
 This year my annual visit coincided with the peak of the spawning run that sends the shad up the rivers of the East Coast. The shad enter the St. Johns during February and March. The peak of the run comes as spring weather warms the water. Reports had them in the St. Johns as far as Puzzle Lake (northwest of Cape Canaveral), where high water and strong currents had produced good angling.
My guide was my longtime fishing companion, Jack Allen of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a premier flyrod angler who specializes in Everglades bass. We left well before first light.
The endless malls and condos flew by, shrouded in ground mist as we sliced up I-95. In his big old yellow Chevy, trailering a scarred but well cared for square stern canoe, Allen kept up his end of the fishing dialogue broken only by a lengthy digression on the genius of Johnny Mercer's lyrics.
We headed west on State Road 46 across the wide prairie formed by the meanders of the St. Johns. We put in just downstream of Puzzle Lake. The morning stillness was broken by the sounds of a large truck and trailer which sped into the parking lot like something out of "Road Warrior."
The driver informed us that he was a commercial eel fisherman, like his father before him. With the economy of motion of a man whose livelihood depends on making good use of his time on the water, he worked as he spoke and within minutes, he was gone.
We were the first anglers. We looped around the lazy bends of the river. Side channels invited us, but Allen knew from experience that we would find shad on a certain undercut bank on a narrow stretch of river. We beached our boat at the outlet of a small feeder stream. The light from the east cast a golden net on the green fields of the flood plain.
Allen gave me a four weight rod on which he had fitted a six weight line. "Overlining" is one of his favorite techniques. It affords the angler the pleasant feel of working a light rod, while the extra weight in the line minimizes false casting and delivers a heavy bug over distance.
I walked along the bank. There were no obstacles in the way of my backcast. Grazing cattle had mown the lawn very nicely. On the far bank, up against the reeds, feeding bass smacked the surface. They broke my concentration the way an insistent child can make you put down a book.
But we were rigged for shad on the bottom, not bass on the surface. The air was dead calm. We would have three hours before the morning wind from the ocean reached us. I put the bass out of my mind and cast, 60 feet straight across the channel.
The heavy shad fly hit with a plunk and swung around in the current. On the third or fourth cast, just as the fly finished its swing I felt the tap tap of fish. He bent the rod and fought well in the current, taking line from the reel. I landed the shad, a 2-pounder and released him. I worked my way downstream and, within an hour, had taken four. I felt flush.
We continued upstream to see if there were any other likely holes. The breeze stiffened and the water was, in Allen's words, "rough as a cob." We came upon some perfect holding water. We jumped on the bank and fought through thigh-high muck to get off a cast, but no matter how we turned the wind was coming straight at us. So much for placid, easy fly fishing. An eight weight flyrod will handle windy conditions. Sink tips seem to be favored over full sinking lines. The shad flies should be gaudy and weighted.
We slogged back to the boat. For the next two hours, as we followed the switchbacks of the river, the wind parried our every move. I wondered why there were no carcasses of spent shad in the river.
Up north they fairly blanket the stream bottom. A local fisherman with whom we struck up a chat, explained: each year when the shad come up the stream, some thousands of sea-going white pelicans follow them. No sooner do the shad finish creating their next generation than the huge white birds descend and devour them.
The relentless wind had driven every fly fisherman on the river back to the stretch of bank where I had found success that morning. It was the only place that offered a lee. So for the balance of the afternoon, about a dozen of us strung ourselves up and down the bank. Once or twice I looked up to see a bend in the rod of the angler furthest downstream, signaling the upstream advance of a new pod of shad. One by one we would hook into a fish until the whole dozen of us had a shad on.
Walking up and down the bank, trading flies and stories, we had a nice streamside party going. One angler, a novice fly fisherman, outcaught the rest of us by a long shot. He never stopped smiling and he and his buddy kept up the running banter that comes so happily when you have a fish on the line.
Since he wasn't the world's greatest caster, we all assumed it was just a matter of his having positioned himself at just the right spot at just the right time. I put our theory to the test when the happy fisherman reeled up at five o'clock. Just as soon as he headed downstream I positioned myself exactly where he was standing. I cast exactly where he had cast and I continued there for half an hour. I never had a nibble.

HEADLINE: Sore Winners

 BODY:
Dovish Democrats have been brooding and bristling as Republicans crow about Commander in Chief Bush's bold victory in the Persian Gulf. Most G.O.P. politicians have had the good grace not to disparage the opposition. They believe, correctly, that Mr. Bush will reap the fruits of victory and that a divisive debate won't help his cause.
But a few sore winners have sought partisan advantage. With 20-20 hindsight, they accuse doves of pusillanimous pessimism, of lacking the guts to take on a blustering bully and the smarts to trust the brave allied forces. 
 The accusations sting. But they miss the thrust of the doves' objections, which were honestly stated. And they ignore the fact that the Administration itself -- including the generals who planned and executed the war -- feared that it would be long and costly. While hawks taunt doves with I-told-you-so's, the top brass is more circumspect.
When the proposal to dispatch troops was first broached, the Joint Chiefs of Staff voiced doubts. How well would U.S. men and materiel stand up to the battle-hardened Iraqis and the desert heat? How long would the public tolerate a war that could last months? "All the Chiefs understand," said a four-star general in August, "that the United States is an impatient country."
Intelligence analysts put Iraqi strength at 516,000 in the Kuwaiti theater. That turns out to have been an overestimate. The 100,000 Iraqi desertions before the ground war began in earnest vastly exceeded the most optimistic forecasts.
To avoid engaging so large a force head on, General Schwarzkopf backed the "hail Mary play" -- going deep into Iraq to cut off the Iraqis in Kuwait. After some restless nights, he tried to delay its execution. Had the Iraqis detected the preparations and counterattacked, they could have inflicted heavy losses and prolonged the war.
Defense Secretary Cheney warned that Iraqi forces had chemical arms. General Schwarzkopf took the threat seriously enough to have troops don protective gear. Even now generals wonder why Iraq did not use gas to slow down the allies.
Early on the Pentagon expected 40,000 U.S.casualties. Just before the ground war began, the estimate was lowered to 5,000. Jiggling the numbers up or down can provide a rationale for reinforcements or a go-ahead for attack. And doubtless, there was some poor-mouthing. But field officers remain amazed at how many allied advances were uncontested and how few Americans fell.
The same was true of the air war. Air Force Chief of Staff Merrill McPeak projected losses of "four or five aircraft a day" in the deliberations leading up to the war. His "private hunch" was less than that. But "even in my . . . wildest dreams," he said, "I would not have said we would lose one aircraft every three days in this kind of operation."
Inevitably, the doves were influenced by this official pessimism. They had other concerns as well. For example, they felt U.S. interests were vital enough to justify force only as a last resort and that the less risky alternative of economic sanctions had yet to be fully tested. The war mooted the issue. But hawks who were quick to say in January that sanctions alone wouldn't disarm Iraq and drive Saddam Hussein from power are now relying on sanctions to complete those aims.
Doves also doubted that war would create the stable Middle East that the U.S. sought. That issue remains in doubt as the troops remain in place, civil war rends Iraq and the peace process sputters. Until all the results are in, faulting the doves for these diplomatic misgivings is premature.
The generals themselves had little reason to believe that a short war was a sure thing. Knowing that, the doves preferred a strategy of patient pressure. Mr. Bush's quick resort to force worked out well. That may make the doves politically vulnerable, but it doesn't make them dishonorable.

HEADLINE: For Yugoslavia, Unity Still Holds Best Hope;
Neighborly Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"On the Edge, in the Lands That Wrote the Book" (The Week in Review, March 3), on Balkanization in the Balkans, couldn't be further off the mark. You state that "nobody outside Yugoslavia is prepared to welcome its separate parts into the European family," but neighboring western and eastern European nations have been giving both Slovenia and Croatia unofficial support.
Countries such as Austria, Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have much to gain by establishment of free and independent democracies in Slovenia and Croatia, with their thriving free-market economies. Slovenia and Croatia, with long historical and cultural ties to these nations, have received vital good will, moral support, favorable news media coverage and other unofficial support from private institutions in those countries. 
 Indeed, Hungary's large sale of automatic weapons to the government of Croatia last fall helped this struggling republic preserve its hard-won democracy by standing up to the Communist Yugoslav army. Unfortunately, this army, whose officer corps is 70 percent Serbian, is the last functioning federal institution in Yugoslavia, through which Communist-ruled Serbia can extend its heavy grip over the other democratic republics.
Clearly, Yugoslavia, and its main champion, Serbia, are finding themselves increasingly more isolated in the international community because of this Serb-controlled army intimidation, because of Serbian repression of Albanians in Kosovo and because of recent Serbian abuse of the federal banking system. Even the International Monetary Fund recently suspended all negotiations with Yugoslavia on monetary aid until this internal turmoil settles.
And even more clearly, the continued existence of Yugoslavia, as it is constituted today, is not in the best interest of Yugoslavia's neighbors. For that matter, it is not in the best long-term interest of the United States either. When push comes to shove in Yugoslavia soon, those European countries will support the democracies in Slovenia and Croatia. So should we.
 
ANTHONY MARGAN
Alexandria, Va., March 3, 1991
 
The writer is a member of the Croatian Democracy Project.

HEADLINE: Bias Lawsuit Jolts Suburb Widely Cited As Integrated

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, March 22

 BODY:
Whatever else New Rochelle has done, or failed to do, in the postwar decades of suburban expansion, integration of its minority residents is considered a major success. So when four residents filed a lawsuit last week charging that the city's election system discriminated against blacks, many in this suburban city were startled.
House-hunting for blacks transferred to the metropolitan area often begins here because, as a bank executive said, "The mix is good." 
 But apparently not good enough to produce more than one black City Councilman, Joseph Evans, in the city's history. Mr. Evans was appointed to the five-member Council in 1965 and went on to win election twice.
Blacks, who represent 18 percent of New Rochelle's population, have been disenfranchised, contends the suit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, because election to the Council is at-large, or citywide, which tends to favor the white majority, rather than from districts.
 
'System Should Be Changed'
 During an era when many Northeastern cities have been touched by racial strife, New Rochelle has long been known as one of the New York metropolitan region's best integrated cities. Its neighbor to the west, Mount Vernon, has a much larger black community, representing 55 percent of the city's population. But it is essentially divided from the predominantly white community by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad line, which cuts the city in half.
Farther to the west of New Rochelle, Yonkers, with a 13 percent black population concentrated on the west side of the city, has had its share of racial discord. Yonkers is under Federal court orders to build 200 units of low-cost housing at seven sites on the east side of the city.
Still, Edward O. Howard, a black lawyer who lives in Rochelle Heights, an integrated community in the city, said this week in an interview that more needed to be done. "Black candidates are not known, generally, outside their neighborhood," he said. "We're not a ghettoized community, nor is New Rochelle racially polarized, but the system should be changed."
Kim Christensen, an assistant professor of economics at the State University of New York at Purchase and a New Rochelle resident, agreed, saying that "every group needs to have its views heard." Professor Christensen, who is white, lives "in a neighborhood that has Hispanics, whites and blacks -- possibly 60 or 70 percent white."
 
Concentration of Blacks
 According to the 1990 Census, New Rochelle's population is 67,160, down 5 percent from the 1980 total of 70,794. Blacks also declined in numbers, and in nearly similar proportion, from 12,689 in 1980 to 12,166, or 4 percent. The city's fastest-growing population is Hispanic, doubling in size from 3,800 in 1980 to 7,200 today.
Black residents, while represented in every neighborhood, are concentrated in a central belt that has City Hall, coincidentally, at its center. Two of every three New Rochelle blacks live in that area, fulfilling one of the "threshold" conditions that mark successful prosecution of Voting Rights Act cases.
Some blacks argue that if the Council members were elected from districts, a black candidate might have a good chance of winning in the neighborhood where black voters are concentrated.
Randolph Scott-McLaughlin, an associate law professor at the Pace University Law School who helped the Center for Constitutional Rights prepare its case against New Rochelle, said, "There have been more than 60 such suits, mostly in the South, and we know what the U.S. Supreme Court looks for in these cases."
"They want to know if the minority community is both politically and geographically cohesive," he said. "If it has no political clubs, no N.A.A.C.P., it probably won't support a minority candidate. Similarly the Court wants to know if a district can be formed with a 65 percent minority population. A city that is perfectly integrated could not form such a district."
 
At-Large Elections Defended
 The center sued the city, the Council and the County Board of Elections on behalf of these black residents: Ossie Davis, the actor; Napoleon Holmes, head of the New Rochelle chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; Wilhelmena Strong, a public-school teacher, and Paul D. Dennis, director of the New Rochelle Youth Bureau.
Ruth Kitchen, a Democratic Council member, defends at-large elections, saying that dividing the city into districts "will polarize the city, forcing Council members to think first of their home district and secondly of the city."
"It is untrue that blacks cannot be elected," Ms. Kitchen said. "A black Democrat who ran with me in the last election lost to a Republican only by the margin of his opponent's Conservative Party vote. Also, election to the Board of Education is citywide, and two of its nine members are black."
New Rochelle is far from perfectly integrated, and Edward Coll, a clothing industry executive, finds that situation satisfactory. Standing at the city's refurbished train station, he said: "New Rochelle is a suburb, but it provides a view of urban life. Our children have gained a lot from living here."
Karin Battersby and Fran Oliver, friends at the high school, find a measure of pride in their racial differences. "It makes a difference; it makes you open-minded," said Karin, who is white. Fran, who is black, said, "It's the real world."
Robert D. Kuklis, principal of the high school, said white students represented 58 percent of last year's graduating class, black 28 percent, Hispanic 8 percent and "rising," and Asian 7 percent.
 
A Suburban Prototype
 For generations, New Rochelle was the prototypical suburb. George M. Cohan set his musical "Forty-Five Minutes From Broadway" in New Rochelle, where he lived. Rob and Laura Petrie, the family depicted in television's long-running "Dick Van Dyke Show," lived in New Rochelle.
But the glitter of the "Queen City of the Sound," as it was known, has faded somewhat over the years. Local merchants were unable to compete with the easy shopping in outlying malls and were further depressed to see New Rochelle companies moving to campus-like settings elsewhere.
New Rochelle is now 31 minutes (and $114 a month) from Grand Central Terminal by Metro-North, and the city is a lot more sophisticated than Mr. Cohan saw it in the song that is better known for its title, "Forty-Five Minutes From Broadway," than for its verses:
 
If you want to find a real hick delegation
The place where the real reubens dwell
Just hop on a train at Grand Central Station
And get off when they shout "New Rochelle."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 26, 1991, Tuesday

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a voting-rights lawsuit against New Rochelle, N.Y., misstated the city's black population in some editions. Blacks make up 18 percent of the population.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
The Field Is Still Open, Time Wanes And, as in '88, the Name Gore Arises

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Fire in the belly is a rare commodity among Democrats these days.
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia says he most definitely lacks it. Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas has left many Democrats wondering. Even Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader and a man with a clear case of Presidential ambition, seems to be trying to dampen speculation about his plans. 
 The party, as a whole, seems to be struggling to work up its enthusiasm for a Presidential campaign against a popular incumbent coming off a popular war. In such a climate, ambition can seem a virtue and unblinking confidence on an unlined face is not automatically dismissed as hubris. And Senator Al Gore stands out.
Fire in the belly? "I guess because I ran before, I will always be suspect of having that fire," says the Democrat from Tennessee. "And I will not deny that."
 
No Decision Yet
 Mr. Gore, whose 1988 campaign for the Democratic nomination sputtered out in the New York primary, says he has not made a decision on whether to seek the Presidency in 1992. But the interest is clearly there, and some Democrats argue that the moment is ripe for the 42-year-old Senator.
The field is virtually wide open. The party is slightly panicked as the weeks go by and the most visible standard-bearers are still George S. McGovern, the 1972 nominee who lost 49 states, and Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts.
What particularly intrigues the oddsmakers in Democratic politics is a simple fact: Mr. Gore is inoculated on the one issue that has tormented his party in recent weeks. He was one of just 10 Democratic Senators to vote in favor of the resolution authorizing war in the Persian Gulf. Almost every other potential Democratic contender voted or spoke against it.
As Carter Eskew, a Democratic political consultant and friend of Mr. Gore, puts it: Mr. Gore could run "without the constant noise, the nyah-nyah-nyah-nyah-nyah, on the gulf."
No one knows how long the Persian Gulf issue will last in the Presidential campaign. No one suggests it is a rationale for a Presidential candidacy. But for now, at least, the issue that has devastated men like Mr. Nunn has shed an attractive new light on Mr. Gore.
"I think Al is positioned extremely well," said Nathan Landow, chairman of the Maryland Democratic Party and leader of a group of financial contributors who rallied behind Mr. Gore in 1988.
The question, for many of Mr. Gore's supporters, is whether a candidacy in 1992 would further his goal of being President one day. If an ambitious young Democrat won the nomination but lost the election against Mr. Bush, as is widely expected, would that candidate be repudiated by his party? Or would he emerge well-positioned for 1996, a tested warrior for a grateful party?
Mr. Gore, of course, does not mention such tactical considerations when asked about the factors he weighs. Sipping tea in his office, surrounded by mementoes of a life in politics, including his own "Doonesbury" story line spoofing his privileged background and youthful chutzpah through the character "Prince Albert," Mr. Gore begins with a disclaimer -- that he does not seek to use this interview to sketch campaign themes or advance a candidacy.
"I have not yet reached the stage where I'm going to make the decision on whether I'm going to run," he says. "But I have very strong beliefs about what this country needs to do, what we as a people need to do."
He recites the Democratic litany of unmet needs. "On the side of running," he says, "I think this country is feeling the Reagan-Bush years and needs to approach domestic problems like the economy, competitiveness, the environment, crime, with a sense of determination and with leadership and with 'the vision thing.' "
On the other side of the scales, he says, are personal considerations. Having run before, he says, "It's a lot harder for me to deceive myself about what it really means to make a two-year campaign for President. The last time I fooled myself into thinking that I would see my family one or two days a week, or that the children could take turns coming out on the road. I don't believe that now, because I know that, when the campaign starts, you almost have to say goodbye to your wife and children for the duration."
 
Concerns for Family
 Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, who gained her own prominence as a critic of obscenity in rock music lyrics, have three daughters, ages 12, 13 and 17, and a son, Albert 3d.
"My son, who is the youngest in the family, is only eight years old, and he's already been through one Presidential campaign, and more," the Senator said. Two years ago, while Mr. Gore was attending a Baltimore Orioles baseball game with his son, the boy broke away and was hit by a car. His injuries were serious, his recovery long.
For all of that, Mr. Gore has long shown all of the symptoms of a common senatorial syndrome: Sooner or later, senators look in a mirror and see a President.
The Harvard-educated son of a prominent Senator, Albert Gore Sr., Mr. Gore crossed that threshold at the age of 39. He jumped into the 1988 campaign for the Democratic nomination, positioning himself as the Southern candidate in a year when the South was supposed to play a critical role in choosing the nominee. It did not.
Mr. Gore careered from message to message, theme to theme, from Southern populism to Gary Hart-style "new generation" politics. He offered himself as the Democrat who was tough on foreign policy, the favorite son of a proud South, the Democrat who was willing to confront the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
He did well on Super Tuesday, the round of Southern primaries on March 8, but his campaign seemed to have no coherent strategy for the day after, when the race rolled back into the North. He withdrew after finishing a distant third in New York.
"He was a very young guy running for President for the first time," said one veteran Democratic strategist.
His critics, and there were many, said his campaign was all about positioning and a search for short-term tactical advantage. Mr. Gore still bristles at the notion that his national security stance was a matter of campaign positioning: "I had a career in the House for eight years and four years in the Senate before I ran for President."
But he adds, with a slight laugh, "I've begun to suspect that I made some mistakes in that campaign. And if that hypothesis is proven out, one of them might be that I didn't do a very good job of articulating and staying with the core beliefs that motivated my decision to run."
Mr. Gore also offers some self-deprecating humor to defuse another charge from the 1988 campaign. "The story I remember from that campaign is: How can you tell Al Gore from a room full of Secret Service agents? And the answer is: He's the stiff one."
The political damage from his 1988 Presidential campaign was less extensive than many predicted. He retired his debt quickly. He handily won re-election to the Senate last fall. While his rhetoric in New York was hot -- he said of Mr. Jackson, "We're not choosing a preacher, we're choosing a President," and his most prominent supporter in New York, Edward I. Koch, who was then Mayor, denounced Mr. Jackson repeatedly -- Mr. Jackson says today, "We have a good rapport, mutual respect."
 
Experience Will Count
 Democratic strategists say the experience of a past Presidential campaign is invaluable. "What Gore has this time is the greatest single asset someone brings to running for President, and that is that he's run before," one strategist said.
Mr. Gore says: "When I run again, whenever that is, assuming that I do, I will spend a lot more time focusing on the priorities that I believe important day in and day out, and a lot less time running from one event to another, keeping in the traveling roadshow that develops in these things."
Mr. Gore has kept working on his pet causes, particularly the environment and global warming. He is writing a book, which he declines to discuss, and has continued to write opinion pieces and guest columns.
Mr. Gore's position on the gulf war vote has made him one of the few Democrats able to take the offensive in recent weeks, as Republicans began to hammer the Democrats for their votes. He took the floor of the Senate this month and declared, "Shame on those Republican operatives for playing politics with American lives, for the disservice they do to the brave American soldiers who made the ultimate sacrifice for their country."
He has begun calling, as he did this morning on the NBC News television program "Meet the Press," for an effort on domestic ills to match the American effort in the gulf, an echo of the old Democratic tradition of aggressive foreign and domestic policy.
"The world as a whole has chosen, with few exceptions, democracy and capitalism as the wave of the future," he said. "And we need to come out and say, here's how we perfect those. But the Democratic Party, in addition, says, let's fight for those values here at home -- our job isn't finished yet."
The dance is beginning again.
"Let's go through a little ritual," said Garrick Utley, the show's host. "I'm going to ask you a question and you're going to give me a straight answer, right? Are you going to run for President?"
Al Gore smiled and said, "I haven't decided yet."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Recruiters Expand Into Outplacement

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
CONFUSION, growing competition and even financial problems abound in two career-oriented service businesses, management recruiting and outplacement. This affects another group, management consulting.
Russell Reynolds Inc, and Korn/ Ferry International, large management recruiting concerns, have cut staffs because of the hiring downturn. Korn/Ferry, among others, has announced broader services such as a new unit to provide executive compensation advice, which takes it into fierce competition with management consultants that specialize in human resource planning, like Hewitt Associates and Towers Perrin. 
 At the same time outplacement concerns say business is good but complain about rising expenses because it takes much longer for displaced managers to find jobs -- eight months reported by some compared with six months last year and a mere three months or less during prosperous years in the 1980's. That means increased costs for expensive counseling, office space and clerical help.
Even so, some recruiters hungrily eye the outplacement field, and more and more -- like the Winchester Group, in San Mateo, Calif., and People Management Northeast, in Simsbury, Conn. -- have already entered it.
"The associations for both groups see it as conflict of interest; I see it as an apparent conflict and I vote for purity," James H. Kennedy said last week. A perennial critic, he is the publisher of newletters and directories on outplacement, recruiting and management consulting.
"Let's see where the conflict is," he added. "There might be double-dipping for fees if an outplaced person is placed in a job through the management recruiting arm of a firm. Some say, 'We don't put the scoop in all the way -- we take a reduced fee.' "
Janet Jones-Parker, former executive director of the Association of Executive Search Consultants Inc., recently joined A. T. Kearney Inc., better known as a management consulting concern, in its management recruiting unit in Stamford, Conn.
She agrees with Mr. Kennedy. "I don't think firms can do both activities well because executive search is so specialized," she said. She added that the earnings decline of many recruiting concerns could be attributed partly to being "locked into a high overhead if they operate in cities like New York."
"My strategy for a search firm," she said, "would be to have a few strong business generators in New York, where rents are high -- four or five at a maximum, who can bring in $500,000 in fees yearly, and more offices elsewhere."
Search fees run about 33 percent of a recruited executive's pay, or $33,000 for a $100,000-a-year and $82,500 for a $250,000-a-year executive. Fees are paid by companies.
Robert M. Hecht of Lee Hecht Harrison, a large outplacement concern, agrees that more and more recruiting firms are expanding into outplacement, but he believes they are in for "a rude awakening" financially. Outplacement fees run only about 15 percent of the displaced person's salary.
"They claim the two functions never overlap," he said, "but I am not so sure that is true or that it is even desirable to operate in both areas. I am not sure that a management recruiting boutique that specializes has the resources to hire the right people for effective outplacement."
"We are in a different business," he added. "Outplacment counselors must have a different mental set. The amount of time, effort and caring attitude involved is monumental. We are continually racing against a psychic clock ticking away an outplaced client's individual esteem and his relations with family. There is trauma involved and we have to provide crisis intervention."
While management recruiting concerns regard outplacement as a way to expand, outplacement firms also look outward. Some, like Mr. Hecht's, are setting up divisions to advise on career renewal, retirement planning and career management for companies, functions of many management consulting firms.
Andrew Sherwood noted that his firm, the Goodrich & Sherwood Company, started in 1971 as a management recruiting firm and added outplacement in 1976. As a contented fence straddler he has a good overview. "For the last three years our recruiting business has grown maybe 1 percent a year," he said. "In other words, it is about flat, but outplacement has grown 100 percent each of those years. I would say that the management recruiting business has slowed partly because outplacement has done such a good job."
Techniques have become so sophisticated that often displaced persons can through networking reach specific companies seeking new managers before the company hires an outside recruiter. "That saves the companies money," Mr. Sherwood said.

HEADLINE: Little-Known Carlyle Scores Big

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For weeks, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia pondered the notion of spending a spare half-billion dollars. Then last month, on the recommendation of American advisers, he used the money to buy up a sizable piece of America's largest banking company, Citicorp.
The advisers were the Carlyle Group -- not a familiar name on Wall Street, certainly. In fact, its only New York connection is that it takes its name from the city's famed luxury hotel, a favorite of the Carlyle partners. 
 The Carlyle Group, relatively new and based in Washington, is led by people with little experience in the investment business but with strong connections, especially in Washington.
David M. Rubenstein, a founding partner, served as a domestic policy adviser to President Jimmy Carter; Frank C. Carlucci, the vice chairman, was Defense Secretary in the Reagan Administration, and Frederick V. Malek, an adviser, is close to President Bush.
 
Where Connections Led
 The Carlyle Group's connections led to a Washington lawyer, Alphonso Christian. Mr. Christian, of the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, is an old friend of Faissal Fahad al-Talal, who represents the Prince in the United States.
The Prince, who had quietly accumulated a 4.9 percent stake in Citicorp common during the fall, was considering an even bigger investment, $590 million in Citicorp preferred stock, and needed help in making it. To that end, in early January, Mr. Christian arranged for the Prince's representative to meet the Carlyle executives, and Carlyle won the business.
Carlyle's competitors for the Citicorp transaction -- James B. Wolfenson & Company and Eric Gleacher, among them -- dismiss the group's success as a fluke. Carlyle's partners say it was a matter of knowing the right people in the right places.
"If the lawyer had not been recommending us, I don't think we would have been hired," Mr. Rubenstein said.
Connections were not the only factor in the decision. Stephen L. Norris, the Carlyle partner who acted as the point man on the Citicorp transaction, said the Prince's lawyer was concerned about "real or imagined conflicts New York firms might have in dealings with Citicorp, as well as their ability to maintain confidentiality at a time when it was important to do so."
Indeed, Salomon Brothers Inc., which received an unsolicited phone call from the Prince's lawyer about representing the Prince, begged off because of business ties to Citicorp.
Carlyle was also willing to take a pittance of the Prince's money -- $50,000 -- in fees. But ultimately Carlyle earned much more, though Citicorp paid the fee, not the Prince. Neither will disclose the amount.
Prince Waleed is the Carlyle Group's biggest catch by far, but the group is also in the beginning stages of a number of other other sizable undertakings, chiefly in mergers and acquisitions of both foreign and domestic companies.
The firm has come a long way from the mid-1980's, when Edward J. Mathias, a vice president at T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore mutual fund company, spoke many times with Mr. Rubenstein, a neighbor and close friend in suburban Maryland, about starting up a small firm as a relatively inexpensive and safe way to learn the leveraged buyout business.
In late 1986, Mr. Rubenstein gave up his partnership at a Washington law firm and began a six-month hunt for investors interested in putting money into such a firm. Along the way, Mr. Rubenstein persuaded two bright young executives at the Marriott Corporation, Daniel A. D'Aniello and Mr. Norris, to join him. William E. Conway Jr., chief financial officer at the MCI Communications Corporation, joined later. The Carlyle Group now employs 25.
"We thought we could take four smart fellas, set them up in business, and lever them with partners that a major firm might have available," Mr. Mathias said.
 
Impressive Backers
 In addition to T. Rowe Price, the original partners and Mr. Mathias lined up an impressive lot to invest in the fledgling enterprise: Alex. Brown & Sons, First Interstate Bank of Los Angeles and the Richard K. Mellon family trust.
Compared with the money Wall Street was raising for deals at the time, the firm's initial capital base of $5 million was paltry. Nevertheless, just two months after its creation, Carlyle found itself in the midst of a takeover struggle when it began buying stock in Chi-Chi's, a Mexican restaurant chain based in Louisville, Ky.
Carlyle never got the chance to run the chain because in March 1988, Foodmaker Inc. acquired Chi-Chi's for $285 million. But Carlyle's stake in Chi-Chi's generated a $3.5 million profit.
Since then, Carlyle has tended to raise money on a deal-by-deal basis. A wide range of foreign and domestic institutions and individuals, from Banque Paribas of France to the Sumitomo Bank of Japan, have invested in or helped to finance Carlyle deals.
Carlyle transactions have generally involved much more equity than most of the leveraged buyouts of the 80's. And much of that equity is sold to management teams that remain in place. In this way, Carlyle reduces the potential return to its investors but it also lowers its risk if its deals crumble under the weight of debt-service payments.
The investment record of the firm is thus far difficult to judge, since payouts in its leveraged buyout business are generally not expected for five to seven years.
 
High Price for Oakite
 What is clear, however, is that in at least once case it paid an extremely high price for Oakite Products Inc., a manufacturer of industrial and consumer cleaners and lubricants in Berkeley Heights, N.J., investment bankers said. Carlyle acquired it in early 1989 for $90 million, more than 12 times the company's pretax 1988 earnings of roughly $7 million.
"At that time paying as much as eight times earnings would have been a full price," an investment banker familiar with Oakite said. Mr. Rubenstein said Carlyle had recently signed a letter of intent with an unidentified German partner who would inject an unspecified amount of capital into Oakite.
Nor does Carlyle win praise for its $19 million purchase of the Ticketron Sports and Entertainment division in 1989 from the Control Data Corporation. Late last month Carlyle announced the planned sale of Ticketron to the Ticketmaster Corporation, a major competitor, Terms were not disclosed, but analysts familiar with the business said that Ticketron had been losing money for months.
Carlyle has high hopes for other projects. It bought Caterair International, an airline catering service purchased from Marriott in 1989 for $650 million. Caterair had revenues of just over $1 billion and earned pretax profits of $100 million in 1990.
 
Asserts Its Worth
 "Despite the fact that the airline business is in trouble, the company is worth an enormous amount more than what we paid for it," Mr. Rubenstein asserted.
As senior adviser to Carlyle, Mr. Malek, who briefly served as director of the 1988 Republican convention, suggested to Carlyle that the President's eldest son, George W. Bush, would be a positive addition to Caterair's board. Mr. Malek is a Caterair director and also vice chairman of Northwest Airlines, a major Caterair customer.
"I thought George W. Bush could make a contribution to Caterair," Mr. Malek said. "He would be on the board even if his father weren't President. The fact that he is in Dallas is an important consideration, because we do a lot of business in the Southwest."
The President's son, who has interests in the oil business, is also part owner of the Texas Rangers baseball team.
Recession and serious overbuilding have severely damaged the commercial real estate market, but Mr. Rubenstein and his partners contend that the firm's $320 million purchase of the Coldwell Banker Commercial Group from Sears, Roebuck & Company in April 1989 will also turn a profit for them. Carlyle executives say Coldwell Banker is increasing market share in a down market, and has benefited from being less exposed in the Northeast than other real estate companies. Roughly 40 percent of the company's business is in Southern California and the Southwest, areas that thus far have not suffered as severely as other parts of the country.
 
Happy With Citicorp Deal
 Carlyle is delighted with the deal it struck for the Prince with Citicorp for its preferred stock. The Prince got the stock with a $16 conversion price into Citicorp common, and an 11 percent dividend.
By comparison, the three dozen institutional investors who together bought an additional $600 million worth of the preferred earlier this month got a convertible price of $18.25 a share, and a 10 3/4 percent dividend.
Mr. Norris, who managed the deal for Carlyle, said the terms for the Prince were some $85 million better than the one that followed.
Whether the deal with the Saudi Prince will lead to further business for Carlyle remains to be seen. But Carlyle has hopes: "We were mostly interested in developing a relationship with him that might lead to other things in the future," Mr. Rubenstein said.

HEADLINE: Resales Of Homes Jump by 7.9%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes shot up 7.9 percent in February, the first increase since November and the biggest in nearly five years, giving private economists hope that a housing rebound may be heralding the end of the recession.
The National Association of Realtors said today that the February rise put sales of existing single-family homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.13 million units. 
 The February bounce in home resales, which essentially erased a 7.3 percent plunge in January, was attributed to falling home prices and lower mortgage rates, luring buyers back into the market following the end of the war in the Persian Gulf.
 
Renewal of Strength Seen
 "After months of sputtering, it looks as though many markets across the nation have passed their low point and are regaining strength," said Harley Rouda, president of the realtor group, "People are ready to buy."
The report on existing home sales followed an equally optimistic report last week that construction of new homes and apartments shot up 16.4 percent in February while applications for building permits rose a healthy 8.5 percent, the first rise for permits in eight months.
Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company, said that the housing sector typically led the country out of a recession. If February does prove to be the turning point for housing, he added, the recession could end between June and October.
 
Biggest Gain Since 1986
 The 7.9 percent February increase in existing home sales was the first since a 2.6 percent rise in November, and it was the biggest monthly gain since a 9.5 percent jump in April 1986.
Analysts noted that home mortgage rates slipped to 9.25 percent in February, their lowest level since early 1987, while home prices continued to decline.
The median price for homes sold in February was $94,800, down eight-tenths of 1 percent from January and three-tenths below a year ago.
 
Huge Increase in West
 Sales were up in every part of the country, led by a huge 20 percent increase in the West, where homes were sold at an annual rate of 540,000 units. When compared with January, sales were up 8.7 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 500,000 units, and up 8.6 percent in the Midwest, where the annual rate was 880,000 units. Homes in the South climbed 3.4 percent, to a rate of 1.22 million units.
John Tuccillo, chief economist of the realtor group, said he was looking for sales of existing homes this year to total 3.19 million units, helped out by further interest rate drops. He added that fixed-rate mortgages should average 9.1 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Rally Pushes Dollar To 9-Month High vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar shot up to nine-month highs yesterday in a powerful rally stoked by political unrest in Germany and optimism about the postwar American economy.
Gold prices were moderately lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery slipped $4.10 an ounce, to close at $359. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $357.25, down $5.05 an ounce from late Friday. 
 Currency traders said the apparent absence of any major central bank interventions freed them to respond to contrasting economic moods in the United States and Germany.
The German mark was weakened by protests in the former East Germany involving more than 85,000 demonstrators, many shouting anti-Government slogans. Demonstrators said Chancellor Helmut Kohl had failed to keep election promises to improve living conditions in eastern Germany rapidly.
Dollar buyers were also driven by a growing sense that the United States' spending for the Persian Gulf war will be less than expected, as other Western economies live up to commitments to pay substantial parts of the cost.
By the close of trading, the dollar was roughly 2 pfennigs higher against the German mark, at 1.6865 German marks, up from late Friday's 1.6485. It was the dollar's highest level against the mark since June.
The market's heavy appetite for dollars was expected to continue even if central banks sell dollars in an effort to drive down its value.
Walter Simon, vice president of foreign exchange at Bank Julius Baer & Company, said the biggest test of the rally's durability will come on April 5, when the Government releases its employment figures for March -- the first postwar month.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.90 yen, up 0.85 yen from Friday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 138.40 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 139.20 yen, up from late Friday's 137.60.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7635, from $1.7890 late Friday. Sterling was also lower in New York, fetching $1.7477, compared with late Friday's $1.7860.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.4370 Swiss francs, up from 1.4135; 5.7265 French francs, up from 5.6030; 1,253.00 Italian lire, up from 1,225.38, and 1.1618 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1578.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $359.45 an ounce, down from $362.75 late Friday. In Zurich, the closing bid was $359.45, down from $362.75 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 76 cents an ounce to close at $363.19.
Silver prices were also lower. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $3.926 an ounce, down 4 cents from late Friday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Import Relief Is Unlikely for Detroit

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
White House officials said today that the Administration was unlikely to ask Japan for further restraints on auto exports to the United States to ease the financial plight of domestic auto makers, but that it could offer such assistance as a temporary easing of some regulatory requirements.
The statement was made as the White House confirmed that the heads of General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler met President Bush last Wednesday in an unannounced session. The auto executives met with Mr. Bush just a few hours before the President welcomed the Japanese Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, and agreed upon April 4 in Los Angeles for the next meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. 
 Speaking of the meeting with the auto executives, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press spokesman, said Mr. Bush listened to their concerns and said he would consider their problems, "but took no position on any of the specific issues."
The President is expected to ask Mr. Kaifu to make faster progress in ending Japanese import barriers, but is unlikely to press the Japanese leader on the auto issue, Administration officials said.
One senior Administration official said he could think of no problem more troublesome than the financial health of the auto makers, but he noted that the industry has had some form of protection for the last 10 years.
Politically the question is troublesome as well; the recession has badly hurt the industry, and Democrats are gearing up a 1992 Congressional and Presidential campaign portraying the Republicans as soft on Japan.
At the White House briefing today, Mr. Fitzwater stressed that while the Administration favored a "free market approach" to trade, it was also "interested in providing a competitive climate for the auto industry."
 
Lower Rates Would Help
 At an earlier meeting with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady on Feb. 27, the same auto industry leaders -- Robert C. Stempel of the General Motors Corporation, Harold A. Poling of the Ford Motor Company and Lee A. Iacocca of the Chrysler Corporation -- were told the Administration was trying to push interest rates lower, which could help spur sales, Administration officials said.
Because nearly half of the Japanese cars bought in this country are made here, the official said it would require "a gigantic import restraint" to curb competition from Japanese companies.
One of the key factors in any decision to restrain imports, the senior official stressed, is the impact on consumers. He pointed out that when auto curbs were introduced in 1981, the domestic industry raised prices.
That hit consumers, and the industry won only short-term benefits because as domestic prices rose, the Japanese were able to export larger, more expensive cars to compete on a broader scale.
General Motors, Ford and Chrysler collectively lost $2.1 billion in the final quarter of last year, and James W. Bush, editor of Ward's Automotive Reports, an authoritative automotive trade publication in Detroit, predicted that losses for January, February and March would be substantially higher. The companies have laid off some 60,000 workers in the last few months.
Chrysler has been the most active of the three companies on the import issue. Mr. Iacocca sent a letter to the President dated March 6 formally asking that pressure be put on Japan to limit car and truck sales in the United States for the next 12 to 18 months.
The Japanese have a 31 percent share of the market, of which 18 percent represents imports and 13 percent Japanese cars produced here.
Because of surplus Japanese production and large dealer discounts offered by such companies as Honda and Toyota, Mr. Iacocca fears the Japanese share of the market could rise to 40 percent.
Furthermore, in response to requests by the European Community, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has asked Japanese auto makers to hold their exports to Europe below 1990 levels, according to a recent article in the Japan Economic Journal. Chrysler fears that the Japanese cars originally headed for Europe will be diverted here.
Chrysler wants the Japanese to cut exports to the United States by 500,000 units this year, which it figures would keep their market penetration level at 31 percent.
