HEADLINE: New Orleans Journal;
Is Park Saved by Destroying a Part?

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, March 25

 BODY:
Even in New Orleans, which dotes on ec centricity, the Piazza d'Italia stands out. Completed 13 years ago, the small rundown park is the quirkiest public place in America's quirkiest city.
At first glance the post-modern piazza looks like the staging for a Hollywood extravaganza that has rearranged itself in transit and plopped down to rest beside an office building: about two acres of odd angles, concentric circles and paving stones. The St. Joseph's Fountain in the piazza is a maniacal subtropical Roman Forum, with rusts and yellows drenching the classical architecture and stainless steel capitals atop the columns. Water pours, spritzes and flows in every direction. Neon outlines the arches and columns. 
 "People either love it or they hate it, which I take as a compliment," said Ron Filson, dean of Tulane University's School of Architecture, who worked on the piazza's design and is trying to keep it intact.
The piazza, which borders Poydras Street not far from the Superdome, has caught the eye of architecture lovers around the world. But it has also caught the eye of a developer who wants to make part of it a driveway for a $100 million luxury hotel.
The developer, Joseph C. Canizaro, has clashed with preservationists in the past, but this is his first duel with post-modern preservationists. In response to the city's search for someone to build a hotel on city-owned land beside the Piazza d'Italia, he has proposed building the 405-room hotel, the Ritz-Carlton, around three sides of the park, swallowing a classical temple, a bell tower and an arch to make room for the 200-foot driveway.
The preservationists emphasize that they are not against placing a hotel beside the piazza. "The piazza was designed to be the middle of a development," Mr. Filson said, with shops, restaurants and a hotel around it, a New Orleans replay of a lively piazza in Italy. "But we don't want parts of it destroyed."
William K. Turner, former dean of the Tulane Architecture School, agreed: "It's a public park, and it shouldn't be the motor court for a hotel."
The piazza lost its status as a public park on Thursday, in a vote by the City Council, even though $1.65 million in state and Federal money was spent to create it. What they call the "undedication" of the piazza was necessary, city officials said, because the title was flawed and because developers were reluctant to develop a place that was designated as a public park. The officials said the city would still have control of development plans.
But the preservationists believe that without its public designation the piazza could be carved up by Mr. Canizaro or someone else.
Built as a tribute to this city's large Italian community, the piazza opened in 1978 with fanfare, chianti and hopes that it would help revitalize the city's center. The opening days brought crowds marveling at the architecture, especially St. Joseph's Fountain, with its 80-foot-long map of Italy, cascades representing Italy's major rivers and pools representing the Adriatic and Tyrrhenian Seas.
But the piazza has fallen on hard times, a victim of Louisiana's struggling economy. No investors ever opened the businesses that would enliven the piazza and pay for its upkeep, as the city had intended.
Tourists and scholars still visit, but they rarely linger. At nightfall a few homeless men spread cardboard pallets for sleeping.
St. Joseph's Fountain began losing its luster almost at once. Neon lights went out and water jets clogged. The fountain now runs part time.
Nineteenth-century warehouses intended as part of the piazza's development have burned or collapsed. Some of the space is being used to park cars.
"This is a significant public space with a strategic location," said Wayne Collier, the city's director of economic development, explaining why the city is seeking a project like Mr. Canizaro's hotel to lease the city-owned land. "If the city is going to be a partner in a public-private venture, we have to look high, at excellence."
And Mr. Collier sees nothing wrong with cars in the piazza. "As a matter of fact," he said, "it's very Italian."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Piazza d'Italia, a park near the Superdome in New Orleans. A developer has proposed razing a classical temple, a bell tower and an arch there to make room for a driveway leading to a luxury hotel. (Matt Anderson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Germany Overtakes U.S. As World's Export Leader

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 25

 BODY:
A newly unified Germany overtook the United States as the world's leading exporter in 1990, the world's trading organization said today.
The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said a 16.5 percent increase in the value of the mark against the dollar helped to raise the value of German merchandise exports to $421 billion, compared with $394 billion for United States exports. 
 Germany was unified on Oct. 3 after 45 years of division. All of the former East Germany's exports were included in the 1990 total, adding $22.5 billion to the German figure.
 
Japan Still in Third Place
 The United States recorded a greater increase in export volume, at 8.5 percent, compared with only 1.5 percent for Germany. Japan remained in third place, with exports rising 4.5 percent, to $286 billion.
The GATT report, from the secretariat of the 101-nation organization, said growth in world trade and output was likely to slow in 1991 for the third straight year. But it said a global recession was unlikely despite uncertainties in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war.
The preliminary report, compiled from information available by early March, said worldwide merchandise trade volume rose by 5 percent in 1990, compared with 7 percent in 1989 and 8.5 percent in 1988. Trade value rose 13 percent, to a record $3.5 trillion, largely because of the dollar's weakness.
Trade in services grew an estimated 12 percent, to $770 billion, from $690 billion in 1989, it added.
 
Crisis Contributed to Lag
 Economic disruption and uncertainty caused by the gulf crisis contributed to slower economic growth in 1990, the report said, but probably did not play an important role.
Saudi Arabia recorded the biggest jump in export rankings, to 21st place, from 25th, as earnings rose by nearly 40 percent, to $39 billion, because of sharply higher oil exports and prices for crude oil.
Imports of the leading Asian trading nations continued to rise much faster than exports. Japan, for instance, saw imports rise 11.5 percent while exports gained by only 4.5 percent. China's imports fell 8.5 percent in value while exports grew 18 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Decline in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose slightly in light trading yesterday, despite a report from auto makers that does little to buttress arguments of a postwar rebound in consumer spending.
Auto sales for the middle 10 days of March totaled over 6 million units at an annual rate, little changed from the first 10 days of the month and the last 10 days of February. The figures were well under the 6.2 million to 6.5 million sales numbers that Wall Street economists had been projecting. 
 Initially, credit market analysts responded positively as the reports trickled in. But selling commenced a bit later on.
The fact the market turned "tells me everybody is day trading," one government bond trader said.
"People are willing to take a pop in the morning, then cover up in the afternoon," the trader said. "I think it will be that way for the rest of the week. Portfolio managers and the Street look like they want to rest on the performance they had for the quarter."
Traders said that at least some of the selling pressure came from foreign central banks. These institutions, which have been sellers of Treasury securities for the last week or so, were liquidating positions in maturities ranging from two years to seven years yesterday, market participants said.
The auto sales figures were released a day before the Conference Board is expected to release its March survey of consumer attitudes.
Preliminary readings from another such survey compiled by the University of Michigan have shown that consumer confidence rebounded sharply after the end of the Persian Gulf war.
Since the end of the war, credit market participants have been fearful that a rebound in confidence could be translated into a surge in consumer spending, a rise that would pull the economy out of recession.
Based on car sales for the first three weeks of March, those worries seem unfounded.
"The numbers call into question what this rebound in consumer confidence really means," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "There is no resurgence yet in buying big-ticket items."
There are sound reasons why consumer spending has not picked up, analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company said.
"The recession has depressed income and employment levels such that any rebound in sentiment will not rebound into an immediate surge in spending," the analysts noted in their daily market commentary.
Based on price movements, that view was not prevalent in the market yesterday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 5/32 late yesterday, down 3/32, to yield 8.31 percent, compared with 8.30 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 97 1/2, down 1/32, to yield 8.12 percent.
In when-issued trading, the new two-year notes the Treasury is expected to auction today were offered at a price to yield 7.11 percent. And the five-year notes that are scheduled to be sold tomorrow were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.81 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the three-month securities were sold at an average discount rate of 5.86 percent, up slightly from the 5.83 percent average rate at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.84 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.82 percent a week ago.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Harris County, Tex., offered $208 million of securities in a negotiated sale through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The issue consists of serial, term and zero-coupon bonds.
The serial bonds were preliminarily priced to yield 5.85 percent on securities maturing in 1995 to 6.40 percent on securities maturing in 2000.
The largest term bond, which matures in 2014, was offered on a preliminary basis with a 7 percent coupon and was priced to yield 7.15 percent.
The securities are rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and AA-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for tax-exempt municipal bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, market participants said. There was little change in prices in either market, according to the traders.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Mid-March Vehicle Sales Off 11.1%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 25

 BODY:
Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell by 11.1 percent in the middle of the month, as demand for new vehicles continued to sputter at recessionary levels.
Surveys show consumer confidence has strengthened since February, and dealers report more visitors to showrooms. But analysts say many people simply cannot afford to buy new cars, because they already have so much debt. 
 "We can pretty much count out any bang in sales from the end of the war," said John V. Kirnan, an automotive analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. "People may feel better, but they still need to have the economic wherewithal to buy new vehicles."
 
Down From Weak '89 Level
 The nine domestic manufacturers sold 180,195 cars in mid-March, a decline of 9.7 percent from the fairly weak sales level of a year earlier. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of six million in the period. Customer demand for new cars has been mired at about the same annual pace of six million cars since January. Last year, cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 million in mid-March.
Sales of light trucks, which account for nearly a third of all vehicles sold, fell by 13 percent, to 104,513.
Nine selling days were in the period this year, from March 11 to 20, compared with eight in the 1989 period.
Tom Webb, the chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers' Association, an industry group in McLean, Va., said the latest results were "conclusive evidence that declining household income is more important than consumer sentiment in determining the pace of new vehicle sales."
Despite the poor results, many dealers expressed optimism at the start of the spring selling season.
"Deals are being made quicker; folks are not negotiating as hard," said Frank Debartolo, the general manager of Celozzi-Ettelson Chevrolet in Elmhurst Ill. "I take that as a sign that their confidence is coming back."
William Hurwitz, the president of Fox Chevrolet in Baltimore, said, "March is the first time in six months that our sales will equal last year's numbers."
But Mr. Hurwitz said many buyers still found it difficult to obtain new-car loans, echoing a concern raised by other dealers. Mr. Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody said 4 of every 10 applicants for new car loans, a record level, were being rejected by commercial banks, which make about half of all new-vehicle loans.
Fritz Elmendorf, a spokesman for the Consumers Bankers Association, a trade organization based in Arlington, Va., said banks had tightened credit standards because many loan applicants were already burdened with high debt. "We're seeing a lot more marginal customers applying for new-car loans," he said.
Some analysts say auto makers face painful choices about how much to cut from their generally strong second-quarter production schedules.
Coming in the wake of production cuts at several domestic and foreign-owned automobile plants in the first quarter, any significant reduction in output "has much broader implications," Mr. Kirnan said, "because the auto industry would continue to be a drag on the U.S. economy."
The Big Three domestic auto makers posted a 12.5 percent drop in their sales of cars and light trucks in the recent selling period. The Japanese car companies with American plants reported a 1.7 percent increase in sales of American-made vehicles.
 
 2/3.M.'s 10.8% Decline
 The General Motors Corporation sold 85,015 cars made at American plants, a decline of 10.8 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell by 11.6 percent, to 43,870.
The Ford Motor Company sold 49,236 cars, down by 15.5 percent. The company's light-truck sales fell by 21.9 percent, to 33,804.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, estimated that the Chrysler Corporation sold 19,500 cars in the period, down by 4.3 percent, and 21,900 light trucks, a drop of 3.6 percent. Chrysler stopped releasing its 10-day sales results in January.
The Honda Motor Company sold 11,205 cars made at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, a gain of 1.5 percent over the period a year ago. After three months of sales declines, Honda in March took the unusual step of reducing by $500 the price dealers must pay the company for new cars.
Honda also stored more than 2,000 unsold Accord models at a former Army depot in Marion, Ohio. A company spokesman said today that the auto maker had reduced the number of cars stored at the depot.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of domestically produced cars fell by 22.2 percent, to 7,510, the largest decline among the Japanese auto makers with American plants.

HEADLINE: Business Nod For Weicker On Tax Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 25

 BODY:
Three of Connecticut's largest business lobbying groups said today that they would support Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan to impose a state income tax if other taxes paid by business were reduced and legal limits were put on state spending.
Equally important, the groups said they would work against any alternative plan, whether it included an income tax or not, if it did not achieve the same results as Mr. Weicker's, including a "significant reduction" in the state's 8 percent sales tax and cuts in taxes paid on interest, dividends and capital gains. 
 Most of the alternatives to Mr. Weicker's plan that are under discussion have avoided an income tax only by maintaining or increasing those other taxes.
The business endorsement, coming on the eve of a daylong public hearing on the budget to be held at the Capitol on Tuesday, reshaped the debate over Mr. Weicker's plan and disrupted the anti-income-tax alliance that some politicians had expected between business groups and Republicans.
 
Republican Alternative
 The lobbying groups that offered Mr. Weicker their support today, the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the Insurance Association of Connecticut and the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, represent more than 7,000 companies across the state. They were joined by the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, a business-supported government research group.
In a separate statement, the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce today also offered conditional support for Mr. Weicker's plan.
Republicans, who are a minority in both chambers of the General Assembly, are drafting an alternative budget plan that has no income tax, but their plan will not be finished until next month.
"They're foolish and stupid," said the Republican state party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., referring to the business groups.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who was elected governor last year as an independent, thanked the groups for "standing up and being counted."
The organizations said in a statement that their endorsement of an income tax was grudging. But representatives of the groups said at a joint news conference at the Business and Industry Association's headquarters near the Capitol that they felt compelled to speak out because they believed the Weicker plan represented the best opportunity to forge the long-term spending restrictions and tax cuts that businesses have sought for years.
And they said they were afraid that if the business community did not take a strong stance, the General Assembly could become deadlocked, creating an atmosphere of uncertainty that would be the worst business climate of all.
"Chaos would be a worse solution," said Timothy J. Moynihan, president of the Hartford Chamber.
 
Setting Conditions
 The organizations said their support for an income tax had four conditions, three of which are already included in the Weicker plan.
Those conditions are cuts in state spending at least equal to the $1.2 billion proposed by Mr. Weicker; benefit and wage concessions from state employees to "bring them into line with the private sector"; reductions in sales and business taxes and the elimination of the existing tax on interest, dividends and capital gains; and long-term controls on spending, written into law or into the state Constitution.
Mr. Weicker, who took office in January, has said he opposes such formal spending controls, especially in the form of a constitutional amendment, but has indicated that some statutory provision to control spending growth could perhaps be negotiated.
Mr. Weicker last month proposed a complete overhaul of the state's fiscal system to address a projected $1.6 billion budget shortfall for the fiscal year beginning July 1 and to stimulate the economy. From the first, he said his plan was designed around cutting business taxes, a step he said was essential. He has vowed to veto any plan that would fail to reduce those taxes.
The price for those reductions, he said, was steep but unavoidable: a flat 6 percent tax on all income over $25,000 for a family, or $12,500 for an individual. Connecticut is one of only 10 states that has no broad-based tax on income.
The president of the Business and Industry Association, Kenneth O. Decko, said that if any one of his group's conditions were not met, support for Mr. Weicker's plan would instantly dissolve into opposition. But he said that any alternative plans would have to meet the same standard.
 The Democrats, who control both chambers of the General Assembly, have taken no unified position on Mr. Weicker's budget, although the Democrats who head the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, have said they support an income tax.

HEADLINE: World's Finances Facing Strains As Troubled Areas Try to Rebuild

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 25

 BODY:
The growing appetite for long-term investment funds may make interest rates higher than they might otherwise have been in coming years as countries in the Middle East and Eastern Europe seek huge sums to rebuild their battered economies.
A new study by Morgan Stanley & Company said the total demand for capital by Eastern Europe, Latin America and the Middle East would exceed the Western world's supply by more than $200 billion a year in the next few years. 
 Such a shortage and the resulting rise in interest rates would send ripples throughout the world economy. It would hurt corporate borrowers worldwide and home buyers in Europe and the United States, and make it more difficult for debtor nations in Africa and Latin America to attract development loans -- and repay them. Higher interest rates would also raise the cost of financing Washington's growing debt load.
 
Crucial Role for Germany
 David Hale, the chief economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said Eastern European developments had already pushed up interest rates. He said Bonn's decision to spend $85.5 billion to revive eastern Germany had caused the German central bank to raise interest rates to keep the economy from overheating. Mr. Hale said the move had pushed up interest rates worldwide by at least 50 basis points, or one-half of a percentage point. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"If the Soviet flag were still flying over East Berlin," Mr. Hale said, speaking figuratively, "American mortgage rates might be 50 or 75 points less."
Jacob Frenkel, chief economist with the International Monetary Fund, said, "In a fundamental sense, there is a problem of a worldwide capital shortage to satisfy the growing demand and need for capital in various parts of the world."
While higher interest rates would have many negative consequences, an investment boom that pushed up rates would have many benefits: more robust economic growth, gains in productivity leading to a higher standard of living, and a boom for industries that make capital goods like machine tools and computers. In addition, higher interest rates would attract greater savings, which would make more money available for investment.
The full force of this capital shortage is not expected to be felt for several years because the recession in the United States and the economic slowdown in Europe have reduced investment spending and helped push down interest rates. In addition, most Eastern European countries are moving slowly to reform their economies, so they are not yet ready to absorb -- nor are Western investors ready to provide -- large sums of capital.
"Even if we're talking about huge numbers for capital demand, for the time being not much has happened." said Charles Wyplosz, an economics professor at the Insead business school outside Paris. "This is a 10-year story."
In the Middle East, the latest estimate by Kuwaiti officials is that $50 billion will be needed to reconstruct their decimated emirate; some economists estimate that rebuilding war-battered Iraq and Iran will require several hundred billion dollars.
The cost of modernizing eastern Germany, German officials suggest, will be at least $300 billion. As for rebuilding all of Eastern Europe, estimates run as high as $2 trillion, and that is before the Soviet Union's hunger for foreign capital is factored in.
 
2 Big Sources Dwindle
 Heightening the problem is that two countries that had been major sources of international investment are now investing more at home. Germany, which before unification had been a huge exporter of capital to other nations, is now channeling its investment funds into its eastern states. And Japan, the other major capital exporter, is sending less money abroad as its economy slows, it refurbishes its infrastructure and its banks recover from plunging stock and real estate prices.
Still, in the eyes of many economists, there can never, strictly speaking, be a capital shortage: If the demand for capital suddenly exceeded the supply of savings, then interest rates would rise, bringing the demand for capital into equilibrium with the supply of savings.
For example, if economic reforms in Eastern Europe pick up steam and the region proves highly attractive to investment, then it could draw in $100 billion a year in investment, many economists say. This could happen because Western investors might conclude that Eastern Europe is a potential gold mine because of its low labor costs, its skilled work force and its expected fast pace of growth.
Prof. David Begg, an economics professor at the University of London, suggested that if Eastern Europe attracted $100 billion a year in outside capital, this could push up world interest rates by 200 basis points, or 2 percentage points.
According to Morgan Stanley researchers, Eastern Europe's and the Soviet Union's needs for imported capital will quadruple in three years, from $28 billion last year to $115 billion in 1993. Morgan Stanley also sees the Middle East's demand for foreign capital jumping from nothing last year to $80 billion next year, and rising to $100 billion in 1992 and 1993.
An increased demand for capital would make it harder and more costly for many third world nations to attract Western investment, economists said. To be sure, most of these countries are not getting much foreign investment now because Western businesses find them unattractive. But economists worry that developing nations that have made large-scale reforms, like Mexico and Chile, and are ripe for investment might have problems attracting money -- or if they did attract it, they would have to pay premium rates.
According to Jacques Attali, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the new multilateral bank set up to help Eastern Europe, the region needs $2 trillion to rebuild. A study done for the London-based Center for Economic Policy Research found that the region needed $1.3 trillion in investment during the next decade if its living standards were to climb to levels on the lower end of Western Europe's, that is approaching Spain's.
 
Raising Living Standards
 David Roche, chief international strategist for Morgan Stanley, said eastern Germany was an example of why former Communist countries desperately needed capital. "The east German experiment involves a switch in technology from six handles on each machine to employ six workers, to have one silicon chip that works six machines," he said. "This is a shift from having full employment with low productivity and low living standards to having higher productivity and higher living standards. This process is very capital intensive, and the demand for this capital comes to the West."
The other region suddenly clamoring for capital is the Middle East. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, Kuwait invested more than $5 billion abroad each year, money that helped finance factories in Spain and lending by British banks. Now, Kuwait is expected to borrow $20 billion a year. And Saudi Arabia, another longtime exporter of capital, has borrowed $3.6 billion from abroad to help pay for the gulf war.
 
Repairing the Infrastructure
 The demand for capital will grow for other reasons. Many industrial countries are concluding that after years of neglect, they should spend more on the upkeep of highways, railroads and other infrastructure. Such work in the United States, Europe and Japan would require hundreds of billions of dollars.
The aging of the population in Europe, Japan and the United States is another factor pushing up demand for investment. "We want savings and investment to be very high for the next decade or two to put in place the capital stock that will in future decades produce the higher income we need," said Ralph Bryant, a senior follow at the Brookings Institution. "We ought to raise productivity now so it can be higher in the future when a smaller percentage of the population is working."
Most economists say these trends mean that to finance future investment needs, it is essential to raise the rate of savings, especially in the United States, which has a far lower savings rate than Japan and most European countires.
 
One Senator's Proposal
 "Our savings rate is at a record low," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "The average American worker saves 5 cents out of every dollar earned, compared to 16 cents in Japan. Lower savings lead to higher interest rates and trade deficits, as well as lower investment and productivity." Senator Bentsen has proposed new legislation on indivudal retirement accounts aimed at increasing the American savings rate.
Many economists stress the importance of reducing Washington's budget deficit, which would translate into an increase in savings. This would in theory stimulate long-term growth by lowering interest rates and allowing more money to be spent on growth-producing investment, rather than on current consumption.
Officials in developing nations often complain that by borrowing so much from abroad to finance its deficit, Washington is using savings that could -- and they say should -- be used to modernize factories in Poland or explore for oil in Mexico.
"The United States may be a place where people can make good investments, but you wouldn't think that we should use the rest of the world's savings," Mr. Bryant said.

HEADLINE: DEADLY PESTICIDE MAY FACE U.S. BAN

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Scientists at the Environmental Protection Agency have recommended a ban on the sale of one of the most poisonous pesticides used in American agriculture, and the agency said today that it would soon decide whether to ban the compound in the United States.
Since 1966 the pesticide, ethyl parathion (prounounced pair-a-THIGH-on), has poisoned more than 650 field workers in the United States, including at least 100 who died, according to studies by the environmental agency, the California Department of Food and Agriculture and other state agriculture departments. 
 Directors of the California agriculture department said the pesticide was so deadly that the nerve gas suits used by allied troops in the Persian Gulf war were being tested this year in a vegetable field in Ventura County, near Los Angeles, to determine whether they could protect workers. Studies by scientists in California show parathion is as deadly to animals and people in relatively small doses as two basic chemical warfare agents, sarin and tabun. Medical studies show that in an hour 140 milligrams of parathion diluted in four ounces of water can kill a person who absorbs it through the lungs, skin, or stomach.
New studies by scientists at the University of California at Davis show that parathion, which is one of the insecticides most widely used in American agriculture, could be a hazard to people and wildlife away from farms because it drifts in the air and can linger in fog. There is also evidence reported by the environmental agency that residues of parathion, primarily in vegetables, raised the risk that consumers could ingest trace amounts.
 
Costs Could Increase
 A representative of Cheminova A/S, the chemical's Danish manufacturer, said a total ban on parathion could cost the company $10 million a year. Studies by the environmental agency said safer substitutes were available, but they would increase costs for farmers and presumably for consumers. The average cost of using parathion, a distributor in Arizona said, is $9 to $12.50 an acre. The cost of a likely substitute, diazinon, is $16 to $24 an acre, the distributor said.
But scientists at the environmental agency said the economic benefits of continuing to apply parathion to roughly four million acres of fruits, vegetables, nuts, and grains each year in the United States were outweighed by the hazards to wildlife and to people.
"Despite existing efforts to protect agricultural workers, mixer/loaders, applicators, and field workers continued to be systematically poisoned," the scientists said in a memorandum that accompanied their recommendation to ban the insecticide.
Linda J. Fisher, the agency's assistant administrator for pesticides and toxic substances, said in an interview today that she would review the recommendation this week and would make a decision soon. Ms. Fisher could decide to ban all uses of the pesticide, some uses of it or take no action at all. Her decision could be challenged by the manufacturer and distributors.
 
Official Expects Quick Decision
"This is a highly, acutely toxic insecticide which is why we're going to take a real close look at it," said Ms. Fisher. "There is no clock on our decision, but I am going to try and make one quickly."
Ethyl parathion, developed in 1947 by the German chemical company Bayer, is one of a family of insecticides, deadly to man as well as pests, known as organophosphates. It has a less toxic sister compound, methyl parathion, which is not affected by this recommendation, the environmental agency said. Introduced in the United States in 1948, parathion did not become popular until 1972, when DDT was banned.
The manufacturer said four to five million pounds of pure parathion were imported by the United States last year. Four American companies mix pure parathion into liquid and granular formulations used to kill insects on roughly 50 different crops. Among the products that receive heavy applications of parathion each year are almonds, peaches, nectarines, plums, apples, lettuce, broccoli, onions, and wheat, the environmental agency said.
"We need to keep this product in the marketplace because it is cost-effective for the grower and if used properly, is safe," said Richard J. Messinger, director of commercial development for the Gowan Company, a small pesticide company in Yuma, Ariz., that sells parathion.
But for years, medical specialists caring for farm workers, the Federal officials and state health and environmental agencies have been concerned about parathion's hazards.
"A lot of the attention on pesticides has been focused on the risk of exposures to residues on food," said Ralph Lightstone, a lawyer for the California Rural Legal Assistance Foundation, a advocacy group for farm workers in Sacramento. "This stuff is extremely deadly poison, and it's hurting workers who are producing the food. We need to focus more attention on the workers on the front lines who handle deadly poisons."
Statistics on deaths and injuries from pesticide poisoning are incomplete, even in California, which has the nation's best system of reporting. Since 1981, California health officials have reported that roughly 200 workers were poisoned by parathion, and most of them were injured seriously enough to require hospitalization. Federal environmental officials estimated in 1988 that 3.5 deaths are caused by parathion every year.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 6.93, to 2,865.84, as Trading Slows

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices ended with a small gain yesterday after being sharply higher earlier in the day. Blue-chip stocks fell back late in the day after the Supreme Court said it would rule on whether health warnings on cigarette packages protected manufacturers from personal injury suits.
Earlier, the Dow Jones industrial average had recovered 25 of the 89 points it lost last week. But by the close, it had given back most of the gain, ending the session at 2,865.84, ahead only 6.93.
 
Volume Drops Off
 I.B.M., which slid 15 last week, recovered 1 7/8, to 113 1/2, accounting for more than half of the Dow's gain, but in the wake of the Supreme Court announcement, Philip Morris slid 2 5/8, to 66 7/8, dragging down the Dow more than 5 points. 
Trading, though, slumped to its lowest level in two months, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange sliding to 153.9 million shares. Birinyi Associates said that even program trading was light.
In spite of the blue-chip selloff, secondary stocks continued to show new gains. The Nasdaq composite index, representing many of the smaller stocks, climbed the equivalent of 27 Dow points.
Figures supplied by Indata of Stamford, Conn., showed that 54 mutual funds it surveys weekly pumped nearly $75 million into stock in the week ended March 22. Cash now totals 9.9 percent of investments, it said.
Moreover, with the Dow blue chips down sharply during the period, the cash appeared to have gone into smaller stocks.
"What you're seeing," said Kenneth M. Spence, director of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers, "is one of the most significant changes in the market place -- secondary stocks are entering a long-term uptrend very similar to 1977 through 1980, when secondary stocks strongly outperformed the blue chips."
Jack Solomon, market technician for Bear, Stearns, attributed the Dow pullback to "vulnerability" in Philip Morris after Fitch Investors Service, the rating agency, put the credit ratings of cigarette producers under review pending the outcome of the Supreme Court case.
He noted that Philip Morris, a big part of the Dow industrials, had climbed $30 since August, when the Kuwaiti crisis began, and more than $20 since mid-January, but that "once its vulnerability was shown, profit taking in Philip Morris spread to other stocks."
Moreover, Mr. Solomon said, RJR Nabisco, which has been a volume leader almost daily, "started to succumb." After reaching a new high yesterday of 13, it fell to 11 3/4, down 1/4, with 12.1 million shares changing hands.
American Brands, another tobacco company, fell 1 7/8, to 44 1/8. Other tobacco producers changed very little.
"Last week," Mr. Solomon said, "the defensive issues, like tobacco and food, were leaders. This week, with the recovery of I.B.M., high-tech stocks are the leaders."
This, he said, "shows the market's stabilizing and the downtrend appears to be broken."
Comforted by the rise in I.B.M., traders began loading up on other technology stocks. Apple Computer, which fell 3 last week, rose 1 1/4, to 64 1/2. Microsoft, which lost 2 7/8 last week, jumped 4 1/2, to 98 1/4. Compaq Computer, which dropped 4 1/2 last week, tacked on 2 1/4, to 61 7/8.
The Pacific Stock Exchange high-tech index jumped 1.2 percent, or 35 Dow points.
 
NCR Talks With A.T.&T.
 NCR rose 1 3/8, to 99 5/8, after its directors agreed to meet with A.T.& T. about the phone company's $100-a-share hostile takeover bid. The chairmen of both companies met for several hours yesterday but no agreement was announced.
Square D, which has rebuffed a $78-a-share takeover bid from Schneider of France, fell 5/8, to 78 7/8, even though Rockwell International said it could neither confirm nor deny its interest in Square D.
Walt Disney slid 3 1/2, to 115 1/2, after Mark Manson of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette cut his earnings estimates because of the impact of the weak economy on its theme parks.

Tokyo Stocks Decline
 TOKYO, Tuesday, March 26 (Reuters) -- Stock prices closed lower in light trading today, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues down 306.41 points, or 1.15 percent, at 26,339.38.

HEADLINE: Vallone Has Alternative For Budget

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The New York City Council, in its most ambitious challenge yet to Mayor David N. Dinkins, yesterday laid out its own blueprint for solving the city's worsening financial problems, cutting $400 million from proposed tax increases and slashing 30,000 jobs over the next four years.
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the new approach was needed because Mayor Dinkins's plan to close the $3 billion gap in the fiscal year that begins on July 1 could permanently damage the city's economy, driving businesses and the middle class from the city. 
 The Council plan calls for the same level of spending cuts -- about $1.8 billion -- proposed by Mayor Dinkins. But some services, like schools, libraries and parks, would be spared some of the reductions proposed by the Mayor. The difference would be made up by consolidating city agencies and making deeper cuts in areas like social services, housing and mental health.
Much of the lost tax revenue would be made up by $350 million from a bond refinancing and the sale of land under New York's airports, the sort of one-shot revenues frowned on by the city's fiscal watchdogs and bond-rating agencies. To make this more palatable, the Council proposed using some of the money to set up a reserve fund of up to $1 billion at the end of four years to deal with future fiscal emergencies.
 
Flexing Its New Muscles
 In a measured response to the proposal, Mayor Dinkins withheld comment, saying the administration received its first copy of the plan only shortly before Mr. Vallone convened a news conference to discuss it.
The plan is almost certain to become a subject of a debate over spending priorities between the Mayor and the Council, which has to approve the budget.
Under the new City Charter, the Council gained the budget powers of the Board of Estimate, which was abolished. The Council was required to comment by yesterday on the preliminary budget presented by the Mayor in January, but was not required to submit its own financial plan. Mr. Vallone apparently used the occasion take some initiative away from the Mayor.
Administration officials said they had already been considering some of the Council's proposals, like productivity savings, service cuts and consolidations. But they questioned using one-time revenues to solve even part of the city's budget problems.
"We do not believe this city can survive simply by cutting services and raising taxes," Mr. Vallone said. "We have to come up with some new ideas."
By presenting its own multiyear budget-cutting plan, the Council is seeking to improve its public standing and put itself in position to battle the Mayor, if necessary, over the city's future direction.
Mayor Dinkins said that he "would be delighted" if he found that the Council had proposed a way of reducing the need for tax increases, but that so far he was not convinced. "We don't have the luxury of just proposing something." he said. "We have to look at its total ramification."
Last week, after months of being criticized as lacking leadership, Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that next year's budget gap had grown to $3 billion, and laid out a strategy for permanently reducing the cost and size of city government, including asking workers to give back health and welfare benefits.
Under the Council plan, 15,000 jobs would be cut next year, 3,500 through early retirement, 5,900 through productivity improvements and 6,400 through service cuts, of which 2,000 would come through layoffs. Attrition and productivity increases would trim another 15,000 jobs over the next few years. There are 225,000 municipal jobs now financed by the city, excluding Transit Authority and Housing Authority jobs.
While the Council proposed slashing nearly two thirds of the $755 million in property-tax increases in the Mayor's budget, it would impose a new tax of 25 cents a ride on cab fares and replace the state's 5-cent-a-bottle deposit with a 5-cent-a-bottle tax to pay for recycling and debt service on sanitation projects. Repealing the bottle deposit law would require action by the State Legislature.
The Council plan won praise from the city's fiscal monitors, who were skeptical of the one-time revenues but impressed by the Council's initiative. Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, said the plan presented a "strategic view" of the city's problems that deserved to be taken seriously.
The plan appeared to benefit both the real-estate industry, which has complained bitterly about property-tax increases, and middle-class taxpayers.
 But environmental groups opposed the proposed repeal of the bottle deposit law, and the taxi industry denounced its proposed tax as "an outrage." The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said that it was willing to discuss the purchase of airport land, but that the $1.2 billion price sought by the Council appeared excessive.

HEADLINE: Miss Austin Wed To Ziv Hellman

 BODY:
Carolyn Frances Austin, a daughter of Jan Higinbotham Austin and Craig L. Austin, both of San Antonio, was married yesterday in Israel to Ziv Zalman Hellman, a son of Gila S. Hellman of Forest Hills, Queens, and Dr. Marcel Hellman of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Arie Strikovsky officiated at the Shoresh Hotel in the Judean Hills. The bride, 26 years old, is a student at Nishmat, a center for Jewish women's studies in Jerusalem. A graduate of Rice University, she received a master of arts degree from the University of California at Irvine. Her father is a lawyer. Her mother is a counselor at Lackland Senior High School in San Antonio. Her stepmother, Lola Austin, is a psychologist.
The bridegroom, 26, is a senior economics reporter and an editor for The Jerusalem Post. He graduated from Princeton University and the Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem. He expects to receive a master's degree in economics from Hebrew University in Jerusalem in May. His mother is a nurse at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills. His father is a hematologist and an oncologist in Flushing.

HEADLINE: Amazon Forest Loss Is Sharply Cut in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
FOREST rangers were murdered, and sugar was poured in the fuel tanks of patrol helicopters during the Amazon's fractious "burning season," but the deforestation rate dropped sharply last year, according to new figures gathered by satellites.
Sparing an expanse of rain forest the size of Delaware, Brazilian farmers and ranchers burned 27 percent less forest in 1990 than in 1989, according to a study by the National Space Research Institute. 
 By comparing Landsat satellite images, researchers found that the annual rate of forest clearing dropped to 5,334 square miles in 1990 from 7,273 square miles in 1989.
"The drop is very clear and very real," said Luiz Gylvan Meira, director of land observation for the Brazilian institute.
 
Global Effects of Losses
 With world concern high over potential global warming from deforestation, the Brazilian figures are eagerly anticipated by scientists and environmentalists every year. After several years of controversy, a consensus has emerged among scientists that figures by the Space Research Institute are the most accurate yardstick for measuring the loss of the Amazon's forest cover.
The institute's data analysis techniques are highly accurate, said Compton J. Tucker, an American biologist who has been using satellites to study Brazil's deforestation for the last decade, most recently for NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland.
Next month in Puerto Rico, the Brazilians plan to train teams from six other Amazon Basin nations in the skills of tracking rain forest deforestation. For the project, the Pan Amazon Deforestation Study, NASA has purchased regional satellite data from the Space Research Institute in Sao Jose dos Campos.
While photographs from space show a slowing of deforestation, people on the ground disagree on the causes.
"I attribute the drop to rain and to the economic recession -- not to the Government of Brazil," said Fabio Feldmann, an opposition legislator who was recently elected chairman of the environment committee of Brazil's Chamber of Deputies. Other critics say that Operation Amazonia, the Government's campaign against deforestation, was begun in late August, well after the annual six-month burning season had started.
Raimundo Deusdarah, who saw several of his forest rangers and helicopters shot at last year, believes otherwise. Mr. Deusdarah, director of fire control operations for Brazil's state environmental agency, recently listed the successes of last year's campaign: agents seized 20,000 illegally cut logs and issued $9 million in fines to 3,500 violators of burning and cutting regulations.
One measure of the program's impact was the violent response by landowners: 4 of the agency's 324 agents were shot to death and 2 of its 6 helicopters were struck by gunfire.
Next month, the authorities plan to begin a more intensive "Operation Amazonia," with a $4 million budget, four times last year's budget.
It is to start with public information campaigns targeted at rural unions, schools and landowners in Para, Mato Grosso and Rondonia, states that accounted for three-quarters of last year's Amazon deforestation. About 12 percent of the original 1.35-million-square-mile forest has been lost, up from 4.4 percent in 1978.
This year, Operation Amazonia plans to enlist the services of military and civil aviation pilots who frequently crisscross remote areas of the forest. Brazil's army has trained 18 environmental agents to plot fire coordinates radioed from aircraft.
Under an agreement reached last September, the Space Institute will transmit by computer modem daily reports on fire sightings read from photographs taken by satellites of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which pass over Brazil four times a day.
But in a country where the economy last year suffered its sharpest contraction in 40 years, environmental officials say they do not know whether budget officials will actually release the $4 million needed for the Amazon preservation campaign.
With saving the rain forest a popular cause in Europe and the United States, Brazil has been showered recently with low-interest loans and outright gifts. But virtually all the money is designated for Amazon research or park preservation projects.
"There is a lot of talk about preserving the Amazon, but very few resources actually arrive for the control side," said Mr. Deusdarah. "We need to buy helicopters, boats, jeeps. Any foreign aid is welcome."

HEADLINE: A Scientific Watergate?

 BODY:
Five years after disturbing questions were raised about a research paper written in part by the Nobel laureate David Baltimore, the celebrated case is finally moving toward a verdict. Federal investigators have concluded, in a draft report, that the paper contained fraudulent data and did not accurately reflect the laboratory experiments on which it was supposedly based. Worse yet, data subsequently published by the Baltimore group to amend and justify its original paper were almost certainly fabricated.
The verdict may well destroy the career of the scientist accused of the misrepresentations and fabrications, Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari. But the most damning indictment should be lodged against the scientific community's weak-kneed mechanisms for investigating fraud. Faced with stonewalling by Dr. Baltimore, one of the nation's most prominent scientists, several investigative panels seemed more intent on smothering bad publicity than digging out the truth. 
 In this respect, the Baltimore case is reminiscent of the Watergate scandal. Just as Watergate started with a "third-rate burglary" and ended in a huge cover-up, so the Baltimore case started with apparent fraud by a single scientist and soon led to a widespread denial of wrongdoing by almost everyone in a position to right the wrong.
 The tale starts with a scientific paper published in 1986 that appeared to announce a revolutionary finding with important implications for the immune system. It was written by a team of six scientists, headed by Dr. Baltimore, who was then at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is now the president of Rockefeller University.
The experiments purported to show that when one strain of mice was injected with genes from another strain, their native genes were forced to produce antibodies very like those produced by the injected genes. That kind of influence by one type of gene on another had never before been seen. And now, it appears, it was probably not seen by Dr. Baltimore's team either.
The first hint that something was amiss came from a junior scientist, Dr. Margot O'Toole, who accidentally discovered that the results published in the paper did not jibe with 17 pages of Dr. Imanishi-Kari's laboratory notes that had fallen into her hands. A graduate student independently became suspicious. But neither got satisfaction when they tried to get corrective action from academic and scientific leaders.
Had the case not been dragged into public view by a fraud-hunting gadfly at the National Institutes of Health, Walter Stewart, and a Congressional committee headed by Representative John Dingell, the truth might never have emerged.
The initial investigations of Dr. O'Toole's complaints smacked of an old-boy network drawing up the wagons to protect scientific reputations. Investigations at Tufts University and M.I.T. found no fraud or even major error. The National Institutes of Health appointed an investigating panel with close ties to Dr. Baltimore. Even after the panel was reconstituted to mollify critics, it produced a pussyfooting report, finding no evidence of misconduct despite the fact that an experiment had been reported that was never actually performed.
Only after Congress became involved did the N.I.H. begin to display some backbone. Its new Office of Scientific Investigations produced the gritty and damning report that finally calls a fabrication a fabrication.
Dr. Baltimore has, from the start, seemed more intent on squelching inquiry that getting to the bottom of the charges. Although he has not himself been accused of fraud, he signed two documents -- the original paper and a follow-up correction -- containing data now deemed to have been fabricated by Dr. Imanishi-Kari.
Dr. Baltimore also belittled Dr. O'Toole as a "discontented" postdoctoral fellow, making her virtually unemployable for several years. And he orchestrated a chorus of support from sympathetic colleagues by sending a letter to 400 scientists warning that Congressional intervention could "cripple American science."
Dr. Baltimore has made enormous contributions to American science; he won a Nobel Prize in 1975, built up a major biology institute at M.I.T. and contributed to the development of national policy on AIDS. But his decision to tough out the allegations of wrongdoing instead of meeting them openly has ultimately harmed the reputation of the profession he so brilliantly represents.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Time to Reclaim the Javits Center

 BODY:
Pilferage, featherbedding and unreasonable charges for routine services now jeopardize the success of New York City's Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
A much-heralded labor agreement struck just before the vast crystalline exhibition hall opened in 1986 was supposed to prevent the extortionate conditions that had repelled customers from the New York Coliseum. But five years later, dismal practices still endure. 
 The pact's no-strike provision has avoided damaging work stoppages. But the state authority that runs the center has been unaggressive in pursuing sensible work rules that keep down costs and corruption. "Even if it takes two seconds to get something done, you have to pay for a minimum of one hour and might have to use three people," the manager of a dental trade show recently complained. To plug in a lamp, exhibitors must use an electrician, incurring a charge of $80.
The problems can no longer be ignored. The sagging economy has intensified competition from convention halls in other big cities, where labor costs may be 50 percent lower. Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, is investigating allegations of extortion and other crimes by the center's employees. And a civil racketeering suit filed by Federal prosecutors last September alleges that Mafia control of the carpenters' union has turned the center into a hiring hall for mobsters and former convicts.
"Convention Center jobs," says one Government affidavit, provide "easy work at overtime rates, together with the opportunity to make even more money by shaking down exhibitors, thefts and other rackets."
Finally facing up to the mess, Gov. Mario Cuomo has named a close adviser, Fabian Palomino, as the center's new president. Mr. Palomino vows an assault on uncompetitive practices, and his early record is encouraging. Security is being beefed up to deter thefts of supplies and equipment, and a new inspector general plans to make extensive use of undercover agents. He has also warned employees against rude and uncooperative behavior toward customers.
But tough issues loom ahead. Most urgently, Mr. Palomino needs to seek new contract arrangements that firmly address concerns about costs and corruption.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Talk in Jerusalem

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Inside Israel's Cabinet, some of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's most important ministers are talking to him about trying a kind of do-it-yourself distancing plan for Israelis and Palestinian Arabs.
They suggest that what the Israelis could do themselves is to pull out their troops from several key towns in the West Bank to the outskirts -- perhaps Nablus, Hebron and Jericho. It would not be a withdrawal or surrender of territory. 
 But it would be a step toward ending killings of Arabs and Jews by putting room between the Israeli Army and the Palestinians, giving both more breathing space.
And these Cabinet members are proposing that the Palestinians then be permitted to take over most of the functions of administering civil life on the West Bank, under an agreed Palestinian board.
Of course, this would not satisfy passions for an independent Palestinian state. That is, a second Palestinian state in addition to the one that Britain sliced off from the Palestine mandate in 1920 and now goes under the alias of Jordan.
 Unfortunately the second state Palestinians have in mind would require Israel to go drown in the sea. It is as much a fantasy as Saddam Hussein's dream of ruling the Middle East, and based on the same fatal self-delusion.
But if the talking becomes reality, Palestinians would have a chance to show if they can run most of their affairs without making every day a carnival of anti-Israel hate and stabbing.
Mr. Shamir also will not be easy to convince. He is a subtle and sophisticated man, which his friends know and his enemies still are learning. But he does not believe in gambling on Israeli security. Suppose Israel pulls back some troops and the Palestinians take flexibility for weakness and bring out more knives?
Who will the world blame for the blood that will flow in putting them down -- who but Yitzhak Shamir and the Israeli Government? He can imagine the U.S. television specials.
The talk in the Cabinet is a variation on a unilateral theme that has popped up over the years. But Mr. Shamir hears his colleagues out. Some of the interested Likudniks are among the most important in the party, among them Defense Minister Moshe Arens, Health Minister Ehud Olmert, Foreign Minister David Levy and Dan Meridor, the Justice Minister. All of them are considered potential successors to Mr. Shamir. They are not acting as a cabal but they do have influence, no question of that.
 They have an audience in mind that goes beyond the Palestinians, and its name is George Bush.
They are totally aware that President Bush is eager for movement in the Israeli-Palestinian situation. They are weary of Israel constantly being the sole target of American pressure.
Secretary of State James Baker goes to a meeting of Arab coalition partners. They refuse to end the Arab state of war against Israel, now almost a half-century steeped in blood and bitterness.
But in Jerusalem, his next stop, Mr. Baker talks about the interesting new ideas he is hearing from the Arabs. That plunks the ball in Israel's political court. But what ideas? He doesn't say and the Israelis insist they still do not know.
The Likud unilateralists hope that if Israel takes the initiative the President will then press the Arabs for a demonstration of the will for peace -- deeds, not words, as American Presidents like to say.
Such as: the end of the state of belligerency and of the boycott of Israel and companies doing business with Israel. The boycott has been more of an economic problem than Israel has liked to admit.
Just a few days ago, Kuwaiti representatives in Argentina officially informed a local company that "Jewish firms" would not be eligible for reconstruction contracts -- raising the nastiness level. Let's see how that sits with the 90 senators who earlier asked the Emir to end the boycott.
So it can be expected that before he agrees to any unilateral move, Mr. Shamir would want some clear word from Washington that the U.S. will indeed drop the Israeli arm and start twisting the Arab, and how hard.
The chances are against any unilateral move but it has become thinkable.
And the chances of the Palestinians getting a better offer if they again show their talent for picking wrong? Why, none.
As for a Palestinian state, it exists already, just across the narrow River Jordan, and one day will be known by its real name.

HEADLINE: No More Uncle Sucker

BYLINE: By Ernest F. Hollings; Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, is chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is waging a desperate campaign to allow fast track consideration of the "free trade" agreement with Mexico and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It would forbid amendments by Congress and require an up-or-down vote within 30 days. What is it in these agreements that the Administration fears will not withstand scrutiny?
Bear in mind, there was no fast track for critical arms treaties with the Soviets; these treaties were exhaustively vetted by Congress and stood on their own merits. SALT II ran into a sticky wicket, but the Soviets came right back to the table to hammer out the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces. If old-school Communists can respect America's constitutional processes, surely our democratic allies can, too. 
 So why is the White House so hot to hogtie debate and effectively nullify Congress's duty under the Constitution "to regulate commerce with foreign nations"? The answer is obvious: the emerging GATT deal and Mexican free trade agreement are so damaging to key sectors of our economy and workforce that they simply will not stand up under unfettered Congressional debate.
These treaties promise more of the same "free trade" magic that has created $100 billion-plus trade deficits for the last decade while gutting America's manufacturing base. Congress is fed up with playing Uncle Sucker. Japan and Europe, after reaping the benefits of one-sided, give-away trade agreements with the U.S. for decades, are at long last about to meet the America that can say no.
Let's be clear exactly where America stands, four and a half decades after World War II. As a victor in that war, we used the Marshall Plan in Germany and the MacArthur plan in Japan to rebuild those countries into democratic, capitalist powerhouses. We provided an abundance of credits, aid and expertise, and we opened our market wide to imports.
Forty-six years later, it's time for the U.S. to take away the punch bowl. We are naive to expect the Europeans and Japanese to be grateful to us and open up their markets to America as we did ours to them. We tried to set an example of high-minded "free trade" openness, and we were mugged. We tried jawboning, and were ignored. Common sense says that our rivals will deal fairly only when we make it their raw economic interest to do so.
As Henry Clay said some 125 years ago: "The call for free trade is as unavailing as the cry of a spoiled child in its nurse's arms for the moon or the stars or the glitter in the firmament of heaven. It never has existed. And never will." The fact is that selective trade protection is as American as the Firecracker 500.
It's also as American as Hamilton and Madison, who teamed up to pass the first bill through Congress on July 4, 1789, erecting a palisade of tariffs as high as 50 percent on some 30 articles, beginning with iron. Our Founders reckoned that their hard-won independence would soon be snatched away if it were not matched by economic independence. They were right.
Today, while Administration officials prattle like schoolchildren about "free trade," our rivals flex their governmental muscles in order to obtain economic growth and commercial advantage. They develop and protect domestic industries, channel subsidies and investment, and orchestrate export-oriented trade strategies to seize market share.
Rather than mobilize for this new challenge of government-orchestrated capitalism, recent American administrations have opted for the commercial equivalent of unilateral disarmament. They have rejected the Federal Government's traditional role as defender of U.S. economic security, instead embracing a style of promiscuous "free trade" that would have made Adam Smith blush.
Last year, we won the cold war. This year, we won the gulf war. Now it is time to win the war that really matters for America's future: the trade war -- the no-holds-barred struggle among nations for market share and standard of living in a largely zero-sum world marketplace.
Let us fire the first U.S. volley in this war by shooting down fast track, kid-glove consideration of GATT and the Mexican free trade agreement. Congress must insist on the full, deliberate consideration intended by Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution.

HEADLINE: Deduct Local Taxes From Federal Income Tax;
Rewards for Risks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The main problem with President Bush's new proposal to reduce the tax on capital gains is that it would continue to tax gains from the sale of new and old securities at the same (albeit lower) rate. As a consequence, it would do little or nothing to stimulate economic growth. 
 The tax should be lowered, but only on investments in new issues, the fuel of economic growth. Our problem is not the level of the capital gains tax, but that gains from new and old securities are taxed at the same rate. Unless you give investors in high-risk, new issues a tax break, 99 percent of stock market action will continue to be in old stocks, which are perceived as safer.
These transactions do little or nothing to stimulate real economic growth, for none of the money changing hands goes to companies that issue securities for use in expanding output, modernizing equipment, adding new products or research. Joe Doaks sells to Tom Smith and uses the proceeds to buy yet another old stock from Frank Jones.
With security transaction volume at record levels, there is hardly a pressing need to try and get more money flowing into the stock market by lowering the capital gains tax across the board. What we need is to get more money going into new businesses. The way to bring this about is to give investors in new isssues a tax break.
 
HAROLD C. PEPPERELL
Tiburon, Calif., March 4, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Equitable Life Names An Investment Head

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
When Brian F. Wruble takes over as chief investment officer for the nation's third-largest life insurance company on April 1, he will help to invest assets that are roughly equal in value to the economy of the former East Germany.
At the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Mr. Wruble will be the chief strategist for more than $60 billion in assets. A former securities analyst who started out specializing in oceanographic stocks, Mr. Wruble was named yesterday to replace Richard H. Jenrette, who continues as Equitable's chairman and chief executive. 
 Like much of the United States insurance business that has invested heavily in commercial real estate, now in a deep recession, Equitable has had problems.
Last year, Equitable announced a net decrease in surplus, or a loss, of $203.5 million, compared with a net increase in surplus, or a profit, of $14.9 million a year earlier. Last December, Equitable also announced plans to raise capital by switching to public ownership from ownership by its policyholders.
When he takes over his new job, Mr. Wruble will have had plenty of practice in directing big investments. As chairman and chief executive officer of Equitable's second-largest subsidiary, the Equitable Capital Management Corporation, he helped direct about $33.2 billion in assets.
The $60 billion in assets Mr. Wruble will now direct is about two-thirds bonds and a few cash equivalents like Treasury bills. The rest is real estate mortgages, like those for shopping centers and office buildings, as well as equity stakes in commercial real estate.
By contrast, Mr. Wruble's experience at Equitable Capital has been in stocks and bonds, mainly private-placement issues. "I expect to spend a period of time studying real estate," he said.
Mr. Wruble was the founding chief executive in 1985 of Equitable Capital and will retain that position, as well as his title as executive vice president of Equitable Life Assurance.
Having helped Mr. Jenrette throughout his tenure as chief investment officer, Mr. Wruble does not expect significant changes in the parent company's investment strategy. "At the margin," he said, "we will take somewhat less risk going forward, mainly scaling back our exposure in riskier bonds and riskier real estate ventueres."
A native of Kalamazoo, Mich., Mr. Wruble is a 12-year veteran of Equitable, having started out as the head of the portfolio management department. Before joining Equitable, he had been a securities analyst for Smith Barney, where he covered consumer durable goods, like refrigerators, automobiles and television sets.
An electrical engineer with bachelor's and master's degrees from Cornell University, Mr. Wruble had worked for a time on navigation for experimental nuclear submarines. "I had the most fun of my life at the bottom of the ocean," he said. He was hired as a securities analyst in the early 1970's when oceanography was in vogue as an investment area.
He and his wife, Kathleen Wilson Bratton, have three children aged 20, 17 and 2 years.

HEADLINE: Honeymoon for Mayor Continues in the Capital

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
When Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon took the oath of office at noon on Jan. 2, she faced two daunting problems -- red ink and red faces.
The city's budget shortfall was pushing past $300 million, with no letup in sight in the demand for more governmental services. 
 At least as serious, the city's once-shiny civic reputation had been tarnished by Ms. Dixon's predecessor, Marion S. Barry Jr., whose personal and political transgressions had resulted in a drug conviction and rejection by the voters.
Less than three months after her inauguration, at which she declared that "nothing is beyond our reach," Ms. Dixon appears to have made significant progress toward solving both her major problems: persuading Congress to help the city balance its budget and persuading many of the city's dispirited citizens that a new political age has, indeed, arrived.
 
Many Barriers to Clear
 But there is still much to do, many more municipal obstacles and much more municipal ennui to surmount. The next week or so, when many new appointments will be made and a new budget will be hammered out with the independent-minded City Council, could be the most crucial time of Mayor Dixon's tenure.
Mixing symbolism and substance, still enjoying the political honeymoon accorded the newly inaugurated, the 46-year-old Mayor has already managed major cuts in the deficit, though the demand for social services and the lagging local economy threaten to keep the red ink flowing. She has persuaded a once-skeptical Congress to give the city an extra $100 million to help it pay its debts, promising in return to slash bloated city personnel rolls and wasteful city programs. She has personally implored so many senators and House members to come to the city's aid that her office staff presented her with a set of kneepads "to make the begging easier."
At the same time, she has suffused the city with a real, if tenuous, "can do" spirit, something long absent. Show her a podium or a clutch of people and instantly she becomes a civic cheerleader, imploring her audience to get involved in city affairs, to believe that the city can polish away the tarnish and solve its deep problems of poverty, crime, housing, health, schooling and racial prejudice.
"Yes, we can!" she fairly shouts at the end of each little spiel, hammering the air with a clenched fist.
 
From Limo to Sedan
 She has dropped in unannounced on numerous city offices, including the notoriously poky motor vehicle agency, serving notice that efficiency will be rewarded but slackers and shirkers will face the ax. She has traded in the imperiously long mayoral limousine for a standard-issue city sedan. She has even mugged it up on television with local sports broadcasters in a campaign to bring big-league baseball back to the city, matching the broadcasters quip for quip, telegenic smile for telegenic smile and arguing earnestly that the return of the sport would be good not only for the city's sports fans and its economy but also, equally important, for its spirit and sense of identity.
"Things are going well, very well," she said the other day as she hurried through City Hall toward yet another meeting and another round of debate about how to raise more money, cut more programs and get more work out of a smaller bureaucracy.
There are critics.
 
Too Much the Candidate?
 Some say the Mayor is too aloof, too inclined to ignore traditional power brokers, too dependent on aides short on political savvy. Worst of all, the critics contend, she has no governing plan or vision other than cuts and reductions of top-heavy programs and agencies inherited from the Barry administration.
They argue that Ms. Dixon still sounds like a candidate instead of a Mayor and has yet to demonstrate that she can master the fractious City Council or the huge municipal bureaucracy. They say she is confrontational and needlessly becomes involved in fights.
"She has worked impressively with Congress, and she has set a good tone of governing," said Joslyn N. Williams, the head of the Democratic Party in the District of Columbia and a local labor leader. "But she's being too much of a loner, and she's trying to balance the budget on the backs of city workers and the poor. The honeymoon she's enjoying is likely to end in the next week or so as she and the City Council finish thrashing out next year's budget."
There are signs that the honeymoon is already ending.
In apparent response to complaints that she did not have enough hard-nosed political insiders in her advisory circle, she recently replaced her chief of staff, Joseph R. Caldwell, a lawyer, with Patricia M. Worthy, the chairman of the city's Public Service Commission. But that move failed to quiet the critics, who contended that Ms. Worthy was also inexperienced politically, a contention that drew a sharp counterattack from Ms. Dixon.
"We are doing things differently from the way some of the power brokers are accustomed to things being done," the Mayor said, picking up some of the language she had used in her campaign. "If it means it doesn't translate in terms of their support at the end of four years, so be it. It will be clear at the end of the four years that we were here, we made a difference."
Another sign that the honeymoon is ending comes from the new chairman of the City Council, John Wilson.
"We've got to come up with a new budget in the next couple of weeks," he said. "The Mayor is talking cuts but no more taxes. I'm not sure you can do it that way. People are going to have to put it on the political line before this is over."
 
Something Good to Say
 But for the moment, the Mayor's critics are in the minority, overshadowed by her successes and a seeming willingness by others who may harbor doubts to let the honeymoon run a bit longer. In fact, some of the city's toughest critics -- members of Congress, which oversees all city business -- say Ms. Dixon's progress has been nothing less than remarkable.
In appproving the $100 million gift and agreeing to consider further grants in coming years, numerous members of the House and Senate, Democrats and Republicans, lavishly praised Ms. Dixon, a Democrat, for setting a new tone in governing the District of Columbia and for re-establishing a strong link between City Hall and Capitol Hill. It was as though the legislators, after a long drought, had found an opportunity to say something good about the Mayor and management of the capital.
"Mayor Dixon is a breath of fresh air," said Senator Brock Adams, the Washington State Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on D. C. Appropriations. "People want her to succeed. The $100 million is directly attributable to her willingess to reach out and meet with scores of legislators and her willingness to cut and trim and remake. All that was absent in the last city administration."
Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., a Virginian and the ranking Republican on the House District Committee, said Ms. Dixon's hard lobbying on Capitol Hill had put a stop to "District bashing" by legislators. The new Mayor, he added, had paid him more visits in her first two months than had her predecessor, Mr. Barry, in the better part of 10 years.
President Bush, whose Administration sharply criticized the Barry administration, has indicated that he will go along with the Congressional gift to the Dixon administration, providing that other sections of the bill unrelated to the District are acceptable. In fact, the President struck up a working relationship with Mayor Dixon well before the Congress did. He invited her to breakfast two days after her inauguration.
"She's off to a good start," said Mark Plotkin, who was active in Democratic Party affairs and now does political commentary for a local public radio station. "She's shown herself to be a great Capitol Hill lobbyist for the city and a great cheerleader. But from here on out, she's also going to have to show that she can be Mayor, too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Things are going well," said Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon of Washington, "very well." Less than three months after her inauguration, Ms. Dixon appears to have made significant progress toward reaching her goals. With her last week in her office at City Hall was Patricecq White, a member of her staff. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)
