HEADLINE: Archbishop Lefebvre, 85, Dies; Traditionalist Defied the Vatican

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 25

 BODY:
Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the traditionalist prelate whose defiance of Pope John Paul II caused the first schism in the Roman Catholic Church since 1870, died today in Martigny, Switzerland. He was 85 years old.
Archbishop Lefebvre, a soft-spoken, stubborn Frenchman, was excommunicated in June 1988 for consecrating four bishops to help carry on his battle to return to a Latin Mass and to preserve other practices rejected in the wake of the ecumenical council Vatican II. 
 "I prefer to be in the truth without the Pope than to walk a false path with him," he said in explaining his rebellious course.
Archbishop Lefebvre died in a hospital of complications from the emergency surgery he underwent a week ago for a cancerous growth in his abdomen.
The Archbishop leaves behind about 300 priests ordained by his order, the Fraternity of St. Pius X, and a following that was estimated by Vatican officials at the time of the schism at 50,000 and 100,000. Church officials say the number has decreased since then as many Catholics have decided to stand behind the Pope rather than follow an excommunicated leader. The Archbishop's supporters say that he has hundreds of thousands of followers and that several million of the estimated 850 million Catholics worldwide sympathize with his teachings.
 
Schools in Five Countries
 His followers have set up schools and seminaries in Germany, the United States, Latin America, Australia and France, the country where he has the largest following.
His principal seminary is in Econe in southwestern Switzerland, where the gaunt, white-haired Archbishop carried out the fateful ceremony that created the church's first major split since the Old Catholics rejected the doctrine of papal infallibility declared at a Vatican council 121 years ago.
The Archbishop spent the last two decades battling changes in the doctrines of the church. For him, it was anathema that the church decided to open a dialogue with Protestants, Muslims and Jews, a move that he said mistakenly lent credibility to other religions. He rejected Vatican II's acceptance of "religious freedom," which he asserted was misguided because it put Catholicism on an equal footing with other faiths.
In a statement today, the Vatican defended the Pope's decision to excommunicate Archbishop Lefebvre, saying: "The Holy Father hoped until the last moment for a gesture that would put things in order. He showed that he was ready to remove the canonical penalty if there was such a sign."
The Vatican's statement added that on learning of the Archbishop's death, the Pope said a prayer "entrusting the soul of the deceased to the mercy of God."
The Rev. Franz Schmidberger, the German designated by Archbishop Lefebvre to succeed him as head of the dissident order, said, "May God reward him for his life entirely devoted to defend the Catholic faith against heresy."
Marcel Francois Lefebvre (pronounced luh-FEH-vruh) was born in Tourcoing in northeastern France on Nov. 29, 1905, the son of Rene and Gabrielle Lefebvre. His father, an official in a textile company, was a monarchist and a devout Catholic who said daily prayers in Latin. Of his seven brothers and sisters, four others became priests or nuns.
He attended a seminary in Rome that was headed by a sympathizer with Action Francaise, a far-right anti-Semitic and anti-democratic movement that was condemned by Pope Pius XI. He obtained doctorates in theology and philosophy before being ordained in 1929. He joined a missionary order, the Holy Ghost Fathers, and in 1932 was sent to Gabon, then a French colony. He spent most of the next three decades in Africa, and from 1955 to 1962 he was Archbishop of Dakar, Senegal. He left Senegal after it won independence.
In a move that chagrined many proponents of change, Pope John XXIII named him to the commission that prepared the Second Vatican Council. The bishops who attended the Council, which met from 1962 to 1965, rejected the traditionalist documents drafted by Archbishop Lefebvre and others, and that was the wedge that began to divide him from the church. Later he declared that "the devil" and "Antichrists" had inspired Vatican II.
He was especially disheartened with the abandonment of Mass said in Latin and other changes relating to the liturgy, including the placement of the altar so the celebrant faces the congregation. He also rejected Vatican II's affirmation of religious liberty and its abandonment of the church's assertion that it held the only universal truth.
 
Moral Deterioration Seen
 "The church in Africa was respected because it clearly told the truth," Archibishop Lefebvre said. "But Vatican II gave the impression that one truth could be as good as another. That has resulted in a general deterioration of moral values."
In 1969, he established the Fraternity of St. Pius X to train priests according to his traditional model. He lambasted the modern Mass, calling it a "bastard rite." As a result of his defiance, Pope Paul VI suspended him from his priestly work in 1976. This meant he could no longer celebrate Mass or administer the sacraments.
But he carried on in his crusade undeterred. He celebrated a Mass before 6,000 people in Lille, near his hometown, saying, "Let us carry on the religion of our fathers."
In 1978, John Paul II tried to establish a truce with the Archbishop, allowing him to resume his priestly functions. In 1988, the Pope sought to head off the schism by offering to name a traditionalist bishop whom Archbishop Lefebvre would nominate.
 
Pope's Compromise Rejected
 Eventually, the Archbishop rejected the compromise, which would not have obliterated the changes that he so disdained. This led to his consecration of the four bishops, a move that according to Catholic doctrine can be done only with the Pope's approval.
"It is to show our attachment to the Rome of forever that we perform this ceremony," he said.
In politics, he was known for extreme right-wing views. He occasionally supported Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the right-wing National Front, and often had kind words for Franco of Spain and the Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet. An avowed opponent of the French Revolution, he also supported the restoration of the French monarchy. "Our future is the past," he often said.
Church officials were uncertain how the Archbishop's death would affect his followers, whom Rome has threatened with excommunication. Jean-Michel Di Falco, spokesman for France's bishops, said, "One can hope that his death will be the occasion of a serious reflection and that perhaps a certain number of his followers are going to recognize that they are on a road that distances themselves from religion."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Analysts Split On G.M.'s Fate

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AUTO MAKERS typically lose money in sour economies, then make it back in spades during prosperity. But the General Motors Corporation's $1.6 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 1990 was so staggering that it has split Wall Street over whether the No. 1 auto maker can recover its earning power when the economy improves.
G.M.'s profitability and dividend payout are critical issues for millions of investors. As one of the most widely held stocks and an institutional favorite, G.M. is the subject of much debate and strongly held opinions among financial analysts. The auto maker tracks the recommendations of 13 leading analysts; currently, 7 are recommending purchase of the stock, 3 are neutral and 3 are recommending sale. 
 The case against G.M. rests on disappointment among the analysts who expected narrower losses given the number of cars and trucks sold. They fear that the industry's three-year labor contract signed last fall, which guarantees most of the pay of hourly workers even if they are laid off, has turned a variable expense into a fixed expense. In past years, when sales slid, auto makers could reduce expenses by laying off workers.
Moreover, the North American production capacity of foreign auto makers continues to grow, making competition tougher. Consequently, auto makers have resorted to paying stiff consumer rebates to maintain sales volume. And the industry is facing soaring costs to meet new clean-air, safety and fuel-efficiency regulations.
True, G.M. is introducing a slew of new models, but the auto maker's overall market share has not gained, meaning that its models are cannibalizing sales from one another.
Yesterday, there was more negative news when Fitch Investors Service said it might downgrade its ratings on debt securities of G.M. and the Ford Motor Company, citing concern about their profitability. [Page D17.]
The cost and profit problems are affecting Ford and the Chrysler Corporation as well, but neither of those stocks is as significant as G.M. to institutional portfolios.
James L. Alexandre, automotive analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, suggests that G.M. is in danger of dropping to about $30 a share over the next year, as the company fails to turn profitable this year or next. Based on its earning power, it probably should not be trading higher than the mid-20's. Yesterday, the stock rose $1.75 to close at $39.50 on volume of 893,000 shares.
"G.M. simply can't generate the cash in an up automotive cycle to justify a raise in the dividend," said Ronald A. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. G.M. sliced its dividend almost 50 percent in February, and Mr. Glantz contends it cannot raise the payout before 1994, suggesting that the stock "should be trading in the 20's." He theorizes that G.M. stock is a favorite investment alternative to bonds and therefore trades mostly on its yield, rather than on growth prospects.
Citing a monitoring service to which he subscribes, Mr. Glantz said the large institutions had mostly remained on the sidelines as buyers of G.M. stock, while some smaller ones had become buyers.
The opposing view is that "it's dangerous to extrapolate from fourth-quarter results," in the words of Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. Although he was surprised by the magnitude of G.M.'s losses and has lowered his expectations for G.M. stock, he remains positive.
Scott Merlis, automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, is one of Wall Street's bulls on G.M. In his view, the United States automotive market seems to be near its trough and should recover by 1992. While he agrees that G.M.'s recent losses are worrisome, he says, "You can't let the crisis obscure the long-term fundamental progress."
G.M. has been cutting costs, and the new labor contract, although expensive, has given the auto maker the flexibility to shut down underused capacity, he said. Rebates are down in the current quarter, and G.M. has joined Ford in promising to scale back market-glutting sales to rental fleets, which are no better than marginally profitable and hurt resale values.
David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd, agrees that G.M.'s profitability has been hurt, but he sees the situation as temporary. Weak demand, not excess capacity, is the big problem; it will disappear by 1992 or 1993, he projects, accompanied by higher capacity utilization, firmer pricing, better profits and, finally, a dividend increase.
G.M. will keep the $1.60 annual dividend through 1991, raise it to $2.40 in 1992 and $3 in 1993, he predicted.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Bailing Out Eastern Germany

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
GERMANY, where money talks and nobody walks, seems to have run out of economic miracles. Nine months after unification, the eastern provinces once known as the German Democratic Republic have tumbled into depression. With 30 percent of the labor force without full-time jobs and industrial production down by half, economic union threatens to become a black hole for taxpayers in western Germany.
In part the mess is simply a measure of the failure of the G.D.R's rulers, who would not give up their belief that Germans could even make socialism work. But in part, suggest four economists from the University of California at Berkeley, the post-unification collapse results from a self-defeating effort to squeeze western German living standards from the unproductive eastern German industrial machine. 
 The least expensive way to brake the economy's free fall, say George Akerlof, Andrew Rose, Janet Yellen and Helga Hessenius, is to subsidize wages. The financial crutch needed to save the jobs of most eastern Germans is a breathtaking three marks for every one paid by employers. But as the unpublished study explains, Germany is apparently committed to maintaining the living standard implied by the wage agreements negotiated since unification. The real choice, then, is whether taxpayers will subsidize an orderly (if expensive) restructuring of the eastern economy or pick up the tab for economic chaos.
A decline in output was inevitable in the wake of economic union, the Berkeley economists concede, as eastern German consumers loaded up on the VW's, Sonys and Big Macs so long denied them. But according to market tests, not every product made under the old regime deserves to be cast on the dung heap of history: before the fall, fully 21 percent of East Germany's G.N.P. was exported to non-socialist countries.
Thus the drop in production, they argue, can be attributed to the financial shock of unification. Even relatively efficient eastern German producers found they were unable to earn enough to pay their bills in German marks.
Factories have an incentive to keep their gates open as long as they can generate enough cash to hire labor, buy materials and perform minimal maintenance on the machinery. But at the wage levels decreed on the day of unification, the Berkeley economists calculate, conglomerates employing a mere 8 percent of the work force could cover their operating costs.
If labor markets in eastern Germany were truly competitive, wages would fall sharply, then gradually recover as the east-west gap in productivity narrowed. But the collapse in wages needed to restore high employment would hardly be acceptable to eastern German voters, whose gratitude offers the ruling Christian Democrats a lock on the chancellor's office.
Nor would a wage cut win friends among western German unions, who fear competition from eastern workers. Indeed, organized labor has been leading the charge for higher wages since unification. The powerful metal workers' union has even managed to ram through an agreement requiring equal pay for eastern and western Germans by 1994.
The way now to avoid a downward spiral in eastern employment and huge migration west, the economists argue, is to subsidize wages. Were Bonn to pay 75 percent of the conglomerates' current labor costs, they calculate that employers would be able to keep about 77 percent of the labor force on the job. The subsidy would equal tens of billions of dollars each year. But it would spare the Government the cost of generous unemployment compensation and lost payroll taxes, which together exceed the proposed 75 percent payout. And since the conglomerates are currently owned by the Government, the windfall in cheap labor gained by the minority of businesses that could get by with lower subsidies would go right back to the Treasury. In fact, subsidies that made the old conglomerates profitable would also make them salable, allowing Bonn to capture the windfall in the auction price.
The subsidy approach, the economists acknowledge, would encourage tough unions to get even tougher with east German enterprises. If Uncle Helmut is paying for 75 percent of the ride, why not insist on a seat in first class?
One way around the problem is to demand a social compact with labor as the price of the subsidy. Another, the economists suggest, would be to structure the aid in a way that discourages generous settlements. The deal might, for example, call for a four-mark subsidy cut for every five-mark increase in negotiated wages.
Another German miracle may yet be possible -- but not without a lot of help from Bonn.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Drop on Rumor Of Big Sales by the Soviets

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A persistent rumor that the Soviet Union might be about to sell large quantities of bullion sent the prices of gold futures lower yesterday.
"There's nothing new here, but the Soviet stories just resurfaced," said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst in New York with Prudential Securities Inc. 
 With oil production slumping, the Soviet Union needs hard currency to pay for its imports, she said. But there is no evidence that the Soviets are selling more gold than usual, she added.
Some Middle Eastern countries have been selling gold to pay for economic redevelopment after the Persian Gulf war. But here, too, the sales have been modest.
"The quantities are not large, but the perceptions that they might sell larger amounts of gold is moving the market," Ms. Raptopoulos said.
In addition to the rumors, the dollar's recent strength has continued to depress the gold market.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery slipped $1.70 an ounce to settle at $357.30. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.50 an ounce, down 75 cents from the late Monday bid.
Silver and platinum futures also moved lower, failing to respond to a couple of mildly encouraging economic reports. These included an improved consumer confidence index and a more restrained decline than expected in the sales of durable goods.
Gasoline futures led energy prices higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
With the market expecting a weekly industry report to show a decline in gasoline stocks, futures advanced more than a penny a gallon before giving up some of the gains.
When the American Petroleum Institute released its data after the close, it showed a much larger decline in gasoline stocks -- 4.54 million barrels -- than had been expected. Further, crude oil stocks also declined, whereas an increase had been expected.
Light sweet crude oil settled 14 cents to 31 cents higher, with the May contract at $19.76 a barrel; heating oil was 0.14 cent to 0.75 cent higher, with April at 56.80 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.50 cent to 0.84 cent higher, with April at 70.48 cents a gallon, and natural gas was 1.2 cent lower to 0.8 cent higher, with May at $1.395 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower But Gains Against the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most foreign currencies yesterday, but rose against the German mark amid perceptions of continued weakness in the German economy.
The United States currency opened higher, following a surge overseas. But it lost ground as leading currencies posted higher gains against the mark, which has been hurt by signs of growing economic weakness in Germany. 
 The dollar closed slightly below 1.7000 marks -- the American currency's highest level against the mark in nearly a year.
"There was a lot of music," said James Maccario, vice president in foreign exchange at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "I don't know if a lot of people were dancing."
That the dollar did not gain more was attributed in part to a movement of investments into the Swiss franc and the Japanese yen, whose strong performances stole some of the spotlight from the dollar.
In addition, Mr. Maccario said, "the market has been messy for the past weak or so, which tends to take people out."
Dollar buyers were encouraged by two economic releases yesterday that raised hopes for a swift economic recovery. The Commerce Department reported that factory orders edged down three-tenths of a percent in February. It was the third decline in the last four months, but not as great as the expected 1 percent drop.
In addition, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index jumped to 81 in March from 59.4 in February. It was the largest single month-to-month gain in the 24-year history of the survey.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 138.50 yen, up from 137.90 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it closed at 138.35 yen. In New York trading, the dollar closed at 138.80 yen, down from late Monday's 139.20 yen.
In London, the pound fell to $1.7545, from $1.7635 late Monday. But the pound gained in New York, closing at $1.7580, more expensive than the $1.7477 of late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.6870 marks, up from 1.6865; 1.4330 Swiss francs, down from 1.4370; 5.7240 French francs, down from 5.7265; 1,253.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1602 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1618.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, were: 1.6900 marks, up from 1.6710; 1.4350 Swiss francs, up from 1.4285; 5.7370 French francs, up from 5.6740; 1.9055 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8830; 1,255.25 Italian lire, up from 1,241.75, and 1.1598 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1603.

HEADLINE: Court Lets Japanese Concern Buy U.S. Company

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
A Federal District Court has blocked an attempt by the Justice Department to prevent the sale of an American high-technology company to a Japanese bidder. The American company plays a central role in the semiconductor industry's efforts to overtake Japanese rivals.
The decision today by the Federal Court of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania is expected to spur debate in Congress on legislation that would make it harder for foreign companies to buy American high-technology companies that are deemed crucial to the nation's economic security. 
 In a ruling from the bench, Judge Clifford S. Green denied the Justice Department's request for a preliminary injunction against the sale of Semi-Gas Systems of San Jose, Calif., to Matheson Gas Products of Secaucus, N.J., a subsidiary of Nippon Sanso K.K., based in Tokyo.
 
Planning to Close Sale
 Semi-Gas is a subsidiary of Hercules Inc., of Wilmington, Del. Robert B. Hessler, director of the company's financial public relations, said after the ruling that Hercules and Matheson "are now discussing when to close the sale."
"We have maintained all along that there is nothing wrong with the sale and are delighted that the court has corroborated our opinion," he added.
The Justice Department intervened on antitrust grounds after President Bush went along with an interagency committee's recommendation last year that the deal posed no threat to national security under the Exon-Florio legislation of 1988, which authorized the President to prevent sales that would hurt the nation's defense.
The sale has been closely followed in Congress because of the sharp opposition to the deal from Sematech, the Government-industry alliance to bolster the nation's computer chip-making technology. Sematech has strong Congressional backing.
Semi-Gas, which has been a supplier to the consortium, makes gas cabinets used in the production of advanced computer chips.
The Justice Department said the transaction would combine the world's two leading suppliers of gas distribution and control systems to computer chip makers and would substantially increase Semi-Gas's dominant position in the United States market.
The judge denied the request for a preliminary injunction on the ground that the Justice Department had not sufficently shown that the sale would result in the purported unlawful market concentration of gas cabinets.
"The Government has not established a basis for this court to find that there is a reasonable probability that the proposed acquisition may substantially lessen competition in the United States gas cabinet market," the judge said.
The department could appeal the decision. A spokeswoman, Gina Talamona, said officials were "reviewing the opinion and considering our options."
The antitrust move represented a last-ditch effort to block the sale by opponents within the Administration.
"The ball is back in the court of Congress," said Bradley R. Larschan, acting managing director and general counsel of the Association for International Investment.
Congressional Democrats, including Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, are expected to move to broaden the Exon-Florio legislation and require that the President weigh the economic consequences, as well as national security, as a consideration in reviewing foreign investment.
Congressional analysts predict big battles with the Bush Administration, which generally favors free investment as well as the free flow of trade.
Under the more narrowly confined 1988 law, there have been 540 reviews of foreign takeovers and 12 full-scale investigations by the interagency Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States.
But President Bush has blocked only one sale -- the purchase by the China National Aero-technology Import and Export Corporation, owned by the Beijing Government, of Mamco Manufacturing Inc. of Seattle, which supplies aircraft components.
As that sale had already been consummated, it required a divestment that was completed only last week when a New York venture capital company, Vestar Capital Partners Inc., acquired it from the Chinese.
Senator Gore characterized the Semi-Gas sale as "a serious loss which occurred because the Administration failed to understand what was at stake until the antitrust objection was the only one left to make."
A spokesman for Mr. Gephardt said today's actions "will increase support" for the investment legislation he expects to introduce "within the next couple of months."

HEADLINE: Rifle Lobby Torn by Dissidents and Capitol Defectors

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
With new gun control legislation pending in both the House and the Senate, the National Rifle Association is in the grip of internal turmoil and there are signs that it may be losing some of its effectiveness as one of the nation's most powerful lobbying organizations.
Long considered a muscular presence on Capitol Hill, the rifle association is an increasingly troubled organization these days. 
 It has lost more than 300,000 members in the last two years as membership has fallen to 2.6 million. It is torn by factional strife, with a group of dissidents deriding the current leadership as being too moderate. Facing complaints of mismanagement and sexual improprieties, the association's executive vice president, J. Warren Cassidy, resigned last month under pressure from the board of directors, former officials of the organization say.
When the association holds its annual convention next month in San Antonio, a major topic will be who should be named as permanent successor to Mr. Cassidy. The post, to be filled by the board, is the organization's top staff job. The group will also try to develop strategies to counter the growing perception that its ability to persuade or coerce lawmakers into supporting its positions is waning.
 
Organization Remains Powerful
 To be sure, no one is suggesting that the association is toothless, and it is mainly its critics who promote the idea of a weakened organization. The group retains the ability to punish some of its political enemies and reward some of its friends. And, despite some early setbacks in Congress, like Senate approval last May of a ban on the manufacture and sale of nine types of semiautomatic weapons, no gun control measures were voted into law last year.
Still, with its antagonists better organized than ever before, with many law enforcement groups willing to actively lobby on behalf of gun control measures that the association opposes, and with the nation shaken by an epidemic of violence, lawmakers and others are questioning whether the group's influence has diminished on Capitol Hill.
The pending gun control legislation poses a major test for the association. Just last week, Representative Les AuCoin, a Democrat from Oregon who had been a staunch N.R.A. adherent, announced he would support a bill requiring anyone buying a pistol to wait seven days to conclude the sale. Mr. AuCoin said he was switching because of concerns over the rising level of violent crime in the country.
"I have told myself that gun control isn't crime control," Mr. AuCoin said at a news conference. "But more and more, the argument in my own ears sounded threadbare."
The bill would allow, but would not require, background checks by local law-enforcement agencies to determine if a potential handgun buyer has a criminal record, is a fugitive from justice or has ever been committed to a mental institution.
The measure, which has drawn bitter criticism from the rifle association, is known as the Brady bill, after President Ronald Reagan's press secretary, James Brady, who was critically wounded in the head in an attempt to assassinate the President in 1981. The attack left Mr. Brady with brain damage and unable to walk.
 
'Out of Step' Leadership
 Mr. AuCoin, who opposed the Brady bill last year before switching his view, said he believed that the rifle association no longer inspired the fear among legislators that it once did. "The N.R.A.'s leadership is so far out of step with thoughtful people that any choke hold it had is, in fact, broken." he said.
Mr. AuCoin is not alone in that view. Last year's Senate bill to ban some semiautomatic weapons was sponsored by a lifetime N.R.A. member, Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona.
When she was on the New York City Council, Susan Molinari of Staten Island opposed a nonbinding resolution urging Congress to ban semiautomatic weapons. For that, the rifle association supported her election to the House of Representatives. But when she arrived there last March, she immediately became a sponsor of the Brady bill. For that, she has been denounced by the association as a turncoat. Denying the charge, she said of the N.R.A., "They put a lot of legislators in very untenable positions."
If some lawmakers view the association as too extreme in its general opposition to gun control, the organization is, paradoxically, facing another challenge from within its ranks from dissidents who assert that it is losing its punch because it has grown too moderate.
"We had the image of a winner," said Neal Knox, a former official of the association. "Now we have the image of someone you can roll over like AuCoin did the other day."
Mr. Knox and others maintain that in recent years, the organization's policies have become weak and contradictory. Mr. Knox points out that the association supported a 15-day waiting period in Oregon, while opposing a national 7-day waiting period.
Current officials of the group declined requests for interviews and would respond only in writing to written questions by a reporter.
 
Reasons for Resignation
 Former officials say Mr. Cassidy was forced to resign because of anger over the drop in membership and problems with a new $10 million computer system that was supposed to be in operation by December 1990, but is still not working. The association says delay is common in installing a new computer system.
Mr. Cassidy was also under fire as a result of the settlement, reported to be $500,000, of a lawsuit charging the association with sex discrimination in dismissing a female employee. Among the charges leveled by the dismissed employee, Marsha A. Beasley, was that Mr. Cassidy favored female employees "who would deal with him on other than a professional basis."
Mr. Cassidy, who denied the charge in court papers, is now a consultant to the rifle association. He could not be reached for comment, and he did not respond to requests for interviews relayed through the association. He had previously cited "personal reasons" for his decision to resign.
Critics of Mr. Cassidy say he would have survived any embarrassment from the lawsuit were it not for the decline in membership, which fell to 2.6 million last fall from 2.9 million in 1989, internal N.R.A. documents show.
 
Decline in Membership
 Gary Anderson, acting executive vice president, confirmed the decline, attributing it to "the economy and the recession." He said a $5 rise in annual dues to $25 in July 1989 had a major effect on membership.
"There is no indiciation that membership declines over all are due to N.R.A. positions deemed either too strident or too compromising," he said.
The disssidents, led by Mr. Knox, have complained that under Mr. Cassidy, the association has been too willing to agree to support laws like the ban voted by Congress on the manufacture and sale of armor-piercing ammunition and a law passed two years ago in Oregon that requires a 15-day waiting period and a background check for people who buy pistols.
The rifle association supported passage of the Oregon law as part of a compromise that established uniform statewide standards for permits to carry concealed weapons. The group's leaders insist that the Oregon statute is a true anti-crime law, since it requires background checks. In contrast, such checks are optional under the Brady bill, which the association says is just a nuisance that serves no purpose.

HEADLINE: HUNGRY CHILDREN PUT AT 5.5 MILLION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
A field network of researchers estimated today that 5.5 million people under 12 years of age were hungry in the United States.
The study, by the Food Research and Action Center, a nonprofit anti-hunger group, was based on interviews with 2,335 low-income households at seven places around the country. The authors of the study called it the most comprehensive effort to date to measure hunger in America. 
 The study defined hunger as periodic food shortages resulting from a family's limited economic resources. It did not attempt to measure clinical malnutrition. Families were classified as hungry if they answered yes to five of eight standard questions like these: "Thinking about the past 12 months, did your household ever run out of money to buy food to make meals? Did you ever cut the size of your children's meals, or did they skip meals because there was not enough money for food?"
Robert J. Fersh, executive director of the Food Research and Action Center, said the findings suggest that one in eight children in the United States experiences hunger each year.
 
The Government's Response
 Catherine A. Bertini, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Food and Consumer Services, welcomed the efforts to measure hunger. But, in a telephone interview from Columbia, S.C., where she was examining local social services, she said, "I cannot endorse the numbers in the report because I cannot say the numbers are either correct or incorrect."
Bush Administration officials refrained from criticizing the report, saying they did not want discussion of hunger to degenerate into a debate over numbers or the proper technique for measuring the problem. Ms. Bertini said the Administration, like the authors of the report, was eager to provide "adequate services to children at risk of hunger."
The report does not have the imprimatur of a Federal agency; the Government does not collect such data. The Food Research and Action Center, a 20-year-old foundation-supported organization, is an advocacy group in that it seeks to eradicate hunger and malnutrition. But the authors said they tried to make the study as reliable as possible and solicited expert advice on statistical technique.
Cheryl A. Wehler, director of the study, known as the Community Childhood Hunger Identification Project, said, for example, that follow-up interviewers were sent to each household to verify answers to key questions.
 
Findings Seen as Plausible
 And epidemiologists and other experts on public health said the findings of the report were plausible, given that hunger is highly correlated with poverty and that 9.4 million children under 12 are classified as poor by the Census Bureau.
Mr. Fersh said the hunger estimates were conservative because the interviews were conducted from February 1989 to August 1990, before the onset of the current recession, and because homeless people were excluded from the door-to-door survey.
Families classified in the study as hungry typically said they had experienced food shortages on seven days in the month preceding the interviews.
The study said hungry children were two to three times as likely as other children to experience such health problems as unwanted weight loss, fatigue, irritability and headaches.
 
More Food Stamp Recipients
 Federal figures show that the number of people receiving food stamps increased to 21.4 million at the end of last year, from 19.4 million in December 1989. The Agriculture Department says that half of food stamp recipients are children under 18.
The study by the Food Research and Action Center found that the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC, served 45 percent of those eligible for assistance. Ms. Bertini said she believed that the program serves 55 percent of those eligible.
The study found that among those interviewed, almost one-third of the families participating in the WIC program said they were hungry. More generally, the study said: "Hungry households spend nearly one-third of their gross monthly income on food, and yet this amounts to an average of only 68 cents per person per meal."
Mr. Fersh said the study cost $1 million. Kraft General Foods, a division of Philip Morris Companies Inc., helped pay for the survey through contributions to the Food Research and Action Center.
 
Where Interviews Were Held
 Each household in the survey was asked 105 questions in an interview lasting about an hour. The interviews were conducted in Hennepin County, Minn., which includes Minneapolis; Pontiac, Mich.; Suffolk County, on Long Island; Hartford; Polk County, Fla.; Sumter County, Ala., and four counties in California -- Fresno, Kings, Stanislaus and Tulare.
G. Ted Fairchild, director of the WIC program in Utah, who served as a member of the technical advisory group for the study, said the seven sites were chosen to reflect a variety of urban, suburban and rural neighborhoods. "We do not claim that this is a nationally representative sample, but it does reflect the variety of conditions in which poor people live," he said.
The interviews were conducted by various nonprofit groups, including the Alabama Coalition Against Hunger and the Nutrition Consortium of New York State, using the same questionnaires and the same procdures, Ms. Wehler said.
Members of Congress from both parties said they planned to use the report to buttress the case for gradually expanding food assistance programs like food stamps and the school breakfast program.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S., FEARING IRAQI BREAKUP, IS TERMED READY TO ACCEPT A HUSSEIN DEFEAT OF REBELS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to let President Saddam Hussein put down rebellions in his country without American intervention rather than risk the splintering of Iraq, according to official statements and private briefings today.
The White House said publicly that it will stay out of Iraq's internal strife, despite reports of atrocities by Mr. Hussein's forces, and a senior official said the American military has no plans to act on a warning to Iraq not to use combat helicopters against the insurgents. The United States acknowledges that Iraq has defied that warning. 
 The assertion that the Administration has decided not to make any new moves to protect Iraqi rebel forces at this time reflects a conclusion that the insurgents cannot control all of Iraq and would only succeed in fracturing the country, officials said.
 
Political Effect Considered
 Mr. Bush also believes that an overt American move to support the rebels would be opposed by Washington's Arab allies, stir up domestic political opposition and spoil hopes for progress on other regional issues, a senior official said.
That policy was reaffirmed today at a meeting of President Bush's seven top military and national security advisers, officials said, during which the President and his aides also completed preparations for a cease-fire resolution that is to be offered to the United Nations Security Council this week.
Although the current draft of that resolution imposes somewhat less stringent terms on Iraq than Washington originally wanted, the United States believes that it will be able to insure the destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and continue a campaign of political and economic pressure aimed at weakening Mr. Hussein's position, the officials continued.
 
Status of Kirkuk
 Mr. Bush was also informed about the fighting in Iraq, where the United States today said Kurdish rebels in the north had seized the city of Kirkuk, an important gain.
But the Pentagon raised doubts about whether the rebels controlled Kirkuk's airfield. Officials said the Baghdad Government's military forces had not yet fully engaged the Kurds and were instead protecting important installations and oilfields.
In the south, the Pentagon said, Iraqi forces were continuing to reassert control over areas briefly held by Shiite Muslim rebels backed by Iran.
Concerned by mounting questions about the Administration's intentions toward the rebellions in Iraq, Mr. Bush and his advisers sent Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, into the briefing room after today's meeting to issue a statement intended to dampen speculation that the United States might move to further support the Iraqi insurgents.
Though American spokesmen used imprecise language to describe the policy on the helicopters, it amounted to a decision, at least temporarily, to let Mr. Hussein freely deal with internal dissent.
"We never made any promises to these people," the senior official said, adding: "Frankly, there is complete agreement in this Government that the American people have absolutely no stomach for a major military operation to dictate the outcome of a political struggle in Iraq. There is no interest in the coalition in further military operations."
 
Hopes of a Palace Coup
 The official, who was familiar with today's meeting, said the United States would continue to urge Mr. Hussein's ouster by his own people and would maintain its policy of putting pressure on the Iraqi leader through the United Nations. The calculation is that if the insurrections fail, as officials here increasingly believe they will, Mr. Hussein's own political organization will remove him.
"We don't want Iraq dismembered, since that would go counter to the reason we fought the war," another official said. "Let Hussein deal with this, then the dust will settle and he's going to have to pay the piper for the war over Kuwait. Or at least, that is what we are counting on."
Thus, the senior official said that while the United States would continue to shoot down Iraqi fighters and bombers, it would not attack helicopters unless they directly threaten allied forces.
"The contrast in the way we have responded to fixed-wing operations and helicopter operations is probably going to continue," he said, acknowledging that permitting use of the helicopters could enhance Mr. Hussein's chances of success against the rebels.
Officially, Mr. Fitzwater said that Mr. Bush was deliberately leaving his intentions "murky." But he pointedly added that the United States did not intend to interfere with Baghdad's attempts to put down the rebellion and did not consider the helicopters a threat to allied forces.
Mr. Fitzwater sought to play down the notion that the flights by the Iraqi copters against insurgent troops violated any formal agreement between Iraq and the coalition. He said that Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander, agreed in a desert meeting on March 3 to an Iraqi request to use its helicopters to ferry troops and supplies as "a side oral discussion, nothing in writing."
But Mr. Fitzwater's explanation was in direct conflict with a reassertion today by the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, that armed-helicopter flights would be considered a threat to coalition forces.
General Schwarzkopf said in a television interview to be broadcast on Wednesday that he felt fooled by the Iraqi generals with whom he negotiated.
"I think I was suckered because I think they intended -- right then, when they asked that question -- to use those helicopters against the insurrections that were going on," he said. "I think that absolutely was their intention."
Since the war with Iraq ended, the White House has said that American forces would remain in the allies' zone of occupation in southern Iraq until a formal cease-fire was signed on the basis of the new Security Council resolution.
Mr. Fitzwater said today that the deployment in Iraq could last until a United Nations observer force is in place. But Administration officials said in public and in private that President Bush was eager to pull American troops out of Iraq as quickly as possible.
However, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on Friday that this could take months.
In Iraq today, the insurgents continued to declare major advances against the Baghdad Government's forces. The Associated Press reported from the town of Zakho that the pre-eminent Kurdish leader, Jalal Talabani, head of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, returned today to northern Iraq and proclaimed that "the whole of Iraqi Kurdistan has been liberated."
"We will continue the struggle until we defeat the regime of oppression in Baghdad and liberate the whole of Iraq," he told a crowd of about 10,000 in Zakho's main square, according to The A.P. report.
 
Accounts of Brutality and Death
 The agency reported from southern Iraq that refugees fleeing the fighting between Government and rebel forces said that Iraqi troops roam the streets of cities ordering young men to join the army or face execution.
Referring to the city of Basra, Khalifa Rahim, one of 26 Iraqi soldiers who surrendered on Monday to American forces, was quoted as saying, "They keep 7,000 prisoners at a university, and they shoot about 50 to 100 every day."
The A.P. said other refugees recounted military brutality. It said that Dr. Makki Jaffar Taher, a civilian, broke into tears as he said: "I lost my wife and children when my house was bombed. I have nothing left."
Iraq has not allowed foreign journalists to visit the rebellious areas, but Mr. Fitzwater said the United States Government had received such reports of Iraqi atrocities. He said that would not change the policy of noninterference.
"I think it's safe to assume that in the kind of warfare being conducted by the rebel forces and the Kurds, as well as by the Government of Iraq, as well as by other groups, that there are all sorts of atrocities and war repercussions taking place -- yes," the spokesman said. "But it is our belief that the best policy is not to involve ourselves in those internal conflicts."

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Fitch Ratings Agency Gives Warning on G.M. and Ford

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 26

 BODY:
Fitch Investors Serviceei, expressing concern about the profitability of the nation's two largest auto makers, said today that it might reduce the senior debt ratings of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation.
Fitch said the AA senior debt rating of G.M. and the AA senior debt rating of Ford had been placed on an "alert" status with negative implications. A spokesman said the intention was to alert investors that the ratings might be lowered after further discussions with the companies, which will take place within two weeks. 
 Fitch said the ratings of the auto makers' finance subsidiaries were also put on alert status with negative implications because of their close integration with the parent companies. The senior debt of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation is rated AA, and that of the Ford Motor Credit Company is rated AA-.
G.M. and its finance subsidiary have about $69 billion of debt securities outstanding; the figure for Ford and its finance subsidiary is about $53.5 billion, a Fitch spokesman said.
"The severe cyclical contraction in North American auto sales has exposed cost structures unsuited to the changing competitive conditions in that market," the ratings service said in its bulletin. Fitch said the auto makers were cutting costs but that it was not clear whether "profitability can be restored to former levels."
On Jan. 24, Fitch lowered the debt ratings of the Chrysler Corporation and the Chrysler Financial Corporation.
Terrence Sullivan, a G.M. spokesman, said: "G.M. and its management has laid out an aggressive plan to restore its profitability in its core automotive business. The entire G.M. team is determined to pull together to cut costs and conserve cash while reinforcing a forward product program."
A Ford spokesman said: "The problems we face are largely cyclical. We have a $3 billion cost reduction under way to improve profits and cash flow."

LENGTH: 1065 words

HEADLINE: Connecticut Tax Hearing: What, No Rage?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 26

 BODY:
By 5 P.M. the barricades set up to contain the crowds stood empty, and the State Capitol police officers assigned to guard the doors to Room 2C had long since wandered off. The signs warning people against cheering or other "public demonstrations" were superfluous in a room that had been largely empty of spectators since midday.
It was near the end of a long-anticipated one-day public hearing on Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s tax plan, which had been expected to go late into the night, but little opposition to a state income tax had appeared: only half a dozen people out of 62 speakers. 
 More important, the powerful voices of organized labor, big business and private welfare agencies, which usually agree on nothing, had all supported a broad-based personal income tax on wages in one form or another.
 
Individual Protests Heard
 There were individual voices of anguish. Theater owners protested that the Governor's plan to extend the sales tax to movie tickets would hurt them. Lawyers said that extending the sales tax to legal services would provoke a constitutional challenge. State employees said the cuts in their benefits proposed by Mr. Weicker were too harsh.
But three of the state's largest business lobbying groups, which announced on Monday that they would support an income tax if it were linked to controls on state spending, found themselves in the unusual position of being criticized by the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee's Republicans, their usual allies.
One citizen group calling itself the Taxpayers Alliance to Serve Connecticut distributed income-tax tea bags to evoke the Boston Tea Party as a way of supporting, not opposing, an income tax.
People who remembered Connecticut's last big experiment with the income tax -- in 1971, when the General Assembly enacted the tax and then repealed it under a storm of protest, including a rally of 10,000 people on the Capitol lawn -- wondered aloud if Connecticut's taxpayers were whipped, or apathetic, or just lying in wait.
"It seems like times have changed," said one committee member, Representative Geri W. Langlois, a Democrat from Thompson, in questioning one witness. "Where's the outcry?"
The witness didn't know.
Some income-tax opponents said the hearing was irrelevant and that those opposed were smart to stay home.
"It's a meaningless dog and pony show," said former State Senator Thomas Scott, the chairman of the Connecticut Taxpayers Committee, which opposes an income tax. "Eighty percent of my members are factory workers. They don't have time for this."
 
Protest Petitions Promised
 Mr. Scott, a Republican who formed his committee this year after an unsuccessful run for the United States House of Representatives against Rosa DeLauro, said he had obtained 40,000 signatures on petitions condemning an income tax and would return to the Capitol when he had 100,000. One day's testimony, he said, will change no minds.
But the finance commitee's co-chairman, Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford, said he thought the low turnout itself would send a message as the General Assembly grinds through the tax debate this spring.
Mr. Mulready, who supports a broad-based personal income tax, had been prepared to work well into the night, hearing the complaints and accusations of hundreds of people. Instead he was back in his office, files packed away, well before 6:30.
Of the more than 115 people on the sign-up sheet, only 62 had stepped up to the table to speak.
 
Resigned Feeling Detected
 "That suggests to me -- though I think it may be a little premature to draw conclusions -- that the people of the state of Connecticut are resigned," Mr. Mulready said. "Not apathetic, but resigned is probably the best way to look at it."
What perhaps also discouraged some would-be speakers were the questions from the finance committee members, who invariably asked every speaker how the state's projected $2.4 billion revenue shortfall should be addressed if an income tax were rejected.
Some opponents of the income tax did not have an answer, while others said the budget was still full of fat despite the $1.2 billion in spending reductions identified by Mr. Weicker in a preliminary budget of about $8.5 billion.
One speaker, Elizabeth Gillern, said she had formed her group, Citizens Against an Income Tax, only three weeks ago and had not had the time or resources to find the answers yet.
"The reality of it is, there is just no more money to give," she said.
 
A Happy Taxpayer Speaks
 More representative of the hearing's tone was the testimony -- and sharp questioning -- of Sharon Palmer, representing the 20,000-member Connecticut Federation of Teachers. She spoke passionately in favor of a progressive income tax as the best way to raise revenue to support education.
"How much taxes are you personally willing to pay?" asked one committee member, Representative Arthur O'Neill, a Republican from Southbury.
"Whatever it takes," Ms. Palmer said.
"You willing to pay an extra $1,500 a year in taxes?" Mr. O'Neill asked.
"Yes, I am," she said.
Mr. Weicker, an independent third-party governor with no members of his own Connecticut Party on the finance commitee or in the General Assembly as a whole, proposed last month a flat 6 percent tax on all income over $25,000 for a family or $12,500 for an individual. The wage tax, he said, would allow other taxes to be lowered -- especially those paid by business -- to stimulate the state's flagging economy.
 
Flat vs. Variable Tax
 The corporate profits tax would be cut from 13.8 percent to 11.5 percent, the sales tax from 8 percent to 4.25 percent, and the separate taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains would be eliminated, with all income treated equally under the new tax.
One of the main side debates in today's lopsided discussion was whether the flat rate was best or whether the income-tax rate should go up with income, the way New York State's does, for example.
John R. Rathgeber, an executive vice president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said his 7,000-member group would support only a flat tax.
The president of the State A.F.L.-C.I.O., John W. Olsen, said he would make the tax steeply progressive, hitting upper-income earners with a 10 percent wage tax and sparing the middle class.

HEADLINE: Brady Sees No Bailout Of Banks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that no taxpayer bailout of the nation's banks would be necessary if Congress approved the Administration's proposed banking legislation and if the economy avoided a complete collapse.
In an interview in his office, Mr. Brady gave an upbeat appraisal of economic prospects, but he suggested that the Federal Reserve could prolong the recession if it became "preoccupied with inflation" and kept interest rates too high. 
 Over the course of an hour, Mr. Brady addressed these other topics:
*The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the savings and loan bailout, will not be able to go out of business by the summer of 1992 as the law requires, and new legislation will be needed to allow the agency to continue to take over failed institutions after that.
*The United States should not help rebuild Iraq, as it did Germany and Japan after World War II, as long as Saddam Hussein is in power.
*The Secretary expects that a report from his staff within the next day or so will show that Mr. Hussein has assets hidden in the United States and other Western countries.
*The United States will not give new credits and other financial benefits to the Soviet Union in the immediate future because of the Soviet crackdown in the Baltic states.
*If Congress passes legislation to cut Social Security taxes, he will advise President Bush to veto it.
 
Fears of a Bailout
 Some officials say that so many banks will fail in the next year or two that the bank insurance fund will become insolvent. The Government would then have to step in and pay off the depositors, as it has done in the savings and loan industry at a cost of up to $500 billion.
Mr. Brady said he was "very close to promising" that a taxpayer bailout of the banks would not occur unless the economy performed much worse than expected and "you have a pusillanimous reaction by Congress" to the Administration's banking proposal.
The central parts of the proposed legislation would permit banks to open branches nationwide and allow mergers between commercial banks and other institutions like investment banks, brokerage houses and even industrial companies.
Interstate banking stands a good chance of being approved by Congress, but passage of the mergers proposal is much more in doubt.
Mr. Brady seemed of two minds about whether he should take an all-or-nothing approach toward the legislation or settle for the parts he can get from Congress quickly and abandon the rest.
At one point, he said he would not make the "mistake" of agreeing to tackle the elements of the measure piecemeal. But later in the interview, he said: "I'm not naive enough to think that when you put legislation in, there won't be changes in it. Of course, there will be."
Agreeing with many economists, Mr. Brady said he expected the recession to end by midsummer, and he said he was spotting some encouraging signs. "Oil prices are down; interest rates are down; consumer confidence has taken a bounce back; home sales were up," he said. "So the leading indicators are leading."
"If the economy is managed properly," he said, "we can have an upward-sloping economy, hopefully in the 2 to 3 percent range, over a long period of time."
But Mr. Brady said the recession was brought on in part because the Federal Reserve kept interest rates too high in 1989 and the first half of 1990, and he worried aloud that the central bank might keep rates too high this spring and summer out of concern over inflation.
The Government reported last week that consumer prices rose by two-tenths of a percent in February and that when energy and food prices were excluded, they rose by seven-tenths of a percent. Many economists said they found the latter figure to be a troubling indication of incipient inflation, but Mr. Brady said he did not. He said the increase resulted primarily from one-time jumps in the cost of postage stamps and the excise tax on cigarettes.
Mr. Brady said that inflation was now primarily "within the services area" and that he had tried to convince Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that higher interest rates would not bring down this kind of inflation.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, met today, but its decisions on what to do about interest rates might not be known for some time. The prevailing view on Wall Street is that the central bank will not make any moves for at least another couple of weeks while it tries to get a better reading of how the economy is performing.
"We ought to be focusing on growth," Mr. Brady said, "not inflation."
Even if the recession lingered longer than he expected, the Secretary said, he did not foresee the Administration offering any measures like extended unemployment benefits in response. He said experience had shown that such steps would not become effective until the rebound was well under way. "I don't think we ought to be pouring gasoline on an already-starting fire," he said.

HEADLINE: Banc One Won't Make Bid

 BODY:
The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it would not, as had been expected, bid for the banks of the failed Bank of New England Corporation. It cited the weak state of the New England economy as the reason for its decision.
"We had no sense of when the region would get better, or if it had already bottomed out," said William Boardman, a Banc One executive who has arranged dozens of acquisitions in the last decade. Over the next several years, "we think there are going to be other opportunities that are probably a better use of our resources," he added.
Bids for the Bank of New England's failed subsidiaries in Massachusetts, Maine and Connecticut are due on Friday, with the winner to be announced in mid-April. In addition to the BankAmerica Corporation, which has said it will bid for all the banks, analysts have said the Bank of Boston Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are interested in some of the banks.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Midway Enters Bankruptcy And Obtains a Line of Credit

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Midway Airlines, the first large carrier to start flying after deregulation in 1979, filed yesterday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
The airline said, however, that it would continue to operate and that it had arranged a $40 million line of credit, while it seeks to bring down its costs and debt. 
 David R. Hinson, Midway's chairman and chief executive, said, "We're committed to the maintenance of our published schedules and to honor all passenger reservations and tickets."
He added that Midway had to file for bankruptcy protection before Continental Bank would extend credit. The step makes the bank the first claim on the airline's assets in repaying money owed. Similarly, Pan American World Airways filed for Chapter 11 protection to get a $150 million loan from Bankers Trust.
In a news conference, Mr. Hinson said that the airline would break even in March and that current bookings were at a high.
"Our wish is to emerge from this financial reorganization as quickly as possible," he said. "We got into a situation where circumstances overwhelmed us."
The bankruptcy filing, made Monday night, will enable the carrier to shrink its operations and restructure its finances, Mr. Hinson said.
Several analysts said that the carrier, whose main hub is at Midway Airport in Chicago, had a chance to reorganize and come out bankruptcy, but that much would depend on the economy.
"Unless there is a traffic recovery by June, then the likelihood of a successful reorganization is dim," said Julius Maldutis of Salomon Brothers Inc.
Midway's shares fell $1.25 each yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $2.625. The percentage drop, of 32.3 percent, was the Big Board's largest.
What put Midway into its precarious position was an attempt to seize the opportunity from the troubles at Eastern Airlines to build a second hub in Philadelphia. Eastern had to keep selling assets to cover its losses, while it tried to revive under the protection of Chapter 11, and Midway was able to buy landing slots, gates, international routes and planes from Eastern for more than $200 million.
The move made strategic sense, but Midway ran into fierce competition from USAir, which did not want another carrier on its turf. USAir, which had also sought Eastern's assets, built up its service at the hub.
In addition, Eastern, which is now being liquidated, cut fares to $79 one way between the Northeast and Florida in a desperate move to win back traffic. That put competitive pressure on Midway.
 
Final Blow: Fuel Prices
 The final blow to Midway came with the crisis in the Persian Gulf, which sent jet fuel prices soaring while traffic began to fall -- "both things they had no control over," Mr. Maldutis said.
In October, the carrier agreed to sell its Philadelphia assets to USAir for $67.5 million, taking a loss of more than $30 million on the sale. Midway, which kept the planes it bought from Eastern, began withdrawing from Philadelphia on Jan. 8.
Midway, which employs 5,700 workers, suspended payments on leases for aircraft and loan payments in December and began talks with its lessors and lenders to reduce costs.
"Over the past eight months, Midway and its investment bankers have explored virtually every option available in order to attract additional capital," Mr. Hinson said. The efforts failed, he said, because of the hostile environment facing the industry.
One thing in Midway's favor is that travelers have become accustomed to Chapter 11 filings by airlines. There may be a small loss of bookings in the first few days after a filing, but in other cases bookings have gone back to normal once travel agents and the public realized that the carrier was operating its flights.
Continental Airlines, for example, filed for Chapter 11 protection last December and experienced only a small decline in bookings. Since then, it has been operating normally.
Midway began as a no frills discount carrier in 1979 and grew rapidly, becoming profitable two years later. The established carriers, however, began to respond to its low fares and Midway changed strategy, becoming a high-cost carrier catering to the business traveler.
 
Changing Strategies
 It offered first-class service for the price of coach, which worked at first, but again the carrier was at a disadvantage. It was unable to offer the extensive frequent-flier programs of the majors and did not have the marketing influence that comes from owning extensive reservation systems. It could not offer frequent flights to many cities.
Again in the late 1980's the carrier changed strategy, becoming a niche carrier, which emphasized Midway Airport's advantages -- being close to downtown Chicago and less crowded than O'Hare International Airport.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Shows Big Rebound

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In the first in-depth survey of consumer sentiment in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday that its index of consumer confidence rose to 81 from 59.4 in February -- a record gain for a single month -- reflecting both relief that the Persian Gulf war had ended and optimism that the economy would improve by late summer.
But the Conference Board, a business organization, warned that the euphoria over the war's end had apparently played such a big role in the upturn that it made the index a temporarily unreliable indicator of whether the recession might be ending. With the war effect gone, confidence could slide in April, said Fabian Linden, the survey's director. 
 "If there had not been a war, I would say, 'Yes, we are coming out of a recession gung ho,' " Mr. Linden said. "But this jump in the index is too big to be explained by saying that people feel all that great about the economy and their jobs."
The survey of 5,000 households, completed in mid-March, asked how people felt about the economy, their job prospects and their incomes -- currently and over the next six months. The answers are tabulated into three indexes: one on future expectations, one on the present situation and an overall index, now at 81, that combines the other two.
The future-expectations index has been the most sensitive in tracking changes in the economy, falling in the early months of past recessions and rising in the final months. Its steep March rise, to 100.4, from 63.6 in February and 55.3 in January, should indicate the end of a recession. But Mr. Linden said he would wait until April to see whether the gain is sustained once war euphoria wears off. The second index, measuring how people felt about their current job situation and income, fell in March to 51.8, from 53.1 in February.
"People still have enormous concern about job security," Mr. Linden said.
When consumer expectations about the future rise -- that is, when consumers say that jobs will probably become more plentiful and incomes will rise -- that optimism often shows up in increased spending. The added buying, in turn, helps to end a recession. The links between confidence and spending are strongest in purchases of homes, cars and appliances, says Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science.
Lately, home sales have risen, but not car and appliance sales.
A second major survey of consumer sentiment, conducted by the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Institute, has not been completed for March -- although a preliminary reading suggested that the Michigan results would be similar to the Conference Board's. But like Mr. Linden, Richard T. Curtin, director of Michigan's survey, said another month's readings were needed to get a fix on the economic outlook.
"People could wake up from their euphoria over the war's end and find that jobs and income are still a problem," he said.
Even with the March surge, the consumer confidence indexes are well below their January 1990 levels, when they began a steady decline. They dropped sharply in August, after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Bush Administration said the recession, which also apparently began last summer, was a result of the war's impact on consumers.
With the war over, the Administration and many private economists say the recession will end soon -- an optimism that neither Mr. Linden nor Mr. Curtin shares. "The notion that the recent abrupt improvement in confidence will catapult us out of recession is excessively optimistic," Mr. Linden said.

HEADLINE: February Durables Orders Down

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Orders for long-lasting goods like cars and refrigerators weakened in February in an economy that was troubled by recession and war, the Commerce Department said today.
But a report released by the Conference Board in New York showed a strong rebound in consumer confidence this month. 
 The Commerce Department said orders for durable goods were down three-tenths of 1 percent in February -- the third drop in four months -- after a revised decline of 1.5 percent in January.
 
Previous Performances
 Orders had risen 1.4 percent in December after a 10.1 percent plunge in November.
"Our guess is that the recession probably ended in February, and we've now seen the low point," said Lynn Reaser, senior economist with First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles. "We've seen it translate only slowly into the auto market, but in the real estate market it's very apparent, so I'd expect a flow-through into durables like household appliances and autos as spring progresses."
Douglas Handler, an economist with the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said the durable-goods report suggested that the slide in manufacturing was ending. "With order backlogs no longer shrinking and shipments holding steady," he said,"the likelihood of additional manufacturing-industry layoffs is reduced."
The February decline in orders was smaller than the consenus forecast of economists, which had been for a drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Possible Errors Seen
 The department estimated the value of durable-goods orders last month at $118.9 billion but cautioned that data processing errors might have skewed the figure as much as 2 percent too high.
Transportation orders rose one-tenth of 1 percent in February, after falling 5.9 percent in January. The department said higher aircraft orders were offset by lower demand for autos and parts.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, an indication of business investment in new equipment, fell 1.7 percent last month after a drop of 9.5 percent in January.
The department revised its estimate for January durable-goods orders to show a 1.5 percent decrease, instead of a 1.8 percent drop.
Shipments of durable goods were unchanged in February, after January's drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent. Unfilled orders, an indicator of future activity, fell one-tenth of 1 percent last month, after being unchanged in January.

HEADLINE: School Tries Longer Classes for Deeper Learning

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOPSFIELD, Mass.

 BODY:
Eight years ago, when Dr. Joseph M. Carroll, the Superintendent of the Masconomet Regional School District, first talked of having 100-minute-long classes in the high school here, teachers scoffed.
"Put students in longer classes and they will learn better," he said. 
 "Leave the curriculum alone," responded teachers and parents from this upper-middle-income school district 30 miles north of Boston. With about 85 percent of the students already going to college, they said, why tamper with a good thing?
But after teachers were asked to assess their own and their students' needs, they decided to give Dr. Carroll's plan a try. The school board agreed, and in the fall of 1989, Dr. Carroll began a school-within-a-school pilot program, the Renaissance Program, at the Masconomet Regional High School.
Eighty students, fully half of the ninth-grade class, volunteered to take two 100-minute "macroclasses." Instead of taking five academic courses, each consisting of a 46-minute class daily, all year long, they take a total of six courses, two each trimester, each consisting of a 100-minute class daily. They join other students for gym and a 46-minute elective period at the end of the day.
 
Good Preliminary Results
 Teachers, meanwhile, with classes of 12 students instead of 25, have time to get to know their students better and offer individualized instruction.
The preliminary results of Dr. Carroll's experiment were good. According to evaluators from the Harvard Graduate School of Education, the grades of students in the Renaissance Program, who for the most part were not high-achieving students to begin with, generally matched or exceeded those of students in the traditional program. Even those students whose grades did not improve were doing more homework and more self-directed projects.
Last fall, despite school budget cuts, Mr. Carroll found $92,000 in private funds to allow those students to continue the program in the 10th grade, as well as to offer it for the incoming ninth grade. One-third of that money was raised by the families of students in the program; the rest came from a foundation. He also stretched the classes to 118 minutes.
Similar extended-period programs have been tried, with success, at the High School in the Community in New Haven, a public magnet school, and at several independent schools. Since January 1990, about 500 educators from more than 35 states and four countries have either come to visit or called Dr. Carroll.
"Changing the schedule is really just a means to an end," said Dr. Carroll, a slow-talking Montana native who wears long, white sideburns and a bolo tie engraved with a buffalo dancer. "The end you are looking for is the change in relationship between the student and teacher."
But such changes often provoke controversy. Partly because of budget concerns and partly because of squabbling about the program's impact, Masconomet's school board voted 9 to 2 last fall to discontinue it after this year, despite widespread praise from teachers, parents and outside evaluators.
"The other structure is so fragmented, so crazy," said David Donavel, an English teacher, about the prospect of returning to the traditional class periods. "It's very, very hard to teach that way."
In the Renaissance Program, he can teach his way. For almost two hours, Mr. Donavel, whom students call "Dave," sits in a circle with the class, listening to his 12 students as they read aloud and discuss their weekly essays, their young voices rising above the rat-tat-tat of the classroom's electric heater.
"For as long as I can remember, I've always wanted to visit the so-called greatest city in the world," read 16-year-old Justin Davis from his essay titled "New York: An Illusion."
But after eulogizing the Statue of Liberty, Justin took a distinct turn in tone.
"During my recent trip to New York I saw that New York is not all glamour and bright lights," he read. "The underground transit system exemplifies the bleakness of the lives of those who are not mentally strong enough or economically rich enough to overcome the barriers of life in New York City."
When he finished, the class exploded with discussion. Some referred to Justin's earlier work. Mr. Donavel directed questions on images, metaphors and style.
"I used to hide way in the back row, but I talk all the time now," said Rebecca Schricker, 15, of Boxford, Mass., after the readings.
Karen Lachmayr, 15, said she liked the depth of discussions. "In other classes," she said, "you just skim over the tops of things. In this class, you have to discuss them."
Teachers, including many at Masconomet, also praise the concept of extended classes, saying it lets them delve into subjects and make thematic connections in a way that is impossible in a 46-minute class.
"In trying to teach about motion in traditional classes, we just give them formulas, show them an experiment and go on," said Charles Hosden, a science teacher. In the Renaissance Program, he said, "We can do the experiment and even change it around."
Although the program is open to anyone who volunteers, and includes some honors students as well as regular students, some parents object that it fragments the school. "To have a sacred cow within the common herd is impossible," said Serena Caperonis, a school board member.
 
Limits on Budget
 Some parents of honors students not in the Renaissance Program say the new program is not so rigorous and therefore honors credits should not be given to any of its participants.
Although no teachers or administrators have been laid off this year, the high school's principal, Stephen Smith, who supports the Renaissance Program, says cuts may come next year. For the last three years, he said, because of the state's fiscal crisis and a refusal by local residents to raise property taxes, the financing of the school district has remained virtually level, at about $7.8 million.
But Dr. Carroll insists that his program has gained enough support so that when the economy improves it should be reconsidered.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I used to hide way in the back row, but I talk all the time now," said Rebecca Schricker, left, sitting beside Patricia MacDonald and reading her weekly essay in an English class taught by David Donavel, right.; Participants in the Renaissance Program at Masconomet Regional High School in Topsfield, Mass., attend classes that have been extended to 118 minutes with a goal of strengthening relationships between students and teachers. Above, an English class taught by David Donavel, center. (Photographs by Rick Friedman for The New York Times)
