HEADLINE: Los Angeles Officers Plead Not Guilty in Beating of Motorist

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 26

 BODY:
Four police officers pleaded not guilty today in the beating of a motorist they stopped for speeding, while some of their fellow officers refused to cooperate with a Federal investigation into the incident.
In firm voices, the four officers, dressed in business suits, each answered charges of assault and other offenses, saying, "Not guilty." They face maximum sentences ranging from four years to more than seven in the March 3 beating, which provoked nationwide outrage after an amateur viodetape taken that night showed officers hitting the man more than 50 times. 
 Judge Gary Klausner of the Los Angeles County Superior Court said their trial might start as early as the week of April 28.
In a Federal investigation, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation broke off interviews with some colleagues of the accused officers after the officers declined to answer the agents' questions voluntarily, a police union representative said.
 
Interviews Terminated
 George Aliano, president of the Los Angeles Police Protective League, said that once an officer said he was giving his statement under duress the F.B.I. terminated the interview. He said about 25 interviews had been terminated in this way.
Cecil Marr, a lawyer for the Los Angeles Police Protective League, said the F.B.I. insisted that the officers' statements be given voluntarily. Scores of officers from the 250-member Foothill Division, where the accused officers worked, were called for questioning, he said.
Fred Reagan, a spokesman for the F.B.I., said the agency's investigation was proceeding, but he declined to confirm whether some of the interviews had been broken off. He said investigators had 21 days to complete their report.
The Justice is investigating the possibility of bringing a civil rights case in connection with the beating. F.B.I. agents have already interviewed the four officers who were indicted as well as witnesses to the incident.
 
'I'm Disappointed'
 A spokesmen for the Los Angeles Police Department declined to comment on the Federal investigation.
Mayor Tom Bradley said he hoped the officers would cooperate. "I have asked for cooperation, the police chief has asked for cooperation and, frankly, I'm disappointed there would be reluctance to do so," he said.
In court today, pleas of not guilty were entered by Sgt. Stacey D. Koon and Officers Laurence M. Powell, Timothy E. Wind and Theodore J. Briseno. All were charged with assault with a deadly weapon -- their feet and police batons -- on Rodney G. King, an unemployed construction worker who was stopped for speeding.
All four were also charged with violating the law that makes it a crime for an officer to assault or beat any person unnecessarily. Sergeant Koon and Officer Powell were also charged with filing false police reports, and Sergeant Koon with being an accessory to a cover-up.
 
Grand Jury Meeting
 A grand jury continued to meet this week as prosecutors presented evidence against other officers among the 27 who were present during the beating.
In all, police spokesmen now say, 21 officers of the Los Angeles Police Department were at the scene as well as four Highway Patrol officers and two from the school district police patrol.
A spokesman for the California Highway Patrol, Sam Haynes, said that his agency had completed an investigation of two of the state officers and that the results were under review.
The four city police officers entered their pleas after the judge refused their lawyers' request for more time to study the 325-page transcript of the grand jury proceedings. They argued that the charges against their clients were not specific enough.
John D. Barnett, the lawyer for Officer Briseno, also argued that repeated showings of the amateur videotape of the beating had put undue pressure on the District Attorney's office to bring quick indictments.
The prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Terry White, said the evidence had been "thoroughly reviewed and thoroughly presented to the grand jury."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Four Los Angeles police officers charged in the beating of a motorist they stopped for speeding pleaded not guilty yesterday. Entering Los Angeles County Superior Court were, from left, Sgt. Stacey D. Koon and Officers Timothy E. Wind, Laurence M. Powell and Theodore J. Briseno. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Ties New York City Aid to Union Concessions

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 26

 BODY:
Injecting a new element into New York City's budget problems, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that the state might come forward with a major package of aid for the city, but only if the municipal labor unions agreed to make major concessions to the Dinkins administration.
Mr. Cuomo said that without concessions in the city's labor contracts he would not act to secure deals that could involve hundreds of millions of dollars from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Battery Park City, the Port Authority and other public authorities in which he plays a major role. On the other hand, he did not guarantee the help if the agreements were reached. 
 "The Mayor is going to come to us for a whole lot of help," Mr. Cuomo said. "There's no conceivable way we could provide that help unless the unions make some contributions first."
The Governor's preconditions on state help represented an unusual intrusion into the authority of Mayor David N. Dinkins over city finances, but they did not seem to be entirely unwelcome. Some people in and out of the Dinkins administration noted that the conditions could help the Mayor not only to gain the concessions, which he has sought over bitter union objections, but also to put at least some of the blame on the Governor for his need to do so.
At the same time, some union leaders said they were angered by the Governor's position and said it would disrupt their negotiations with the Mayor.
 
'No Right to Threaten'
 "The Governor has no right to threaten the people of the city," said Barry Feinstein, president of the teamsters local representing city workers. "What the Governor said today to every New Yorker is that 'I've got money here, but I'm going to hold the city hostage unless the unions give something first.' "
Mr. Cuomo's stance against the city unions comes as he is in the midst of a major battle with the state's public employee unions over a new state spending plan. He has proposed laying off 7,000 state workers and eliminating 11,000 other state jobs.
Some of the larger state workers' unions, in an attack on the Governor that seemed to throw state budget negotiations into even further disarray, said today that they were starting a $1 million television advertising campaign to assail Mr. Cuomo's plan to balance the state budget with severe spending cuts and instead were backing Assembly Speaker Mel Miller's proposal to raise personal income taxes to help close the state's budget deficit.
The proposal by the unions, which have strong support from lawmakers here, in fact goes well beyond Mr. Miller's spending plan by advocating major increases in income, business and sales taxes that would offset many of Mr. Cuomo's planned spending cuts, including the layoffs.
Both Mr. Cuomo and the Republicans who control the State Senate have strongly rejected tax increases in these areas, saying they could devastate the state's economy and drive many businesses out of New York altogether.
 
Need for Sacrifices
 The Governor said his comments on the city budget were consistent with what he has been saying for months, that all sides should be required to make sacrifices for the city to get its financial house in order.
And he took pains to emphasize today that he was not saying the money was available, only that there should be no discussion of it if the unions did not agree to the kinds of concessions Mayor Dinkins called for last week. Among those were a rollback of health insurance costs and other benefits.
But even the possibility of new state money -- which could come in the form of bonds issued by the assistance corporation, or from selling shares in a public authority like the Battery Park City housing corporation -- adds an important dimension to the budget negotiations.
 
'The Fox Hunt'
 On the one hand, it holds out the promise of softening at least some of the severity of the Mayor's task in closing a $3 billion gap in the budget for the coming fiscal year. But it could also add much contention to the budget debate, with unions and others seeking to use the money to offset proposed cuts while business leaders might push for reducing the size of tax increases.
"The fox hunt has now begun," one top Dinkins administration official said.
As Governor, Mr. Cuomo could bring considerable weight to any of several methods that could produce some extra revenue for the state, including arrangements in which public authorities sell off assets or shares, or issue bonds that produce immediate cash and that are paid off over a number of years.
But while there has been discussion about such plans, many of them are complex and can be subject to criticism because they load future obligations onto taxpayers.
One-time sources of revenue like the bond transactions, sometimes described as "one shots," also can be faulted by rating agencies that assess the city's credit because they cannot be counted on in future years and thus raise questions about the city's long-term fiscal health.
For now, city officials say they are not planning on any of these extra sources of revenue to close the budget gap, but Mayor Dinkins has not closed out the possibility, and at a City Hall news conference today he seemed to be laying the groundwork for a justification if they did wind up in the budget.
"One shots are frowned upon or not frowned upon depending to a great degree on how much in relation to a total hole you fill," the Mayor said. "So if we have acceptable methods of meeting our problem," he added, "save for an amount equal to X -- X will not be defined at this point -- then such a one shot might be seen as acceptable, desirable, not even frowned upon by the monitoring and rating agencies that examine us."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Trying to Soften the Blow"
 
The Public Employees Federation, the second-largest union of state employees, plans to begin broadcasting a series of commercials this week that attack Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget and promote higher income taxes and business taxes to offset some of his cuts. Here is one of them.
 
TEXT
 
"Providing vital services for people. That's the heart of New York State. But look what's happening. Doctors and nurses in state hospitals fired. Services for children and youth opportunity tragically cut. Aid for the disabled and elderly slashed. And care for the mentally ill decimated.
 
"New York is in a budget crisis. But wealthy taxpayers and big corporations don't pay their fair share. So, let's stop the firings. End tax cuts for the rich. And keep the heart in New York."
 
BACKGROUND
 
There is wide agreement that the proposed cuts will be among the most severe ever undertaken in state government, but there is also considerable opposition to raising the tax revenues to offset many of these cuts.
 
The unions' budget proposal would raise roughly $3 billion in taxes from the following sources: tax increases averaging $3,000 for taxpayers making more than $100,000; elimination of a series of business tax credits, including the investment credit, and expanding corporations' taxable income to include their out-of-state income, and broadening the sales tax to include services such as lawyers, accountants and computer programmers.
 
The Governor and the Republican-controlled State Senate have rejected many of these tax proposals, arguing that they could drive people and businesses out of the state and produce far less in revenues than the union projects.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BORDEAUX, France, March 22

 BODY:
When the famous Emile Peynaud put away his test tubes and tasting cup for good two years ago, it was commonly believed that the era of the celebrity enologist was over. No way. In the Medoc, these days, if Michel Rolland hasn't been sniffing your barrels recently, you are definitely out of the loop.
Mr. Rolland, 46 years old, owns Chateau Bon Pasteur in Pomerol and manages Chateau Beauregard, among others. And, consulting as an enologist, he is currently the latest word in wine wisdom. He has ranged as far afield as eastern Long Island and California to dispense his expertise, but it's here in Bordeaux that he is most appreciated. His speciality is the proper use of the Merlot grape, the principal variety in Pomerol wines. Chateau Petrus, the most famous Pomerol, is 100 percent Merlot. 
 In a sense, Mr. Rolland is carrying on Mr. Peynaud's work. The elder wine guru was, and still is, an advocate of rounder, more approachable wines that don't take 30 years to age. And how do you make such wines? One of the most important ways is to add lots of merlot to the blend.
Not that Mr. Rolland can't be second-guessed; he was consulted on the final blend at Chateau Prieure-Lichine but the proprietor, Sacha Lichine, was not satisfied. He asked Patrick Leon, the wine maker at Chateau Mouton-Rothschild and an old friend of his late father, Alexis, to do a little tasting and sniffing.
Mr. Leon suggested a few changes. "I took his advice," Mr. Lichine said with big grin. "I like the blend better, and it gives me 1,000 more cases."
To make the best wine they can, the top chateaus eliminate second-rate batches of wine, especially those made from very young vines. There is constant tension in seeking a balance between quality and quantity. A chateau like Margaux or Latour will cut out 70 percent of a year's production to achieve the highest quality. A good blend and 1,000 extra cases is the sort of combination bound to delight any chateau owner.
 
New Tastings Banned
This year, for the first time, the classified growths in Bordeaux (the top chateaus) banned tastings of the new vintage before this week. In recent years, the owners got fed up with very early reports by wine writers eager to be out with the first pronouncements on the new wine. In certain vintages, the chateaus envisioned some future sales evaporating in the wake of early reports that the vintage was going to be mediocre.
Of course, all news bans are imperfect and the word is that the 90's are quite good, if not in the class of the 89's. Price increases should be minimal. The 1989 vintage was enormous; if the world economy has not picked up by the time the wines are released next year, a lot of Bordeaux wine will want for buyers.
Not that that isn't happening right now. Some chateaus here have actually taken back some of their 1984 wine, an indifferent vintage, from importers in the United States and Britain who see little possibility of selling it.
 
Silver Linings All Over
If there are dark clouds on the horizon, most people here are ignoring them. Construction crews are at work everywhere, their tall cranes visible for miles in the flat vineyard country. Small properties that had fallen into obscurity or disuse are all polished stone, gleaming wrought iron and formal gardens.
At Chateau Pichon-Baron in Pauillac, work continues apace on an enormous new chais -- or winery -- a visitors' center and a museum. Prieure-Lichine, a classic Bordeaux country house and wine chais from the road, has built a circular gift shop, restaurant and heliport behind the 16th century chateau and its more modern but conventional aging cellars.
Much of this prosperity is fueled by France's big insurance companies. By competing with one another to buy wine chateaus, they have increased chateau prices five- and tenfold. Older hands who know Bordeaux's boom-and-bust history are skeptical. They see another generation of corporate executives becoming disenchanted by low-yield wine properties and bringing the current euphoria to an abrubt end.
Meanwhile Bordeaux itself -- the city -- couldn't look more prosperous. New construction is everywhere. The Grand Theatre, designed by Victor Louis (and possibly France's most beautiful theater) is closed for two years of refurbishing, but, for more contemporary tastes, the Grands Hommes center is now open. This remarkable glass-domed amalgam of chic shops, restaurants, food stalls and underground parking garage has taken over the site of the old central market.
Then there is France's newest Virgin Megastore, just opened on the flower-filled Place Gambetta. It's supposed to be a record store, but it offers a restaurant, a hi-fi shop, video rentals, a bookstore and even a wine shop (this is Bordeaux, after all), on six levels connected by three glass elevators in glass tubes.
Not so successful, yet, is the Cite Mondiale du Vin. A project of the powerful C.I.V.B., the French initials for the industry's promotional arm, Interprofessional Committee of the Wines of Bordeaux, the Cite Mondiale is immense and meant to house merchants, importers, wine laboratories, schools for wine professionals and amateurs, restaurants, tasting centers -- just about anything else remotely connected with wine.
It is in the center of the Chartrons, the wine merchants' headquarters in Bordeaux for 500 years. It faces the river Garonne. Most of the old participating companies are gone, but the beautiful facades of their buildings remain. The Cite Mondiale project preserves most of those facades; it is rising behind them.
But the industry shows too little interest and the project is seriously behind schedule. The famous old concerns are not interested in rubbing shoulders with the jug-wine people; even the backwater chateau owners say a tasting in an old, damp cellar is far more romantic than a tasting in a squeaky-clean city laboratory.
Construction is slow. Earlier this month, L'Express published an article on the center called "The Grapes of Indifference."
More successful by far is Vinexpo, the biennial Bordeaux wine fair; it opens here again in June. From modest beginnings eight years ago, Vinexpo has become the most important merchandising and promotional event in the wine world. Wine makers from every country that can raise grapes vie for booth space in the huge Vinexpo tent at Bordeaux Lac, an industrial park just north of the city.
Two years ago, space in and around Bordeaux was so scarce that some exhibitors chartered helicopters to fly their people to and from hotels far out in the countryside. More important than booth space are invitations to the best parties. Heaven help the ambitious young marketer who provides his boss with tickets to Chateau Inconnu's pool party the night of Eric de Rothschild's dinner in the great Ricardo Bofill chais at Lafite.
 
TASTINGS
 
Estancia Cabernet Sauvignon 1987, California, Alexander Valley; about $8.
 Estancia is a separate label of Franciscan Vineyards in the Napa Valley. It is separate because the Estancia wines -- there is also a chardonnay -- come from properties north of the Napa Valley, in the Alexander Valley in Sonoma County. Produced under the supervision of Franciscan's wine maker, Greg Upton, the Estancia wines are consistently good and, possibly because they are so reasonably priced, often underrated. Which is certainly to the consumer's benefit because good wines (and particularly cabernets) selling for under $10 are becoming scarce. This 1987 cabernet is rounded and rather soft, by which I mean it is not at all harsh, as some more tannic wines can be. But it has concentration and plenty of fruit and flavor. It doesn't give the impression of being a wine that will last, but so what? It's a wine to drink and enjoy right now.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Lawrence Welk Encore

 BODY:
Reacting to an avalanche of embarrassing publicity, the House and Senate approved an amendment last week that rescinds a $500,000 grant to develop a museum at the North Dakota birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the polka-playing bandleader. A small victory against Congressional pork-barreling? Don't count the savings yet.
Senator Quentin N. Burdick of North Dakota, the powerful Democrat who inserted the Welk museum grant deep in an agriculture spending bill last fall, also voted to rescind it. However, in a tortured reading of the legislative history, he says the amendment doesn't kill the grant; it merely prevents using the funds to restore the champagne-music maker's home. Mr. Burdick says the money may still be used to turn the site into a German-Russian heritage museum and tourist attraction. 
 The Farmers Home Administration must now decide the issue. But the continuing saga merely affirms the tenacity of Congress, and the need for some fundamental reform. Deciding if a project is pure pork or a legitimate economic development effort deserving Federal funding can be a difficult call. But typically there is no debate. The current budget process permits senior members to quietly insert pet projects in funding bills without real scrutiny by the appropriate committees.
Representative Jim Slattery, the Kansas Democrat who led the fight to rescind the Welk museum grant, now proposes a modest antidote to the usual logrolling: Shed more light on the process by requiring a separate listing of all specially earmarked grants for everyone to see before Congress votes on appropriations.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
After Mr. & Mrs. T, Who?

 BODY:
That the financial struggle between Donald Trump and his former wife is over (she got $14 million, the house and the old Mercedes) is presumably a great relief to both. But for at least one onlooker it is little short of a disaster.
Had it not been for Mr. & Mrs. T., this onlooker -- and countless other Americans -- might have drowned in dark thoughts about the economy, unemployed friends, crime and punishment. But Mr. & Mrs. T. were life preservers, in that to contemplate the tribulations of the rich and famous is to be saved for awhile from one's own. 
 Last weekend, however, Mr. & Mrs. T. put their signatures in all the right places, leaving the onlooker to float alone upon a sea of troubles. Who, she wonders, will buoy her now?
Roseanne Barr is usually good for a supermarket headline or two, and Madonna never fails to tease. But times like these demand the really big guns, the biggest of whom is . . .
Elizabeth Taylor, make your move!

HEADLINE: A LOOK AT THE CITY;
Public Duty: Right Here, and Now

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
New York City is in a war for its future, but does not know how to fight. It has no generals like Powell and Schwarzkopf, no plan and few outside allies. It falls ever deeper into a sinkhole of economic decline, crime, dirt, cynicism and fatalism.
 President Bush struts the world stage, and disdains the home front. Gov. Mario Cuomo excels at lamentations like "there is no money," and confuses rhetoric with action.
 
 Without Washington and Albany providing leadership and money, there can be only one way to fight a war -- with talent and experience.
 New York City needs a government that draws on its impressive array of civic leaders, lawyers and businessmen, many with extensive government experience. Mayor David Dinkins needs to call them to public service, challenge them to give something back to the city that has given them so much and save a city whose creativity, energy and synergy remain unique in our nation.
 Why should Mr. Dinkins do this? He recruited able people, and many should stay with him. But what is required now is not just able people, but the best the city has to offer.
 Mayor Dinkins probably does not think he needs such a drastic revamping of his team to win renomination. He seemingly starts the primary with almost 40 percent (most blacks and many Hispanics) of the total party vote. But if he fails the city, he fails blacks most of all. And if he cannot put the city on the road to recovery, most of his white supporters are likely to abandon him.
 If Mr. Dinkins can attract the most talented into government and turn the city around, he will deserve a second term.
 Why should the city's elite join up? Most of those named below have earned great wealth. Most are Democrats who have no prospects of a Democratic Sir Lancelot carrying them off to Washington and national fame.
 If they genuinely care about public service, they can do their duty right now, right here. If the bright ideas on solving domestic problems they toss around at dinner parties amount to anything, they can implement them right now, right here. Their city needs them no less than the nation.
 Yes, they run risks in working for a Mayor who has a do-little reputation and who might not listen to them. But the alternative for the city's elites is to sit around complaining and giving to charities.
 The challenge will be extraordinary, as will the rewards. They can prove their ability to get things done. They can attract fine young talent back to city government, a place that used to be a proving ground for higher responsibility. It can be so again.
 Who am I talking about? First, Mr. Dinkins needs a top-notch chief of staff. He is not organized and tries to avoid decisions. Someone like Peter Goldmark, President of the Rockefeller Foundation and a former city official, could make City Hall hum. So could David Burke, who held the top staff position for Gov. Hugh Carey.
 For Deputy Mayor for Economic Development or budget director, there are at least three exceptional choices: Peter Solomon, who held the deputy job under Mayor Koch; Roger Altman, formerly an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, and Robert Rubin of Goldman Sachs.
 Richard Beattie, with Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, would be a splendid head for Health and Hospitals. Richard Parsons, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank, would do well at Human Resources.
 Winston Lord, who ran the State Department Policy Planning Staff, is a world-class planner. He knows little of city affairs, but learns fast.
 No one knows more about drugs than Mathea Falco, a natural to lead the Mayor's Drug Council.
 Richard Ravitch is the clear choice for Housing Commissioner.
 Percy Sutton could step out of the shadows as an informal Dinkins adviser and become Deputy Mayor for the Disadvantaged. Angelo Falcon, a leader in the Puerto Rican community, deserves a high position also.
 Charlayne Hunter-Gault could take leave from public television and become the Mayor's press secretary.
 And who knows, maybe Henry Kissinger would leap at the post of Commissioner of Ports and Trade.
 Yes, I know this is crazy. Mr. Dinkins won't ask for help. The talented and experienced won't serve. Why bother? The city is a hopeless mess; let someone else fight the war. They can always escape to the tennis courts and to Connecticut and the Hamptons on the weekends.
 But what if the Mayor did ask, and they or others like them said yes?

HEADLINE: The U.N. Squeezes Iraq

 BODY:
The United Nations seems about to crown military success in the Persian Gulf with hard but equitable peace terms. The conditions for a cease-fire set forth in a draft resolution before the Security Council are remarkable in both their sweep and precision. For Iraq, the price for cessation of hostilities is willingness to destroy terror weapons, pay a portion of its oil revenues into a U.N.-administered reparations fund and recognize the inviolability of Kuwait's frontiers.
The council's five permanent members -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- are close to final agreement on this landmark resolution. That would clear the way for likely approval by the council as a whole, meaning that Iraq will actually be held accountable for its high crimes against the family of nations. 
 The cease-fire terms would put U.N. observers in a demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait, so that U.S. forces could withdraw to the safer confines of Kuwait and out of a crossfire in Iraq.
If Saddam Hussein rejects U.N. terms, the state of war will continue; so will the presence of foreign forces on Iraqi soil. Punitive economic sanctions would also remain in place, with an exception allowed for "materials and supplies for essential civilian needs." These levers provide real pressure against a tyrannical regime fighting for its life against Kurdish and Shiite insurgents.
Yet if Saddam Hussein accepts the harsh terms, he will be ending a war in which Iraq gained nothing with a peace in which Iraq's military power has been radically reduced, a dire outcome for which he would be personally accountable to the Iraqi people. It is a fittingly bitter dilemma, and his only real choice may be compliance.
The U.N.'s draft terms are deservedly punitive and preventive in calling for the destruction and removal of chemical and biological weapons, plus all ballistic delivery systems -- i.e. Scuds. This would be subject to on-site scrutiny by a special commission. Iraq would also be required to renounce nuclear weapons and place all its weapons-grade nuclear material under international custody for removal.
As compensation to victims of Iraqi aggression, a percentage of Iraq's petroleum revenues would be allotted to a special international fund to meet claims for injuries to people and property, including damage to the environment. The principle is surely just, though it may be some time before a devastated Iraq can make a substantial contribution. Every bit as just is insistence that Baghdad once and for all recognize, as it did in 1963, the sovereign frontiers of Kuwait.
From every vantage, these seem the outlines for a safe and reasonable settlement that is consistent with U.N. resolutions and responsive to security fears of Iraq's neighbors. And by their rigor and breadth, these are terms calculated to discourage other regional bullies with covetous designs on vulnerable smaller states.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Arming the New Order

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Wouldn't it be ironic if the resounding defeat of Iraq, led by the high-tech forces of the U.S., resulted in a third world newly armed to the teeth with smart bombs, ballistic and cruise missiles, helicopter gunships, Patriot-style interceptors and radar-invisible aircraft?
That would make wars between third-world rivals more likely, if one thought it had gained a qualitative advantage over another. Such wars would certainly be more lethal and destructive, and might be more likely to draw in forces from industrialized nations guarding their interests or promoting their weaponry. 
 Even without wars, the increased cost of arms buildups and rivalries among nations that could ill afford such weaponry would divert resources that could better be spent to encourage economic growth and fight endemic poverty.
Yet, just such a third-world race for the latest and best in lethal devices seems in prospect -- encouraged, in all probability, by the Bush Administration's inexplicable decision to aid U.S. military contractors in promoting overseas sales of their hardware.
The war itself, of course, has done the most to stir interest in the acquisition of high-tech weapons. Even the most backward and isolated national leader can hardly be unaware today that Iraq's vaunted army -- said to be the world's fourth-largest -- was quickly blown to pieces by the advanced armaments the U.S. and its allies used so effectively.
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, for one, drew the obvious lesson. "To undermine the science, technology, research and modern advances in defense is disastrous," he said in a speech in which he emphasized the need to make Pakistan "an impregnable fortress." If Pakistan goes that way, can India be far behind? Or vice versa?
The U.S. Director of Naval Intelligence, Adm. T. A. Brooks, has said that at least 40 nations are seeking radar-evading "stealth" technologies, and that by the end of the century nine more states will join the six that already deploy reconnaissance satellites. Numerous countries now have the ability to build cruise missiles and their guidance systems.
Israel is acquiring submarines from Germany. France does an active arms-export business. China and others have ballistic missile programs, and the Chinese are willing to sell. The Soviet Union, in its need for hard currencies, continues to make available advanced jets and other weapons to third-world countries.
But name-calling does little good, for Uncle Sam himself is one of the world's biggest arms merchants -- peddling $10.8 billion in conventional arms in 1989, second only to Moscow's $11.7 billion. Thus these two accounted for $22.5 billion in such sales out of a world total of $31.8 billion.
Now the Bush Administration has informed Congress that it wants to sell high-tech weapons worth $18 billion -- including F-16's, Patriots, M-1 tanks and multiple rocket launchers -- to five Persian Gulf allies. With such weapons going to Arab nations, Israel's defense worries are bound to increase; and Israel already is one of the largest recipients of the Pentagon's grants and low-interest loans for foreign nations' arms purchases.
The Administration also is siding with arms contractors who have been lobbying for restoration of government authority -- unavailable since the late 1970's -- to underwrite up to $1 billion in arms sales abroad. The proposal, if approved by Congress, would permit the Export-Import Bank to guarantee commercial bank loans made to overseas buyers of U.S.-made arms.
Administration spokesmen insist that there's no conflict with its stated aim of limiting arms sales to the third world. The guarantees, they say, would be available only to the NATO allies, Japan, Israel and Australia, unless -- a very big unless -- the President found it in the national interest to include other nations.
Those spokesmen must be kidding. Only a few years ago, President Reagan found it in the national interest to sell arms to Iran. U.S. weapons sold to legally authorized countries, moreover, often have been resold to unauthorized third parties. Any way you look at it, the Bush proposal would encourage the proliferation of weapons -- including high-tech weapons, perhaps ultimately to third-world nations.
How can that help Mr. Bush build that stable new world order to which he pays such ardent lip service?

HEADLINE: Veterans Deserve Simple Justice on Claims;
Mortgage Game

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Give Them More Than Parades" (editorial, March 9) discusses the steps government and business can take to help returning members of the military from the war in the Persian Gulf adjust to civilian life. One proposed measure is lowering the rate on mortgage loans for these veterans to 6 percent.
The Veterans Administration now guarantees mortgage loans to veterans of 9 percent on a fixed, 30-year loan through approved banks and mortgage companies. The mortgage bankers who offer these V.A.-guaranteed loans add a minimum of 5 percent, known as 5 points, simply for the privilege of borrowing through this program. Any broker in the New York metropolitan area will quote at least this 5 percent figure to a veteran who inquires about the cost of borrowing through this Government-backed scheme, no matter what the linguistic stratagems (such as "origination fees") to disguise the brazenness of charging so many points. 
 Banks in the metropolitan area are charging the public a bit above 9 1/4 percent for a fixed 30-year loan, asking between 1 and 3 points of the would-be home buyer. A veteran participating in the V.A.-sponsored loan is penalized at least 2 up-front percentage points for paying 1/4 percent less on borrowing. Consider also, the veterans loan program has had a minuscule measure of default; further, the lender has virtually no risk of losing his money: the loans are guaranteed through the Federal Government's underwriting.
Now is the time for our leaders in the Government, our senators and representatives, to question this longstanding unconscionable practice of charging a veteran such a huge number of points, well above what is charged in the marketplace to non-V.A. borrowers, for securing a mortgage through a Government-insured program. The lender confronts little risk, yet doubles the points charged to the veteran.
Now is the right time: economists believe that this huge crew of returning veterans, with the right to gain Government-secured mortgages, constitutes a corps of home buyers. Such buying, goes the reasoning of the forecasters, will stimulate the economy and recreate its health after the damage done by the last few months of the recession. Yet veterans should be wary: Why borrow with the new power of a V.A.-guaranteed mortgage if the former serviceman or woman is to be punished by the bankers with the extra points for doing so?
 
SUMNER BRAUNSTEIN
Oceanside, L.I., March 10, 1991

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.&T. Adds Fees For New Credit Cards

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A.T.& T. said yesterday that new applicants for its Universal Card, a combination credit card and a telephone charge card, would receive less generous terms than those who had signed up since the card was introduced a year ago.
As of today, new applicants will be charged an annual fee of $20. In starting the card, A.T.&T. said it would not charge a fee to people who signed up in the first year, as long as the cards were used at least once a year. 
 New customers will not receive the 10 percent discount on long-distance calls that existing card holders receive when charging calls on the Universal Card. And new applicants will pay an interest rate one percentage point higher than the variable rate, currently 18.9 percent, that is charged to the initial customers.
Credit-card industry analysts said the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's move represented a shift in emphasis from gathering new customers to realizing profits.
"I'd say they're giving up," said Joseph E. Wallace, a Chicago consultant. But David F. Robertson, vice president of the Nilson Report, a credit-card newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif., said the move made financial sense.
Paul Kahn, president of A.T.& T.'s Universal Card unit, noted that the company had always intended to charge an annual fee for cardholders who applied after an initial period.
Mr. Kahn said the Universal Card's rates of delinquent payments and bad debts were small fractions of the industry averages and that the company had maintained high levels of customer service while issuing many cards quickly.
A.T.& T. said 5.2 million Universal Card accounts had been opened and 8.5 million cards had been issued.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 2, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about new charges for applicants for the A.T.&T. Universal Card misattributed a comment in some editions. The statement -- that A.T.&T. appeared to be giving up promoting the card -- was made by Joseph E. Wallace, a credit card consultant in Chicago. (David F. Robertson, vice president of the Nilson Report, a credit card newsletter, said the changes made financial sense.)

HEADLINE: William B. Fretter, Physicist, 74

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., March 27

 BODY:
William Bache Fretter, a physicist who was vice president of the University of California from 1978 to 1983, died Sunday. He was 74 years old.
Before becoming vice president, Dr. Fretter taught physics at the Berkeley campus for 32 years and conducted research into high-energy particle physics. 
 He received two Fulbright scholarships and a Guggenheim fellowship. In 1964 he was named a Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor.
After retiring as vice president, he was associated with a World Bank project to revitalize Chinese universities devastated by the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's.
He is survived by his wife, Grace; a daughter, two sons and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed for a 4th Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, and reported yesterday, were mixed for the fourth consecutive week.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's say that last week's consumer price data for February set the market back somewhat, leaving no sense that the recession is over, but they say most of rate decline has passed. 
 Some sectors in the economy are improving, or may have even stablized, they say, but it will take strong economic data in either direction to persuade the Federal Reserve to move from its current middle-of-the-road policy, they said.
For tax-exempt money funds in the week ended yesterday, the average number of days that securities were held in money managers' portfolios remained unchanged at 50. The assets of such funds declined by $288 million, to a total of $90.8 billion. Analysts say the potential exists for greater cash outflows from the money funds if the stock market, which competes with the funds, continues its strong performance.
The average seven-day compounded yield for the period was 4.44 percent, up by 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, while the 30-day compounded average yield rose by 8 basis points, to 4.26 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield was 6.16 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 6.62 percent for those in the 33 percent bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund produced the best return on investments, with a yield of 5.39 percent, or about 95 basis points more than the seven-day compound yield.
The large spread over the week's average yield suggested that the fund might have invested in securities that for some investors were subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. The fund is managed by Strong/ Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee.
 
Taxable Assets Down
 The assets of taxable money funds fell by $1.8 billion in the week, for a total of $462.7 billion. Most of the outflow came from institutional assets, which lost $1.5 billion, for a total of $113.3 billion, while consumer assets declined by $300 million, to a total of $349.4 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 2 basis points, to 6.22 percent, and the 30-day yield fell by 6 basis points, to 6.31 percent. The fund with the best return on investment in the week was the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund, with a yield of 7.19 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds and are included in The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, showed that the average rate of return was down by 6 basis points in the week, to 5.53 percent.

HEADLINE: New York City to Cut Garbage Rate for Businesses

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
For the first time, New York City will lower the rate that the city's 250,000 businesses pay private haulers to pick up their garbage.
The city is planning to announce today a 7.5 percent cut in the amount that private garbage haulers can charge commercial customers, said Mark Green, Commissioner of the Consumer Affairs Department, which regulates the hauling industry. Mr. Green said the reduction reflects a drop in haulers' costs in recent years, including a decline in the disposal charges that they pay and technological improvements that have saved them money. Beginning May 6, the maximum rate would fall to $13.60 a cubic yard, from $14.70.all figures cq
 
Businesses Pay $1 Billion a Year
 New York City businesses pay haulers more than a $1 billion a year, a cost that has long been an irritant. Businesses here pay garbage collection bills that are three times as high as their counterparts in Chicago and Los Angeles, a Consumers Affairs Department survey found. Many businesses also complain that a lack of competition within the industry makes it difficult for them to change haulers or pay less than the maximum rate.
 Under the new rate, Macy's at Herald Square, which spends more than $500,000 a year for garbage collection, could save at least $35,000, the department says. Con Edison's $2.1 million bill could be reduced by more than $140,000. A delicatessen or grocery that pays about $15,000 a year could save more than $1,000.
The city's Sanitation Department, which is responsible for collecting residential garbage, picks up about 17,000 tons a day. Private haulers collect at least 10,000 tons a day.
The lower rate "properly balances the profits the carters deserve under the law with the economic needs of New York City's businesses," Mr. Green said. "At a time when so many other business costs are rising, the city is pleased to help lower one major cost."
 
Haulers to Fight Rate Cut
 Private haulers will go to court to block the decrease, said Salvatore Spinelli, a lawyer for the Council of Trade Waste Associations, a group that represents many of the more than 400 haulers. Mr. Spinelli said the city had miscalculated haulers' expenses and had not given them "due process" in developing the new rate.
But Mr. Green said an analysis of 1989 financial information supplied by the haulers indicated that their costs had fallen in recent years. For example, the department asserts that technological advances had enabled haulers to compress more garbage into a truck, raising the profit of each load.
Haulers have also cut their disposal costs, Mr. Green said. They last received an increase in fall 1988, when the maximum rate rose to $14.70 a cubic yard, from $10.66. They won that rise because the city had raised its charge for dumping garbage at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. But rather than pay the higher dumping fee, haulers have found less expensive dump sites out of state.
Mr. Spinelli, the haulers' lawyer, said the Consumer Affairs Department had miscalculated in both areas. "The figures are wrong," he said.
Since the $13.60 rate was proposed last November, the haulers have been seeking a new higher rate of more than $19, Mr. Green said. Such a rate is unjustified, he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Holders Approve Saatchi Revamping

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 27

 BODY:
Shareholders of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company approved the advertising giant's recapitalization plan today, and the company's banks agreed to increase the size and extend the maturity of its credit lines.
Under the plan, preferred shares will be converted to common shares, resulting in the former preferred shareholders owning 78.8 percent of the company. In addition, about 60 million ($105 million) worth of new common shares will be sold. Most of these shares will be offered first to existing shareholders. 
 If existing common shareholders do not buy any of the new shares, the portion of the company they own will be reduced to about 13 percent. If they buy all the shares offered to them, they will own about 20 percent.
 
Two Big Holders
 Two preferred shareholders will end up owning the two biggest stakes in Saatchi. St. James's Place Capital P.L.C., the London-based investment firm controlled by Jacob Rothschild, the British financier, will become the biggest shareholder, with about 12 percent. A group led by ESL Partners II L.P., a Dallas-based investment firm, will own more than 9 percent.
Approval of the plan removes a ticking time bomb: A financially weak Saatchi faced having to pay 211 million ($368 million) in July 1993 to redeem some preferred shares.
Saatchi's 19 banks agreed today to increase credit lines to 320 million ($557 million) from 270 million ($470.5 million) and to extend the maturity of the lines to January 1996 from January 1993. Half of the extra 50 million will be used to replace short-term loans.
Charles T. Scott, Saatchi's finance director, said the recapitalization would enable the company to reduce its net average debt by the end of the year to 185 million ($322 million) from 230 million ($400 million).
 
Share Price Falls
 In London trading today, Saatchi's shares closed at 19.5 pence (34 cents), down 1 pence (1.7 cents). At its peak about four years ago, the stock sold for 6.95, or 695 pence.
At the special meeting, Maurice Saatchi, the company's chairman, said the recapitalization would enable the company to endure the recession in international advertising "and be well positioned to take advantage of the recovery when it comes."
Mr. Saatchi and his brother, Charles, founded the company and built it through acquisitions into what is now the world's second-largest advertising services company, behind the WPP Group. The Saatchi agencies have been grouped into two networks: Backer Spielvogel Bates and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

HEADLINE: Soviet Opposition Defies Ban on Rally

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 27

 BODY:
Opposition leaders defied a Kremlin warning today and called on the public to ignore the Soviet Government's ban on staging a rally in the capital Thursday on behalf of Boris N. Yeltsin, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief critic and rival.
Rally leaders stressed that marchers should avoid police provocation and stay calm, as they remained intent on rallying the public against an attempt by Gorbachev supporters in the Russian republic's Parliament to oust Mr. Yeltsin as President of the Russian republic. 
 With the police firmly promising to prevent the rally in Manezh Square in the heart of Moscow outside the Kremlin, the city was set for an anxious and uncertain day of political confrontation Thursday as the long-running Gorbachev-Yeltsin rivalry reached a new peak amid the nation's continuing economic and political downward spiral.
 
Rally Tactic: Avoid Provocation
 Muscovites, mindful of Government warnings and sometimes exaggerated reports of police and military preparations, debated whether to challenge the ban. Many clearly were making plans to at least try to march peacefully from two gathering points in the city toward the Kremlin, intending their mere presence in the streets as something of a moral blow against the Kremlin ban.
At the same time, leaders of Democratic Russia, the main opposition umbrella group sponsoring the rally, stressed that marchers should avoid violence and follow the lead of City Council members and other democratic politicians planning to try and stabilize the situation, with peaceful retreat, if necessary, according to some of them.
There was a sense of wariness in the city today, with speculation focused on two well-remembered events.
The first was the memorably large march and rally 13 months ago before which the Kremlin had issued dark-edged warnings of risk and danger, only to tolerate an ebulliently peaceful rally with no incident of confrontation.
 
Lethal Vilnius Confrontation
 The other was the lethal confrontation two months ago in Vilnius, when Soviet tank troops were used on behalf of local Communists against unarmed Lithuanian independence pickets. More than 15 people were killed and President Gorbachev later defended the action as necessary for the sake of maintaining Government order.
Thus, the events of Thursday seemed likely to provide a further reading of just how much more hard-line, or tolerant, the Gorbachev Government is willing to become in trying to deal with political protest.
The city has had two years of experience with street rallies by the nation's fledgling insurgent political opposition, replete with demands for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation, and there have been no instances of street violence.
Large numbers of police and military personnel were in reserve in and near the city, as is usual for all the city's planned and ad hoc politicial events.
 
Gorbachev Sets Urgent Tone
 But there was no advance show of force to be seen today beyond six heavy dump trucks parked at the main entrance to Red Square, which constitute a typical blockade on rally days.
Officials denied reports that armored personnel carriers would be used to block the marchers' way, saying the authorities would rely mainly on their usual measure of large numbers of foot patrolmen and soldiers carrying riot sticks and guiding pedestrians from closed areas.
Mr. Gorbachev set the urgent tone of the confrontation when he called on the Moscow City Council on Monday to ban the Yeltsin demonstration in the name of maintaining public order.
The city government, dominated by insurgents, refused, saying that the rally had been legally approved and that the Kremlin ban was a violation of the public's right of assembly.
 
Exploiting Hard Times
 Mr. Gorbachev, accusing opposition politicians of seeking to exploit the nation's hard times, then ordered the national Interior Ministry to supersede Moscow city officials and take control of the city's law enforcement.
Tass, the Soviet press agency, contended in a commentary today that the public protest rally was nothing less than an attempt to "topple Gorbachev by crowd pressure."
Some of the Democratic Russia officials, in turn, asserted that Mr. Gorbachev's extraordinary measures against the rally were certain evidence of his returning to "totalitarianism."
Members of the Communist opposition have called for Mr. Yeltsin's dismissal for his behavior in criticizing President Gorbachev and demanding his resignation because of the nation's continued political and economic crisis.
The Gorbachev move against the rally came after 29 members of the Russian Parliament complained of feeling intimidated by the public's assembling for political protest.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Internal Judgment,' U.S. Says
 WASHINGTON, March 27 (Reuters) -- The United States said today that the order giving the national Interior Ministry control of Moscow's law enforcement was an internal matter.
"Our position on this is that it is an internal judgment of the Soviet Union as to what powers should be held by a given level of government," said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Wind Storms in Kansas Push Wheat Prices Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wind storms in Kansas evoked visions of crop damage among grain futures traders and sent wheat prices up by a nickel a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
On other markets, livestock and meats were mostly higher, precious metals declined and energy futures were mostly lower. 
 While the winter wheat damage from the wind and dust storms might prove to be minimal, the market was not taking any chances, said Don Roose, an analyst in Des Moines with U.S. Commodities Inc.
Of more concern is a continuing dry spell throughout the hard red winter wheat belt, although some rain last weekend did help. As of Monday, 52 percent of the crop was rated good to excellent, compared with 26 percent the previous week.
In addition to weather concerns on the futures market, prices were helped by traders who were buying to cover short positions before an important crop report came out today.
Wheat settled 4 cents to 5 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $2.84 3/4 a bushel. Corn was 1/4 cent to 1 cent higher, with May at $2.51 a bushel. Oats were unchanged to 3/4 cent higher, with May at $1.22 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 2 1/2 cents to 3 3/4 cents higher, with May at $5.71 1/4 a bushel.
Livestock and meat futures prices advanced on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, responding to a better tone in the economy, said Chuck Levitt, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in Chicago.
Live cattle settled 0.12 cent to 0.42 cent higher, with the April contract at 81.15 cents a pound. Feeder cattle were 0.08 cent lower to 0.35 cent higher, with March at 89.77 cents a pound. Live hogs were 0.10 cent lower to 0.75 cent higher, with April at 53.20 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 0.32 cent to 0.47 cent higher, with May at 66.42 cents a pound.
Energy futures were mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Light sweet crude oil closed 35 cents lower, with the May contract at $19.41 a barrel. Heating oil was 0.18 cent to 0.57 cent lower, with April at 56.61 cents a gallon. The April unleaded gasoline contract, which expires today, was 1.83 cents higher while other deliveries were unchanged to 0.26 cent lower.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A successful auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes and rumors that labor market conditions continue to deteriorate helped to push up prices of Treasury securities yesterday, and interest rates fell.
At the auction, the new securities were sold at an average yield of 7.81 percent, a level dealers said was extremely attractive relative to yields elsewhere on the maturity spectrum. 
 "In a relative value sense, this is the highest yield on a five-year security in almost a year," one government securities trader said.
At the last five-year auction, on Feb. 21, the securities were sold at an average yield of 7.51 percent.
The perception that the five-year note yield was attractive was manifested in trading following the auction.
By late in the day, the new five-year securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.76 percent.
Talk that weekly unemployment claims numbers to be released today will show further increases also helped to spur some buying.
 
March Employment Data
 "The market is beginning to anticipate that the March employment numbers will be weak," another trader said. The employment data are expected to be released by the Labor Department on April 5.
Last week the claims numbers rose to an eight-year high.
Since employment is an indicator that lags behind turns in the economy, "the market is absolutely right" to expect that the March data will be weak, said Nancy Kimelman, chief economist at Thompson Financial Networks in Boston.
Ms. Kimelman added that although there are some signs of life in the economy, "I still think we are in for another two or three months of bad economic statistics."
In addition, the rise in the dollar since the start of the year, an ascent that has accelerated in recent weeks, is causing renewed interest among foreigners in American securities, some analysts said.
"With the enormous strength of the dollar, it is clear we are getting a rebasing of portfolios," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist and managing director at Midland Montagu Economics.
 
30-Year Bond Issues
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 95 7/8, up 18/32, to yield 8.24 percent, down from 8.30 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 29/ 32, up 11/32, to yield 8.05 percent. And the two-year notes auctioned by the Treasury on Tuesday at an average yield of 7.15 percent were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.05 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates also fell.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.76 percent late yesterday, down seven basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.78 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.90 percent, down six basis points.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities remained light.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said that prices of most widely quoted securities inched up by about 1/8 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of five-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Many Competing Bills Chase the Energy Problem

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Lawmakers have responded to the Bush Administration's national energy strategy with a flurry of competing proposals to raise gasoline taxes, improve automobile mileage, raise energy efficiency in businesses and homes, open sensitive regions to oil exploration, and spend hundreds of millions of dollars for research on conservation and renewable sources of energy.
At last count, the House Energy and Commerce Committee was reviewing 68 proposals for revamping Federal energy policy, and, in the Senate, four main bills and more than a dozen others have been introduced. 
 Despite the intense energy expended in making proposals, some of the most influential lawmakers have expressed doubts that Congress will resolve fierce regional, economic and environmental issues and reach a consensus on a final package. The reason: Oil supplies are steady and prices have fallen since the end of the Persian Gulf war.
 
No Shortages, No Brownouts
 "At the moment, there are no gasoline lines or brownouts," Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said last month. "I wonder if we are serious enough about energy to solve the problem at long last."
Even if a bill emerges, staff experts in both houses say it is likely to take five or six months to reach the House and Senate floors. The conference to resolve differences between the bills will take more time and, if successful, a final measure may be ready before the election in 1992.
Few members of Congress disagree that there is an energy problem. Low prices discourage domestic oil and gas production, economists say, while also encouraging people to waste energy. The United States is importing nearly half its oil, accounting for half the $108 billion international trade deficit in 1990, according to the Department of Commerce.
Most important, higher imports are vulnerable to costly disruptions of supply. Though the Bush Administration insists the Persian Gulf war was primarily a response to Saddam Hussein's aggression, few in Congress doubt that it was also prompted by oil.
What nobody in Congress knows is whether the public views the Persian Gulf war as a call to action on energy policy or as the price a nation must periodically pay to preserve its oil-based way of life.
"Regrettably, we were not wise enough 10 years ago to continue the energy security measures enacted after the oil crises of the 1970's," said Representative Leon E. Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee, who introduced an energy proposal last month that called for establishing a minimum price for oil. "Our dependence has tragically resulted in war. How many times do we have to learn this lesson?"
The debate in Congress will be framed by two issues: whether to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a 17.9-million-acre wilderness in Alaska, to oil and gas exploration, and whether to raise fuel mileage standards on automobiles by 40 percent.
 
Drilling in the Refuge
 The opening of the refuge was proposed on Feb. 20 by the Bush Administration in its national energy strategy and was included in several Congressional bills, including one introduced by Senators J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, and Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, the chairman and ranking minority member of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.
The President's plan also includes removing obstacles to the constructon of nuclear power plants, reducing restrictions on utilities that generate electricity for the wholesale market and simplifying licensing for hydroelectric power plants, along with a modest conservation effort, including encouraging the use of alternative fuels in vehicle fleets.
The nation's largest environmental groups, among them the Sierra Club and the National Wildlife Federation, have vowed to block any effort to drill in the Arctic refuge. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins promised Senator Johnston in a hearing earlier this month that the President would veto any bill that did not include opening the refuge to oil exploration.
Increasing fuel efficiency in cars was offered by Senators Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, and Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. It calls for raising average fuel economy in cars from 27.5 miles a gallon currently to nearly 40 miles a gallon, an increase that could save 2.8 million barrels of oil daily, about nine times as much oil as the Arctic Refuge is expected to produce daily, Senator Bryan says.
Environmental groups support the bill. But Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, said on Tuesday that raising fuel mileage standards would destroy the domestic auto industry and he would urge the President to veto any bill that contained such a provision.
Having watched two of the most important groups in the debate stake out their positions, members of Congress and their top staff experts now wonder how much the White House or the environmental community will compromise or whether either the White House or the environmentalists can afford to be accused of derailing a substantive energy bill.
"The question for Congress is, do you lose people by putting both controversial items in a comprehensive bill or do you gain people by tackling the issues and putting both items in," said Jack Riggs, director of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Energy and Power. "That's what we're going to spend a year finding out."
Other proposals are attracting considerable attention as well.
Environmental groups are fond of the bill introduced last week by Senators Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, and James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont. It seeks to improve the energy efficiency of homes, businesses and the Federal Government but does not mention opening the Arctic Refuge.
In the House, Representative Panetta proposed to control supplies of oil by price strategies. Mr. Panetta's bill would set a price floor of $16 a barrel for domestic oil. It would also raise gasoline taxes.
Under Mr. Panetta's plan, if oil prices increased and then fell back, the Government would be able to collect half of the retreat as an additional tax on gasoline. The Administration has said it opposes any new motor fuel taxes.
Representative Norman F. Lent, Republican of Long Island, the ranking minority member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has proposed an energy bill with other House Republicans that is similar to the White House energy strategy. It would make it easier for utilities to license nuclear power plants with streamlined procedures. The bill would provide tax credits for utilities that generate electricity with renewable energy sources including the sun, wind, and hot water from deep wells. It also seeks to make it easier for pipeline companies to build interstate natural-gas pipelines.
And Philip R. Sharp, Democrat of Indiana, introduced five proposals that would require the Government to set new fuel-efficiency standards for utilities, expand the Strategic Petroleum Reserve from a billion to 1.5 billion barrels, streamline regulations for building gas pipelines, and provide tax breaks for utilities that generate electricity with renewable sources of energy.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Highest in a Year Against Mark in Busy Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar reached its highest level in a year against the German mark yesterday as comments from Germany's top economic official strengthened the currency's postwar rally.
Gold was lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold fell $1.30 a troy ounce to settle at $356.30. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $355, off $1.50 a troy ounce from Tuesday's late bid. 
 The dollar broke 1.7000 German marks early in New York trading, an important psychological barrier that has not been cleared since last March.
The move came after remarks by the German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, that his nation could live with the German mark at its current levels. That resulted in an immediate rise in the dollar's value against the mark, as traders rushed to buy dollars before they rose even higher.
By the end of the day the dollar settled at 1.7065 German marks, up from late Tuesday's 1.6870.
The dollar, which was down slightly against the yen in overnight Tokyo trading, rose through the New York session against that currency as well.
"Everytime you turn around it's a little bit higher," said Liliana Nealon, first vice president and currency analyst at Union Bank of Switzerland's New York office.
The upward move defied concerted attempts yesterday by the world's leading central banks, with the apparent exception of the Federal Reserve Board, to drive the dollar lower.
Weaknesses inherent in Germany's economic reunification have become vividly apparent amid reports of increasing joblessness in the former East Germany.
The dollar was also helped by a Commerce Department report that the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter, an improvement from an earlier estimate of a 2 percent decline.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 138.40 yen, down 0.10 yen from Tuesday's close. It had gained 1.45 yen in the previous two days. Later in London, it was quoted at 138.50 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 139.56 yen from late Tuesday's 138.80 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7405, from $1.7545 late Tuesday. The pound also lost ground in New York, closing at $1.7425, down from $1.7580 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.4560 Swiss francs, up from 1.4330; 5.7930 French francs, up from 5.7240; 1,269.50 Italian lire, up from 1,253, and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1602.
Silver fell. The metal slipped 6.9 cents a troy ounce to settle at $3.814 on the New York Commodity Exchange. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $3.83 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $3.94.

HEADLINE: Surge in Dollar Surprises Some, Worries Others

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar is back from its recent depths, buoyed by allied successes in the Persian Gulf and hopes for an economic rebound at home. The sudden rally has come as a surprise to currency traders, confounded some forecasters and begun to worry Government finance officials because of its potential impact on exports.
In just seven weeks the dollar has leaped 17.9 percent against the German mark and nearly as much against other currencies, ending a 17-month downturn that brought it to historic lows against the mark and the Swiss franc and near record lows against the Japanese yen. 
 After hitting bottom at 1.4475 marks on Feb. 11, the dollar surged on the war news, stirrings of economic life in the United States and hopes for falling interest rates abroad. Yesterday the dollar closed at 1.7065 marks.
"It's incredible, isn't it?" said Liliana Nealon, vice president at Union Bank of Switzerland, noting that the dollar has jumped 3.6 percent just since Friday. "I really think the market is looking back and saying, 'Wow.' "
For the world economy, the dollar rally is a mixed blessing, which is why the response from the United States and its economic partners has been relatively muted so far.
It is an immediate boon for American tourists, who had clearly been suffering from sticker shock on visits to Paris, London, Rome and Berlin, but whose dollars now go further in all those places. It can also ease some inflationary pressure by making imports cheaper.
The stronger dollar and the weaker mark are also welcome news to many Europeans. The shift has enabled countries in the European Monetary System, like France, Spain, and Britain, to lower interest rates to counter slowdowns or recessions. Before the dollar rally, lowering interest rates might have weakened the franc, the peseta and the pound and pushed them out of their fixed trading ranges within the monetary system. But the fall of the mark, the central currency in the system, has widened the room for maneuvering.
For American exporters and manufacturers, however, the stronger dollar could make competition abroad and at home more difficult, as American exports become more expensive and foreign imports cheaper. But for this impact to be felt, the dollar would have to remain at these higher levels for some time.
"I don't think it is a fluke," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "It hasn't run its course, but it is bound to slow down." Mr. Kudlow had been expecting the dollar to strengthen, but the move has been so quick that many other forecasters, like Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch, have sought to catch the wave by quickly revamping their forecasts that the dollar would stay low.
The rally has brought the dollar back to its levels of a year ago. But at 1.7065 marks to the dollar yesterday, it is still well below the average level of 1.88 in 1988 and the highs of more than 2 marks hit in the late 1980's. And it is still far below its all-time high of 3.475 marks in February 1985.
For American companies with large sales abroad, profits will be hurt when the foreign earnings are converted into dollars. But the reverse will be true for Japanese and, especially, European companies that had been hit hard by a weak dollar.
Some corporations seemed to have been caught unprepared. Mrs. Nealon said she has corporate customers who did not expect the dollar to rise much beyond a brief victory rally after the war. Now they hope to buy dollars when the value dips, only to find that the dollar just keeps rising, forcing them to pay even more.
 
Affecting the Trade Deficit
 A stronger dollar could also slow or even eventually end the decline in the American merchandise trade deficit, which dropped to $100 billion last year. Some economists have advocated an even lower dollar to help reduce this troublesome deficit. But others, like Mr. Kudlow, contend that the deficit can continue to fall, even if a little more slowly, with the dollar at these levels. They say that American manufacturers are more competitive than they were a few years ago and that a modest economic recovery should not create a consumer boom that would cause a surge in imports and a rise in the trade deficit.
The response by officials in the Group of Seven, composed of the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, was a little confusing yesterday but did not indicate strong opposition to having the dollar at present levels.
In Bonn, Theo Waigel, the Finance Minister, said the United States and Germany could live with the current levels of the dollar. His comments, coming on his return from a meeting with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady on Monday, were taken by traders as clearance to push the dollar higher, and it shot up, passing 1.70 marks and closing at 1.7065, its highest level since March 27, 1990.
In Washington, David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, told reporters: "We are concerned about the rapidity of the rise. We are not seeking a stronger dollar." But he also said that Mr. Waigel's comment was accurate at the time of the meeting with Mr. Baker, which was Monday when the dollar closed in New York at 1.6840 marks.
The dollar's surge started after it hit its low of 1.4475 marks on Feb. 11 in New York trading. At first many traders said the rally would be just a short-lived response to what was shaping up as a quick and easy victory in the war against Iraq. But the rally was pushed further on expectations of a rebound soon from the American recession and a slowing of economies abroad.
Then in early March, the German Government said it would raise taxes to help pay for modernizing eastern Germany. By raising taxes, the Government would have to borrow less, making it suddenly more likely that German interest rates, which set the tone for Europe, would not rise further and even begin to decline.
Foreign exchange traders concluded that interest rates would fall abroad, while remaining stable in the United States or falling only slightly. Such a narrowing of the interest-rate differential between dollars and others currencies makes the dollar more attractive to foreigners.
One immediate effect of the dollar's rise is on the contributions from Germany and Japan to pay for the costs of the war. A report from Bonn yesterday said the German Government agreed to pay more marks to make up for the appreciation of the dollar.
The Japanese have refused so far to cover the loss from the dollar rally. They made their pledge in yen but the United States wants it counted in dollars.
