HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate Down 1.6% In Sign of Milder Slump

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
The economy shrank at an annual rate of 1.6 percent in the final three months of 1990, a significantly smaller downturn than previously reported, as spending on the military in the Persian Gulf helped cushion the decline, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department report on the gross national product -- the country's total output of goods and services -- raised hopes that the recession would be short and shallow. 
 Some private economists said the Bush Administration might well be proved correct in its forecast that growth in the G.N.P. would resume in the April-June quarter, but they cautioned that huge leftover debt from the 1980's would dampen a recovery.
 
Optimism From Administration
 The Administration, however, held to its belief that the country was on the verge of a rebound that could rival the peacetime record for growth set in the 1980's.
"We have seen the first tangible signs of a turnaround," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the United States Chamber of Commerce today. He cited a big jump in a consumer confidence index and increases posted for February in housing construction and home sales.
But analysts said any strength would have to come from consumer spending, because export growth, the main bright spot last year, was likely to be held back by economic weakness overseas.
And given the fact that more than a million people have lost their jobs and paychecks since June, analysts said consumer buying would be constrained.
"Consumers can be as confident as they want, but if their financial ability to go out and spend is not there, it won't do anything for the economy," said Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates of West Chester, Pa.
Another report today emphasized the strains American companies are operating under. The Commerce Department said corporate profits from current production posted their second straight annual decline, the first two-year drop since 1969-70. Profits were off 3.8 percent last year after falling 7.7 percent in 1989.
The 1.6 percent decline in gross national product in the fourth quarter was an upward revision from previous reports. Two months ago, the decline was put at 2.1 percent; last month, it was put at 2 percent.
The improvement came from export sales, which added $37.7 billion to the economy in the fourth quarter as sales abroad rose sharply and American companies reaped greater profits from their overseas subsidiaries than originally estimated.
Economists said higher military spending related to the Persian Gulf troop buildup added about $5 billion to the G.N.P. in the quarter. .
On the negative side, the Government said consumer spending fell by an even larger amount than first estimated, dropping at an annual rate of $23.2 billion in the fourth quarter.
Data included in the revision of the gross national product for the fourth quarter of 1990 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates:

HEADLINE: Small Stocks Surge as Market Levels Off Before Holiday

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Smaller over-the-counter stocks continued to post strong gains yesterday, but the rest of the stock market leveled off as traders pulled back before the holiday weekend.
Many seemed particularly worried about the Government's report on initial unemployment insurance claims, which is to be released today. 
 A heavy increase in jobless claims could bring a cut in interest rates -- and a big rise in the market. But fewer claims could stall a stock market advance that carried the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday to within 82 points of an all-time high.
The Dow industrials rose 2.72 points yesterday, to 2,917.57. Showing that big stocks were generally weak, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.95, to 375.35 while the New York Stock Exchange index slid 0.23, to 205.32.
The Nasdaq composite index, which measures many of the smaller stocks, hit a 52-week high for the second day in a row, rising 3.80, to 482.37, the equivalent of 23 Dow points.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, though, zoomed to 201.8 million shares, the strongest level in almost two weeks, from 198.7 million shares on Tuesday. Advances only narrowly led declines.
But while only four Big Board stocks dipped to 52-week lows, 146 rose to highs. Drug stocks continued to be prominent among them: Johnson & Johnson soared to a 52-week high of 99 1/2 before ending at 96 3/4, down 7/8. Bristol-Myers Squibb jumped to a high of 80 3/4 before ending at 78 3/8, down 1 1/8. Abbott Laboratories rose to a high of 49 7/8 before ending at 48 1/4, down 1 1/8.
With the economy now expected to bounce back more quickly than expected only a short time ago, airline, railroad and trucking stocks lifted the Dow transportation index 15.16 points, to 1,117.95. Some of the bigger air carriers responded to signs that fare cuts pushed by American Airlines were bringing in business.
American's parent, AMR, rose 1, to 59 1/8, and UAL, the parent of United Airlines, rose 3 1/8, to 146 3/4. Roadway Services, a large trucking concern, rose 2, to 50. And Midway Airlines, which entered bankruptcy proceedings on Tuesday, rose 7/8, to 3 1/2, in heavy trading.
Traders attributed the market's sluggishness to caution about the new jobless claims figures.
Nancy R. Lazar, currently senior vice president and economist of C. J. Lawrence, noted that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, "followed the number very closely."
"If claims are higher than expected," she said, "odds are the Fed will cut the discount rate."
But Ms. Lazar, who will become executive vice president of the newly formed International Strategy and Investment Group on Monday, said that she expected the number to drop to 480,000 from 519,000 the previous week, and that if she was correct, she did not believe it would prompt the Fed to cut the discount rate.
"But," she added, "my estimate of 480,000 could be too low."
Traders argued that if jobless claims were regarded as exceptionally high, the Fed could trim the rate it charges banks by as much as a half of a percentage point, enough to give the market a hefty push. On the other hand, if the Fed feels that jobless claims are not that serious, it could trim its rate by, say, only a quarter point, which some thought would be disappointing.
With the exchanges closed on Good Friday and the possibility of crucial Fed action, many traders pulled back, taking some profits.
Microsoft, for example, traded as high as 109 1/4 but closed at 107 3/4, ahead 2 5/8, with 1.3 million shares changing hands. Amgen, the hot drug stock, moved as high as 133 1/4 before ending at 132 1/4, up 2 1/4. Apple Computer climbed as high as 70 1/4 before finishing at 69 1/4, down 3/4.
Stocks took off on the opening bell, with the Dow rising 14 points, but they soon began to seesaw. By noon, the Dow was ahead 24 points, but within an hour it slid 26 from where it was. By 2:30, it regained 14 from the low, but dropped 20 from there, bouncing back a bit by the close.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said heavy computerized selling cut 11 points off the Dow in nine minutes, starting just before 1 P.M. Program buying cut the loss a point.
In the Square D takeover battle, Square D slumped 1 5/8, to 76 3/4, or below the $78-a-share offer by Groupe Schneider of France. A Federal court in New York denied a motion by Schneider to reject Square D's antitrust claims.
Bandag, a leader in tire retreading, rose 3 1/2, to 96. Bloomberg, a financial information service, said Merrill Lynch had issued a report on the company.

 TOKYO, Thursday, March 29 (Reuters) -- Japanese stock prices moved slightly higher today, rebounding from an early selloff. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 102.27 points to close at 26,206.92. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 234.73 points.

HEADLINE: Weicker to Accept Cap On Growth in Spending

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 27

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., taking the unusual step of personally testifying before the legislature, told lawmakers today for the first time that he would accept limits on the future growth of state spending as part of his budget and income-tax plan.
A spending restraint measure, written either into the statute books or into the State Constitution, has been sought by members of both major political parties who worry that tapping the state's wealth with an income tax would lead to an uncontrollable spurt in spending. Connecticut has the highest per-capita income in the nation and is one of only 10 states with no broad-based income tax. 
 Mr. Weicker, who testified for more than 90 minutes today before the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, said he understood and welcomed the efforts by individual state representatives and senators to carve the best deal they could out of the budget for their constituents.
 
'Not Going to Happen'
 But he urged them to assert themselves as leaders and not to pay too much attention to what constituents say because he believes a majority of residents will remain opposed to an income tax, however necessary it may be to resolve the state's fiscal and economic crisis and however convincing the arguments.
"At no point are we going to have a majority saying that they want more taxes and less services -- that's not going to happen," Mr. Weicker said.
"But," he continued, referring to the next election year, "a year from now, as the state rebounds with black ink and jobs, those people who lead now will lead in '92. Those who lie in the weeds waiting for mistakes will end up in the prone position in '92."
For Mr. Weicker, Connecticut's first governor elected as an independent in this century and believed to be the first ever to propose an income tax, overcoming the traditional reluctance of Connecticut governors to testify and be grilled at length by lawmakers about budgets and taxes seemed almost an offhand decision: another day, another tradition to be trashed.
Sitting alone before a microphone, he answered questions, dodged others, flattered supporters and warned recalcitrant committee members that there would be "no advantage to be gained by exploiting your state's misery."
 
An Exploratory Tone
 The main tone of the committee's questions was exploratory rather than hostile. Both co-chairmen of the 40-member Democratic-controlled committee -- Senator William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford, and Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford -- have already expressed their support for an income tax.
Many other sympathizers wanted to know how much could be changed in Mr. Weicker's budget without turning him against it -- a line of questioning that the Governor generally sidestepped.
His answers also often seemed contradictory. Without ever mentioning the word veto, he seemed to wave the committee away from changing his plan a great deal. Moments later, he encouraged them to take their best hacks at it.
To one questioner, for example, he said the need for an income tax was dictated by the state's huge deficit and was unavoidable without bringing about great increases in other taxes that would devastate the economy or cuts in spending that would devastate state services. The decision to seek an income tax was so obvious, he said, as to be a "no brainer."
But almost immediately he expressed his own personal dislike of the plan and encouraged the panel to find some other way, though he warned them they would fail.
 
Spending Question Pressed
 Even those committee members, mainly Republicans, who have gone on record as opposed to Mr. Weicker's plan seemed unwilling to challenge him directly. Instead, they mainly pressed the question of the cap on spending. How would Mr. Weicker feel about it being written into the State Constitution? The Governor said he opposed a constitutional measure, but his opposition is largely irrelevant; if an amendment is approved by a three-quarters majority in both chambers of the General Assembly, it goes directly to the voters.
Several Democrats questioned the level of Mr. Weicker's spending cuts and wondered whether some money might be restored without provoking a veto. Mr. Weicker's $7.5 billion spending plan is about $1.2 billion less than a preliminary budget prepared last year under Gov. William A. O'Neill.
 
Chief Tax Mechanism
 Mr. Weicker's plan, presented to the state last month, would lower an array of taxes paid by businesses in an effort to stimulate the economy and simultaneously resolve a $2.4 billion shortfall in tax revenues.
The chief mechanism would be a flat 6 percent tax on all income over $25,000 a year for a family and $12,500 for an individual.
The corporate profits tax, now the highest in the nation at 13.8 percent, would be reduced to 11.5 percent, and the 8 percent sales tax, also the highest statewide rate in the country, would be cut to 4.25 percent but expanded to include new categories like the sale of movie tickets and gasoline.
Existing taxes on income from interest and dividends, which peak at 14 percent for families earning $100,000 or more, and the 7 percent capital-gains tax on income from the sale of stock or other assets would both be eliminated, with all sources of income taxed equally at 6 percent.

HEADLINE: Court Limits Copyright Protection

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
In an important copyright decision, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the alphabetical listing of names and addresses in the white pages of a phone directory was not protected by Federal copyright law.
The decision, which overturned a ruling by a Federal appeals court in Denver, has broad potential implications for the computerized information industry and for other publishers of compilations that are essentially factual in nature. 
 While the full scope of the decision will not be clear until courts begin to apply it beyond the context of telephone directories, copyright experts predicted today that the Supreme Court's approach would make it much more difficult to obtain copyright protection for compilations of factual material.
Writing for the Court today, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that "copyright rewards originality, not effort," and that "in no event may copyright extend to the facts themselves." In the case of the white pages, she said, alphabetical listings of names and addresses "do not satisfy the minimum constitutional standards for copyright protection" because they are "devoid of even the slightest trace of creativity."
The decision overturned a $6,000 judgment for copyright infringement that a small Kansas telephone company, the Rural Telephone Service Company, won in 1987 against a publisher that incorporated the listings from Rural's telephone book into a competing telephone book that covered a wider area of the state.
While 10 other small telephone companies in the area had sold the publisher, Feist Publications Inc., the right to copy their listings, Rural refused to do so. Feist then copied 1,309 of Rural's listings and included them in its own telephone book. Rural won its copyright infringement suit in both the District Court in Kansas and the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver.
While the financial stakes were small for the two parties in the case, Feist Publications v. Rural Telephone Service, No. 89-1909, they are likely to prove substantial for other elements of the information industry.
David Lange, a copyright specialist at the Duke University Law School, said the decision might prove "revolutionary for the information industry," with the double-edged result of making information more widely available to the public and at the same time diminishing the economic value of data bases that are essentially compilations of facts.
 
'Sweat of the Brow' Doctrine
 Copyright experts said an important aspect of the ruling was the Court's firm rejection of a basis for copyright protection known as the "sweat of the brow" doctrine. Under this approach, which had been accepted in several appellate circuits, compilations of facts were entitled to copyright protection on the basis of the publisher's effort and investment, not the product's originality.
"Without a doubt, the 'sweat of the brow' doctrine flouted basic copyright principles," Justice O'Connor said. "Rural expended sufficient effort to make the white pages directory useful, but insufficient creativity to make it original."
For phone companies, the impact may not be great. While direct-mail marketers are now free to copy the telephone listings, many will be willing to continue paying for the convenience of obtaining the information on computer disks. Phone companies have typically been willing to sell their listings, as 10 of the 11 Kansas companies did in this case.
 
Selection or Arrangement Cited
 The impact is likely to be felt in other areas of the information industry. Justice O'Connor said that "the vast majority of compilations" would still be entitled to copyright protection as being based on some kind of "original selection or arrangement." But she added that the protection was "limited to the particular selection or arrangement," and not to the facts that were being arranged.
Steven J. Metalitz, general counsel for the Information Industry Association, a trade association of 800 information companies, said the decision raised questions about copyright protection for many data bases. "You'd have to think twice now about making the investment in time and effort" to compile factual material, he added.
Several cases now in the lower courts may soon begin to provide answers to what Mr. Metalitz called the "second generation questions" posed by today's decision. One case, Black's Guide Inc. v. Mediamerica, now before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, is a copyright dispute between competing publishers of guides to commercial real estate.
Justice Harry A. Blackmun agreed with the outcome of the phone directory case today, but he neither signed Justice O'Connor's opinion nor filed one of his own.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Lessons of S.& L. Crisis Echo in Talks on Banks

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
The time: Shortly before a Presidential election. The voices: Administration officials, asserting that a federally guaranteed deposit-insurance program needs to borrow only a few billion dollars to stay afloat.
The action: Officials huddling with lawmakers to devise a way to borrow and/or rely on industry funds to duck a Federal rescue effort. 
 The election comes and goes. Within days of his inauguration, the new President declares a problem of historic dimensions, a bailout that by later estimates will cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.
That was in 1988 and 1989, and the issue was the savings and loan industry. The question for 1991 and 1992 is whether the banks are offering a replay.
"Everybody is looking at the politics of this and saying it's deja vu all over again," said Karen D. Shaw, a consultant at the Washington-based Institute for Strategy Development, which monitors government action for business.
The variation is that in 1988 the problem was neglected altogether. This time around, while Treasury officials insist that no taxpayers' money will be needed, they are seeking to borrow a whopping $70 billion to bolster an insurance fund that the White House says should post a deficit of only $2.2 billion in 1992. Moreover, they buried the proposal in the fine print of a 317-page bill that they presented as a request for $25 billion in borrowing.
"It's so damned reminiscent of the savings and loan bailout," said Joseph C. Lewis, the House Banking Committee spokesman. "Everyone thinks that something is being camouflaged. In this town, history does no good at all."
Why so much money for a need that the Administration says is minuscule compared to that of the savings and loans?
Regulators insist the reason is to have a reserve -- a kind of "backup plan" that will most likely not be needed, as L. William Seidman, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, keeps saying.
The other explanation making the rounds is politics. The Administration's private fear is that the condition of the bank insurance fund could drastically worsen, and it wants to avoid returning to Congress with hat in hand until after the 1992 elections.
In this view, no agency asks for less money than it intends to spend. And what elevates the plight of the bank insurance fund to the level of political threat is that at the moment it is, along with the economy, one of the few potential blotches on the Bush re-election effort.
Administration officials have good reason to be concerned. Independent economists, including those at the General Accounting Office, have projected much smaller deficits than has the Administration. All acknowledge that it is easier to predict the Dow Jones average than the future of the bank insurance fund.
Over the past few months, the problems of the insurance fund have snowballed. Mr. Seidman, who initially forecast that the fund would be profitable last year, has revised his predictions downward almost monthly, finally conceding that 1990 was the worst year in the fund's 57-year history. Now he says that 1991 will be even worse, "probably" posting a decline of $5 billion on top of 1990's decrease of $4.8 billion, leaving it with too little cash to handle one large bank collapse.
The Administration seems willing to contort to almost any degree to avoid the appearance of using taxpayers' money. One sign is that it is proposing to borrow much of the money from the Federal Reserve instead of the Treasury. To most economists, including those at the General Accounting Office, that move is little more than window dressing: Federal Reserve money that would normally go to the Treasury to reduce the Federal deficit would instead be lent to the insurance fund.
But Administration officials insist that they have no political motives in mind with their plans to fix the fund, and in particular that they have no interest in sweeping the problems under the rug until after the elections.
"I can promise you, the first time I ever thought about that was right when you asked me the question, right now," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in an interview this week. "I mean, among other things, we're going to have an S.& L. debate that's going to go on every half-hour, I guess, so not to worry about if anybody wants to talk about things that are unpleasant."

HEADLINE: All-Natural Bedding: Counting On Sheep, Cotton and Even Milkweed

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN

 BODY:
YOUR bed may not be a safe place in which to hide from bad environmental news.
Most of the books at the Terra Verde Trading Company in the SoHo section of Manhattan tell the same sad story: beds can pollute. Polyester sheets are not biodegradable, nor are urethane-foam mattresses, which also emit nasty fumes. And even down offends some environmentalists' sensibilities because of the suffering that plucking inflicts on birds. 
 For alternatives, an increasing number of sleepers are turning to all-natural, cruelty-free bedding, one of the more rarefied corners of the expanding environmental movement. Products range from familiar all-cotton sheets to more exotic pillows packed with buckwheat hulls to fluffy comforters filled with milkweed seed parachutes. Buyers include chemical-sensitive people who cannot abide anything synthetic as well as fans of mother nature's output.
"We take in so much pollution, so many toxins during the day," said David Hormel, a carpenter and woodworker in Santa Rosa, Calif., who sleeps only amid cotton and wool. "It's important to be as healthy as you can while you sleep."
David M. Kingsberg, a Miami businessman, has resorted to all-natural bedding because of allergies. "I've bought, tried and then given away thousands of dollars worth of bedding over the past 10 years because it made me feel like I'd been poisoned," he said. In his tile-floored bedroom, with unpainted wood furniture devoid of glues, he now sleeps on a futon and pillows stuffed with organically grown cotton, wrapped in white all-cotton sheets and blankets.
As for people who do not have such allergies, air-quality researchers have not yet determined whether all-natural bedding is more salubrious than synthetics. "With bedding, we're dealing with a lot of man-made materials that haven't been well tested, that's true," said John Girman, branch chief in the indoor air division of the Environmental Protection Agency. "On the other hand, it's extremely difficult to prove that something's safe; it's much easier to prove that something's dangerous. One thing is certain: being paranoid isn't good for you."
For the moment, the major mattress manufacturers are not feeling much pressure to avoid artificial ingredients. "The consumer wants comfort, support and durability, more than anything else," said Russell Abolt, the executive vice president of the International Sleep Products Association in Alexandria, Va. "Most people don't ask what's in the mattress they're buying. They just want what feels right." Still, mainstream suppliers are not ignoring the all-natural trend.
Next month, at least well-known two makers of bed linens, Fieldcrest Cannon and J. P. Stevens, will introduce unbleached, undyed, untreated cotton products. The solid cream-colored sheets will be available in 180-count and 310-count weights from Fieldcrest Cannon, and 200-count from J. P. Stevens. Prices will be about the same as those for other all-cotton sheets of the same quality.
J. P. Stevens expects retail stores to buy $2.25 million worth of its all-natural bed linens in 1992, said Ana Maria McGinnis, a vice president. She described them as "a very tiny part of the business," but she added, "We're only selling the line to the upper-end outlets."
Anne Bertsch, the director of public relations for the National Bath, Bed and Linen Association in Manhattan, said: "I definitely see a move toward natural fibers. It's surprising because we're such a wash-and-wear country."
There are, of course, many ways to define the word natural. All-cotton sheets and pillowcases have been available for centuries, but in recent years many of them have been treated with formaldehyde, which is used in printing processes and to lock in easy-care finishes.
The E.P.A. considers formaldehyde fumes a "probable human carcinogen," said George Semeniuk, the formaldehyde project manager at the E.P.A.'s Office of Toxic Substances. But a single washing dramatically diminishes the amount of the chemical in fabric, and after that, he said, "there just isn't enough there for the customer to worry about."
The most common non-synthetic casing for futons and mattresses is cotton. Environmentally minded manufacturers scrub the fabric several times to remove pesticide residues: cotton is a heavily sprayed crop, and there is not yet enough organically grown cotton available to persuade fabric mills to weave it.
Natural fillings for mattresses and futons include cotton batting treated with boric acid, a reasonably benign compound used here as a fire retardant; untreated cotton; organically grown untreated cotton; wool, and chemical-free wool.
Buyers pay a premium for the organically grown fillings. An ordinary cotton-filled twin-size futon can be bought for less than $100; one stuffed with organic cotton can cost twice that, and a futon with organic wool stuffing is nearly double the cost of organic cotton.
Although ordinary cotton is inexpensive, its purity varies. "Floor sweepings and even dead birds have turned up in the cheap stuff," said Phillip Abernethy, the inventory manager at Futon Designs in Asheville, N.C.
Because of flammability regulations, untreated cotton is available only by prescription. But many suppliers accept doctors' orders fairly casually. "We'll take them from chiropractors, M.D.'s, naturopaths, whatever," said Valko Sichel, the chief executive of Northwest Futon in Portland, Ore.
Wool stuffing is inherently fire-resistant. Perhaps the country's creme de la natural wool comes from Pure Podunk , a small workshop in Thetford Center, Vt. Its catalogue of mattresses, futons, furniture, toys and household miscellany declares that all its wool comes from "happy sheep raised on small family farms."
Dorian Kinder, an owner of the company, said: "We process the wool with solar power. That doesn't affect the wool at all, but people get a kick out of knowing it."
Since fire-retardancy rules do not apply to pillows, manufacturers can take more liberties with fillings. In addition to cotton and wool, there is kapok (a fluffy white cotton look-alike grown primarily in Asia); millet hulls (millet is a small, round, yellowish seed, a major component in bird food), and buckwheat hulls (confetti-size brown husks, which in pillow form evoke beanbag chairs).
As for natural blankets, all-cotton and all-wool products have been around for centuries, and now there's milkweed. The Ogallala Down Comforter Company in Ogallala, Neb., sells cotton-covered quilts stuffed with 70 percent down and 30 percent milkweed. The company oversees 160 acres of milkweed in southwest and central Nebraska.
"I tried to develop milkweed as an alternative energy source in the 70's," said Herb Knudsen, Ogallala's chief executive. "Milkweed can be processed into synthetic crude oil, but not economically by any stretch of the imagination, so then we started exploring its potential as a down substitute. I'm glad we found a use for it.
"The customer reaction has been kind of skeptical," he added. "It's a tricky crop to harvest, too. If you let it go too long, it can really get away from you -- gone with the wind."
 
A Sampling of Suppliers
THERE are dozens of sources of all-natural bedding. Here is a sampling of suppliers from around the country:

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Follow the Kurds to Save Iraq

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Bush was "sickened" at the sight of a man being clubbed senseless by police while a gang of cops looked on. Yet his stomach is not turned at the spectacle of an American army standing by and watching Saddam Hussein's gunships rain death on the Kurdish people for daring to answer George Bush's call for an uprising.
Having repeatedly incited Iraqis to oust the tyrant in Baghdad; having publicly promised to clear the air of the dictator's deadly choppers -- Mr. Bush suddenly choked up. 
 What is to explain his loss of nerve and sense of moral purpose? The answer is Brer Rabbit's fear of the "tar baby": he does not want to become involved in a genuine uprising of Shiites in the south and Kurds in the north, because that might lead to "instability."
The only outcome Mr. Bush -- and his Saudi and Syrian advisers -- will accept is a military dictator of the Sunni elite not named Saddam. To this inglorious end, we are ready to turn our face away from the wholesale slaughter of innocents, and to abandon the last best hope of the beginning of freedom in Iraq.
Republican Guard troops, who run from foreign armies but enjoy killing their own countrymen, have put down most of the Iran-sponsored Shiite uprising in the south; now their tanks and aircraft will move north to retake Kirkuk from the Kurds. If unhindered by our forces, these thugs will use air cover that General Schwarzkopf admits was "suckered" out of him.
This will make Mr. Bush the third U.S. President to sell out the Kurds. Richard Nixon did it in the 70's, at the behest of the Shah of Iran for regional stability; Ronald Reagan did it in 1988, by rewarding Saddam Hussein with greater commodity credits despite the poison-gassing of 12,000 Kurds in Halabja.
The legendary Kurdish leader Mulla Mustafa Barzani, dying of cancer, was brought to Virginia exile with his young son by the C.I.A. in 1975 after our betrayal. I never met a warrior with fiercer eyes or greater dignity. He repeated with rue the central saying of his 1,000-year-old culture: "The Kurds have no friends." Since that time, I have tried to be one.
Barzani's son Massoud was interviewed this week by American correspondents reaching the Iraqi portion of Kurdistan. Unlike most of the leaders opposed to Saddam Hussein, he is a fighter on the scene, not a voice in exile. He represents his people within Iraq, not the interests of bordering nations, and comes across as a true son of Mulla Mustafa.
His message: The four million Kurds who make up nearly a fourth of Iraq's population do not seek independence now; they will be satisfied with autonomy within an Iraq that respects the rights of disparate groups, religions, ideologies.
That conflicts with the desire of Iran, which wants a Shiite state; with Saudi Arabia, which wants a Sunni military dictatorship; and with Syria, which wants Iraqi anarchy.
But it will no longer upset Turkey, which has begun at last to recognize the ethnic heritage of its own 10 million Kurds. President Ozal wants his nation to be a part of Europe's economy and was undoubtedly moved by the Kurdish human-rights espousal of Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the French President.
Massoud Barzani's goal of a federated Iraq should be America's goal. After World War II, we did not re-install Nazis in Germany or militarists in Japan in the name of "stability." After Desert Storm, we should not demand a Saddam II -- "our" tyrant -- as if Arabs and Kurds were too mentally backward or culturally afflicted to deserve a chance at some form of democracy.
General Schwarzkopf told David Frost he had recommended against Mr. Bush's decision to cut off the ground war at 100 hours, letting Saddam survive in Baghdad; the President disputes this, in the first shot of the campaign of '92. But this much is indisputable: The premature cease-fire, intended to save Iraqi soldiers' lives, threatens to cost hundreds of thousands of Iraqi civilian lives.
U.S. troops in Iraq should not be forced to stand idly by as anti-Saddam forces are slaughtered by tanks and gunships. The word Mr. Bush should deliver to Baghdad is "Freeze!" -- no movement of armor, no northward deployment of forces.
We should dispatch a high-level emissary to Massoud Barzani. We should send a message to the Iraqi high command in Baghdad: Depose Saddam Hussein in 48 hours and begin negotiations with the Kurdish rebels -- or else.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Won't Change the Soviet System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stephen F. Cohen ("Gorbachev the Great," Op-Ed, March 11) and Leslie H. Gelb ("Bomblet in Moscow," column, March 13) ignore the ever-increasing democratic forces that challenge the authoritarian center of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 Both of them are wrong in assessing Mr. Gorbachev as a person and as a politician. Mr. Cohen credits Mr. Gorbachev with everything that has happened in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in the last four years. Doesn't he know that the satellite countries became free because they fought and gained their freedom and not because of Mr. Gorbachev's decision to set them free? His political goal was merely to render the Communist system efficient, while leaving it intact.
Moreover, doesn't Mr. Cohen know that among Moscow intellectuals who in his opinion are wrong were Andrei Sakharov, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, Eduard Shevardnadze and Gavriil K. Popov, to name but a few, who initially sided with Mr. Gorbachev and whom he excluded from his circle after he altered his course? And what about a sizable interregional group of anti-Gorbachev intellectuals who long for true democracy? And what about numerous journalists who committed themselves to glasnost and are told to return to the ideologically coded language?
Mr. Gorbachev has had no intention to change the system of a state-run economy, party organizations, the Bolshevik empire and, above all, the Communist Party. At this point there are two major issues to be resolved if democracy in the Soviet Union is to take root and flourish:
(1) The political rights of the Soviet nationalities have to be accommodated. Mr. Gorbachev regrettably cannot do it because his only goal is to maintain the political status quo.
(2) The center has to be decentered. It is the major obstacle to genuine restructuring of the Soviet Union. The center will just continue to maintain its autocratic authority and contain all creative forces in the constituent republics.
Why are Americans, including the White House, so scared of the inevitable disintegration of the Soviet empire? Wouldn't it be more advantageous for democracy to have an alliance of free and sovereign states, rather than the politically, militarily and economically antagonistic Soviet Union?
 
VITALII DONCHYK
New Brunswick, N.J., March 14, 1991
 
The writer, a member of the Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, Kiev, is a visiting professor, Rutgers U.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 472 words

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Won't Change the Soviet System;
Time to Move On

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. Stephen Cohen's Op-Ed piece, "Gorbachev the Great" (March 11), is in many ways a refreshing counterpoint to much of the anti-Gorbachev rhetoric we hear from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. There can be little doubt that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has had insufficient time to carry out the large-scale reforms to deal with the Soviet Union's economic and political crises. Moreover, perestroika, despite its troubles, is still an important achievement in a bureaucratically ossified society. 
 Given the hardships of Soviet life (it can take a week to find a bottle of milk), it is no surprise that the country's citizens are frustrated and impatient. It is all too easy for Mr. Gorbachev's critics to rally round simplistic democratic slogans. As Professor Cohen points out, genuine reform must be as gradual as it is consensual. There can be no shortcuts to the transformations required to move a planned economy to a market system. Against the complexity of the problem, all crash programs will only jerk the society from one crisis to the next.
Yet, Professor Cohen fails fully to convey the essence of the concern underlying the radical democratic opposition. Behind the calls for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation is the belief that perestroika and glasnost remain efforts to reform, rather than to abandon socialism. The elimination of socialism -- in any form -- is more often than not the real thrust motivating the attacks on President Gorbachev. Fundamental to much of his opposition is the belief that it is no longer possible to reform Soviet socialism. Efforts to do so, it is feared, will only cover deeper social and political structural problems.
Most of those opposing Mr. Gorbachev concede his historic role. But they see him as a man who has played that role, a man who must step down for someone who can lead the country into the next phase of social and democratic transformation. As one Russian recently explained to me, despite his willingness to recognize and confront the failures of socialism, Mr. Gorbachev is not yet ready to give up the socialist cause. Heart and soul, he remains a true son of the Soviet system. His greatest nightmare, as she put it, is that his grandchildren will one day read that their grandfather was the man who destroyed the Soviet Union and with it the dream of the socialist state.
Mr. Gorbachev is arguably state socialism's last best chance. But large numbers of people in the Soviet Union are saying they no longer believe in the socialist project and that after some 70 years they are ready to leave the experiment behind. To overlook this is to slight the deeper political dynamic being played out in both the Soviet Union and its former satellites.
 
FRANK FISCHER
Professor of Political Science
Rutgers University
Newark, March 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Abboud Out as Chief At Houston's First City

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 27

 BODY:
A. Robert Abboud, the Chicago banker who arrived in Texas three years ago to lead a $1.5 billion bailout of a Houston bank, was ousted today as chairman and chief executive of the First City Bancorporation of Texas in the face of mounting losses and problem loans.
The bailout, which consisted of $970 million in funds from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and $500 million in private capital, began to stumble about a year ago after some foreign loans turned sour and three major borrowers, Circle K, Federated Department Stores and Drexel Burnham Lambert entered bankrutpcy proceedings. Although First City suffered from further deterioration in commercial real estate values in Texas, the bulk of its troubles were out of state.
 
A Second Setback
 The shake-up at First City represents the second time that Mr. Abboud, an aggressive manager, has been asked to leave the helm of a large bank and ends his personal quest to resurrect First City, once Houston's biggest bank. It also dashes his hopes that his successful stewardship of First City would vindicate his bumpy banking career. Mr. Abboud was dismissed in 1980 as chairman and chief executive of the First Chicago Corporation after board members criticized him for losing ground to a rival, Continental Illinois. 
 After Continental failed in 1984, Mr. Abboud maintained that he had prudently led the First National Bank of Chicago, the main subsidiary of First Chicago, and was unfairly forced out.
But at First City under Mr. Abboud, the bank's bad loans threaten to overwhelm it. The bank said today that it expected a first-quarter net loss of between $50 million and $75 million. That loss would come on top of $268.2 million in losses First City incurred in the last half of 1990. In the first quarter a year ago, First City managed to report a $90.1 million profit buoyed only by a pretax gain on the sale of its credit card operation.
 
Federal Review
 The expected loss apparently comes after a Federal regulatory examination of the bank late last year that found some new loan problems. Partly as a result, First City said it expected its nonperforming assets, mainly troubled loans and foreclosed real estate, to climb by between $75 million and $125 million in the first quarter. That would bring its total nonperforming assets to at least $568 million, or about 4.2 percent of assets, or as much as $618 million, or about 4.6 percent of assets.
Faced with the losses, First City also said it was casting about for $200 million in additional capital or may seek a merger or a buyout by a stronger institution. Among the banks that are weighing buying all or part of First City is the First Gibraltar Bank, the largest savings bank in Texas. The Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the investment banker that stitched together the 1988 bailout, has been hired to find the funds. At the end of 1990, First City's common equity capital, the clearest measure of its cushion to absorb losses, was $349 million, or a unhealthy 2.6 percent of assets. With the expected first-quarter loss, the number would shrink to between $274 million and $299 million.
 
Successor Is Named
 First City said its board, which met in a special meeting today, replaced the 61-year-old Mr. Abboud with C. Ivan Wilson, 63, a longtime First City banker in Corpus Christi, Tex. It was widely assumed by analysts that Mr. Wilson would be a caretaker chairman and chief executive while a search is conducted for a permanent replacement.
Mr. Abboud remains a First City board member.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, First City's shares closed at $4.875, down 12.5 cents.
Analysts said that Mr. Abboud's quest to reassert himself at First City in the image of the powerful, global banker that he aspired to be at First Chicago might have caused him to take on impractical risks for a regional bank that had traditionally been a Texas lender in energy, real estate and consumer loans.
Also, several experts suggested that in his passion to beat out other bidders for the failing bank three years ago, Mr. Abboud did not ask for enough F.D.I.C. money. His investor group got $970 million from the F.D.I.C.'s insurance fund; two other bidders each sought more than a $1 billion in Federal assistance.
That amount of backing, plus the complex structure of the bailout, left First City more vulnerable to sliding values in commercial real estate assets inherited from the old First City. Later bank bailouts in Texas were structured differently and better insulated investors from further losses on loans made by the failed institution.
Mr. Abboud also was too optimistic about the pace of the Texas economic recovery. With few opportunities for loan growth in the still-sluggish economy, Mr. Abboud approved the expansion of the bank's foreign lendings and joined groups of banks that made highly leveraged loans for corporate buyouts and restructurings. All along, he was under pressure to deliver steady growth in loans and profits for the investors who contributed $500 million to the bailout.
 
Too Big for His Bank?
 "First City is, after all, a medium-sized bank, and Abboud wanted to be a major player," said Paul M. Horvitz, professor of banking and finance at the University of Houston. "The losses for the most part were not from doing their knitting in Texas."
The largest blunder was a 1989 loan of $140 million to the Coca family of Spain, which was classified as nonperforming last summer, a year after the loan fees it produced were included in First City's then-healthy profits.
In recent weeks, as the bank's condition worsened and Mr. Abboud ordered 800 jobs pared from First City's work force of 6,400, senior managers also turned against him. They were led by Robert D. Richley, 47, who was recruited by Mr. Abboud as president and chief operating officer.
In today's management change, Mr. Richley retained those posts as well as his directors' seat.
 
Loss for Donaldson
 The messy end to the Abboud management of First City appears likely to cost both him and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The firm lent several million dollars to Mr. Abboud to buy First City stock, which is now valued at one-fourth the purchase price. The F.D.I.C. owned 18 percent of First City's shares in 1988 but sold the block to Donaldson, Lufkin for a profit.
Analysts said Donaldson, Lufkin also holds large amounts of the stock. Catherine Conboy, a spokeswoman at the firm, said today that officials at the firm were unavailable for comment.
In the years between his jobs at First Chicago and First City, Mr. Abboud wrote a book in which he tried to explain his lending philosophy and attempt to clear the record about his stormy departure at First Chicago.
He often cited his book -- "Money in the Bank: How Safe Is It?" -- in interviews upon arriving in Houston. The title of the first chapter is "We're Only Human" and is followed by another chapter he called "Learning the Hard Way."

LENGTH: 811 words

HEADLINE: Kansas City Journal;
Old Outpost of Slavery Joins Era of Black Mayor

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 27

 BODY:
Residents of this old frontier town, once the western outpost of pro-slavery forces, awoke today with a black Mayor-elect, their first in history. Family legend has it that the Texas shanty in which he grew up was once a slave cabin.
But the election of the Rev. Emanuel Cleaver on Tuesday reveals as much about his city as it does about the man himself, experts here say. And they say it reveals much about his supporters and how the campaign unfolded in a city that has one of the smallest percentages of voters who are black -- 26 percent -- among those that have elected black mayors. 
 Mr. Cleaver and his supporters in the nonpartisan election said today that they were already turning their attention to the city problems he will face when he takes office April 10, succeeding Mayor Richard Berkley.
Mr. Cleaver, a three-term City Councilman who has continued to serve full time as pastor of a United Methodist church, won with 53 percent of the votes cast. He defeated Bob Lewellen, a white City Councilman and businessman, who received 47 percent.
For most experts, the outcome was no surprise, although the only published opinion survey had shown Mr. Cleaver favored by twice as many respondents as Mr. Lewellen. As expected, a large bloc of voters who had said they were undecided swung into the Lewellen column.
The key to the outcome was the candidate himself, said Max Skidmore, a political science professor and dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of Missouri-Kansas City.
"Cleaver managed to suppress the racial element," said Dr. Skidmore. "While holding on to his black support in the predominantly black wards, he was able to attract white support in all areas of the city. His whole career has been spent building bridges between the races."
Just as important, Dr. Skidmore said, "I don't find the sense of racial antagonism here that you find in many other areas."
"It is true that Kansas City has one of the most racially segregated housing patterns," he said, describing one north-south thoroughfare, Troost Avenue, as a sort of Berlin Wall. "But we simply don't have the degree of racial tensions you find elsewhere."
"There is a strong mixture here of Southern and Midwestern roots," he continued. "In this case, I think, the Midwestern prevailed."
Luther Washington, Mr. Cleaver's campaign manager, agreed up to a point. But he said, "This could only happen because of the qualities of the black man who was running."
He added, "What it says about Kansas City is that we still have some blemishes, but we have progressed."
When the vote-counting was over, the 46-year-old Mayor-elect said: "This is not a Cleaver victory. This is a Kansas City victory."
The man who won, others noted, was a far cry from the the young man who arrived here from Texas in 1968 and soon came to be viewed as a radical advocate of civil rights causes. But during his three terms on the City Council, he establised a reputation as a moderate on racial issues who shared many of the goals of local business leaders. For the last four years, he has been Mayor Pro Tem, a sort of vice mayor.
That background served him in good stead in the election. It enabled him to win the support of prominent white business leaders, including James Nutter Sr., a mortgage banker and a skillful fund-raiser who became a campaign chairman.
Mr. Cleaver now inherits the task of trying to solve the city's problems with few powers beyond the force of his personality.
Kansas City's economy benefits from its central location and a concentration of agribusiness interests, and has proved largely resistant to recession. Its downtown is dotted with new office towers as a result of a building boom, but it also has a high vacancy rate. Its population, now about 448,160 people, had been declining but that turned around in the last decade.
The city's most intractable problem, as many business leaders see it, is a school system that is operating under a court-ordered desegregation plan but that has shown little success in regaining substantial numbers of whites who had fled.
As Mayor, Mr. Cleaver is limited by the city's history and charter in his power to deal with such problems. The school district has an independent board. And the city government itself has a mayor-city manager system that reflects efforts more than a half-century ago to curb Thomas Pendergast, the powerful political boss.
The system gives the Mayor one vote on the City Council and the right to name committee chairmen, but little else besides a "bully pulpit." The administration of city agencies is the responsibility of the city manager.
But, Dr. Skidmore noted, the system never prevented Pendergast from controlling public agencies, and he has little doubt that a forceful Mayor can find ways to make his presence felt today.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 698 words

HEADLINE: Surrealpolitik

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is executive editor of The National Interest.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, was here this week to assure the United States that Germany would abide by its financial obligations in the gulf war effort. Last fall, Germany belatedly increased its contribution in response to allied irritation with its military free-riding, and to outrage at the role of its industry in arming Saddam Hussein. Of the more than $11 billion Bonn pledged to the allied effort, the $5.5 billion directed to the U.S. will be paid by the end of this month.
Now that Chancellor Helmut Kohl has fulfilled this minimal commitment, the Administration should make it clear that in future conflicts the new world expects more of the new Germany in the new world order. 
 Pressure to identify German with American foreign policy may be the last thing Mr. Kohl wants. Since January, his popularity has plunged from 71 percent to 34 percent. The Chancellor, who underestimated the costs of unification, has been forced to raise taxes -- taxes that he claims are in part the result of Germany's war contribution. Now the opposition Social Democrats are portraying him as a dupe who is allowing the U.S. to make a profit by accepting promised contributions even though the war cost less than expected.
Mr. Kohl's credibility gap in Germany is his problem. Germany's credibility gap in the world is ours. The war is over, but the millennium has not arrived. A strong and responsible Germany, prepared to undertake military action with its allies in NATO and the Western European Union, is as important as ever, now that Iraq is inflamed by civil war, Yugoslavia is in crisis and the Soviets are cheating on the treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe.
To his credit, Mr. Kohl continues to stress the importance of German participation in NATO. Early in the gulf crisis, however, he did not contest the claim of the left that the West German Constitution prevented him from sending troops.
This claim is doubtful, to say the least. The German Constitution arguably permits the armed forces to participate in collective security actions. The Italians, whose postwar Constitution is far more restrictive, managed to send troops to fight against Iraq. Ironically, in calling for an amendment to permit what many good legal scholars believe is already permitted, Mr. Kohl is giving the Social Democrats a chance to have the Constitution rewritten in a way that will make it more restrictive.
The "political" excuses for German nonparticipation in the war are even less impressive. Some in Germany suggested that sending forces would have raised the ghosts of military adventurism. Nonsense. Nothing could have exorcised phantoms of the Third Reich better than a few German fighters hunting down Scud launchers, to protect Israel from attacks by missiles German business helped to build.
The real reason for Chancellor Kohl's policy has been Germany's fear of the world, not the world's fear of Germany. Polls showed that large majorities of Germans supported the allied effort but wanted Germany to stay out of it. Similar majorities chose Switzerland as the best model for the united Germany. Germany, however, can no more be Greater Switzerland than the U.S. can be Canada writ large. Rather than treating the unrealistic isolationism of today's Germans as a given, Mr. Kohl should have tried to shape opinion during the war by exercising leadership.
For examples of such decisiveness, he need only have looked to past leaders who were willing to risk unpopularity in promoting the interests of Germany and the West. Konrad Adenauer brought Germany into NATO against the wishes of many Germans. Helmut Schmidt sacrificed his prestige in the Social Democratic Party to his resistance of Soviet nuclear blackmail of Europe.
Mr. Kohl himself recently displayed statesmanship of a high order when he seized a passing chance to unite Germany within NATO. The spirit of Kohl present stands rebuked by the ghost of Kohl past. Europe's most important nation could use, if not an Iron Chancellor, at least a chancellor with iron in the soul. It would be unfortunate if an uncertain Germany should find its image in a chancellor of wax.

HEADLINE: Rise in Inflation Cited by I.L.O.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 28

 BODY:
Inflation was higher in 28 industrialized and developing countries in 1990 than it was the year before, according to a survey released today by the International Labor Organization, a Geneva-based agency.
It said that in 19 of these countries, the rate was higher for the second successive year and that 12 reported double- digit inflation. "Inflationary pressures are once again undermining economic stability in many countries," it added. 
 Based on consumer price indexes covering the year ending last December in 46 countries, the study showed a general trend of rising inflation. Only 17 countries reported a lower rate of inflation. They included Germany, France, Ireland, Finland and Canada.
Japan's inflation rate of 3.8 percent was the lowest in Asia, although it was higher than the previous year's 2.6 percent.
In the United States, which showed a higher rate for the second successive year, inflation rose from 4.6 percent, to 6.1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark But Rises in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar's rally faltered against the mark yesterday, but reached a seven-month high against the yen.
Gold edged up 80 cents an ounce, to $357.10, on the New York Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356 an ounce, up $1 from late Wednesday. 
 The dollar, which hit a 12-month high against the mark on Wednesday, slipped yesterday after news that an angry protest in Moscow did not result in violence. Traders interpreted the relatively calm event as a sign that neighboring Germany's economy might not be adversely affected by restlessness in the Soviet Union.
The yen, traders said, was weakened as Japanese banks bought dollars to replenish year-end reserves to hedge against possible losses in North American investments. Japan's fiscal year ends today.
 
Japan Bank Intervenes
 The dollar peaked in New York at 141.50 yen before settling at 141.23 yen, up sharply from late Wednesday's 139.56 yen. It was the highest intraday level since the dollar hit 142.45 yen on Sept. 6.
The rise came despite two interventions by the Bank of Japan in Tokyo trading earlier. The dollar closed at 139.95 yen in Tokyo, up 1.55 yen from Wednesday's close and its highest level there since Sept. 7. Later, in London, it rose to 141.15 yen.
Leading central banks this past month have tried unsuccessfully to stem the dollar's roughly 20 percent advance since the end of the Persian Gulf war.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7380, from $1.7405 late Wednesday. Sterling also lost ground in New York, closing at $1.7405, down from $1.7425 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.7038 German marks, down from 1.7070; 1.4543 Swiss francs, down from 1.4560; 5.7755 French francs, down from 5.7930; 1,268.00 Italian lire, down from 1,269.50, and 1.1579 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1593.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.7055 German marks, unchanged; 1.4550 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.7820 French francs, up from 5.7790; 1.9222 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,269.25 Italian lire, up from 1,268.75, and 1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1607.
Silver rose. In New York, it was up 3.5 cents an ounce, to $3.849, on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Postwar Goals Of Turkey's Chief

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C.

 BODY:
PRESIDENT Turgut Ozal of Turkey, a short, rotund man, is an electrical engineer by profession, who describes himself as "logical, rational." Just the eighth president of his country, he is the first who was not a military officer. Interviewed here at Duke University on his swing through Eastern educational institutions, after talks in Washington with President Bush, Mr. Ozal made clear his belief that Turkey, having contributed significantly to the war against Iraq, could play a significant role as a peace maker. And he made no bones of saying that he was seeking economic benefits for Turkey.
Turkey's support of the anti-Iraqi coalition involved substantial costs, which Mr. Ozal conceded were difficult to measure, since they included lost trade with Iraq and Kuwait, lost construction contracts, lost fees for oil from Iraq flowing through the Turkish pipeline and for various goods in transit, lost remittances from Turkish workers in Iraq and Kuwait and the suspension of repayment of Iraqi debts. 
 To be sure, no matter what Turkey had done, many of those costs would have been incurred anyhow. But Turkish sources, including Mr. Ozal's angry critics at home, put the country's losses at $9 billion or more. There is scant likelihood that Turkey will get anything like that sum in cash. Washington is talking about $2 billion to $3 billion.
The Bush Administration wants to do what it can to help the Turks, partly through the donations of other members of the coalition, including Germany, Japan, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. Prof. Bruce R. Kuniholm of Duke University said that in return for Ankara's military assistance, American officials had explored the possibility of supplying the Turks with a long list of military items, including tanks, planes, helicopters, missiles and missile destroyers.
Turkey, with the second-largest army in NATO (after the United States), is eager to modernize its forces, now more than ever after the demonstration of Western technological superiority over Iraq.
Mr. Ozal also wants civilian technology and foreign investment, and is hopeful of paying for it by enlarging Turkey's agricultural and textile exports to the West. As Mr. Kuniholm notes in a forthcoming article in Foreign Affairs, President Bush has pledged to review Turkey's textile quotas with a view toward increasing the country's access to the American textile and apparel market. And, most of all, Mr. Ozal wants to get Turkey into the European Community and seeks Mr. Bush's help in persuading the Europeans to let the Turks, their NATO partners, become economic partners as well.
But the Europeans, wary of the large numbers of Turkish workers who want jobs in the West, and of the low Turkish wages, are not eager to open their doors widely either to Turkish goods or Turkish workers, especially with new pressures coming from Eastern Europe. Turkey, already a nation of 57 million, including 10 million to 15 million Kurds, could become the most populous country in Europe by the end of the first quarter of the 21st century.
With its Muslim traditions, Turkey faces East as well as West. Mr. Ozal, fundamentally Western oriented, sees a tremendous opportunity for Turkey to be a bridge between the Middle East and the West and further the peace process. "Wars do not solve problems," he said. "Wars inflict new problems."
He remarked in Durham, "Iraq was stable; now it's unstable, and I don't know how it can be stabilized." He has said publicly that the United States should let the Iraqis decide who will control their government, but this week he said in an interview that the United States could not stand by and allow the Iraqi dictator to exterminate his opposition. Some officials in the Bush Administration expect Mr. Hussein to fall within a few weeks. The Administration, at this point, is determined to avoid assuming the political risks and the enormous economic burdens of trying to govern Iraq, and of organizing and financing its reconstruction.
As a contribution to the peace process, Mr. Ozal stressed the so-called Peace-Water Project, which would include countries from the Persian Gulf to the eastern Mediterranean, including Israel. The Israelis are very short of water, partly because, for domestic political reasons, they are using it so wastefully on cotton production.
High-ranking Turkish officials traveling with Mr. Ozal said they had been meeting regularly with Israeli leaders, sometimes in Ankara, sometimes in Tel Aviv. They said they saw grounds for hope that the Israelis could be brought into wider negotiations over land and water. On the other side, Mr. Ozal said, "As a result of siding with Saddam Hussein, the P.L.O has lost credibility and is not acceptable as a negotiator." He added, "The situation is more complex than anyone thinks."
And more costly, in economic terms, than anyone thinks. Just the American-estimated costs for the reconstruction of Iraq -- "a rubble heap," as a highly placed United States official put it yesterday -- have gone up from $100 billion initially to $250 billion.

HEADLINE: LOOKING OVERSEAS FOR SCHOOL EXAMS

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Reacting to concern about the link between education and the nation's economic competitiveness, a Congressional research group, began looking at examination systems in other countries today and their implications for possible national testing of American students.
"There is going to be some action on a national test this year, whether it's an extension of existing programs or something new," said Gordon M. Ambach, executive director of the Council for Chief State School Officers. Mr. Ambach was one of the participants discussing foreign exam systems at a conference conducted here by the Congressional research group, the Office of Technological Assessment. 
 But opposition to nationwide standardized tests for elementary and high school students remains strong. On Wednesday, two dozen education, civil rights and parents groups denounced the proposals, which have been endorsed by a Presidential advisory panel and a growing number of business leaders.
"Adding more testing is clearly not the way to improve education any more than taking the temperature of a patient more often will reduce his or her fever," said Monty Neill, associate director of the National Center for Fair and Open Testing, a nonprofit group in Boston.
 
'Simple, Stupid and Dangerous'
 Mr. Neill said his group was concerned that President Bush's desire to be the education President and a sense of educational crisis in the nation were encouraging Mr. Bush to do "something simple, stupid and dangerous like a national test."
Other opponents include the National Parent Teacher Association, the American Association of School Administrators, the National Education Association, the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Proposals for national testing have been pushed in recent months by politicians and business groups frustrated with what they term under-prepared workers produced by the American education system.
 
Need Seen for New Standards
 In January, an advisory group recommended to Mr. Bush the creation of a national examination for elementary and high school students.
Education Secretary Lamar Alexander, a member of the panel that recommended tests, said today that national testing was important because "the world has changed, and there are new higher standards for what American children need to know and need to be able to do to live and work in that world."
Also fueling the momentum for national tests are the six education goals agreed upon by the President and the nation's governors last year. Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who heads a panel responsible for issuing a report on the educational state of the nation next September, has expressed support for some kind of national testing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities a Bit Higher

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher yesterday in unusually active pre-holiday trading. Dealers and traders said there was also a fair amount of domestic and foreign retail buying, considering that most market participants had closed their books for the quarter and in Japan for their fiscal year as well.
Because today is Good Friday, there will be no markets in corporate or tax-exempt debt issues. The Chicago Treasury bond futures market will also be closed. Although the Treasury, Federal Reserve and many banks will be open, the New York Government securities dealer community will not operate. 
 "Any business in Treasury paper on Friday will be like watching paint dry," said Mark A. McCluskey, chief Treasury securities trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. "Most markets in Europe will also be closed for the Easter Monday holiday as well."
One reason for the positive mood in the Treasury market was the good reception accorded the auctions of $20 billion of two- and five-year notes this week. Another reason was the usual "window dressing" of portfolios with Treasury bills and notes that many investment managers undertake at the end of a quarter.
 
Amount of Business Surprising
 The amount of business was somewhat surprising because many bond traders are reluctant to assume sizable positions unless they can hedge, or lay off, part or all of their exposure in the futures market.
"But it's also true that the front end of the Treasury market looks very cheap to many," Mr. McCluskey said. "That's one reason why this week's auctions of the two- and five-year notes went so well."
The new 7 1/8 percent notes of 1993 were offered late in the day at 100 5/ 32, up 1/32, for a yield of 7.04 percent. At Tuesday's auction, the average yield on the two-year notes was 7.15 percent. The new 7.75 percent notes rose 2/32, to 100 2/32, for a yield of 7.73 percent. This compared with an average yield of 7.81 percent produced at Wednesday's auction of the five-year notes. Both Treasury maturities are now auctioned each month.
 
Claims for Unemployment
 Although the Government reported that the initial claims for unemployment insurance in the week ended March 16 was 510,000, it was somewhat below market expectations and had no effect on the fixed-income market, Mr. McCluskey said. Nor did the increases in personal income and consumption for February reported yesterday.
Among the shortest maturities, discount rates on Treasury bills were little changed on the day. The 90-day bills slipped two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.76 perent; six-month bills dipped a basis point, at 5.79 percent, and the one-year bills lost three basis points, at 5.89 percent.
The Treasury sold $13.5 billion of 15-day cash management bills at an average discount rate of 6.05 percent, and also announced that it would hold its regular auction of one-year bills on Thursday. The size of the auction is $10.75 billion.
Among the longer maturities, the Treasury's 7.75 percent notes of 2001 were unchanged in price and yield at 97 31/32 and 8.05 percent, respectively. The benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue due February 2021, rose 3/32, to 95 31/32, as its yield slipped to 8.23 percent, from 8.24 percent the day before.
For its part, the Federal Reserve added $1.5 billion of reserves to the banking system to accommodate the usual holiday demand for cash. The funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans was at 6 1/8 percent when the Fed intervened. The funds then traded down to close at 6 percent, the Fed's perceived target level for this bedrock cost of credit.

HEADLINE: SUNY Trustees Vote New Policy On Tuition Rise

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 28

 BODY:
The 400,000 students at the State University of New York would face automatic increases in annual tuition under a broad new tuition policy adopted today by the system's Board of Trustees.
The policy, which must be acted on by the State Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, would for the first time in the university's 43-year history link tuition rates to a fixed percentage of the system's operating costs. 
 While those increases might eventually be tied to the inflation rate or some other standard figure, they could at first be much larger: student tuition now pays for about 20 percent of the system's costs, but under the policy adopted today it would be allowed to account for as much as one-third.
The board's vote comes against a backdrop of tremendous pressure on SUNY, the largest university system in the nation, and public universities in many other states to cut costs and raise tuition to help solve massive state budget problems.
At the university in particular, administrators are facing state aid cuts of up to 10 percent of the system's $1.5 billion budget in the coming fiscal year, and their complaints of hardship have not always fallen on sympathetic ears here.
A draft of a new audit by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, for instance, concludes that faculty salaries and other expenses at the state university are significantly higher than at comparable public universities and should be reduced, and it recommends that four of the system's 64 campuses be closed to save money. University officials dispute the findings.
Three months ago the Legislature approved raising annual university tuition by $300, to $1,650, and it is now debating a proposal by Governor Cuomo to increase it by another $500, which if approved would mean that the university's tuition will have risen more than 50 percent in the course of a year.
The University of California system recently voted to raise its tuition rates by 40 percent from $1,850 to about $2,500. The system has nine campuses.
Although any tuition increase is bound to be unpopular, the new policy in New York seemed aimed in part at heading off the bitter student protests and legislative convulsions that inevitably follow any attempts to raise tuition under the present system, in which lawmakers each year have either granted large block increases or kept rates unchanged.
Still, while the board's plan would have the apparent benefit of letting lawmakers off the hook for future tuition increases, its fate is unclear because those same officials may be reluctant to cede the important measure of authority they now have over the system in controlling tuition rates.
The chairman of the state Assembly's Higher Education Committee, Edward C. Sullivan, Democrat from Manhattan, said he was willing to consider a system in which increases were automatically indexed to a specific figure such as the inflation rate, but not one that pegged tuition to rates to whatever size of budget university officials wanted to develop.
The university's chancellor, D. Bruce Johnstone, said after the board meeting here that "moderate, regular" tuition increases would be far preferable to the erratic system now in place. He said the state's budget problems, combined with a seven-year freeze on university tuition before this year, had now "led to an increase being proposed that is much greater than I'd ever like to see happen again."
