HEADLINE: I.B.M. Taking Big Charge and Cutting Jobs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
I.B.M. announced yesterday that it was taking a $2.3 billion charge, which will probably result in a large quarterly loss, to pay for the retirement benefits of current employees. The company also said it will shrink its worldwide work force by 14,000 employees this year.
The International Business Machines Corporation became the first of the nation's leading corporations to comply with a new accounting rule that will require companies to set aside money annually for each employee's eventual retirement benefits, said Diana J. Scott, the project manager for the rule at the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a rule-setting body for the accounting profession. Many other big American companies are also likely to make large provisions, she said. 
 The money set aside -- $2.6 billion -- will result in tax benefits, but they will be only $300 million because of the way I.B.M. handles retirement benefits, said Robert Ripp, the company's treasurer. As a result, the one-time after-tax charge against I.B.M.'s first-quarter earnings will be $2.3 billion.
I.B.M. told analysts last week, who had expected profits of about $1 billion in 1991's first quarter, that its earnings would be as little as half that level, for an indicated quarterly profit of $500 million to $600 million, or 90 cents to $1 a share, from operations. John B. Jones Jr., an analyst at Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage, said that with the provision for retirement benefits, the company could have a loss of $1.7 billion.
I.B.M. earned $6.02 billion on sales of $69.02 billion last year.
After the morning announcement of the set-aside and job cuts, I.B.M.'s shares rose $1 yesterday, to $113.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The nation's biggest computer maker did not take a separate charge for the planned shrinkage of its work force, which amounts to 3.8 percent of the 373,000 people employed at the end of last year. The move coincides with an undisclosed profit on the sale of the company's office equipment division and is intended to produce large savings from reduced labor expenses, said Peter W. Thonis, a company spokesman. That deal closed yesterday, allowing the company to shed the division's 4,000 employees.
No layoffs are planned, Mr. Thonis said, but I.B.M. will try to eliminate 10,000 positions through attrition and by offering early retirement and voluntary resignation incentives. The company's employment peaked at 406,000 in 1986.
 
Focus on Staff Jobs
Incentives will include two weeks' pay for each year of employment at the company or the addition of extra years to an employee's service record for pension purposes. Mr. Thonis said staff positions, primarily in the United States and Europe, are the main targets; factory positions are less likely to be affected.
I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., is among the likely targets for the voluntary resignation and early retirement programs, he added.
Mr. Thonis said the work force reduction was part of a long-term plan to shrink the company and was unrelated to last week's comments on earnings.
But Howard M. Anderson, president of the Yankee Group, a consulting firm in Boston, said that the need to shrink the company was closely linked to its faltering results.
Big companies are forcing divisions to share a few, very large mainframe computers, he said, and many companies are running their computer programs on small, less expensive desktop computers instead of investing in a mainframe computer and many terminals.
 
I.B.M.'s Strength
 I.B.M. is far stronger in the mainframe market than in the desktop market. "The economy is responsible for half of their problems, their product mix is responsible for the other half," Mr. Anderson said.
But despite its current troubles, I.B.M. remains wealthy enough to take a one-time accounting charge that many large manufacturers have resisted.
Most companies now pay for retirement benefits as retirees incur them. A few, including I.B.M., have been estimating the benefits that each employee will use and setting aside enough money to pay for those benefits when the employee retires.
Now I.B.M. will set aside part of the money for these benefits each year that an employee works at the company. The $2.6 billion provision is the amount that I.B.M. would have set aside annually since each current employee joined the company.
The new accounting rule was passed by accounting profession panel in December and does not become mandatory until 1993. Mr. Ripp said that the company decided to make an immediate provision because each year of delay would enlarge the amount of money needed.
Miss Scott of the accounting standards board said the rule was needed to help users of company reports, like individual investors and pension fund managers, determine the extent of a company's obligations.

HEADLINE: Journalists Meet And See Gloom On Job Security

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
With many news organizations in the economic doldrums and work force reductions becoming commonplace, there is an undercurrent of worry at the annual convention of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists that began in New York yesterday.
"It's a horrible time to be looking for a job," Gilbert Bailon, metropolitan editor of The Dallas Morning News, told his fellow Hispanic journalists at a session yesterday that focused on the effects of hard times. 
 Despite the perceived paucity of jobs, or perhaps because of it, the usual networking between journalists and recruiters at the Marriott Marquis Hotel at Broadway and 45th Street was under way with special fervor as the association's members made connections that they hoped would lead to new or better jobs.
Though many of the nation's largest news organizations have sent representatives to the convention to scout for likely prospects, there was considerable skepticism that many had jobs to offer.
 
Dismissals a Concern
 And there was widespread concern that a disproportionate number of minority journalists might be dismissed by news organizations if the advertising climate does not improve.
While many newspapers and broadcast stations have aggressively hired minority journalists in recent years to improve newsroom diversity, those most recently hired are often the first to be dismissed because of union restrictions that the least senior employees be the first laid off.
The association, which was formed in 1984, includes Hispanic journalists who work for English-language and Spanish-language publications and broadcast stations.
Jose McMurray, executive director of the association, estimates that more than 3,000 Hispanic people work as journalists in the United States. As the number has increased over the years, the association's meetings have broadened from their original focus of securing more newsroom diversity.
Mr. McMurray said that this year's convention was the first time that management training was offered as part of the program, which he said reflected the advancement and ambition of many of the association's members.
But signs of the soft advertising market were also evident. This year, 81 companies have taken booths at the convention job fair, compared with 92 last year. And overall attendance thus far is down about 20 percent from last year, in part because some companies were not so willing to pay for their Hispanic employees to attend.
The Latino Reporter, the convention newspaper published by Hispanic journalism students, reported in its first issue that the association itself may face budget and staff cutbacks because declining profits at news organizations have meant fewer donations and corporate sponsorships. The companies and their foundations provide much of the financing for the association, as well as for similar associations of black, Asian and Indian journalists.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Bloomberg Is Starting Financial News Service

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Michael Bloomberg is moving into the financial news business. The audacious former Salomon Brothers trader, whose computer terminals deliver financial data and analysis to a loyal following of securities traders, will be in direct competition with such giants as Reuters Inc., Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Inc.
"Our mission is to provide everything that issuers of securities, investors and intermediaries need around the globe," Mr. Bloomberg said. "That includes news." 
 Some of the news reports that Mr. Bloomberg currently transmits to his customers come from numerous news agencies, including Dow Jones and The Associated Press, as well as from specialty market and economic research agencies like Moody's Corporate Credit Report.
 
Own Corps of Reporters
 Now, however, Mr. Bloomberg is trying to go beyond transmitting other people's news. He is developing his own corps of reporters to supply the news that might move markets and the background information to help traders guess what might happen next.
Rivals say he may be making an expensive tactical error.
"No one can provide absolute coverage, so there is always a nugget someone new can pick up," said Richard Levine, vice president and editorial director of Dow Jones Information Services. "But that doesn't mean you can do it profitably, because it's people-intensive and you need expensive communications."
Comparisons with other companies that provide financial news electronically can be misleading because many of their reporters are involved in gathering other news as well. But the Bloomberg Business News service is clearly going up against several hefty competitors.
 
200,000 Reuters Customers
 Reuters, the world's largest provider of financial information, with more than 200,000 customers, has 1,300 journalists in 116 bureaus around the world, including photographers and cameramen for its video news group.
Knight-Ridder Financial News has about 200 reporters in 19 bureaus and is especially strong in its coverage of commodities markets. Its business news service also draws on the work of 4,400 reporters at newspapers owned by the Knight-Ridder chain.
Dow Jones's basic business news service, known as the "broad tape," has a staff of 50 in the United States. About 50 more reporters contribute to specialty services like the Capital Markets Report.
The Dow Jones news services also draw on more than 500 domestic reporters for The Wall Street Journal and hundreds more overseas who are employees of foreign editions of the paper or Dow Jones's joint venture with The Associated Press. Dow Jones distributes its news services through its subsidiary, Telerate Inc., and several other data vendors, including Bloomberg. But the company said it would stop using Bloomberg by September, now that the upstart vendor was becoming a news competitor.
Numerous smaller companies make a living in niches in the financial news-gathering business, including Oil Buyers Guide, a Princeton, N.J., company recently acquired by Bloomberg. But the hazards of trying to provide broad coverage were highlighted a little more than a year ago when McGraw-Hill Inc. shut a news service set up at its Standard & Poor's subsidiary to compete with Dow Jones in supplying financial news to brokerage houses.
 
Multimillion-Dollar Investment
 Bloomberg L.P., which is privately owned and backed by Merrill Lynch & Company, which holds a 30 percent stake, has already invested several million dollars in developing its own news service. It has hired more than 50 reporters and has opened news bureaus in New York, Washington, London, Tokyo, Toronto and Princeton, N.J.
Partly to enhance Bloomberg's reputation as a supplier of news, the company has furnished terminals at discount rates to a handful of news organizations, including The New York Times and The Associated Press.
Bloomberg currently charges its customers a basic rate of about $1,000 a month for its terminals.
Interviews with Bloomberg users -- all of them lavish in their praise -- turn up little evidence that news coverage is a large selling point for Bloomberg's terminals. From big banks with scores of terminals to small brokers with one or two, Bloomberg's big attraction remains its core business of supplying prompt, accurate data on securities prices and sophisticated programs for analyzing trends and relationships between different securities.
"If they wanted us to pay for the news service, I would give it some serious thought, but my initial reaction would be 'no,' " said David Poitras, head of bond trading at Wayne Hummer & Company in Chicago.
 
Bloomberg's Only Regret
 Such talk does not faze the 49-year-old Mr. Bloomberg, who said his only regret was not starting his own news service a year earlier.
"Every month has produced a new income and revenue record and that hasn't stopped since we added news, so I have to believe its helping to sell our terminals," said Mr. Bloomberg, who would not disclose specific financial information.
He said nearly 12,000 terminals had been sold and new ones were being added at a rate of about 400 a month.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Bloomberg, right, the founder and chief executive of Bloomberg L.P., with Matthew Winkler, the head of the Bloomberg Business News service, at the company's Park Avenue headquarters. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Shows A 0.6% Climb in February

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Consumer spending, depressed for months, rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.
The rise in consumer spending was the biggest since an eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in September, but economists were unimpressed. They said the gain was primarily a reaction to the severe six-tenths of 1 percent spending drop in January. 
 The economists noted that Americans' income growth remained depressed last month, posting a tiny two-tenths of 1 percent gain after having fallen four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Disposable income -- after-tax income after accounting for inflation -- looked even more lackluster, rising by just one-tenth of 1 percent in February. It had fallen by nine-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Analysts attributed the weak income growth to the rising level of unemployment, which hit a four-year high of 6.5 percent in February. They predicted that it would climb to 6.7 percent or higher in March based on the large increase in unemployment claims so far this month.
The Bush Administration has been predicting that the recession, which pushed overall economic growth down by 1.6 percent in the October-December quarter, will end by midyear. But economists said for the turnaround to occur, the weekly level of unemployment claims will have to start shrinking rather than expanding.
 
Claims for Unemployment
 The Labor Department reported today, however, that the number of new claims for unemployment benefits remained above the half-million mark for a second consecutive week in March, something that had not happened in more than eight years.
The department said 510,000 people filed initial claims for state unemployment insurance in the week ending March 16, after 519,000 claims filed in the previous week.
While the number of new claims can be erratic from week to week, analysts said the high levels suggested that the recession was continuing in March despite other, more favorable reports showing a big jump in consumer confidence and signs of life in the housing industry.
"There is a recovery out there in the not-too-distant future, but it is not in the immediate future," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch in New York. "We still have a few more months of lousy economic numbers to go through."
Unemployment claims are now at the highest level since January and February 1983, a period when the country was just beginning to pull out of the steep 1981-82 recession. Claims hit a weekly high of 676,000 during that downturn, which saw unemployment climb to a post-Depression record of 10.8 percent.
Economists said they believed the unemployment rate in this downturn would not go higher than 7 percent, but they also said a variety of factors would dampen the ensuing recovery, making it much less robust than the typical rebound.
"The critical question now is not whether we will have a recovery, but how robust it will be," said Samuel Kahan, an economist with Fuji Securities in Chicago. "The weak income growth, high consumer debt levels and a lack of pent-up demand will make economic activity relatively anemic."
He said that gross national product growth could well rise in the April-June quarter, as the Administration is forecasting, but he said that economic growth is likely to average only 1 to 2 percent for the rest of the year, far below the 6 percent average that is typical in the first nine months of a new expansion.

HEADLINE: Dynamics Gets Korea Jet Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, March 28

 BODY:
In a surprising reversal of one of the United States' biggest arms deals, the South Korean Government said today that it was dropping the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from a $5 billion program to build fighter planes for its air force, and would award the contract instead to the General Dynamics Corporation, the maker of the F-16.
The sudden change came after months of disputes between South Korea and McDonnell Douglas over costs for the project, which Korean officials said had skyrocketed after they chose McDonnell's F/A-18 fighter more than a year ago. But military analysts here said they also thought the war in the Persian Gulf had had a big effect on the decision, convincing South Korea's Defense Ministry that the less expensive F-16 could match the best Soviet-made equipment flown by North Korea.
 
Price a Big Factor
 The higher price was perhaps the biggest factor in the Koreans' switch to the F-16, said Howard C. Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc., in New York. The price for the F-16 was listed at $18.4 million a plane, compared with $30.8 million for the F/ A-18, in the Defense Department's 1991 budget, although those prices differ from those paid by the Koreans. 
 The decision is a blow to McDonnell Douglas, which has already said it will lay off thousands of workers because of losses on a new commercial jet project and Pentagon budget cuts. It is a big victory for General Dynamics, which in 1989 was awarded the prime contract for one of the most controversial weapons-and-technology sales of recent times -- Japan's FSX fighter, which is also based on the F-16. [Page D4.]
McDonnell's shares fell by $1.125 today, to $37.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. General Dynamics' shares rose by 75 cents, to $33.50, on the Big Board. Both companies are based in St. Louis.
The fate of the Korean fighter program has been closely followed here, especially at a time when South Koreans say they are more confused than ever about the intentions of Kim Il Sung, the aging and increasingly isolated North Korean leader. Seoul is only a few minutes' flight from the demilitarized zone that separates North and South. The type of aircraft chosen to defend the capital is viewed as especially critical.
In announcing the decision tonight, after briefing members of South Korea's Cabinet, the country's Defense Minister, Lee Jong Koo, gave few details about the country's decision. But he suggested that the chief motivation was economic, contending that the price of the McDonnell Douglas project had risen to more than $6.2 billion last year. South Korean news reports, citing military officials, said the entire new project would cost roughly $5.2 billion.
Mr. Lee said the deal with General Dynamics would involve a "significant transfer of technology," something that South Korean industry had insisted upon as it begins to set its sights on the aerospace business. But the details were kept vague.
 
Provisions of Old Pact
 Under the provisions of the old contract with McDonnell Douglas, the company was supposed to provide 12 F/A-18's, built in the United States, to South Korea. An additional 36 were to be built in South Korea out of kits, largely from parts imported from the United States. The remaining 72 planes were to be built in South Korea under McDonnell's guidance, by the Samsung Group, one of Korea's biggest electronics conglomerates. Korean officials said the same mix would be used with the General Dynamics F-16.
It is unclear whether the new deal with General Dynamics will be similarly structured. But in recent months Samsung officials have begun to show some nervousness about the project, chiefly because Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the giant Japanese company that is heading up the FSX project, has complained that the work yields little profit and enormous political headaches.
The troubles with the McDonnell Douglas deal, South Korean officials have said in recent days, began at around the same time. Soon after the contract was awarded in 1989 the program was estimated to cost about $4.2 billion. But the Korean Defense Ministry added new features to the plane, and the original estimates were based on estimates of inflation that turned out to be incorrect.
In addition, the cost of "localizing" production in South Korea, rather than buying the planes off the shelf, sent the price far higher.
By the end of last year the Defense Ministry began a full reassessment of the program. Once the air war over Iraq and Kuwait broke out in January, Korean officials scrambled to assess the performance of the planes. "The conclusion, I think, was that the F-18 may be more capable against the most advanced North Korean planes, like the MIG-29's," a Western military analyst here said. "But I think they decided either plane could do the job."
McDonnell Douglas's agreement with Korea was not a final contract. A spokesman for McDonnell Douglas, James Reed, called the Government's decision "greatly disappointing" but he added, "While this is a setback, firm U.S. Government approval for current and advanced versions of the F/A-18 insures a bright future for the Hornet well into the 21st century."
 
F-16 a Gulf War Star
 The F-16 Falcon proved its worth as an effective tank killer during the Persian Gulf war, flying night missions to seek out Iraqi formations and discriminating among real tanks, damaged tanks and decoys. Its success helped allied forces to dramatically increase the rate of tank destruction in the days leading up to the Feb. 23 ground offensive.
The carrier-based F/A-18 Hornet, more limited in range and payload than the F-16, was largely relegated to flying combat air patrols to protect the American naval presence.
Moreover, there are considerable economies in operating the F-16. Versions of the same plane are stationed in South Korea by the United States military forces. South Korean pilots are already trained in how to fly the F-16, and military officials said its adoption would make it easier for the two allies to share spare parts.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
IRAQ, HITTING HARD, REPORTS BIG GAINS AGAINST THE KURDS

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 28

 BODY:
Iraqi troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein began a major attack today on Kurdish rebels who have occupied a vital oil city in northern Iraq for about a week, diplomats in Cairo said.
Late tonight, the official Iraqi press said Government forces had captured the city, Kirkuk, the most important site in Kurdish hands. Kurdish rebels would not confirm that Kirkuk had fallen, but the Baghdad television showed what it said was footage of an Iraqi official touring the city. 
 Earlier in the day, the Kurdish rebels said they were rushing arms to the city to confront an assault by as many as 150,000 Iraqi soldiers.
 
Food Shortages
 They also said food shortages had become a threat to their revolt, and they appealed to the West and the United Nations to send aid to the region and to let them to use a half-dozen captured airplanes and helicopters to stiffen their resistance against the Iraqis.
As the Iraqis concentrated their firepower on the Kurdish revolt in the north, pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims who have risen up in the south said they had retaken a holy city, Karbala, after losing control of it a week ago to Iraqi loyalists. But the Shiites said Iraqi helicopters were circling and dropping leaflets warning of an attack.
[In Teheran, the spiritual leader of a major Iraqi Shiite opposition group said that Iraqi forces had retaken virtually all the towns in southern Iraq and that Iraqi rebels were now fighting in rural areas. Page A6.]
Karbala has been the focus of intense fighting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, and the Shiite rebellion seemed all but put down more than a week ago, when Iraqi Army troops retook the center and a dozen other southern cities. Even if the Shiites had managed to rise up again in the city, officials in Iran, the United States and Arab countries say they are not strong enough to hold on without outside help.
The dual rebellions in Iraq have strained Mr. Hussein's Government nearly to the breaking point since his army was swept out of Kuwait by allied forces at the end of February. There were expectations that the rebel groups might hold their own against Baghdad's battered military, either overthrowing Mr. Hussein or leaving him so politically weak that his own Sunni Muslim loyalists would chase him from power.
But on Tuesday, the Bush Administration said it had decided to stay out of the rebellions because neither group was strong enough to rule Iraq, and if they succeeded in their regions, the country would be fractured. With both revolts appearing quickly to fizzle, the decision has led to political problems for President Bush at home and to questions among some Arabs about the direction of American policy.
 
Kurds Had Made Gains
 In the last week, Iraqi, Arab and Western officials say, the rebellion in the south all but collapsed, and Iraqi refugees fleeing into allied-occupied parts of the country spoke of Iraqi soldiers sweeping into the southern cities and exacting harsh retribution.
The rebellion in the north has been equally ferocious as Kurds battling to liberate their ancestral homeland moved swiftly to gain control of cities in the mountainous region. On Tuesday, an exiled Iraqi Kurdish leader rode triumphantly into Zakho, a Kurdish border city in Iraq, and spoke of setting up a provisional government.
But today, that leader, Jalal Talabani, pleaded with the West to sustain his uprising. "The food situation is very serious," he said. "We will face starvation if we don't receive food in one month."
Mr. Talabani said he sent messages to the allies asking that they let food into the Kurdish region from Turkey and Iran. Supplies had been embargoed as part of the international pressure on Mr. Hussein, but in the face of a United Nations report describing the country's state as near-apocalyptic, the Security Council decided last week to allow essential supplies into Iraq. The Kurds now say Iraqi troops are blocking the supplies from reaching areas where rebellion is under way.
 
Claims by the Iraqis
 Late today, the official Iraqi press agency said the Baghdad television had shown film of Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of Mr. Hussein's ruling Revolution Command Council, touring Kirkuk. A rebel in Damascus was quoted by Reuters as saying the Kurdish rebels might have abandoned Kirkuk "to avoid more killing of civilians."
"They might leave for strategic places overlooking the city," he said. "The city itself is not of strategic importance."
In Damascus, the National Kurdistan Union said Iraqi troops were preparing to attack Kirkuk by shelling it with long-range artillery and firing on it from helicopter gunships. The union also asserted that Iraq was preparing to bomb the city with fixed-wing airplanes.
Iraq has been denied the use of fixed-wing airplanes under the allied-imposed terms for a cease-fire in the gulf war. If confirmed, the development could increase pressure on Washington to help the rebels, who have appealed to Washington to aid them by restricting Mr. Hussein's freedom to use his armed forces against the uprisings.
For now, that appeal has been turned down, partly to avoid the "Lebanization" of Iraq, partly to keep from embroiling American soldiers in the Iraqi upheavals, and partly out of a wish to abide by international agreements, which gave the allies a mandate to chase Mr. Hussein from Kuwait but did not state that rebels should be armed and organized to drive him from power.
 
'An Internal Matter'
 This view, which has taken hold within the Bush Administration, was echoed today by Prince Khalid Bin Sultan, commander in chief of the Saudi Army. He said the rebellion against Mr. Hussein was "an internal matter" and the business of the Iraqi people, not of the coalition.
These statements, Arab diplomats here say, reflect a fear in Washington and Riyadh that a splintered Iraq could leave pro-Iranian Shiite rebels dominant in the south, giving Iran a major power base on the Iraqi and Kuwaiti borders, and independence-minded Kurds dominant in the north, encouraging other Kurds to rebel against Iran and Turkey.
The Arab diplomats here said that Washington and Riyadh were betting that the severe economic hardships that Iraq now faces would be enough to provoke a coup against President Hussein by the end of the year by army generals. The generals may be more capable of keeping Iraq independent while establishing better ties with its gulf neighbors.

Companies
South Korea dropped McDonnell Douglas from a $5 billion program to build fighter planes for its air force and will award the contract to General Dynamics. [D1.] General Dynamics stands to get $2 billion in added revenue through 1999; analysts say McDonnell may not suffer severe damage. [D4.]

The demand for new stamps prompted the United States to have Canadian company print at least two stamps. [A10.]
 
Markets

Treasury securities moved slightly higher in unusually active pre-holiday trading. Traders were apparently encourged by the note auctions earlier in the week. [D12.]

Grain and soybean futures edged higher. A Government crop report issued after the market closed showed that farmers intended to plant less than traders expected. [D13.]

Mutual fund investors turned away from conservative funds like those with Government securities and toward riskier investments like stock funds specializing in growth companies and high-yield bond funds. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: UTAH POLYGAMISTS ALLOWED TO ADOPT

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, March 28

 BODY:
The Utah Supreme Court has tacitly acknowledged the practice of polygamy as an alternative way of life, entitled to at least some legal protection.
While the Court affirmed the Utah Constitution's ban on polygamy, it ruled Tuesday that a family could not be automatically prohibited from adopting children simply because it is openly polygamist. 
 Justice Christine Durham, writing the 3-to-2 decision, said it was not the role of trial courts to dismiss "without consideration, for example, the adoption petitions of all convicted felons, all persons engaging in fornication or adultery, or other persons engaged in other illegal activities."
Polygamy was widely practiced in Utah from 1847, when Mormon pioneers entered the Salt Lake Valley. Congress sought to halt the practice by imposing political and economic sanctions on the Utah Territory, and in 1890, to gain statehood, the Mormon Church agreed to ban polygamy. Nevertheless, tens of thousands of fundamentalist Mormons in Utah, Arizona, Nevada and California continue the practice.
 
Children of Third Wife
 The ruling was a victory for Vaughn Fischer and his two wives, who are seeking to adopt the six children of Brenda Johanson Thornton. She married Mr. Fischer in 1987, becoming his third wife, but died two months later.
Shortly before she died, Mrs. Thornton signed over custody of her children to Mr. Fischer, with their father's consent. But Mrs. Thornton's father and two sisters, Pat and Janet Johanson, are also seeking to adopt the children and went to court to challenge the right of a polygamous family to adopt.
The Johanson sisters were once active fundamentalists but now say polygamy is immoral and essentially sexually abusive. They also said Mrs. Thornton was coerced by fundamentalist leaders into marrying Mr. Fischer.
A lower court sided with the Johansons, ruling that "the practice of polygamy constitutes immoral conduct," and that it would not be "in the best interests of the children to be raised in such an atmosphere."
The Fischers appealed to the state Supreme Court, which ruled that they could proceed with an adoption hearing.
 
Rights of 'Normal Citizens'
 Sharane Fischer, one of Mr. Fischer's wives, said the decision is "one more step forward in obtaining rights that normal citizens have, that every citizen should have," adding, "We feel we should have the right to adopt our own children."
Mr. Fischer called the court decision the fulfillment of God's will. "Of course we believe this is in the Lord's hands, but this very well could be the beginning of things being righted," he said.
The decision does not award adoption to the Fischers but sends the case back to district court, where the Fischers' overall qualifications as parents will be put on trial.
A state social worker visited the family's home in 1987 after the adoption application was filed and found the Fischers "highly qualified" to adopt the children.
Tim Anderson, a lawyer for the Johansons, said: "Obviously the effects of polygamy relative to the adoption of children, and the state allowing the inappropriate placement of children into that environment, will be addressed at that time. Polygamy in Utah will be put on trial."
 
Civil Rights Issue?
 But polygamy is not the issue, said David Nuffer, a lawyer for the Fischers. "It's a decision that speaks of freedom," he said. "It means people who practice plural marriage still have civil rights."
While the case proceeds, the children, who are age 8 to 21 years, will continue to live with the Fischers in the tiny town of Hildale in south Utah, as they have done since their mother died.
"The children are happy about the decision," Sharane Fischer said. "The children have been with us all the time, so it has been life as usual."

HEADLINE: Newark's Unsung Delights

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
It happens every time. You let people know that there is a sprawling, historic, undiscovered city only half an hour from midtown Manhattan. You explain that they'll be able to explore celebrated inexpensive restaurants, neighborhood exotica, a world-class museum and engage in a bit of sightseeing.
You find that there is considerable interest. Enthusiasm, certainly. In fact, people are eager to visit, until they learn the name of this well-kept secret: Newark. 
 Yes, Newark. Improbably, nearly a quarter of a century after the 1967 disturbances established the city's name as the ensign of urban malaise, its reputation is still intimidating to the unenlightened. Of course, the culinary and cultural highlights of Newark have long been part of the fixed universe of those who live in, or near, the city. But for many others, the very idea of an excursion in Newark -- a visit to sample its sights, its cuisine and its neighborhoods -- summons up images of a riot-torn wasteland aglow with the phosphorescence of decay.
Those in possession of this idee fixe are not only New Yorkers but also many New Jersey suburbanites, to whom the very sight of Newark's spires on the horizon is a harbinger of unease.
Certainly the seekers of urban blight can still find plenty of it in the ghostly relics of the Newark that used to be. But visitors who are anticipating a nightmarish keep-the-car-doors-locked excursion will be surprised. They will find, instead, a bustling, regenerating, multi-cultural city that has managed to hold on to a large part of its spirit and identity.
It is a city that welcomes discovery. The political renaissance of Newark that accelerated with the election of Mayor Sharpe James in 1986 has been followed by a continuing economic turnaround, which has, in turn, led to a new master plan for downtown development from the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts.
 The faint-hearted might best benefit from a program of gradual confidence-building exposures to the city, to develop tolerance -- and ultimately, affection -- in easy stages. Perhaps the simplest introduction to Newark is a journey to the Ironbound section, the city's flourishing Portuguese neighborhood that is one of the wonders of the metropolitan world.
Visitors don't need a car to get there: it's only a few blocks from Pennsylvania Station in Newark, which can be reached by PATH train or by Amtrak from Manhattan, or -- for New Jersey residents -- by New Jersey Transit buses, trains and also Newark's own subway-trolley system.
From Manhattan, the trip generally takes 30 to 50 minutes. Once you've arrived at Penn Station in Newark, it's worth navigating this Art Deco monument to transportation. It was opened in 1935, and designed by the architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White, and is connected on weekdays to Gateway Center, the multi-building complex that is a cornerstone of Newark's downtown revival. An escalator leads to the walkway to the Gateway, where, among many other tenants, WNET-TV, the nation's largest public-television station, makes its home.
On weekdays, wandering the Gateway corridors gives the feeling of the stroll from the lobbies of the World Trade Center across the walkways to the World Financial Center in Manhattan, with a congeries of shops, restaurants, art exhibitions and performing musicians. On Saturdays and Sundays, however, most of the shops are closed, although the corridors are open to visitors and may be entered from the escalators of Gateway One on Market Street.
 
Ironbound Diversions
 The Ironbound, so called because the neighborhood is circumscribed by the rails of the iron horse, is only a three-block walk from Penn Station to Ferry Street, the nearly milelong locus of Newark's Portuguese universe. Head out the Raymond Plaza East exit from Penn Station, cross the street, walk right one block to Ferry Street and make a left, walking two more blocks past Edison Street and McWhorter Street.
On the way, you'll pass the 1848 Second Reformed Dutch Church, where Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini, the first naturalized American to attain sainthood, served as the principal of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Elementary School.
To stroll through the Ironbound is to encounter one of the largest concentrations of Portuguese in the United States, with block upon block of restaurants, bakeries, vegetable markets, fish stores, jewelry shops and travel agencies offering Portuguese delicacies, wines, housewares and gifts. Nearly every sign is written in Portuguese; fado music emanates from the loudspeakers outside stores, and everyone speaks Portuguese -- although most of the shopkeepers also speak English. The neighborhood is welcoming to wandering strangers, and safe by day and night.
If you're driving, park in one of the many lots; some restaurants have their own parking areas. Another popular space on Congress Street is the Ferry Street Parking Station, where parking costs $3.
 
Sampling Restaurants
 Nearly everyone has a favorite restaurant in the Ironbound, and people feel almost possessive about giving out their names. There are dozens to choose from, but the best known include Fornos of Spain, 47 Ferry Street, (201) 589-4767; Roque and Rebelo, 90 Ferry Street, (201) 589-6588; Sagres Restaurant, 71 Ferry Street, (201) 589-4070; Castelo's Restaurant, 61 Ferry Street, (201) 589-2929, and Iberia Tavern and Restaurant, 82-84 Ferry Street, (201) 344-7603.
The common denominator of these establishments is that you will be fed an uncommon amount of food for uncommonly little money. If in doubt, the best strategy is to stroll down Ferry Street and hunt for restaurants, debate the menu and then trust your instincts.
 As in Little Italy in Manhattan, an important part of the ritual is to partake of dessert at a convenient bakery. Strong Portuguese coffee is de rigueur, along with sweet dessert cakes, confections and breads. Three of the most inviting bakeries are Coutinho's, 121 Ferry Street, (201) 344-7384; Delicias Bakery, 167 Ferry Street, (201) 589-0504, and Teixeira's Bakery, 184 Ferry Street, (201) 344-4902. With its marble exterior and sleek counters and shelves, Teixeira's looks like the First National Bank of bakeries.
 
Visiting the Museum
 Fortified by a visit to the Ironbound, heartened by a first exposure to Newark, visitors might want to head over to the Newark Museum, at 49 Washington Street, (201) 596-6550. It's a five-minute cab ride from Penn Station in Newark; parking is also available in an attended lot next to the museum.
A year ago, the museum completed the $21 million reconstruction and expansion program envisioned by the architect Michael Graves. In its 66,000 square feet of new and renovated gallery space, the museum always has several new shows, along with its renowned permanent collections of American and Asian art. Admission is free.
 
Brunch at Priory
 If your appetite has been whetted for more of Newark, think of driving there on a Sunday, so you can begin with brunch at the Priory Restaurant, in an imposing 1872 former church built of brownstone blocks on a hill overlooking the city. The tidily appointed restaurant in a space to the rear of the soaring nave draws a friendly family-oriented after-church crowd to its Southern-style $8.95 brunch.
The meal has all the standard buffet fixings in addition to corn pone, grits, Southern-fried chicken, Southern-fried whiting and homemade cobbler. Brunch is served 9:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. at the restaurant at 233 West Market Street, (201) 242-8012. It's also open for lunch and dinner.
 
Touring the Cathedral
 Since it's Sunday, you might drive a few blocks over to one of Newark's most photogenic monuments, the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart, a spectacular French Gothic cathedral, the fifth largest in the nation. The flagship of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, at the corner of Clifton and Victoria Avenues, is noted for its huge gargoyles, the largest rose window in the Western hemisphere and its 9,500-pipe organ, one of the finest in the country.
The cathedral was begun in 1898 and completed in 1954, and recently underwent an extensive renovation. Architectural tours are given on the first Sunday each month after noon Mass; on other Sundays, or on Saturdays and weekdays, you can conduct your own tour: the entrance is at 89 Ridge Street; information: (201) 484-4600. A concert series is given by the cathedral's own orchestra, the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra; information: (201) 484-2400.
 
Other Sights
 Another Newark destination in its own right is Newark Symphony Hall, behind its sculptured limestone facade at 1030 Broad Street. The 2,800-seat auditorium was built in 1925 as a Shriner temple, and is now host to an effervescent year-round program of plays, concerts and performances. Call (201) 643-8009 for tickets and call (201) 643-4550 to be put on the mailing list.
What has this mini-tour of Newark left out? Nearly everything, including Branch Brook Park, America's first county park, which puts forward its mammoth explosion of cherry blossoms every April. Another treasure is the New Jersey Historical Society, at 230 Broadway, (201) 483-3939, which is open the third Saturday of each month, and Wednesday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; admission, $2. Information: (201) 483-3939.
And finally, a note about safety: Newark, like many other cities that just happen to be visited by the Metroliner -- New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore or Washington, for example -- has its share of the homeless, the poor and the criminal. Many people who drive to Newark don't like to leave their cars on the street unattended; many visitors will feel safer leaving them in a parking lot. But if one abides by the common-sense behavior demanded in any urban environment, there is nothing to fear in Newark but fear itself.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Portrait of a Family From Shifting Points of View

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
Now You See It
By Cornelia Nixon
186 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.
Many of the interlinked stories that make up "Now You See It" first appeared in such small magazines as Ploughshares, Black Warrior Review and Quarterly West 27, and they announce the arrival of a wonderfully talented new writer. 
 A teacher at Indiana University, Cornelia Nixon combines Alice Munro's sympathetic understanding of character with Ann Beattie's radar-sharp eye for the dislocations of contemporary culture. Ms. Nixon also has a thoroughly original voice, a voice that moves fluently from the poetic to the visceral, from the absurd to the mundane.
She's equally adept at capturing the babble of 4-year-olds and the pretentious effusions of grown-up academics, the stilted exchanges of unhappy lovers and the wary transactions that take place between parents and children. Though each of the chapters in this volume can easily stand by itself as a short story, they work together to form a novelistic portrait of a family as seen from the shifting points of view of a husband, a wife, two of their four children and the husband's lover.
When we first meet the Hooper family, they are driving to California, making the great westward trek of the pioneers in a dilapidated car. "The ground was littered with burnt stubble," writes Ms. Nixon, "as if it had been planted with something years before, then cut and left to dry out. It was a landscape that spoke of dinosaur death, indifferent to the lesser life forms passing over it since."
Already, the tensions between Edward, a Harvard-trained philosophy professor, and his wife, Ella, a German immigrant, are all too apparent. She is sick of his self-absorption and lackadaisical irony. He is tired of her strictness, her insistence on order and routine. It's not long after they've settled in Berkeley, Calif., that Ella decides to leave Edward for good: she scoops up her children, puts them in an oversize stroller and begins walking across the Bay Bridge to San Francisco. Only when she is arrested as a German spy at a local military base (World War II is still going on) does she begin hoping that Edward will track her down and beg her not to leave.
Somehow, the marriage stumbles on. Edward becomes involved with Laura, one of his philosophy students; Ella starts a career as a photographer. There are signs of betrayal: Edward fails to come home for dinner one night; Ella is caught rummaging around in his office; both come down with a sexually transmitted disease.
Meanwhile, their four children grow up. Charlie, the oldest, becomes an engineer with an oil company. David, the sensitive one, goes to Vietnam as a medic and later becomes a professor at Berkeley, like his father. Hank, short, impulsive and solemn, affects "a grave adult manner" and makes up "multilingual puns, delivered without a trace of humor." Later he moves to Cuba to study Marxist agricultural techniques. Jane, the youngest, is still a teen-ager when we last see her, helping scatter her father's ashes after he dies of a heart attack.
She remembers him as "one of those tall boyish men who look the same way most of their lives," an inveterate joke-teller who cloaks his real feelings with acerbic asides. Her mother is described in slightly less affectionate tones -- an energetic, willfully correct woman who "taught us to do things California children never did, such as stand when an adult came into the room, say 'ma'am' and 'sir,' and 'lie' instead of 'lay.' "
Writing in deft economical prose, Ms. Nixon gives the reader an indelible portrait of the Hooper family, delineating the myriad ways in which affection can sour, blossom, evolve and endure within the confines of a family. One story (or chapter) titled "Affection" reveals the fracture of the Hoopers' marriage through the eyes of Jane, who has her first glimpse of the fickleness of emotion when her cat leaves her to move in with the new neighbors across the street. Another story, "Assumed Identity," delineates Edward's fumbling efforts to come to terms with Hank's immersion in radical politics and his abrupt disappearance into the underground.
In showing us the lives of the Hoopers in all their familiarity and oddness, Ms. Nixon also creates a finely shaded picture of Berkeley and its noisy embrace of the 1960's counterculture. Her quick, low-key sentences somehow succeed in capturing that period's energy, confusion and adversarial passion, while her sensitivity to light, color and mood enable her to communicate that bay city's physical beauty and anomalous atmosphere of laid-back idealism and off-kilter enthusiasm.
This is a luminous and compelling book, a captivating photo album, filled with vivid verbal snapshots of familial love and disintegration.

HEADLINE: Mr. Reagan Finally Leads on Guns

 BODY:
The gun control campaign conducted by James Brady, who was wounded in the 1981 Presidential assassination attempt, has touched millions of Americans. But until yesterday, one prominent American remained oddly silent. Ronald Reagan, target of the bullet Mr. Brady stopped, seemed oblivious to his former press secretary's cause.
In a speech yesterday and an article on today's Op-Ed page, Mr. Reagan finally breaks his silence with a resounding endorsement of the so-called Brady bill. His welcome support adds heft to growing pressure for the bill and puts President Bush, who continues to oppose it, on the spot. 
 The bill, introduced by Representative Edward Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, would impose a national seven-day waiting period between purchase and delivery of a handgun so police could check the purchaser's background. Similar laws in several states, including Mr. Reagan's native California, block thousands of illegal gun sales each year.
The National Rifle Association resists the national bill and argues that few criminals go to gun shops to purchase guns. That's true -- but beside the point. Street criminals typically purchase guns from neighborhood entrepreneurs who realize handsome profits smuggling guns from shops in states with lax laws for street-corner sales in cities with strict ones. A national waiting period could severely inhibit that deadly black market.
Beyond honoring his friendship with Mr. Brady, Mr. Reagan, a member of the N.R.A., makes clear that no one need be bullied by the big gun lobby when it strays from common sense. That's an act of leadership for President Bush to follow.

HEADLINE: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker's "Winners and Losers" (column, March 16) was yet another example of the absolute refusal of some liberals to rethink their position on the use of force.
Saddam Hussein accepted five weeks of bombing, the elimination of electricity, telephone service and clean water in his capital and the destruction of his army without changing his behavior. He has been coerced, not convinced. How then could anyone assert, as Mr. Wicker does, that "the possible efficacy of the collective economic sanctions never can be determined"?
Tony Coelho and Andrew Young have both spoken of their revulsion and outrage at the savage and brutal behavior of the Iraqis in Kuwait. A vote for sanctions would have given the Iraqis more time to rape, torture and murder. Surely, hindsight allows people to reconsider the human cost of their vote.
As Mr. Wicker notes, "the war was shorter and U.S. casualties were fewer. . . . Iraqi resistance was weaker, Arab allies' reliability greater and the American triumph more overwhelming." There is nothing dishonorable in saying those facts should lead one to conclude that a no vote in January was in retrospect a mistake.
What is frightening is not the Democratic leadership's virtually unanimous opposition to the use of force in January. Honorable, conscientious patriots could legitimately vote no on a grave risk. What is frightening is the determination of the Democratic leaders (and columnists like Mr. Wicker) to avoid learning from the experience.
If knowing what we now know, the Democratic leadership would still have voted against the use of force (and certainly Senator George Mitchell, Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have made that assertion), then it is very hard to see how we could expect them to learn anything about the real world.
 
(Rep.) NEWT GINGRICH
Republican Whip
Washington, March 18, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf;
What Security Threat?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Party Derided" by Leslie H. Gelb (column, March 10) reminds us that neither Democrats nor Republicans have been consistent on United States policy in the Persian Gulf. But I was disturbed by Mr. Gelb's questioning if Democrats have "the toughness to protect America's security." I make no brief for the toughness of the Democratic Party. What I find difficult to believe is that any minimally informed person thinks our national security was threatened by Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
With no effort at all, I can understand how United States security is threatened by our inadequate response to the schools, to insufficient medical care, to rampant racism and crime, to collapsing banks and to crumbling cities and infrastructure. With a bit of effort, I can understand how United States security might be threatened by the turmoil in Eastern Europe. But no effort has convinced me that United States security was at stake in the Persian Gulf.
Also disturbing is Mr. Gelb's description of the crushing of Iraq as a "triumph" for President Bush and his aides. Before proceeding with the killing, Mr. Bush insisted the United States had no quarrel with the Iraqi people, only with Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush's "triumph," however, resulted in the massacre of Iraqi conscripts by the tens of thousands and the ghastly suffering of Iraq's civilian population.
At the end of the triumphant war, however, Saddam Hussein is still in power, although perhaps on the way out. To ignore so blithely what has been inflicted on a people with whom we had no quarrel is another example of the "instant historical amnesia and analytic hogwash" that Mr. Gelb decries.
 
MILES GALVIN
East Brunswick, N.J., March 10, 1991

LENGTH: 813 words

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Taking Big Charge and Cutting Jobs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
I.B.M. announced yesterday that it was taking a $2.3 billion charge, which will probably result in a large quarterly loss, to pay for the retirement benefits of current employees. The company also said it will shrink its worldwide work force by 14,000 employees this year.
The International Business Machines Corporation became the first of the nation's leading corporations to comply with a new accounting rule that will require companies to set aside money annually for each employee's eventual retirement benefits, said Diana J. Scott, the project manager for the rule at the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a rule-setting body for the accounting profession. Many other big American companies are also likely to make large provisions, she said. 
 The money set aside -- $2.6 billion -- will result in tax benefits, but they will be only $300 million because of the way I.B.M. handles retirement benefits, said Robert Ripp, the company's treasurer. As a result, the one-time after-tax charge against I.B.M.'s first-quarter earnings will be $2.3 billion.
I.B.M. told analysts last week, who had expected profits of about $1 billion in 1991's first quarter, that its earnings would be as little as half that level, for an indicated quarterly profit of $500 million to $600 million, or 90 cents to $1 a share, from operations. John B. Jones Jr., an analyst at Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage, said that with the provision for retirement benefits, the company could have a loss of $1.7 billion.
I.B.M. earned $6.02 billion on sales of $69.02 billion last year.
After the morning announcement of the set-aside and job cuts, I.B.M.'s shares rose $1 yesterday, to $113.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The nation's biggest computer maker did not take a separate charge for the planned shrinkage of its work force, which amounts to 3.8 percent of the 373,000 people employed at the end of last year. The move coincides with an undisclosed profit on the sale of the company's office equipment division and is intended to produce large savings from reduced labor expenses, said Peter W. Thonis, a company spokesman. That deal closed yesterday, allowing the company to shed the division's 4,000 employees.
No layoffs are planned, Mr. Thonis said, but I.B.M. will try to eliminate 10,000 positions through attrition and by offering early retirement and voluntary resignation incentives. The company's employment peaked at 406,000 in 1986.
 
Focus on Staff Jobs
Incentives will include two weeks' pay for each year of employment at the company or the addition of extra years to an employee's service record for pension purposes. Mr. Thonis said staff positions, primarily in the United States and Europe, are the main targets; factory positions are less likely to be affected.
I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., is among the likely targets for the voluntary resignation and early retirement programs, he added.
Mr. Thonis said the work force reduction was part of a long-term plan to shrink the company and was unrelated to last week's comments on earnings.
But Howard M. Anderson, president of the Yankee Group, a consulting firm in Boston, said that the need to shrink the company was closely linked to its faltering results.
Big companies are forcing divisions to share a few, very large mainframe computers, he said, and many companies are running their computer programs on small, less expensive desktop computers instead of investing in a mainframe computer and many terminals.
 
I.B.M.'s Strength
 I.B.M. is far stronger in the mainframe market than in the desktop market. "The economy is responsible for half of their problems, their product mix is responsible for the other half," Mr. Anderson said.
But despite its current troubles, I.B.M. remains wealthy enough to take a one-time accounting charge that many large manufacturers have resisted.
Most companies now pay for retirement benefits as retirees incur them. A few, including I.B.M., have been estimating the benefits that each employee will use and setting aside enough money to pay for those benefits when the employee retires.
Now I.B.M. will set aside part of the money for these benefits each year that an employee works at the company. The $2.6 billion provision is the amount that I.B.M. would have set aside annually since each current employee joined the company.
The new accounting rule was passed by accounting profession panel in December and does not become mandatory until 1993. Mr. Ripp said that the company decided to make an immediate provision because each year of delay would enlarge the amount of money needed.
Miss Scott of the accounting standards board said the rule was needed to help users of company reports, like individual investors and pension fund managers, determine the extent of a company's obligations.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 30, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about I.B.M.'s decision to list as a liability $2.6 billion for some employee retirement benefits misstated the operation of new accounting rules for American companies. Each year, the companies will subtract from earnings part of the cost of eventual retirement benefits for current employees. While that sum will be listed on the corporate balance sheet as a liability, the money will not actually be set aside.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Who's Not Fit to Be Governor? Just Look at This

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 28

 BODY:
By the sedate standards of Japanese politics, the race for Governor of Tokyo is not a typical election.
Among the 16 candidates are a popular rock singer running on the slogan "Don't Make Tokyo a Dangerous Place Like New York"; a politician's wife who wants to evict the Emperor of Japan from the Imperial Palace and put up a new Parliament building on the palace grounds, and a man styling himself Japan's Ralph Nader who poses in the blue uniform and motorcycle helmet of a San Francisco policeman and wants to abolish automobile inspections. 
 The leading aspirant is the 80-year-old incumbent, Shunichi Suzuki, who offers proof of his fitness for a new term in office by performing calisthenics at political rallies, including a deep bend at the waist in which he touches the floor with his palms, bringing instant applause from admirers.
His chief opponent, Hisanori Isomura, an urbane and mellow-voiced former television news anchor, has a different image problem. Battling a charge that he is not a man of the people, he showed up at a public bath and, wearing nothing but a small towel, scrubbed the back of a startled bather.
The Persian Gulf war is over, trade frictions with the United States are in a lull, the Japanese economy is running smoothly, as always; what better subject of gossip for residents of this crowded, noisy capital than the sloppiest political brawl in anyone's memory?
Politics in Japan is rarely the spectator sport that it is in the United States, but this election, due April 7, is enlivened by charges of corruption, back-stabbing, clandestine liaisons and double-dealing.
The most disputed thing done by Governor Suzuki, who presides over an $81 billion budget the size of the economy of Norway, for instance, was to build an immense 48-story City Hall, the tallest building in Japan, costing $850 million and prompting endless complaints about government waste.
On dedicating the new building this month, Mr. Suzuki proudly declared the new behemoth in western Tokyo to be "not extravagant and not luxurious" but "a monument to the people for the 21st century."
"He conceives of himself as the Emperor of Tokyo," Mr. Isomura sneered, pointing out that Mr. Suzuki has an office with a marble bathroom and shower while most of his constituents live in tiny apartments. "If this were a foreign country, there would have been a taxpayers' revolt by now."
A year ago, resentment of Tokyoites over City Hall and other giant construction projects smoldered and Governor Suzuki was deemed unelectable. Fearing a debacle, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party pleaded with Mr. Suzuki to retire gracefully.
"The opportunity has already slipped away," the Governor told the Prime Minister, explaining that his campaign was already in high gear.
Failing in their task, Mr. Kaifu and his aides then unceremoniously dumped Mr. Suzuki as the governing party's nominee and replaced him with a popular and suave newscaster who had reported for the Japan Broadcasting Company from Washington, Paris and the Middle East.
Mr. Kaifu and his Cabinet even boycotted the dedication ceremony for the new City Hall.
All this maneuvering backfired. Japanese public opinion reversed itself almost overnight, rushing to Mr. Suzuki out of sympathy for an underdog independent. Now the Governor is improbably portraying himself as an outsider battling the "bosses" who were his lifelong allies.
"In the elections up until now, I was always supported by big organizations," the Governor happily told a crowd recently. "I felt as if they could hardly be called elections. Now I'm really getting my hands dirty. I'm saying to myself, this is a real election."
If Mr. Suzuki loses, many of his dreams -- a $12 billion new city on landfill in Tokyo Bay, another hotel-theater-shopping complex at the mouth of the Sumida River -- could be in jeopardy. Not surprisingly, some of the country's biggest construction contractors are lined up with him.
For a while, the campaign also featured a well-known professional wrestler named Antonio Inoki, a lantern-jawed gadfly in Parliament in the Sports and Peace Party. He entered the race to avenge Mr. Isomura's once commenting on television that one of his wrestling matches had been a farce.
The wrestler's candidacy was short-lived, however, as Mr. Kaifu and two former Prime Ministers, Noboru Takeshita and Takeo Fukuda, sternly advised him to bow out. Their maneuvering only prompted news reports that he had been paid off by party kingpins to make room for Mr. Isomura.
Mr. Isomura has denied that he is a pawn for the power brokers and had difficulty explaining how he will build 350,000 new apartments, as he has pledged, and also cut taxes by a trillion yen, or $7 billion. Meanwhile, his debonair French and English phrases go over most people's heads.
"People around Suzuki are spreading frivolous information," Mr. Isomura complained recently. "Baseless things, like, 'There's a woman in his closet' or 'He doesn't know how to use honorifics in French.' I myself refuse to slander or defame. As for my French, please ask the French Embassy."
Some months ago, the squabbling looked as if it would be a great opportunity for a move by the Socialist Party. Indeed, Takako Doi, the popular party chief, was widely encouraged to run for Governor herself. But Miss Doi admitted publicly that she was suspicious of the entreaties of party colleagues who, she said, simply wanted to push her into certain oblivion. So the Socialists are fielding a 64-year-old professor of local administration, Mitsunori Ohara, who is given no chance of winning.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The two leading candidates for Governor of Tokyo are Shunichi Suzuki, above, the 80-year-old incumbent who does calisthenics to demonstrate his fitness, and Hisanori Isomura, far right, who tried to show he was a man of the people by scrubbing the back of a man at a bathhouse. (Asahi Shimbun)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Loud and Nasty: The Hound on Radio

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV

 BODY:
EVERY Saturday afternoon at 3, the world becomes a little less refined. While some people are taking in a matinee at the opera or visiting a quiet art gallery, WFMU-FM (91.1) is awakening with a snarl. It is time for the Hound.
For the next three hours, an anarchic flood of forgotten rhythm-and-blues, rockabilly, country and old rock-and-roll will pour from the radio, engulfing listeners in a sea of jitterbugging juvenile delinquents in search of loud music and fast times. 
 Fly-by-night musical obscurities, like Jack and the Rippers, Gene Franklin and the House-Rockin' Spacemen, and Tommy Jim Beam and His Four Fifths (who recorded for the 100 Proof label), are brought back to life. Disembodied voices punctuate the spaces between songs, hawking extinct oddities (Lardinsky Sausage Products, Queen Bee Barbecue and King Kong Hair Straightener). Bits of cultural arcana drop in unexpectedly: "Man, that cat comes on like Godzilla," declares one voice. Excerpts from old chitlin'-circuit comedy teams enhance the underbelly-of-society atmosphere.
Interspersed in this juke-joint theater is biting, wise-guy commentary by the Hound and his radio family on current events, popular music and anything else that strikes their fancy. Together, it's a slice of what was once forbidden fruit: a realm of pulp fiction, B-movies and pulsing music that is tremendously funny, especially when it wasn't meant to be that way.
"It's sick, twisted, horrible noise," said John Zorn, the saxophonist and avant-garde composer. "Those are four of my highest compliments."
Robert Quine, the rock-and-roll guitarist, put it this way: "The key factors are brutal and stupid. It must have redeeming value."
Jim Marshall, as the Hound is known off the radio, offered this definition: "It's music of wild abandon and snarling attitude. These are just the records I like, and we present the stuff in the spirit in which it was made."
Mr. Marshall, a fanatical record collector, is a man whose mission is to protect rock-and-roll -- music with grease under its fingernails and whisky on its breath -- from those who would exalt it by cleaning it up. He says he particularly resents the approach of many college radio stations that treat blues, rhythm-and-blues and rockabilly as sterile artifacts.
"That's putting it under glass so you can't even touch it," he said. "The last thing you want in rock-and-roll is good taste."
With his pack of fellow East Villagers, Mr. Marshall -- who is 31 years old ("born the year rock-and-roll got bad") -- treks each Saturday to the WFMU studio in East Orange, N.J. There, he and his cohorts, Bruce (Il Brooche) Bennett, Dennis (Denwah) Uhrinek and Sally (Miss Sally) Showalter, along with the rock guitarist Eric (Roscoe) Ambel, who has phoned in his weekly "Vibe Report" from as far away as Denmark, re-create the rock-and-roll universe as they see it.
"This is real music, by real musicians, not self-conscious art-school cretins," said Mr. Bennett, 28, who delivers tenacious barbs with unctuous understatement. He oozes benign contempt for most fashions, on one recent show denouncing the currently popular male ponytail as "dweeb knobs."
In a news segment, for which the Hound crew scours newspapers for bizarre can-you-believe-it tales, Mr. Bennett tells listeners of a 6-year-old Pennsylvania girl mauled by a pit bull terrier given to her by her grandmother. "Nothing like a gift that opens you back," he says.
Mr. Ambel says simply: "Everybody on the show hates everything, but is committed to excellence. They do things for themselves and like-minded people."
 
An Archeological Dig
 The show came about, Mr. Marshall said, because his displeasure with today's pop music forced him "to invent his own entertainment." He estimates his radio audience at 20,000 to 50,000, and cites fan letters from all over this country, Europe and Japan. He is stationed behind a console adorned by a two-headed dinosaur, one of its mouths biting down on a baby bottle, a nightmare of baby boomers gone awry.
"I like the archeology of digging this stuff up," he said. "I can create something new."
Creation must be satisfaction enough for Mr. Marshall, who like other broadcasters for WFMU, a public station affiliated with Upsala College in East Orange, N.J., is not paid for his work. He ekes out a living with freelance music writing, construction work, bartending and even occasional work as a bicycle messenger.
He recently celebrated the fifth anniversary of the Hound show with the Hound Hangover Hop at Brownie's bar on Avenue A. And though the East Village today seems a mix of artists and the homeless, poised against a continuing yuppie encroachment, the Hound radio show represents a quality of cultural rebellion for which the Village is still known, a rebellion characterized by an uncompromising refusal to abide by mainstream values.
 
The Cost? Employment!
 For the Hound, this has meant a refusal to conform to the standards of commercial radio, which would require him to play music he does not like, or to the standards of the music industry as a whole. And this has cost him employment opportunities, he said.
"Everybody in the business thinks he's nuts," Mr. Ambel said. "They're threatened by his knowledge or something. Most people in the business have to work with whatever gets assigned to them."
Mr. Zorn calls this quality a maverick esthetic. "I think this relates to pioneerism," he said. "It's real American."
Many Hound fans are united by their passionate love for the music, and their equally passionate refusal to compromise.
"This area is still known for the Bohemian thing," said Chris Kush, the owner of Mojo Guitar Shop on East 12th Street, where many in the Hound crowd hang out.
 
Country-Store Hangout
 As they would at a country general store, listeners, friends and neighbors stop in at Mojo to shoot the breeze, finding seats among bits and pieces of old guitars and amplifiers, taking their own coffee and slices of pizza. Mr. Bennett drops a guitar off for repair one Saturday morning before heading off to East Orange for the show.
"The Hound's music is a lot of swinging r-and-b and crazy blues," Mr. Kush said. "I try to sell only the instruments that those guys would have played."
Robert Cohen, 40, a co-owner of Finyl Vinyl, on Second Avenue and Sixth Street, sells the records made by the guys playing those instruments. "We're covering the underbelly of the 50's and 60's," he said. "These are not for people who need to read the reviews first in Rolling Stone."
It's a trash-camp esthetic whose wide appeal can be seen at Finyl Vinyl, at See/Hear (an East Seventh Street store carrying music and books as well as catalogues of scandal magazines, posters, exploitation movies and pinup models showing how collectible the paraphernalia of juvenile delinquency has become), and at many other East Village spots.
"There's an international mafia whose roots are 50's and 60's trash culture," Mr. Cohen said.
 
Cracked Plaster and Posters
 Mr. Marshall himself lives in a small three-room fourth-floor walkup in the East Village. Lurid posters of B-movies like "Hot-Blooded Woman" cover cracked plaster, and a bedroom wall is lined with more than 10,000 LP's. Another set of shelves holds upward of 3,000 45-r.p.m. records. A desk holds a collection of skulls and photos of Brigitte Bardot.
"The trashier, more desperate these low-level exponents of pop culture were, the more realistic," Mr. Marshall said. "Some of these blues singers more accurately portrayed the way life was than Nat (King) Cole songs."
Then, he pulls out some of his more esoteric 45's of the late 50's: "Gonna Snatch Me a Satellite," by the Rockin' R's; "Gonna Get Me a Satellite," by Little Ernest Tucker; "Satellite Rock," by the Rebelaires; "My Satellite," by Jesse Belvin, and "Rockin' Satellite," by Ray Sawyer. These songs have more in common with Cadillac tail fins than with Chuck Berry.
"Stupidity is one of the unifying feautures of all these records," he said, pulling out a copy of "Betty Lou Got a New Tattoo," by the Creep. "I think stupidity is great. These guys aren't Stravinsky."
 
Bottom Line: Simplicity
 Ultimately, though, the appeal of the music is simple: "It's all gut level, very direct," Mr. Marshall said. "It's very easy to act profound, but to take a really complex emotion and make it simple, to me that's beautiful."
The economics of today's centralized record industry have made it almost impossible to make music with real guts to it, he said, and have led record companies to play it safe in their search for polished hits. The records he treasures, he said, were made before rock became a formula, when people had the freedom to make mistakes, when accidents became hits.
"A big part of the CD thing is keeping independent companies out of the business," he said. "In the 50's, any kid with $100 could make a record. Elvis started on a tiny label. Anything was possible."
In contrast, putting together a weekly radio program that does not fit a recognized format in the 90's seems impossible, and Mr. Marshall worries about the future of the Hound show. WFMU is involved in a legal battle that may result in having its radio signal weakened, and Mr. Marshall is trying to have his show syndicated to capitalize on the music's popularity abroad. "Aside from him, you're going to hear the same oldies over and over," Mr. Quine said. "Unless it was a Top 20 hit, you're not going to hear it on the radio. A lot of his stuff, he's dug up himself."
For himself, Mr. Marshall doesn't want much: "It'd be nice to have a place where it's always dark and the music's always good."
 
WHERE TO FIND VINTAGE RECORDS
 A few outposts remain dedicated to the proposition that vintage rock-and-roll sounds best on vinyl. In Manhattan, these four stand out:
*Downstairs Records, 35 West 43d Street, second floor (212) 354-4684. This midtown enclave is the place to look for old 45-r.p.m. singles, especially unfamiliar country, rhythm-and-blues, doo-wop and oldies hits. Customers may even play records in the store, as in the old days, to check condition or simply to browse for palatability. There are a few compact disks behind the counter.
*Finyl Vinyl, 89 Second Avenue, south of Sixth Street (212) 533-8007. This store keeps a melted compact disk hanging on its wall. "Vinyl's in my blood," said Rob Cohen, a co-owner. And vinyl's about all you will find in his store, which carries a wide array of the latest reissues of old blues, rhythm-and-blues, soul and rockabilly.
*Hideout, 5 Cornelia Street (near West Fourth Street) (212) 463-8900. Hideout buys, sells and trades records as well as compact disks. It has many out-of-print, vintage rock-and-roll records that are difficult to find elsewhere.
*Midnight Records, 255 West 23d Street, (212) 675-2768. This store is full of "everything we think is worth having," said J. D. Martignon, the owner. That means an excellent selection of rock-and-roll from the earliest blues to the hardest core. Midnight operates a large mail-order operation that also includes compact disks. -- ERIC ASIMOV
